column2: and I will be your conference operator today. At this time
column3: I would like to welcome everyone to the ACI Worldwide Reports Q1 Earnings Conference Call. All lines have been placed on mute to prevent any background noise. After the speakers' remarks
column4: there will be a question-and-answer session. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. John Kraf
column5: Vice
column6: you may begin your conference.

column1: John Kraft: Thanks Jacquelyn
column2: and good morning
column3: everybody. Today's call like all of our events
column4: is subject to both Safe Harbor and forward-looking statements. You can find the full text to both statements on the first and final pages of our presentation deck today
column5: a copy of which is available on our website as well as with the SEC. On this morning's call is Phil Heasley
column6: our CEO and Scott Behrens
column7: our CFO. With that
column8: I'd like to turn the call over to Phil.

column1: Phil Heasley: Thanks John
column2: and good morning
column3: everyone. I am pleased to report our first quarter financial results. We are ahead of our expectations and a strong start to 2017. First quarter revenue of $231 million was up 10% compared to last year. We also generated $42 million in EBITDA which was a 68% increase over last year and operating free cash flow of $76 million
column4: which was a 157% from last year. In the quarter
column5: we signed some important contracts across a range of solutions and geographies. We signed an important contract with Jack Henry to help bring Immediate Payments for a wide range of their financial institution customers
column6: notably customers who have connected with some Clearing House and Zelle Networks through real-time systems allowing consumers and businesses to send and receive payments and data instantly directly from their accounts to the financial institutions. We also continue to make progress with our Universal Payments and Retail Payment solution initiatives signing important renewals including two with large national switches
column7: one in the Middle East and one in Asia. These customers plan to use our flexible Universal Payments technology to gain competitive advantage with functionalities such as Apple Pay Acceptance and ATM Surcharging. Further we are seeing that transaction capacity requirements are growing faster than customers expected in terms of both newer wallets and micro payments
column8: as well as traditional usage. In our fast-growing e-commerce segments we continue to sign contracts with traditional merchants that increasingly appreciate our industry-leading Omni channel solutions and endpoint connectivity. We are also signing customers pursuing new used cases including end console payments in the gaming vertical. Looking ahead in our pipeline we are making progress with several customers that are interested in leveraging the power of UP in significant and transformational way. We hope to have more to say later in 2017 about this. Following the successful Investors Day in March
column9: as well as several customer-focused events
column10: plus key geographic regions
column11: we remain extremely optimistic that we have positioned ACI to benefit in the coming years in the evolving electronics payments landscape. In summary
column12: ACI is off to a good 2017. We are firmly on track to achieve our financial targets for the year and are fully committed to our longer term growth goals. With that
column13: let me turn the call over to Scott to provide details on our first quarter and 2017 guidance. Thank you.

column1: Scott Behrens: Thanks Phil
column2: and good morning
column3: everyone. I first plan to go through the highlights of the first quarter and then provide a reminder of our outlook for the full year 2017. We'll then open the line for questions. I’ll be starting my comments on Slide 6 with key takeaways from the quarter. Now
column4: overall
column5: we had a solid start to 2017. Our renewal bookings were particularly strong up 34% over last year. This was offset by a decline in new bookings mainly given the timing and the particularly strong comparison in Q1 2016 when we saw nearly 50% growth. We continue to expect full year new bookings growth to be in the high-single-digits Our 12 month and 60 month backlog declined $6 million and $23 million respectively from Q4 2016
column6: again mainly due to the timing of new bookings. We saw strong growth in revenue
column7: up 10% over the prior year quarter and given a relatively fixed cost structure
column8: this revenue growth delivered adjusted EBITDA growth of 68% compared to the prior year quarter. We saw strong growth in operating free cash flow coming in at $76 million and more than double the prior year quarter and while we don’t officially guide the cash flow for the year
column9: we are clearly tracking ahead of our original forecast. We ended this quarter with a $100 million in cash and a debt balance of $710 million
column10: down $43 million during the quarter. And lastly
column11: here we have $78 million remaining on our share buyback authorization. And one thing of note
column12: as we mentioned at our Analyst Day in March
column13: we have updated our financial segment disclosures in our Form 10-Q to reflect our new two P&L organizational structure and have presented our revenue and profitability for our ACI on-demand business
column14: which consists of our Software as a Service and Platform as a Service and our ACI on-premise business which consists of our traditional license maintenance and professional services operations. So you will see that when we file our 10-Q. Turning next to Slide 7 with our full year outlook. We are reaffirming our full year guidance for the full year 2017 we expect revenue to be in a range of $1.0 billion to $1.25 billion and we continue to expect adjusted EBITDA to be in the range of $250 million to $255 million and we expect new bookings growth to be in the high-single-digits. For Q2
column15: we expect revenue to be in a range of $225 million to $230 million. So overall a strong start to the year and positions us well to achieve our financial targets in 2017. That concludes my prepared remarks. Operator
column16: we are ready to open up the line for questions at this time.

Phil Heasley: Our pipelines are very

column3: but – around the world and last place is whether it be in India
column4: Far East
column5: places that are just growing their consumer economies they are growing much more rapidly on the ecommerce side than they are in
column6: the more traditional
column7: what we view as traditional way.

column3: you also just mentioned

column2: is that – I guess
column3: my question – but about a point on is
column4: has that kind of changed early in 2017 versus what you saw last year or is that just a continuation of the trend that you are speaking to?

column2: and then
column3: Scott

column3: our – I would say we apply it for historical uses of cash. Obviously

column2: thanks for taking the questions.

column4: railroads
column5: retailers and I am not saying the third category.

column4: George. So

column1: Phil Heasley: Well

column4: Financial Analysts Day. But we also did it the day before demonstrating our – the UP capabilities and that UP is not hard wired hub type structure but it’s a tightly orchestrated
column5: very variable interactor set so to speak. That really struck us forward with several of our – of the people that follow our industry that hadn’t attained that level of comfort before. So
column6: that was very positive for us.

column2: guys.

column3: I don’t know

column6: was there any further progress or anything else to comment regarding the IT consolidation in Europe?

column2: I mean
column3: we are – thanks for asking that question. We are within one quarter of taking 20 some datacenters down into four datacenters and I think you know we said we’ve invested in the very recent past $100 million in capital costs and some of that cost is continuing to build highly leveragable infrastructure that today were easily balanced between our ability to support North America and our ability to support the European
column4: Middle East African continents. So
column5: we are within one quarter of concluding that effort.

column2: the license by its nature has a pretty – I mean that’s a lot of that is not recurring. So it has seasonality to it part of the beat in the first quarter was higher than expected with capacity revenues which can be – it’s really
column3: it’s based on a numbers by the customers that need capacity in a given quarter. So
column4: part of that beat was higher capacity which in last year sort of came later in the year.

column1: Wayne Johnson: Okay
column2: great. All right. Thank you

column1: Operator: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from Alex Veytsman from Monness Crespi & Hardt. Your line is open.
Alex Veytsman: Yes

column4: I mean
column5: the Jack Henry deal although
column6: I mean
column7: I think the question is whether it’s going to impact this year? Is that just you being conservative keeping the guidance intact or is there something you could be seeing for the next few quarters?

column4: we could get out over our feeds and what not to be more aggressive. We are a little more aggressive as relative to cash we are going to bring in. But other than that

column6: do you want?

column1: Scott Behrens: I would agree with that. I think it’s certainly de-risked to what would typically be a pretty heavy fourth quarter. So
column2: great way to start the year and we are comfortable with where we are at.

column1: Phil Heasley: If you look at what we are doing certainly is
column2: we have significantly increased bookings in our business and the bookings
column3: it takes us at the short end of the 180 days
column4: at the long end it takes us almost 500 days to install these bookings. And so
column5: if you ask me if I felt lot better about 2019 and second half of 2018
column6: I do feel a lot better about it. But
column7: we don’t felt – so we can’t convert it right away to our revenue line.

column2: that’s fair. That’s fair. And then
column3: the Jack Henry deal
column4: I mean
column5: when should we expect going be first or the once they hit is it going to be this year or is it mainly next year?

Alex Veytsman: Okay

column3: but from now

column1: Alex Veytsman: All right. And then finally

column1: Scott Behrens: Not necessarily I think one of the bigger ones is Jack Henry. So we said that will likely begin next year. On some of the contracts that are in our SaaS and platform businesses have shorter time to install. So we could begin to see those recurring revenues kick in before we exit 2017. But not a pretty – not a significant contributor this year and lot of the sales that we get in any particular year are going to build our backlog and really contribute to future year’s revenue.
Alex Veytsman: Okay
column2: very helpful. Thank you guys.

Brett Huff: Thanks

column1: Scott Behrens: Well
column2: I would say
column3: again Q1 had a – I said it in my prepared comments
column4: the comp with last year
column5: Q1 last year if you look back was nearly 50% growth. So
column6: we had a very strong Q1 last year and essentially maintained our full year guidance. I wouldn’t look at Q1 as anything other than a – as a tough comp. So and the backlog is also a factor of that in that in a quarter in which you have as much revenue as we did. It’s again
column7: it’s a timing issue when we have the new bookings
column8: because it’s the new bookings
column9: that’s still backlogs. And so
column10: again
column11: I think they are both are a function of timing in the year and as we get into Q2
column12: Q3 and Q4 and we start to see those new bookings pick up
column13: that’s ultimately going to feed the backlog and contribute to future.

column1: Phil Heasley: Yes
column2: Brett
column3: this is Phil. I just think
column4: I don’t want to overly make it. Bookings by quarter
column5: fourth quarter is picking up that you can really have a good year-on-year. But what will probably happen in the second quarter is
column6: we will do tremendously versus the previous year. So
column7: and I wouldn’t want to overly celebrate that too
column8: right. It just has to do with the way it comes
column9: certainly the first half of the year
column10: the way it comes in. We are – I could not – I am more confident than I was three months ago about our ability to make our full year bookings. But
column11: I don’t want to make too many excuses about the first quarter and I am not going to pretend second quarter that with the second coming
column12: because we have such a great year-to-year comp. It’s kind of – it’s year-to-year
column13: we sell capital-oriented items and what not
column14: where there is only buys at the first quarter
column15: they buy at the third quarter
column16: that’s not that big
column17: that’s not that big a deal. What we like about selling it’s earlier in the year is it gives us more discretion towards the end of the year
column18: but we are very
column19: very comfortable. The momentum is here. I think we told you
column20: we are not renewing deals prematurely unless there is some customer needs for it to take place and that shows up the year-to-year a little bit. We signed very little in the way of renewal but it wasn’t a time appropriate to do. So
column21: I am very
column22: very – the net is
column23: I am very comfortable where we are and we are not going to take more credit than we deserve
column24: say
column25: next quarter we blow that at the border
column26: we are not going to take credit for that
column27: because it’s the sum of the two quarters
column28: it’s again the full year commitment.

column1: Brett Huff: That’s helpful. And then
column2: my follow-up is
column3: I walked away from the Analyst Day thinking I have underappreciated the Immediate Payments opportunity. The panel was really helpful that signing of Jack Henry is a big deal. We’ve been very focused on the UP deal specifically vis-à-vis the banks kind of from their debit business and moving beyond that as you say more different electronic payments
column4: as you guys look out and think about the addressable market
column5: are you – do you see the Immediate Payments markets ultimately being larger
column6: maybe than the UP market with the banks in your more traditional business? Or give us a sense of how you rank those.

column1: Phil Heasley: Well
column2: I think you know that UP powers everything we do. So UP powers our Immediate Payments capability. I think that
column3: just my personal – lot of decades in the payments business
column4: I think we are underestimating the power of Immediate Payments the same way thirty years ago we underestimated the power of credit buys. And that I think we’ll be amazed – I think real-time commerce deserves and requires real-time payments and whether the world collectively understands what they are putting together it happens then
column5: but suddenly all the governments around the world and their central banks become en lighten that that real-time payments and I think you are going to see under an UP infrastructure that real-time had wire and Immediate Payments are going to become couple cousins and you are going to see a lot more sophisticated way that companies big and small and there is no way they are going to hold the individual out of the benefit of Immediate Payments. I think Immediate Payments is huge
column6: first you have to build the infrastructure
column7: then you have to build its usage. But so much of the world is coming onboard at the same time and so many of the people are thinking globally about how the scheme should work and it’s just making a lot of – I couldn’t be more enthusiastic about Immediate Payments and we are seeing that in the marketplace. I mean
column8: the – our customer base certainly getting it. So
column9: the ones that are seeking us out
column10: they certainly get it. And I would say that the retailers understand and the e-commerce players understand Immediate Payments maybe – they are making more benefit to us than even the financial institutions and financial intermediaries.

column1: Brett Huff: That’s helpful. Thank you.
Operator: There are no other questions at this time. I turn the call back over to the presenters.
John Kraft: Well
column2: thank you all for dialing in and we look forward to catching up with everybody in the coming weeks. Have a good day.

column2: and good morning
column3: everybody. Today's call like all of our events is subject to both Safe Harbor and forward-looking statements. You can find the full text to both statements on the first and final pages of our presentation deck today

column1: Phil Heasley: Thank you
column2: John
column3: and good morning
column4: everyone. I am pleased to report our second quarter results. Q2 was another strong quarter for ACI and continued affirmation of our universal payment strategy. And second quarter new bookings were up 11% over last year. Second quarter revenue up $241 million was up 10% over last year
column5: we also generated $44 million in EBITDA which was a 105% increase over last year. In the quarter in second quarter we continued to sign some important contracts across the range of solutions and geography and made substantial progress with large and transformational universal payments opportunities. In our fast-growing e-commerce platform
column6: we continued to expand our end points and global connectivity with new partnerships including Alipay the world's largest online and mobile payment platform
column7: we also signed a large on demand contract with another top European retailer for our UP retail payments offering. In our bill payment platform segment
column8: we signed several contracts including a large U.S. based online loan originator for our UP payment bill payments solution. Lastly
column9: we continue to sign new immediate payment contracts with both the Mexican and international
column10: financial institutions. One notable contract was signed with a large financial institution in Asia for both ACI's immediate payment solution as well as our universal online banker cash management solutions
column11: this customer will use ACIs universal payments to orchestrate their overall payments business. Looking ahead our pipeline is substantial
column12: the number of customers is leveraging the power of UP continues to grow. In summary 2017 has been strong
column13: we are well prepared to achieve our financial targets for the year we remain commitment to our longer-term growth goals. With that
column14: let me turn it over to Scott who will provide you with much more detail the second quarter of 2017. Thank you.

column1: Scott Behrens: Thanks Phil
column2: and good morning
column3: everyone. I first plan to go through the highlights of the second quarter and then provide a reminder of our outlook for 2017. We'll then open the line for questions. I’ll be starting my comments on Slide 6 with key takeaways from the quarter. I still say Q2 was another strong quarter for us with new bookings up 11% over the prior year quarter
column4: these strong bookings contributed to solid growth in our backlog with 12 months and 16 months backlog drawing 18 million and 24 million respectively during the quarter. Q2 revenue was $241 million up 10% over the prior year quarter
column5: this strong growth combined with our relatively fixed cost structure helped us deliver very strong 105% growth in adjusted EBITDA. We ended the quarter with $95 million in cash and a debt balance of 705 [ph] million which is down from 753-million-year end and we have 78 million remaining on our share buyback authorization. Turning next to slide seven. With our full year outlook
column6: we are reaffirming our full year guidance for the full year 2017 we continue to expect revenue to be in a range of $1 billion to $1.025 billion. We continue to expect adjusted EBITDA to be in a range of $250 million to $255 million and we expect new bookings growth to be in high single-digits. And for Q3 we expect revenue to be in a range of $210 million to $225 million. So overall
column7: we are very pleased with the Q2 performance with strong growth in new bookings revenue and EBITDA
column8: this follows a strong Q1 performance allowing us to reaffirm our full year guidance. So that concludes my prepared remarks

column1: Operator: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of George Sutton from Craig Hallum. Please go ahead.
George Sutton: So
column2: I wanted to understand a little bit more when Phil when you say pipeline is sustainable I wanted to look at that in the context of some of the UP success that you have had as folks have begun to go live what that is doing relative to the velocity of that pipeline?

column1: Phil Heasley: We can discuss the pipeline for a long time because we have the retailer segment we have the bill payer segment
column2: which we don’t talk as much about those as we do the core banking
column3: the bank statements but they are growing very well more and more as ecommerce becomes more global and these guys have platforms that deliver real time product around the world
column4: they are finding it more and more difficult to have 15
column5: 18 different relationships in order to execute their payments. So
column6: they are getting out in front of the market place and figuring out how to -- in effect build the layer on top of those 18 layers to control their destiny. And that’s going very
column7: very well. And you couple that with -- I talked about Alipay and what not
column8: that people in terms of wanting global reach they do it through global connectivity right now. And our PAY.ON product which is built into that UP platform as a multipurpose solution not just a connectivity solution is being very well received around the world. We are having some very good conversations. And at that point it starts melting
column9: it starts crossing over because the financial institutions
column10: the financial intermediaries they have the same kinds of needs as the retailers do as that point as each one is trying figure out how to globalize their solution. And quite honestly how you pay you pay ubiquitous versus access the payment ubiquitous
column11: so they want as many different payment methods to make sense and the more and more that are real time
column12: the more that match their business model the more they want to take in. So
column13: we are ending up having conversations all around the world just very good and some are very large and many of them are more medium to large. And they are just progressing very well because I think everyone has consultants and as they are -- everyone's getting consulted towards solutions we are being looked on that in a rather favorable life
column14: we are very proud of that at this point. I don’t if that answers your questions I can't get specific about customers or anything like that that would be disingenuous
column15: but that’s the best attempt I can make to answer that question.

column1: Unidentified Analyst: And let me also ask you in this context and this will be my follow up. So
column2: the faster payments paper summary just came out I was just curious what do you think that does to some of the velocity of your pipeline and now that there is at least some sense of a time date set? I'm just curious your takeaways from that updated paper.

column1: Phil Heasley: Well
column2: we feel good about it
column3: but we view Immediate Payments as global phenomena. It's amazing how much of the world is involved in this. We're working Immediate Payments on every continent that has payments to speak so. It's good to see the U.S. catching up because the U.S. has actually been way behind and I think for a lot of reasons. But they've been way behind in terms of this and I think that's very positive as the U.S. represents really important market both inbound and outbound as it relates to the Immediate Payment offerings.

column1: Operator: Your next question comes from the line of Brett Huff from Stephens. Please go ahead.
Brett Huff: Good morning
column2: Phil
column3: Scott and John. Thanks for taking my questions and congrats on a nice quarter. Two questions for you
column4: one I think this is for Scott
column5: you had a nice speed on revenue and profit in 2Q but didn't raise guidance. Should we imply that you all just maybe got some revenue sooner than you expected or how should we interpret those two facts is that the right interpretation?

column1: Scott Behrens: Well
column2: if you look relative to last year obviously we had a disproportionate amount of our revenue set in the fourth quarter and our margin set in the fourth quarter. So
column3: you look at it on a year-over-year basis. Yeah
column4: we had a very strong first half
column5: but it's essentially deep risks what we have to do to deliver on the second half of the year. So
column6: lot of opportunities gives us options but we're comfortable with where we are at in the guidance that we have out there.

column1: Brett Huff: Okay. That's helpful. And then can you just walk us through the -- how the existing UP deals as they have been implemented or being implemented

So

column6: the real values when they get it installed and they begin to put the weather its consolidating volumes on to their switching or they put alternative payment type volumes through UP. That's really where the power of it comes to us

column1: Phil Heasley: So

Most of the opportunity for us we had a little bit ad contract signing of over the increased level of yield over the next five years but then our big opportunity comes as they start not so much converting but putting on other it becomes very efficient for them to put other programs on and one way if I was a third-party and I will want to see how well that was doing

column1: Operator: Your next question comes from the line of David Eller from Wells Fargo. Please go ahead.
David Eller: Good morning
column2: thank you for taking my questions. You mentioned you are making progress on the bill pay segment with the large U.S. originator online loans and also if you can talk a little bit more about the bill pay business
column3: if I recall correctly that was historically more domestic focused and maybe if you could just talk about opportunities you have there and whether there are opportunities to expand internationally?

column1: Phil Heasley: We are in the EBPP business we are not in the classic bill pay business where you go have your monthly journal and you do your bills
column2: that’s not our business. Our business is connecting -- again its payments its connecting people who need to satisfy a payment with the end point that they need to take place. We have actually gotten very
column3: very good feedback and we built quite a book of business around with financials and financial intermediates that are in. The loan type businesses that really need flexibility and looking more -- they are looking more and more at the value of direct connections and whereas they are ready fairly well connected with the financial institutions in terms of the origination and maintenance of the loans satisfaction of the payment it's something that they are looking for more agility and more options and what not and that’s working out very well for us. We have put I think we have worked four years now on improving the platforms that we purchased and we have a little bit probably another year and a half or so to go before we would think about going internet. We want to really build what we have as best of class and then we will think about internationalizing it. What a lot of people think about as I think EBPP may end up being one of the main payment types. We think of bill payment as a gateway. The combination of Immediate Payments and bill pay -- bill pay may lend up actually begin the payment type that M&A stand up the growth of immediate payments.

column7: availability and throughput
column8: we don't build things first small or medium volumes. We build things for high volumes. And so

column10: we're finding that scaling is becoming difficult in a lot of these implementations and that very nicely plays into our space because we're up into solution in terms of scaling it up. But
column11: I don't want to really enter the fray in terms of the realism and the timeline so not hope you can appreciate that.

column1: Phil Heasley: Well
column2: Wayne

column5: we certainly have formidable competitors and we are kind of niche on the EBPP side but we obviously plenty of competition
column6: we see plenty of competition there. On the retail side
column7: on the retailer side
column8: I think the transformation that’s going to take place there is going either people’s businesses are going to become obsolete or they are going to have figure out how to try to work their way towards being more competitive with what leads you. So
column9: I expect some level of competition there
column10: but in terms of our core capabilities
column11: I still think our biggest competitor would be someone deciding for whatever reason they want to build that capability themselves and they are willing to put the 3 to 5 or 4 to 6 years into whatever it would take for themselves and I think has to be some overarching strategic reason why that makes sense from the plumbing of the industry but that’s the best answer I can give you.

column1: John Kraft: Thanks Raquel and good morning everybody. Today's call
column2: like all of our events
column3: is subject to both Safe Harbor and forward-looking statements. You can find the full text of both statements on the first and final pages of the presentation deck today
column4: a copy of which is available on our website as well as with the SEC. On this morning's call is Phil Heasley
column5: our CEO and Scott Behrens
column6: our CFO. But before we start
column7: I just want to make sure everybody is aware that we will be attending Citi's Financial Technology Conference on November 7th and that ACI will be hosting an Analyst Day here in Naples on November 14th. Later in November
column8: we'll be attending the Bank of America Leverage Finance Conference as well as the Credit Suisse 21st Annual TMT Conference. With that
column9: I'd like to turn the call over to Phil.

column1: Philip G. Heasley: Thanks
column2: John and good morning everyone. Quarter three was another strong quarter for ACI in continuation of a solid 2017. We came in ahead of our revenue and EBITDA guidance and made significant progress in the execution of several strategic initiatives. Our sales pipeline remained strong and growing across all our solutions
column3: and we are confident in achieving our full year financial targets. Let me discuss some of the trends in the market and strategic deals signed in the quarter. We continue to have success with our Up Retail Payment Solution program
column4: including the renewal of a large customer in Australia this quarter. 2017 is the second year we have offered RPS
column5: and we continue to see virtually all of our BASE24 customers opting for this package
column6: which bridges them to our powerful UP technology. The results of the RPS programs are exceeding our expectations
column7: and we are realizing 25% to 30% uplift in contract values over the terms of the agreement. In Asia
column8: we have been awarded a contract to build out a national switch
column9: which will leverage our UP immediate payments as the infrastructure for its real-time payments platform. All of the approximately 40 member banks will require technology to connect to this switch. With many of these member banks already ACI customers
column10: we have multiple opportunities for additional immediate payment gateway deals. We are seeing significant interest in our UP immediate payments offering and expect to sign several more contracts in the coming quarter. We also continued to sign large EBPP contracts
column11: including one of the largest contracts ever in the healthcare space. This customer will use ACI's Up build payment solution to offer their clients an omnichannel solution with an easy-to-use single e-wallet experience. Healthcare is a growing market for our biller solution. Overall
column12: there's been a lot of activity in the payment space. In conjunction with numerous industry events
column13: including Sibos and Money20/20
column14: we have announced material upgrades to several ACI solutions
column15: including UP payment risk management
column16: our fraud and analysis solution
column17: UP real-time payments which combines our UP immediate payments in MTS solutions
column18: into a single offering for both high and low value real time payments as well as our award-winning digital banking solution
column19: Universal Online Banker. With three major product releases 2017 is not a normal year. In addition
column20: we also unveiled a new API manager capability across all our UP solutions to support financial institutions open-banking strategies. These upgrades are the combination of significant investments we have made over the last several years
column21: and we are confident they will create increased shareholder value in the years to come. You will hear more details at our Analyst Day on November 14th. This event will be in Naples for both industry and financial analysts. In summary
column22: 2017 is proving to be an important year. We have largely digested recent acquisitions
column23: winding down our data center and cyber security investments and taken the actions to support ongoing growth. We are well prepared to achieve our financial targets for the year and remain committed to our longer-term growth goals. With that
column24: let me turn it over to Scott
column25: who'll provide more detail on our third quarter and full year outlook. Thank you.

column1: Scott W. Behrens: Thanks
column2: Phil and good morning everyone. I first plan to go through the highlights of the third quarter and then provide an update on our outlook for 2017. We'll then open the line for questions. I'll be starting my comments on slide 6
column3: with key takeaways from the quarter. As Phil said
column4: Q3 was another solid quarter for us. We saw revenue of $226 million
column5: up 3% over the prior year quarter and ahead of the guidance we provided you last quarter. This revenue growth contributed a strong EBITDA growth
column6: which was up 34% from last year and an EBITDA margin of 25%
column7: which was 600 basis points higher than last year. New bookings were $143 million
column8: which was down from Q3 last year in our 12 month and 60 month backlogs of $883 million and $4.1 billion
column9: were also down a bit during the quarter
column10: although it's not uncommon for us to see small decreases before we enter the fourth quarter
column11: which historically represents our biggest bookings quarter. And we do expect to see strong sequential growth in all these categories in Q4. Year-to-date
column12: we've generated $82 million in free cash flow
column13: which is up 94% over the same period last year. We ended the quarter with $68 million in cash. We had a debt balance of $703 million
column14: which is down $51 million this year. And we have $78 million remaining on our share buyback authorization. Turning next to slide 7
column15: with our full year outlook
column16: with 60 days left in the year
column17: we are raising the low-end of our revenue guidance range for the year. So for the full year
column18: we are now expecting revenues to be in a range of $1
column25: which is up from the prior range of $1
column31: 000. We continue to expect adjusted EBITDA to be in the range of $250 million to $255 million
column32: and we continue to expect new bookings growth to be in the upper single digit. So overall
column33: Q3 results continue a solid 2017 performance
column34: and we're comfortable raising the lower end of our revenue guidance range. That concludes my prepared remarks. Operator
column35: we are ready to open the line for questions at this time.

column6: when we told you we were going to move from -- we were going to move right up to renewal date

column8: right? So what you see is that we are now through one year
column9: anyhow
column10: we've put it in there quarterly. We're now through one year of pushing out the renewal. And whether you renew at 48 months or you renew at 60 months

So it's sort of an odd standard that says you accelerate your revenue and you defer your costs. But we're no different
column8: we've put some pretty extensive disclosures in our SEC filings. column42: with our 2018 guidance
column43: in addition to reporting actual results under both the new and old GAAP
column44: we’ll also provide our forward guidance under both as well
column45: starting with our guidance under historical accounting or ASC 605. For the full year 2018
column46: we expect revenue to be in a range of $1.05 billion to $1.075 billion
column47: which represents 3% to 5% growth over 2017. Adjusted EBITDA is expected to be in a range of $270 million to $285 million
column48: which excludes approximately $5 million to $7 million in significant transaction-related expense and we expect to generate between $210 million and $220 million of revenue in the first quarter under ASC 605. Under the new accounting standards
column49: we expect revenue in 2018 to be between $1.03 billion and $1.055 billion and adjusted EBITDA to be in a range of $255 million to $270 million. And we expect to generate between $200 million and $210 million of revenue in the first quarter under ASC 606. And to help with your modeling
column50: you’ll find additional guidance assumptions on slide nine
column51: new bookings are expected to grow in the low-double digits for the full year 2018
column52: which is above our trend line
column53: but we expect 2018 to compensate for the anomaly we saw in 2017 bookings. We expect GAAP interest expense of $37 million and cash interest of $34 million. Capital expenditures are expected to approximately $50 million
column54: continuing the downward trend of the last couple of years. Depreciation and amortization is expected to approximate $100 million
column55: non-cash compensation to approximate $30 million and cash taxes should approximate $40 million. Pass-through interchange should be in a range of $170 million to $175 million
column56: and lastly
column57: our diluted share count should approximate $160 million
column58: which excludes any future share buyback activity. And finally
column59: turning to page 10
column60: we’re providing you our long range outlook for adjusted EBITDA targets beyond 2018. We expect a leverage in the business model that’s beginning to show up in our EBITDA growth are driven by both scale
column61: as well as our focus on the Rule of 40s for our SaaS and platform business to continue to drive EBITDA expansion. We see that trend continuing beyond 2018 and are targeting EBITDA on 2019 to be in a range of $300 million to $350 million and in 2020 to be in the range of $335 million to $350 million. So
column62: in summary
column63: we generated revenue at the high end of our guidance
column64: EBITDA in excess of our guidance. That strong EBITDA growth and resulting strong cash flow generation was used in part that continue to pay down debt
column65: resulting in our lowest leverage ratio in five years. We also purchased 3 million shares of our stock and are well-positioned with our reloaded 200 million share repurchase authorization. And finally
column66: we believe we are well-positioned for EBITDA growth and strong cash flow generation in 2018 and beyond. So that concludes my prepared remarks. Operator
column67: we are ready to open the line for questions at this time.

column1: Operator: Thank you. [Operator Instructions] And your first question comes from the line of George Sutton with Craig-Hallum. Please go ahead.
Jason Kreyer: Hey gentlemen. Good morning. It’s Jason on for George.
Phil Heasley: Hi
column2: Jason.

column1: Jason Kreyer: So you’ve mentioned in your prepared remarks
column2: you’d said that the bookings pipeline is larger than ever. And just wondering if you can give some specifics on you know where you see that composition. I know you ran through some things in your script
column3: but what are the drivers of that bookings pipeline?

column1: Phil Heasley: Well
column2: yeah
column3: I have to get back into ‘17 to answer that. I actually have to get all the way back to ‘16 a little bit to answer that question. The fact that our bookings are in a strong as they could and should be on a -- on our trend line is largely impacted by four things that ACI did to itself. We announced -- we told you in the last year at this time that we had deliberately strategically closed the gap on our renewals and said that we’re only going to do renewals in the year of renewals and that the RPS program was driving that and it was a major -- and in fact instead of working on two years of renewals
column4: we doubled down and working on one-year renewals
column5: because bridging everyone to the new technology was a task number one
column6: objective number one. So
column7: that in itself slowed down bookings
column8: because we in fact cut even though our pipe -- our renewals were there and we’re running it close to 100% renewal. We shut -- we basically shut half of the amount of renewals we’d against. Second one was that we made it very clear that the marketplace that we’re coming out with significant new GAs in 2017 and we did the two analyst meetings since -- without trying to signal to all of our competitors and what not that we were out of the market on digital and we were -- we had slowed down our efforts on the other platform GAs. We did that because we wanted to have the Linux offering and the values that came from the Linux offerings. So that slowed down our bookings also. The third area which shouldn’t be underestimated is we reorganized into the two P&L structure. We went from one salesforce to three salesforce. Now we separated renewals from cross-sell and we separated both of those from our business development. There’s significant interest in our UP technology and we weren’t organized in a way to directly confront that and so we went through trying to use the Olympic analogy we were in the hockey game and we did try to score a point
column9: because we’re changing lines
column10: right
column11: and so I wouldn’t underestimate that. And then the last one was coming into the fourth quarter
column12: we did not -- we have -- we are a way too in my opinion
column13: we’re a way too dependent on the fourth quarter and when we’re satisfied with the revenue from sales
column14: we had no reason to be making less than optimum -- optimal deals closing out the year and that’s why I stick on to you that’s the --that the first quarter is already at last year’s first quarter level and what not. And so those four reasons or all reasons why -- so on a go forward basis
column15: if you don’t -- it slow down -- all those reasons had nothing whatsoever to do with bookings or pipeline. We’ve been winning awards for our new technology and in fact one just crossed the wire this morning. We think that that the R&D was the right move. We think the reorganization was the right move. The focus on the two pieces of business was the right move. We -- RPS is validating itself as being the right move. And the fourth quarter where I’d really like to spread more the business in the other three quarters of the year than just wait for everyone’s budgets to get approved and have a rare mad dash to signing contracts.

column1: Jason Kreyer: Great color on that. Thank you. Just one more question for me the decision to provide the long-term guidance for 2019 and 2020
column2: that’s not something we’ve seen from you guys in the past. So it would appear that’s coming from more confidence in the pipeline going forward
column3: but just give me your thoughts on why you chose to provide that level of guidance?

column1: Phil Heasley: Well
column2: I think
column3: it doesn’t -- everything
column4: it supports everything we said
column5: right. So I’m not going to reiterate a bunch of what we said. I think there is another way to look at it. We just bought back 3% of our stock and we put out the authority to buy back another 7% of our stock. We think that -- we do a very disciplined discounted cash flow in terms of when we buy earnings per share
column6: right. Think about it that way or EBITDA per share. And we can’t -- we’re having a real hard time finding anything that’s more attractive than our own EBITDA per share and I don’t want to get into a lawsuit or whatever that says that we’re being overly huge in terms of how we’re going after that.

column1: Scott Behrens: Yeah. Jason
column2: the only other thing I’d add is
column3: I think
column4: providing this is a natural progression of what we’ve been talking about now for essentially about the last year. It was last year about this time that we introduced our two P&L segments for the On Premise and our SaaS and platform business. When we met in November in -- at Analyst Day
column5: we talked about the Rule of 40s and our commitments to getting the cloud business to the Rule of 40. And I said at that time over the course of the five years
column6: we have EBITDA growth targets out there of 100 basis points
column7: but the quicker we can get traction on the Rule of 40
column8: we’re going to move that needle probably a little higher than 100 basis points. And so that’s a part of the reason to put it out there for 2019 and 2020 was to kind of get some direction to where we think our ability to execute on the Rule of 40s and how it will drive in particular the profitability of our cloud business.

column1: Phil Heasley: And you see the cash that the company is generating and we have to be holistic -- we have to be clear with all the options we have for that cash.
Jason Kreyer: Great. Thanks a lot guys.
Operator: And your next question comes from the line of Peter Heckmann with Davidson. Please go ahead.
Peter Heckmann: Hey. Good morning
column2: everyone. Thanks for providing that longer term guidance. I think that’s a bold move
column3: it’s something that the market will welcome. But as we try and model towards those numbers
column4: can you help us a little bit thinking about what type of revenue growth might be contemplated at the lower and higher ends of those longer term EBITDA guidance ranges?

column1: Scott Behrens: Yeah. Well
column2: for -- certainly for 2018
column3: we’ve obviously guided to 3% to 5% revenue growth. We said over the five years that we’re talking mid-to-upper single digits. So I think what you’ll see in ‘19 and ‘20 is a progression
column4: 2018 is the baseline towards that mid-to-upper single-digit revenue growth.

column1: Peter Heckmann: Okay. And…
Scott Behrens: But I -- it is really
column2: but there’s two dynamics to
column3: I guess
column4: our ability to deliver on those EBITDA targets. One is going to be revenue growth
column5: but the other is going to be the efficiency and the optimization of our cloud business. So
column6: again
column7: we put a lot of investment in the past into product development
column8: as well as infrastructure costs and we’re at -- we’re now going into the three-year period or so that we’re going to be able to see the dividends in that set. So I really see it as a combination of both the revenue growth and cost optimization that will help us on delivering on those targets.

column1: Peter Heckmann: Okay. Okay. And then is there a minimum level of bookings in 2018 that you need to get to achieve those 2019 numbers
column2: I mean
column3: if let’s say we have a year of flat bookings in 2018 on a relatively easy comp
column4: how much will that effect to you guys.

column1: Phil Heasley: Well
column2: when you -- going forward even so ‘17 was a leap year
column3: from a 60-month backlog standpoint
column4: we still replenished -- we still replenished the backlog and it grew a little tiny bit. So that would be the baseline that you want to start with. We’ve been stocking away into backlog more than revenue growth for the three years before that
column5: so you think that. The AOD business
column6: the historic On Premise business of ours very much follows the bookings backlog
column7: revenue
column8: revenue generation and out
column9: and that’s going to stay very predictable in that way. The AOD business is going to have full organic revenue growth and bookings response as drivers of its increased revenue. So we’re expecting very good bookings growth right and like we said
column10: if you add ‘18 and ‘17 together and divided by two
column11: we feel very confident we’re going to be on trajectory. AOD has another mechanism by which its -- they are in the transaction business and it’s not a fixed multiyear contract. It’s a floor right and the whole idea is to beat that floor and to get as much share in the digital transformation as possible and then roll off of that chair. And the growth in real time payment has not been disappointing anybody in terms of forecast versus actual in terms of organic growth should be a bigger piece. And yeah
column12: we should be comfortable that take ‘17 and ‘18
column13: divide them by two and we feel comfortably on that trajectory.

column1: Peter Heckmann: Okay. And then just last question
column2: I didn’t totally understand your comment on the renewals piece
column3: I see it in the bookings numbers
column4: term extensions
column5: and perhaps
column6: the upgrade were both lower. But what was the comment on was it less focused on renewals and more focused on the deployment?

column1: Phil Heasley: No
column2: no
column3: no. I apologize. What I said was we traditionally go out and we aggressively renew contracts in their third year and fourth year. We in the end of ‘16 changed that and said that with the complexity of RPS and bring -- combining the old and the new technology isn’t we want to come out of this cycle with everybody operating on UP. We -- in effect said
column4: we’re only going to work on current year. And of course
column5: when you only work a lot of our new business our core new business comes from the add-on of renewal business. So when you
column6: say
column7: well
column8: gee
column9: I’m only going to renew half of it that not only impacts renewals
column10: it also impacts the add-on and additional capacity that is purchased. Does that make sense?

column1: Peter Heckmann: It does. It does. So…
Phil Heasley: Yeah.
Peter Heckmann: … as in prior quarters or prior period is that that business is still locked in
column2: there hasn’t been an increase in cancellations
column3: we will just…

column1: Phil Heasley: No. Our attrition rate is virtually zero.
Peter Heckmann: Yeah. So we have a high-level of confidence
column2: we will see those come through in ‘18 or ‘19?

column1: Phil Heasley: Yeah.
Peter Heckmann: Okay. Thank you.
Phil Heasley: Yeah.

It sounds like you did that in the fourth quarter here in the U.S. And I don’t understand why the backlog in bookings number or specifically why the bookings number wouldn’t have been much better given at least our understanding of how big those contracts are and you were talking about 25% to 30% lift on those contracts. I don’t understand how that math doesn’t flow through to that bookings number. I’m just confused on that lack of flow through?
Phil Heasley: Well
column2: a little bit of that has to do with yoking back the number
column3: the number of renewals. Now
column4: we’re definitely not going to talk about individual contracts. We’ve got our customers would be upset. But we also did you know
column5: so basically what we’ve done is we look for 25% to 30% and I don’t think there’s any
column6: no
column7: no real secret. The number we’ve achieved is 28% and that’s a combination of
column8: it’s almost all buying incremental volume. Now that that lands up and what we’ve done is
column9: we actually take a slightly -- we’ve taken a slightly lower ILF
column10: so there’s less revenue impact on the current year. But it gives us a nice 5% plus growth rate over the duration of the contract
column11: because if you think about 28% provided by five-year contract
column12: you’re going to get 5% in change. By giving them the new technology on top of the old technology
column13: I said that
column14: we had 13 contracts that followed
column15: most of which are from fourth quarter ‘16
column16: first quarter ‘17 bookings. As they start adding more volumes into it
column17: they then contract us or they do it themselves or they contract us to work on them on projects to bring more volume in
column18: right. I guess the best way -- you want to add on?

column1: Scott Behrens: Yeah. Brett

column4: which came with a renewal
column5: but it was substantial term extension event
column6: as well as the substantial new bookings event. So we had one of those customers that Phil talks about being RPS was signed in Q4 ‘16. So

column1: Brett Huff: Okay. And second question is -- that’s helpful. Thanks for that insight. Second question is we had guided to high single-digit net new bookings for this year. By my math it came in down mid-teens and even though you’re guiding for low double-digit growth for next year on that lower base. By my math

That’s also confusing to me and is there just a general delay or are we being conservative on the low double next year for ‘18. Where does that $150 million go?

column2: well
column3: first of all
column4: low double
column5: probably
column6: a wider range than maybe what you’re computing. But in terms of -- and it still goes back to what we’re seeing in Q1. Q1
column7: we are seeing
column8: as Phil said
column9: I mean
column10: we’re nearly at the level of bookings we have for all of the first quarter last year. So we’re going to see strong comps here early in the year and I think that that makes it different. I think
column11: historically where we had deal slipped from year-to-year
column12: they slipped
column13: they took with them revenue and margin. That wasn’t the case this year. So deals -- these deals slipped were deals that likely would have driven just it would have gone straight in the backlog and would have likely gone into projects status delivered revenue for each year. So the fact that we’re signing those now in the first six weeks of the year
column14: really doesn’t knock this off path
column15: because again a lot -- most of that would have gone to backlog and into a project status delivered at some point in the future.

column1: Brett Huff: Okay. And then last question from us
column2: despite a little bit lower license mix than usual
column3: Phil
column4: I think
column5: you mentioned
column6: you guys had a lot of success in one -- quarter one through quarter three in getting some of the renewals done or the higher margin stuff done. The license mix wasn’t as favorable yet
column7: you guys really had great not particularly COGS leverage but OpEx leverage. What was driving that and I don’t know if that’s for Phil or for Scott
column8: but on all three lines or four lines of OpEx
column9: much lower than we expected in. What drove that -- should we think about that going forward and maybe is that implied in sort of your longer term EBITDA guidance?

column1: Scott Behrens: Well
column2: yeah
column3: I think
column4: if you look at and just say relative to the midpoint of our guidance or relative [ph] 3% (42:30) it’s a lot of that excess revenue that we achieved did deliver bottomline EBITDA. But I think it gets into the scale in the leverage of the model. And again a lot of that investment that we’ve made in the past is not only coming to a natural ends
column5: but it’s also -- those investments were also into driving high amount of incremental dollar will drop to the bottomline. So
column6: it’s really the scale and the leverage of those investments we start to see.

column1: Phil Heasley: Brett
column2: I also want to answer it
column3: because it’s one of the reason I put you guys through a long set of comments this morning. When you buy 11 companies and what you’re really trying to buy is his capabilities and whatnot
column4: and you’ve got a real vision for what it is you want to build. What you’ll end up having to do is you’ll end up having to divest
column5: you’ll end up having to do one-time kinds of tests and whatnot to make those 11 companies and your core company one company. And one thing that we’ve not done a great job of explaining to the street is that we’ve actually -- our gross revenue -- gross is a bad term
column6: I think. But the amount of revenue growth that we’ve had for the last three years
column7: four years has been offset by revenue that we’ve driven out of the business
column8: because we discontinued one of S1’s major online business lines
column9: but we weren’t going to put a flag out in front of the building and we weren’t going to -- we have to work it logically out with our customers
column10: a lot of whom we continue with other products and whatnot. So if we are driving out revenue that has little to no margin and then we’re growing good business that has margin
column11: it looks like you don’t have that much of a revenue growth rate
column12: because on a net day basis you don’t. But what it does to your EBITDA
column13: so once it’s gone its expenses go away and its revenue went away
column14: but the marginal effect becomes a multiplier and that’s what you’re beginning to see. And the other one was is that closing those 25 data centers and building out the four. We went through a bunch of cost that we expect efficiency. We’re also expecting leverage against that fixed cost investment in those. We have years of growth before we have to readdress those centers in the way we did just now.

column1: Brett Huff: Okay. That’s helpful. And last one for me. What are the kind of the upsides
column2: downsides that might drive better or worse than the
column3: I think
column4: what you guys are seeing is a low double-digit range
column5: and Scott
column6: I don’t know if you want to comment
column7: you mentioned that maybe it’s -- I don’t know you implied it was more mid-teens in your prior comment. But what would drive upside and downside to that? We’ve gotten some questions
column8: just how conservative is that outlook now
column9: because folks are trying to get a handle on what is the right kind of bookings run rate? Thank you.

column1: Phil Heasley: Well
column2: I’ll give you a couple of things and then I will let Scott as our CFO give you a couple of things. We have no -- merchants and banks are probably two of the biggest recipients of the tax reductions. And whereas merchants have been investing
column3: they’ve been investing in what they can afford and it’s possible that they’ll invest more
column4: right. Banks really under this regulatory regime of the last eight years have invested little to nothing that they didn’t have to invest against the regulatory scheme. And that has not been positive. We have a lot of customers that need to do transformational kinds of projects and they have just been below the regulatory regime in terms of things that they can do and whatnot
column5: that’s potentially a positive. And the best way I can say that is that after a couple of years of saying
column6: well
column7: gee
column8: we’ve got this great technology
column9: people are just going to come and do huge deals with us and forecast that as part of our business going forward. In 16 week we quit doing that. So when we talk about our growth rates and whatnot
column10: they are not dependent on any elephant or well-sized initiatives that are out there and those would be -- on the negative side is that something happens to severely injure
column11: the banks get in trouble again or something
column12: but I can’t really forecast that one.

column1: Scott Behrens: Yeah. The only thing I’d add to that is that
column2: I agree on the downside it would be something macroeconomic. On the upside though
column3: we’re -- there’s a lot of drivers of upside. We’re entering the year three of our RPS program
column4: where we’re getting the 25%
column5: 30% price uplift. So that’s -- and that’s been very high
column6: nearly 100% adoption rate. So that’s really subject to the pool of renewals we have each year. And so
column7: again
column8: in year three of that
column9: we just introduced our real time payment solutions. So not on the retail side
column10: but more on the wholesale side of payments
column11: that’s structured very similar to the RPS program. And that’s -- this will be the first full year of that program. And then
column12: just overall the new product release. So the Linux capabilities
column13: as well as the new digital banking solution are really what will drive the upside.

column1: Brett Huff: Okay. Thanks for your time. I appreciate it.
Operator: And your next question comes from the line of David Eller with Wells Fargo. Please go ahead.
David Eller: Good morning. And
column2: Phil
column3: thank you for all the commentary and the slides to start the call. Scott
column4: on the share repo
column5: typically you’ve held 75% to 80% of your cash offshore and I wondered if you could give us some context related to Tax Reform on how efficiently or quickly you might be able to bring that cash back and then if there’s any timeline related to the new $200 million authorization?

column1: Scott Behrens: Well
column2: we historically had a generally pretty efficient tax structure
column3: meaning the ability to get cash back from overseas. So I don’t necessarily look at that cash is being trapped for any particular reason. Obviously
column4: we’re going to be in a more flexible position going forward
column5: because now it’s already is a part of the unremitting earnings tax. So there’s still working capital requirement for where we operate in 50 countries. So there’s certainly an element of working capital required to be overseas and then certain jurisdictions have
column6: it’s not that we tax that when it comes in to the U.S. They tax it when it leaves the country. So there’s those kind of dynamics. So I don’t think in and of itself the tax law will impact that again
column7: so efficient structure certainly more flexibility going forward because essentially it’s already been taxed. And in terms of the $200 million authorization
column8: the only thing I’d say to that is
column9: of course
column10: of the last
column11: call it 90 days we’ve purchased 3 million shares. Yes
column12: we have 200 million as of today available and I would just reiterate what
column13: Phil said
column14: we look at our stock and what we’re seeing in our future is a very compelling use of our cash. So
column15: I think
column16: that’s as much as I’d say about any timing of use of that…

column1: Phil Heasley: I’ll give you a little add-on to that. If you take a backwards look at us
column2: we’ve purchased about 40 million of our shares and this is actually a pattern to how we buy back our shares. So
column3: if you take backwards look you could might make a forward interpolation in terms of this and that might be the best way to answer the question.

column1: David Eller: Okay. Thank you for that color. And then you also mentioned that you continue to have $100 million of net operating losses that you can use after Tax Reform
column2: can you give us any kind of estimate of when you might exhaust those or kind of what -- how long you might be able to use those going forward?

column1: Scott Behrens: Well
column2: there -- there’s no limit
column3: right. There’s no risk at this point in terms of our future earnings that we would lose any of the availability of that. We have really a couple more years of pretty heavy utilization on those. Before that -- some of those limitations drop off and get out to 2020
column4: but what we’ve got a couple more years of pretty heavy utilization.

column1: David Eller: Okay. And then
column2: last question for me about housekeeping. I think in prior years you’ve provided a specific free cash flow number in your guidance and I think you’ve given us a lot of the kind of assumptions that we can drive to that
column3: but did you provide a free cash flow number for this year?

column1: Scott Behrens: Same -- it’s very similar to what we’ve done in the past. All the components
column2: I think are on slide nine. If you -- but if you do what we call kind of the sanity check math
column3: where we start with EBITDA
column4: which is again we’ve guided to range to $270 million to $285 million
column5: and then you reduce it really to three major cash components being the cash taxes of $40 million and interest of $34 million and CapEx around $50 million
column6: you get in that high $150 million range
column7: so the growth is -- should be commensurate with our EBITDA growth.

column1: David Eller: Okay. Thank you so much for taking my questions.

Wayne Johnson: Hi. Yes. Thank you for all these data points. Very helpful. Just in case I missed it in the beginning part of the call

column3: when you look at the whole year?

Scott Behrens: The recurring revenue?

Total EBITDA was lower in the quarter compared to the prior year from our On Premise business as a result of the timing of those high-margin license fees that we get on renewal. We expect 2018 to follow a more historic pattern of quarterly phasing of renewal events. Our On Demand business delivered strong growth in EBITDA with net EBITDA margins increasing over 800 basis points
column15: driven by a combination of both revenue growth and lower expenses compared to the same period in 2017. We continue to be very optimistic about future margin improvement opportunities in our On Demand business. We ended the first quarter with $74 million in cash on hand

column17: and a debt balance of $689 million
column18: down $7 million from the end of 2017. Our adjusted operating free cash flow for the quarter was $36 million

column5: ACI’s fiscal year is on track. Q2 revenues were in line with guidance and above street consensus. We saw continued strong demand for our UP solutions across all four of our targeted segments of banks

column11: or RPS

column16: which continues to see increased global adoption of cloud-based omni-channel solutions. Merchants are driven to meet customer expectations for anytime
column17: anywhere
column18: any channel payments. Included in the key wins are one of the 10 largest grocery retailers in the U.S.

One of Canada’s top five banks has adopted a cloud-first strategy with its initial focus on corporate expansion. This soon-to-be published report demonstrates that large banks would be able to process 1 billion transactions per month for a significantly lower total cost of ownership
column43: up to 90% improvement. The study also validated that the Linux platform could easily handle the mission critical payment processing needs of very large banks with high-availability
column44: scalability and high-transaction throughput. Further

column1: Operator: [Operator Instructions]. Your question comes from George Sutton with Craig-Hallum.
George Sutton: Good morning
column2: guys. Phil
column3: you’re obviously enthusiastic about the second half driven by a pipeline that you see. Obviously we don’t see that detail. Could you just frame that enthusiasm and opportunity for us?

column1: Philip Heasley: Well
column2: I’m comfortable with the second half for several reasons. One is we did what we said we were going to do in the second quarter. And our whole year is more like most businesses’ quarter because the shape of our delivery is an annual delivery; it’s not a quarterly delivery. So it’s hard for us in any given quarter to be overly enthusiastic by variances that are just driven by timing
column3: by the annual sign up in that year. We’re just really confident. Most of our – we’ve made our revenue numbers this part of the year mostly by over performance in the On Demand side of the business and we’re still waiting for the annual renewals that we know are going to take place and they’re going to take place further on in the year. So a lot of our – all this good news in bookings is coming from new names and new logos and new businesses
column4: not so much associated with the renewals that are going to come in the second part of the year. And this strange new way we’re going to look at revenue under 606
column5: renewals are much more valued or they’re almost over valued in the 606 accounting. So the fact that we are where we are from both the 605 and 606 standpoint
column6: we’re very comfortable. The bookings are coming in very strong and the amount of usage
column7: now we’re a little bit different than other companies
column8: a lot of other companies is that we book and then we implement and then we grow revenue. So one of the reasons we feel confident is that the implementation book continues to grow and we can only implement as fast as we can convert or build for our customers and as fast as they can ramp. So at this point
column9: our revenue is an important driver of EBITDA whereas our expenses are very much constant as they work their way through the year. So yes
column10: there’s no reason not to be very – there’s no reason not to be confident
column11: especially since year-to-date has been largely driven by over performance on the On Demand side of the business.

column1: George Sutton: Perfect. Just one other thing. A recent trade rag named real-time payments as the number one sort of major initiative in the FinTech world. You’re obviously a direct beneficiary and you mentioned 14 new contracts this quarter. Could you just give us a sense of how significant this opportunity should be for you?
Philip Heasley: Well
column2: I don’t want to get into the forecasting how quickly adoption rates are going. If you look at countries like India
column3: India is forecasting 1 billion transactions a day on their new – it would be the equivalent of [indiscernible] and whatnot. You have to believe in the ramp statistics in terms of getting there and whatnot
column4: because there’s a fraction of those numbers. But I believe particularly Asia
column5: Southwest to Southeast Asia
column6: they are going to bypass the heavy concentration of transactions coming through the credit side and then maturing into the debit side. It’s going to be more on the debit – they’re going to go directly to the debit side of the equation. So we view – I think we view two trends. On average
column7: we are in less than one-seventh $0.01 for transactions in terms of what we do. But we do many
column8: many more – we do more transactions than Visa or MasterCard who tend to earn – tend to process a transaction for what they do
column9: right? We see our volumes coming in very strongly in the next two or three years and we see the revenues
column10: it’s kind of a CAGR gain
column11: because we’re not going to see as big a pop as it moves up the S curve. But as it moves up
column12: we think those numbers – put another way
column13: we think – well
column14: if you look at the German profile and with its low penetration of credit and its high number of transactions per individual
column15: we think Asia is going to look like – and I’m not talking about Japan and we’re really not talking about mainly in China yet
column16: but they’re really not open markets for the rest of – but we’re talking about the rest of Southeast and Southwest Asia. And we think the transaction – we think there’s easily a driver of – driving that 1.1 trillion
column17: 1.2 trillion transactions a year where it’s doubled in the next five years. And we’re going to get our requisite share as long as we keep signing up the people that are adopting it. It’s not a get-rich-quick scheme
column18: because we’re not going to get the volume day one
column19: month one
column20: year one
column21: but we’re going to get the opportunity for the volume.

column2: Phil. I appreciate it.

column2: which is right on us. And the reason I say that is that it doesn’t look – we’re beginning to see the non-renewal customers. We’re beginning to see a lot of new business from FinTech and other type players that are seeing a very different cost of entry

column4: especially in the Linux environment and whatnot. And we’re – the banks are still concentrated on profitability and showing you guys their revenue growth every quarter. We’re not seeing the heavy non-regulatory investment. We see dialogue on it and the Canadian banks are certainly

column6: but we think most of our opportunity is in front of us on the financial segment. On merchants and corporates

column1: David Eller: Great. And then
column2: Scott
column3: on the – you kind of reiterated your 2019 and 2020 goals. I think for 2019 EBITDA
column4: your range was like 300 to 315. That midpoint would be like 17% growth for next year and I think consensus is looking for 4% to 5% revenue growth. So can you help us maybe understand some of your assumptions around margin improvement for 2019 and maybe 2020 as well?

column1: Scott Behrens: I think that there’s really I would say two drivers and a lot of its driven by our path to – our rule of 40 that we talked about in our AOD business. Really it’s based on the profile of combinations of two things. Its revenue growth on top of that cost structure but also lower costs as we exit 2018. We’ve talked in the past about a lot of the heavy investments we’ve made in building out that infrastructure
column2: whether it’s physical
column3: virtual
column4: cyber-security. And so it’s really a combination of both
column5: higher revenue as well as lower-cost as we exit 2018.

column1: David Eller: Great. And then last call for me
column2: I know your bond call price drops to par in August. Can you maybe talk about your thoughts around your capital structure? And then if you could remind us maybe your target leverage and what considerations go into that leverage target?

column1: Scott Behrens: Well
column2: I think we’ve historically said that we’re kind of comfortable around
column3: call it that 2.5x. And if you look historically when we’ve done acquisitions
column4: we’ve sort of – you’d see a step up in leverage. It is part of the acquisition
column5: but then we quickly delever from there. So we’re comfortable with 2.5. We’re also comfortable with the right cash flow structure
column6: we would acquire something that we’d be able to – on a combination be able to bring that down. In terms of our bonds
column7: yes
column8: we’re aware that we’re coming up on the five year and the expiration of these call premium. The market conditions are certainly favorable for us to get in and refinance those. So we’re keeping an eye on that.

column1: David Eller: All right. Thanks for taking the questions.
Operator: Your next question is from Peter Heckmann with Davidson.
Alexis Huseby: Hi
column2: guys. This is Alexis on for Pete today. So first
column3: I’m just hoping you can comment a little more on the year-to-date eCommerce wins within the merchant space and specifically some of the factors that are helping drive merchants to decide to take some of this payment capability in-house?

column1: Philip Heasley: Well
column2: I really think there is two behaviors going on in the e-retailers. I think you have one set of customers who say
column3: my top five priorities are A through E and payments is not one of them. And they’re more than likely to go to a full solution provider like Avion or Global Payments or Paymentech and say listen
column4: we’re not doing it as the top of the – top five priority and whatnot. Then you have other ones who deal – they have good global volume around the world. They’re thinking about it from a global standpoint. They’ve got to figure out how to do global logistics execution from a delivery standpoint. So the whole concept of managing an integrated step of [ph] logistics and managing the cash
column5: there is a huge – there’s huge benefit for them to leverage that capability and be able to drive yield and liquidity from it. And we tend to do very well with those companies. The other ones that are a driving factor which is kind of a new one
column6: but it’s a very nice one. We’re seeing a lot of M&A funds that are beginning to concentrate in categories and also by five different fast-food companies and whatnot. And they’ll want to put in as many payment capabilities as possible of the one modernized – they’ve been kind of in jail with their pedant merchant providers and whatnot. And so instead of owned company by owned company
column7: these guys are managing the efficiency of that across their portfolio of businesses that you’ll end up working
column8: one day you’re doing hamburgers and the next day you’re doing tacos or whatever in turns
column9: but it lands up being a leverageable payment system for them. And that’s been a very nice arena of business. A lot of those are – we have several of those in the implementation phase. And then another form is we’re doing very well in transportation. And you say
column10: well
column11: transportation is really not an e-retailer
column12: they are really – they’re very much physical. But the truth of the matter is
column13: 99% of people want ticket in hand and the transportation company wants ticket in hands and kiosk is initially in concept
column14: but kiosk is kind of the point of the last resort. So omni-channel there works very well and it’s very leverageable. And a lot of those guys who are willing to work with each other because the American railroad system or the French railroad system are not in competition with each other
column15: they are kind of in the – they’re kind of categorized together and whatnot. So those are the ones that I would – I think we told you last time about camera-based traffic observation. It’s really clear that the lower the average ticket
column16: right. And the other one is gaining for us
column17: right. The lower the average ticket
column18: you really can’t afford. If you have a $10 average ticket and a $8 average ticket
column19: you’re not going to – you don’t want to pay $0.40 say or $1 a transaction
column20: right
column21: on that and you’ve got to make your forward decision very quickly
column22: you’ve got to make your payment decision very quickly and you can’t – you’ve got to really go for a least cost routing in terms of doing it. So we’re just filling natural niches. And there are other companies in which you could argue that it isn’t in their top five priorities right now
column23: but we’re filling a natural set of niches that eCommerce is creating by changes in behavior – how we behave differently. Domino’s
column24: 95% of people pay for the pizza at the time they order it whether they pick it up or they don’t pick it up or whatever. So it’s following behavior and the objectives of the company is in terms of executing those behaviors.

column1: Blake Anderson: Got it. And then just lastly on free cash flow
column2: I know you said it was up year-over-year. You reiterated guidance. It was a little low relative to our industry expectations. Were there any one-timers you would call out?
