column1: Operator: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from George Sutton with Craig-Hallum.
George Sutton: I'm curious
column2: when we do due diligence and talk to existing and potential customers
column3: what we find is a competitor systems being replaced is a fairly slow process; and you mentioned this quarter
column4: you actually saw a fair of that. I'm curious is there certain functionality or foreign types that are the appeal that's causing that change to be made?

column1: Ramesh Srinivasan: Hi
column2: George
column3: thank you for joining the call. The competitive replacements picking up
column4: we've been noticing that trend for quite a few quarters now. I would say for the last four or five quarters
column5: the rate at which we've been replacing major competitive systems because that is what we keep track of replacing. Major competitive system has really picked up and they don't necessarily take too much time George.There have been cases where a customer has contacted us and they have gone live with our product like a couple of months later. Now some of the things that trigger that is there could be a competitor system for whom a hardware refreshers coming up
column6: on the POS side. And while you're spending that kind of money on that refresh
column7: they start thinking why don't we go look for a system. That could be one.The other thing that very often happens is they want certain enhancements done to help their business and very often a lot of those vendors just don't have the engineering breadth and wherewithal to get those changes done quickly. They will want an interface created with another system that they have bought that many competing vendors just don't do and that becomes a compelling event for them to change the system. And their business could expand for which the other vendor may not be able to keep up.I don't think these decisions take too much time
column8: George
column9: based on our experience. But there are cases where
column10: let's say
column11: they're marginally like another system. But they're quite happy with their current system
column12: but they would really like to have a competing system
column13: that could take time. They might wait for a year or so before they really make that decision. But when there are compelling events and there are many
column14: especially with many vendors not doing great customer support
column15: these kinds of things do tend to happen a lot faster than probably what your sample sizes show.

column1: George Sutton: And your product strength and your professional services strength which has been a consistent thing for us to see
column2: can you give us a sense on
column3: is that something we should continue to expect for a period of time? Are we going to start to see the subscription side of it that really start to show that that benefit?

column1: Ramesh Srinivasan: Yes
column2: the product and services strength that you're seeing will lead to recurring revenue and subscription revenue strength. So like how Tony described in his prepared remarks
column3: what comes first is product revenue. So
column4: as part of the sale given the nature of our POS business
column5: a certain amount of hardware comes with it
column6: a certain amount of services revenue comes with it
column7: that's the first thing that happens.And then as we go implement and the customer wants more activities from us
column8: the services revenue picks up. And that's a good indicator of the fact we are doing a lot of implementations now. We are taking -- we're replacing a lot of companies and systems
column9: and we are doing a lot of new product installs of customers who already have other products. So
column10: as a services activity picks up
column11: as we've seen in the last six months
column12: that leads to recurring revenue.So
column13: those customers go live and the recurring revenue you should expect will pick up
column14: and it just so happens that more and more of our customers are preferring subscription-based arrangements. We don't force them into that. We want to be customer centric and we try to do what the customer wants us to do. It just so happens more and more customers want software solutions based in the cloud and subscription based arrangements.So as you see
column15: the product revenue is a good indicator that our business is doing well. We are doing a lot of sales
column16: selling out. Services revenue is a good indicator that we are doing a lot of implementations and in turn that will lead to recurring revenue in the future. And it just so happens. A good portion of the implementations we're doing happened to be SaaS subscription basis.

That has already gone live with about five or six customers already.Then the other one is mobile check-in

column4: right

column11: right
column12: or for different reasons. Like there is no one magic module that's going to create it. But as we keep doing all this R&D innovation work

column44: one quick update on customer retention
column45: fiscal 2020 was our best year in recent memory with respect to customer retention success. Customer retention was again well over 95% and our best percentage in many years.We measure customer churn and reverse of it customer retention in the old fashioned conservative way. We measure customer churn as a simple division of annual recurring revenue lost during the year as a percentage of total annual recurring revenue. And customer -- and we report customer retention as 100 minus customer churn percentage therefore by definition our customer retention measure cannot be more than a 100%.Please note that we measure customer churn as a percentage of only recurring revenue and not as a percentage of total revenue. Given our recurring revenue is about half our total revenue
column46: churn and its reverse customer retention is even better if you think of it as percentage of total revenue.We are aware that many software companies express customer retention in dollar retention terms using a variety of different formulae designed to make the numbers look great and often report them to be higher than 100%.If we use any of those methods
column47: our dollar retention rate would also be significantly higher than 100%
column48: because the extent of repeat business we get from current customers in terms of new property sites and new products far exceeds the extent of recurring revenue loss during the year. However
column49: we continue to believe that the old fashioned method of calculating customer retention as a percentage of recurring revenue is the right measures.We continue to retain well more than 95% of our recurring revenue base and also further act with significantly through business expansion as you can derive by our consistent increases in recurring revenue year-after-year.Going back to the subject of sales measured by annual contract value of sale agreements closed during a period. column7: and we began to integrate the Connect and Piper business units that we acquired from Icontrol in March. In early April
column8: we had a strong presence at the International Security Conference & Exposition
column9: known as ISC West. This is the largest event in the U.S. for the physical security industry. This year's show included a record number of attendees and exhibitors with increased emphasis on connected devices and cloud services. It's gratifying to see how our innovations have driven the industry in this direction. ISC West gives us an opportunity to take the pulse of our channel by engaging with a broad cross section of our service provider partners in direct meetings
column10: training sessions and hosted events. We also introduced a couple of new product initiatives that I'd like to highlight. We demonstrated the way our hardware ecosystem is expanding with new connected devices. For example
column11: we added a new Slim Line Edition of our successful video doorbell product. This new form factor will give our service providers more installation flexibility when deploying Alarm.com's integrated perimeter security solution. We also announced enhancements to our business intelligence offering for our service providers. Business intelligence is a key differentiator for Alarm.com and enables us to better align with the goals of our service providers. Our enterprise grade analytics solution helps our service providers implement a specific set of installation and service best practices that have been proven to increase account retention. Business intelligence reports allow executives and managers to monitor implementation of the identified best practices across the sales
column12: installation and support processes of their businesses. They can see how branches
column13: teams and individuals are performing
column14: track account installation quality and identify and address service hotspots
column15: so that they can better direct resources to ensure a superior customer experience. I also want to share some of the market feedback and observations that I took away from ISC West. First
column16: my conversations with our service provider partners reinforced that we offer the right set of services and have the right go to market strategy. Security centric services delivered by professionals are driving the broad adoption of IoT technology for both homes and businesses. Supported by the Alarm.com platform
column17: our service provider partners are leading the security industry's transformation from traditional alarm monitoring services to broader and more highly valued monitoring and automation solutions. Most service providers are now eagerly adopting new technology instead of resisting change
column18: and our newer offerings generate consistent interest. With these favorable market conditions
column19: we see significant opportunities for continued growth in the North American security channel. A second takeaway is the ongoing proliferation of devices capable of being integrated into an Alarm.com installation. As we deploy fully integrated solutions around otherwise disparate devices
column20: our service providers can extend security

column24: as the Internet of Things makes more interesting installations and applications attainable
column25: consumers are looking to service providers for a full complement of installation
column26: monitoring and support services. The Alarm.com platform enables our service providers to efficiently deliver the level of service necessary to capture this high value and growing market segment. Our fully integrated solutions address the needs of these consumers

We posted solid results across the board to start off the year. In the first quarter of 2017
column5: SaaS and license revenue grew 26% over the same quarter last year to $50.2 million. This includes a partial quarter contribution from Connect
column6: following the closing of the acquisition on March 8. I'd also like to mention that our other segment achieved growth of 121% year over year in the first quarter
column7: albeit off a small base. Our SaaS and license revenue visibility remains high with a revenue renewal rate of 93% in the first quarter. As expected
column8: this is slightly below our revenue renewal rate of 94% in the fourth quarter of 2016. We indicated in our last conference call that we expected some impact in 2017 from AT&T's 2G sensor program that took effect at the end of 2016. Taking this into consideration
column9: we still expect our revenue renewal rate to stay within our long-term expectation of 92% to 94%. Hardware and other revenue in the first quarter was $24 million
column10: an increase of 26% year over year. Video camera and video doorbell sales continued to drive growth in hardware. We are pleased to have introduced our new Slim Line Edition of our video doorbell this quarter to add to our portfolio of video products. Total revenue for the first quarter of 2017 increased 26% over the same quarter last year to $74.2 million. Gross margin for our SaaS and license revenue was 84% for the first quarter
column11: up about 200 basis points sequentially from the fourth quarter of 2016 and up 100 basis points from the same quarter last year. This is mainly due to the contribution of Connect
column12: which has a higher gross margin percentage than Alarm.com because of a different model. With Connect
column13: we provide the software and the service provider deploys
column14: manages and operates the software in their own network operation center with their own personnel. The service provider also needs to purchase around server capacity
column15: network operations bandwidth and cellular services. With Alarm.com
column16: all the services I just mentioned are managed by Alarm.com on a turnkey basis for the service provider. Like Alarm.com
column17: Connect also charges a monthly per-subscriber fee but at a lower amount. Comparing the models from a financial perspective
column18: Connect has a lower per-subscriber fee and less costs as the service provider incurs the cost of operating the service. Alarm.com has a higher per-subscriber fee to cover the additional cost of service. This results in Alarm.com having a slightly lower gross margin percentage but higher gross margin dollars per subscriber. Hardware and other gross margin was 23% for the first quarter of 2017. This is down about 200 basis points from Q1 2016 due to the larger contribution from video products. Total gross margin was 64% for the first quarter of 2017
column19: up about 200 basis points sequentially from 62% in the fourth quarter of 2016. This is mainly due to the higher SaaS and license gross margin in the first quarter of 2017 as I just reviewed. Turning to operating expenses. column1: Operator: Thank you. And our next question comes from Gabriela Borges of Goldman Sachs. Your line is open.
Chelsea Jurman: This is Chelsea Jurman on for Gabriela. You mentioned that you'd had some strong attach rates for your thermostat product this year
column2: and so I was wondering if you can give any update on what the overall attach rate is for home automation devices and how this is tracking versus 12 months ago or what you see the opportunity is being longer term.

column1: Steve Trundle: All right. Chelsea
column2: yes
column3: the overall attach rate on new activations for automation currently is about one out of four installations. Then all of the things that we can overtime do if that data to make either prosperities more efficient or at times even as we've demonstrated with the energy health business at times made utilities more efficient. So that's the trend that's sort of in the right direction and I think we will expect the summer season comes along to see that continue upward.

column1: Chelsea Jurman: Great. And then can you give any update into what full year guidance includes for some of the adjacent markets in terms of vacation rentals or commercial or even international and whether that is a meaningful portion in 2017?
Steve Valenzuela: Gabriela
column2: it's Steve Valenzuela. We did say on the call we saw good growth from our other segment quarter over quarter
column3: year over year. We actually saw growth of SaaS revenue from other segment of 121%. Now it is off a small number
column4: and it's a smaller contribution. We expect -- in the guidance that we provided
column5: we expect to continue to see good growth from the other segment. But just keep in mind
column6: it is a small percentage of our total revenue. So I would just keep that in mind as you look at the guidance number we provided.

column1: Operator: Thank you. And our next question comes from Nikolay Beliov of Bank of America. Your line is now open.
Nikolay Beliov: Question for Steve Valenzuela. Steve
column2: relatively
column3: recently you came on board. And looking at the margin structure provided a couple of years back during the IPO
column4: EBITDA margins of 20% to 25%. And when you compare the last quarter numbers versus the IPO framework in terms of margins
column5: you're pretty close
column6: and you're already within the framework
column7: 20% to 25% EBITDA margins. And gross margin and OpEx are pretty much more or less within the framework. How should we think about -- are you comfortable with this framework? How should we think about EBITDA margin expansion going forward over the next
column8: let's say
column9: two to five years? And then in light of that question
column10: also
column11: Steve Trundle
column12: the organic subscription growth rate
column13: if you exclude Icontrol
column14: has been -- has come down to around 20%
column15: maybe high teens. Is that sustainable? How should we think about the growth rate going forward in light of the multiple -- so like revenue leverage you guys have?

column1: Steve Valenzuela: Let me take the first part of your question. So the actual -- if you look at our guidance for the year
column2: if you look at the SaaS growth
column3: we're coming at about 20.4% growth on an organic basis
column4: 35% for the total. And if you factor in the adjusted EBITDA
column5: 20% that we've incurred in the past
column6: we actually said -- and if you look at the past at the IPO
column7: we gave a five-year range of 20% to 25% adjusted EBITDA. And we said that
column8: that was about two years ago at the time of IPO. So given the guidance we've given now for the year of 20%
column9: I think we're comfortable with that level given that there's still a lot of opportunity for growth. We're not ready to really raise that
column10: and we're comfortable with that 20% range for adjusted EBITDA.

column1: Steve Trundle: Yes. I guess I would just reiterate. I think the two are kind of linked
column2: which are the more comfortable you are with the growth opportunities in the market and sort of the megatrend towards IoT deployment
column3: then the more excited we're going to be about investing to take advantage of that trend line. And that would lead us naturally to not necessarily want to take the adjusted EBITDA margins up to the high end of that range. But that said
column4: I think we're comfortable with the range still
column5: and we'll see sort of how the world unfolds over the next four to five years. With regard to the growth rate
column6: yes
column7: I think we're about where we expect it to be. And we're obviously a much larger business than we were when we went public. But as we build off sort of a larger base
column8: we would expect to see the growth rate taper back from the 20%-plus range a bit
column9: but that's going to be a gradual process.

column1: Operator: And our next question comes from Bhavan Suri of William Blair. Your line is now open.

Bhavan Suri: Maybe my first question is for Steve T. I'll focus on the commercial opportunity a little bit. Just remind us sort of as you -- the go-to-market has been really efficient sort of for consumers
column2: and you've seen some great leverage there. We've talked about the commercial for a little while. What's the overlap between the dealers that sell to commercial businesses? And how is that progressing in terms of penetration? You sort of have pretty solid penetration within the dealers itself to consumers. I'm just trying to get the overlap of that channel and sort of what that penetration might look like as we start executing on that opportunity.

column1: Steve Trundle: Yes. That's a good question. We seen
column2: it varies. So out of 6
column3: 000 service providers that are going to be all over the map
column4: a handful are probably purely residential. But the majority
column5: especially when we get down into what we call the carriage trade component of the service provider base
column6: the majority are doing residential and commercial already. That mix can be as high as 50-50 in some cases. We also see a couple of our larger partners that we've talked about
column7: the Guardian or at Vector or an ADT also selling both commercial and residential. So the market is a little smaller than residential
column8: probably in terms of number of sites. The commercial markets in the U.S.
column9: more like 4 million as opposed to 22 million that we associate with monitor and security. But I think there's significant overlap. And therefore
column10: we think that as we begin to progressively deploy more and more of the commercial future set and go after a couple of the components that are needed for a full solution
column11: one of these being access control
column12: that we'll see pretty reasonable uptake. That will take time. The one challenge with commercial is most of the sites are already monitored and have some amount of existing equipment
column13: existing service that they're receiving. So you have to wait for a cycle of those sites who are going through an upgrade
column14: and we would hope to be in a place to
column15: with our service providers take some gains there.

column1: Bhavan Suri: Got it. That was really helpful. And then just turning to guidance
column2: Steve V.
column3: here. When you look at the hardware guidance
column4: it sort of implies that you're not
column5: despite of the comments about sort of solid growth in thermostat and stuff
column6: it doesn't feel like you're accepting any growth in hardware for the rest of the year. Maybe my math is slightly off
column7: but it feels like you're being just a tad sort of conservative on that. How should we think about sort of full year guide vis-à-vis sort of the outperformance that we saw in Q1?

column1: Steve Valenzuela: Yes. We did see hardware revenue in Q1
column2: up $24 million
column3: 26% year-over-year growth
column4: but we just want to be cautious here. Hardware is not a recurring item like SaaS and license revenue
column5: so we don't see any benefit of really putting a large number out there. So I think we're comfortable with the guidance we provided.

column1: Steve Trundle: So that's a good straightforward answer. I'll just add
column2: though
column3: that we do see -- one of our goals is always to drive as much cost out of the components as possible. So we want the customer to benefit from as many devices as they can
column4: and there's an economic equation there. So it's in our interest to try to shift down the cost structure of some of these elements such as video cameras
column5: doorbell cameras
column6: thermostats
column7: et cetera. I think what we're seeing in our work and our models is higher unit sales
column8: so unit sales turning up. But at the same time
column9: we're doing everything we can to drive down cost to the consumer
column10: and I think we're making some meaningful gains there. So you end up with sort of a flat line sort of top line
column11: but we get probably better impact and better customers
column12: which helps us with the SaaS line.

column1: Bhavan Suri: Great. So one quick follow-up
column2: and just because I'll push back a little bit. So obviously
column3: also really good SaaS outperformance in the quarter
column4: and it feels like you were also conservative on that line. And so a directive answer because that would be great
column5: just to help me understand how you guys are thinking about that because obviously that is recurring. And it feels like you did well in Q1
column6: but the flow through is maybe a little more muted than I might have thought.

column1: Steve Valenzuela: Well
column2: we did raise the guidance for the year
column3: right? So if you look at the. So we did raise the guidance. So we said for the year
column4: the range is now $231.7 million to $232.7 million. So we raised the right range
column5: and we also raised -- we also initiated guidance for Q2 of $57.8 million to $58 million. So those equate to very good growth numbers.

column1: Operator: Thank you. And our next question comes from Mike Koban of Raymond James. Your line is open.
Mike Koban: This is Mike Koban on for Tavis McCourt. Honestly
column2: a bunch of mine have already been answered. Just kind of some general stuff here. You guys have mentioned that the integration was going very smoothly
column3: and then everything seems to be on track. So I guess my first question is what do you -- if everything continues in an ideal world to go as smoothly as it did this quarter
column4: how long do you think this integration process will take?

column1: Steve Trundle: Yes. So this is Steve Trundle speaking. We've -- in the quarter
column2: we had about eight days to work on things
column3: and we've had about 1.5 months
column4: a little more than
column5: I guess
column6: about 1.5 months afterwards. And so far
column7: so good. We're -- we haven't -- I think one of the biggest things is when you do an acquisition like this and you're not able to sort of embed in the company until the day after the deal is completed
column8: one of the things that you're concerned about is what are your surprises going to be. What are the things that you weren't able to discover because you were somewhat -- I mean
column9: if you remember the challenges we have with the FTC
column10: we weren't really able to embed very deeply in any sort of normal diligence process. So
column11: so far
column12: we've been pleased that we haven't had any surprises. Integration is going smoothly. We're seeing opportunities to grab some synergies on R&D work
column13: so domains where the Connect team may have expertise that's particularly strong
column14: and domain is certainly where we know Alarm.com has strong demand expertise. So I think we'll let that continue to unfold throughout the year. I would bet that by the end of the year
column15: we'll have a pretty good picture of how the teams are working together. And we'll have very common set of shared objectives
column16: and we'll also have an understanding with the largest customers of Connect on exactly how they would like to move forward into '18 and '19. So that's roughly the way I look at it. And there will be a lot of activity. It's not as if we're waiting
column17: putting off
column18: procrastinating till the end of year or anything. There's a lot of activity sort of every day. But I would expect by end of year
column19: really we're talking about one entity at that point.

column1: Mike Koban: Great. And I guess just kind of on the -- while we're looking at these acquisitions. If I'm remembering correctly
column2: you completed the acquisition of ObjectVideo before the quarter was over. Did that have any contribution to
column3: in any financial material way
column4: this quarter?

column1: Steve Valenzuela: It did not have a contribution in a material way. It didn't have a slight contribution. I think the important point with ObjectVideo
column2: we acquired some great technology and some great people
column3: so that's really the focus there and some video analytics capability that -- with some great technology. So that was really the focus of the acquisition.

column1: Steve Trundle: It drove up -- to the extent there was impact
column2: it really wasn't on top line. It was on our R&D cost structure. So we obviously made some moves in the first quarter to expand R&D. ObjectVideo is a big component of that. And that's probably where we saw more impact than anywhere
column3: first quarter.

column1: Mike Koban: And then my last question is just on this hardware line item
column2: seeing that the gross margin clearly seems to bounce around a reasonable amount. And I know it's not as much of a strategic imperative for you guys
column3: but I believe you said as the video line and the video doorbell windows are higher proportion of revenue or a higher proportion of that line sales tends to affect the gross margin. So do you have any plan to try and sell hardware items within this that are higher gross margin? Or are you just kind of viewing that as a way to get people in the door
column4: into the ecosystem?

column1: Steve Trundle: No. Generally
column2: our strategy with hardware
column3: first
column4: is to defer to our hardware partners whenever we can and whenever we think that's a reasonable approach. But if it's hardware that we're producing
column5: then our goal is -- typically
column6: that's going to be a hardware that enables a -- that directly enables a service. So a video camera enables a video service. A cellular module enables an interactive home security experience. So in those cases
column7: we're generally going to lean towards running that -- those efforts at margins like what we've done in the past. And there'll be some volatility quarter-over-quarter
column8: just because the mix will shift to product
column9: new product comes out. And they have slightly different margin profile
column10: or people may buy more of one thing at one quarter versus another. But generally
column11: the range we've shown is probably where I think we'll keep that.

column1: Operator: Thank you. And our next question comes from David Gearhart of First Analysis. Your line is now open.
David Gearhart: I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about the international business
column2: if you can give an update there. I think on the last quarter call
column3: you're running at about 3
column4: 500 additions per month. Just wondered if we can get an update on what the current run rate is and what you're seeing in international.

column1: Steve Trundle: Yes. In terms of what we're seeing there
column2: we're not -- we're probably not going to update the run rate each quarter
column3: but we have continued to make progress. The pipeline is solid. We're in the process now of -- with Securitas of launching in Belgium
column4: the Netherlands
column5: Sweden
column6: Norway and Iceland. I think in a couple of those markets
column7: we still have to localize the app. I know in Iceland
column8: for example
column9: we need localization. Seeing more opportunities in other sort of markets
column10: so we've got active cycles now with an entity in Israel. And generally
column11: it looks to us -- I've seen a little bit more uptake in Latin America so far. So things are generally going as we expected. I think international is still a place where the business is less predictable than the North American market. We do hit issues occasionally that take us a quarter or two to work through
column12: particularly on the product side. But that gives you a little bit of color
column13: so things are moving. And generally
column14: by end of year
column15: we think we'll be ahead -- be about where we expected to be.

column1: David Gearhart: And then if we could shift back to ObjectVideo. Just wondering if you could shed any insight into some product ideas that you're thinking about or is it too early to expect any color there?

Steve Trundle: No. I think I can give a little bit because we showcased this or at least talked some of our thoughts at ISC West. So ObjectVideo has a track record in video analytics that's almost unmatched
column2: and we're trying to bring a lot of those capabilities to residential-grade
column3: low-cost cameras that traditionally haven't had much processing power. So it starts with fairly simple stuff
column4: like filtering out events that might trigger a motion to cliff when the event is meaningless to the user
column5: so we want to be able to train the system. And if something like a moving tree branch is generally a motion in a video clip
column6: we want to filter that out. We want to be able to do things like tell the direction that someone is moving
column7: whether coming in or out of a door. If they've left a package on the front step
column8: we want to be able to make that determination. So there's a whole slew of
column9: basically taking a device that's been relatively
column10: at least on the residential side
column11: been sort of short of an intelligent device and making it intelligent
column12: so that it becomes far more valued and useful to the consumer. And a lot of this also will be applicable to what we're trying to do on commercial. So those are a few things that we see going forward that the team is focused on.

column1: David Gearhart: Okay. And then last question for me. You talk about the 20 million-plus homes that have some sort of security system in place. Just wondering
column2: as you look at do-it-yourself
column3: monitor-it-yourself solutions
column4: do you see a path to using those kind of capabilities or solutions to attack more of the market that may not have professional installation or have somebody professionally monitor it? Do you see it as a potential additive to your business over the next few years?

column1: Steve Trundle: Our experience so far in that segment has been one where
column2: two parts to the answer. One is do we have the technology to enable that segment? I think the answer is probably yes. The second question is does it make rational economic sense to compete in that segment. And thus far
column3: our calculation has been no
column4: that we're better off focusing on our service providers. We think they're going after probably the more attractive part of the market. And therefore
column5: in the near term
column6: anyway
column7: next couple of years
column8: I think we'll remain focused on doing everything we can to make our service providers as successful as they can be and probably not getting into as much of the self-monitoring business
column9: unless one or two or more of our service providers sort of pull us in that direction and implement a business model that we think works for the long term.

column1: Operator: And our next question comes from Darren Aftahi of Roth. Your line is now open.
Darren Aftahi: Just 2 questions
column2: I think
column3: for Steve Trundle. One
column4: you always had good growth last year on video products. I you know you talked a lot about attach rates with thermostat. I'm just kind of curious if you're seeing any change in the demand for video products and whether people are looking for video doorbells versus a full-service kind of peripheral solution. And then your time at ISC
column5: any feedback in terms of any kind of hardware
column6: whether you're internally developing or OEM that may be missing on the platform that some of your service providers are looking for?

column1: Steve Trundle: Sure. So on doorbells
column2: just to make sure I understand that you're asking for sort of the mix of doorbell uptake versus regular video uptake?

column1: Darren Aftahi: Yes. Wondering if you're seeing any kind of general slowdown in that demand.
Steve Trundle: No. I mean
column2: doorbell seems to be probably gaining momentum. We're shipping this quarter a new instantiation of the doorbell that's called the Slim Line which is more rectangular and narrow
column3: so it fits more different types of door frames. It has a slightly lower price point in some cases. So I think we'll continue to see that item perform. It does pull through some video sales. And video
column4: once you have one camera and you're watching your front door
column5: it's not atypical for someone to say
column6: Look
column7: I can see that. I might also want to see my driveway or my backdoor. And likewise
column8: if someone gets video
column9: they often want doorbells. So there's quite a bit of overlap there. I would say the majority
column10: probably two thirds of the installations that get doorbell get a full video service
column11: and something less than one thirds choose doorbell only. So that's sort of the trend line we're seeing
column12: and I think we'll see that sort of continue to inch up
column13: particularly as we bring to market some more elegant video monitoring capabilities for the consumer. With regard to the device mix
column14: yes. We're always working on taking feedback from the dealers
column15: from the service providers on what they need for devices and trying to execute upon that. And we have a mix of cameras coming out throughout the year that are either more industrial grade in some cases; in another case
column16: some slightly lower cost. We've added audio to a number of the cameras
column17: so there are upgrade cycles on the video cameras and a couple new form factors that will show up as the year progresses.

column1: Operator: Thank you. And your next question comes from Jeff Kessler of Imperial Capital. Your line is open.
Jeffrey Kessler: You may -- I may have missed this part
column2: but have you been able to pair? As you move into small business and other non-resi businesses
column3: have you been able to start pairing things like EnergyHub or other ancillary apps that you've been producing with your moves into small business where they might be taking -- that might be taking a broader range of product?

column1: Steve Trundle: Right. To your question
column2: Jeff
column3: I think EnergyHub -- so EnergyHub is applicable to really any location. And if a small business is deployed with either our Smart Thermostat or one from a variety of our competitors even and they happen to be in one of the markets
column4: which is ever growing
column5: where there are programs for thermostats from the utility
column6: then we can enroll that device
column7: and we can generate some EnergyHub revenue and also some revenue for our service provider
column8: which is the cool thing about that program. With regard to some of the other technology
column9: I think what we're going to see is that some of the things we've built for the PointCentral business around unattended access and unattended delivery are going to make their way into our commercial offering for small businesses towards the end of the year
column10: so we'll get some probably pickup there. Beyond that
column11: no
column12: I think those are probably two good examples. And -- but energy definitely is a part of the -- is part of the equation with the small businesses. If you've got hundreds of facilities out there and you're trying to reduce the cost and we can tell a story that energy management will
column13: in some way
column14: shape or form
column15: begin to pay for your security services
column16: that's a pretty compelling message. So we do use that.

column1: Jeffrey Kessler: I noticed that when I was over in Europe that -- and I get it is a different business model. I get that at the beginning. That Verisure is running around with kind of standardized -- I'm not going to say suitcases
column2: but standardized presentations to homeowners. And I'm wondering if you're seeing a more standardized type of marketing approach by -- particularly by your midsize and smaller dealers who may have -- who may not have all the flexibility that your largest dealers have. Are they beginning to -- here's the line of products that we offer. Here are the apps that we offer. Here is the way Alarm.com fits into it to make that sale a little bit more easily understood by the end user and get you into that house a little more quickly?

column1: Steve Trundle: So we've seen progress on that
column2: but that still represents an opportunity for us. So by progress in prior quarters
column3: I've talked about Customer Connections and the adoption by our service providers have a lot of our marketing materials and everything from content for their websites to live blogs that are rebranded to
column4: in some cases
column5: lead services and then the CRM component
column6: which is Customer Connections
column7: to drive referrals and to drive upsell activity. So where we've been successful with that
column8: I think we're getting good results. We're not where I would absolutely like to be. And that in a perfect world
column9: all of our smaller midsize dealers would have migrated to more thematic marketing that's consistent with a lot of our messages. And that process is underway. It just takes a long period of time. And it's not something we are completely in control of. But I think we're seeing the trend in the right direction
column10: but it would be too early for me to say that we've seen and gotten to the point where folks are as consistent as we would like.

column1: Operator: Thank you. And our final question comes from the line of Nehal Chokshi of Maxim. Your line is now open.
Nehal Chokshi: Now that the Connect business of Icontrol has closed
column2: are you seeing any evidence of pricing pressure or pricing power from your dealer network?

column1: Steve Trundle: I would say we always see evidence of pricing pressure
column2: meaning our service providers are always working in a competitive market
column3: competing with large new entrants and others
column4: and whenever possible
column5: would like us to be as aggressive as we can in the way that we price our services. So that hasn't changed. It's been sort of a fact of life since we got started. So I haven't seen anything that's dramatically new there. In terms of pricing power
column6: no. Likewise
column7: I would say we haven't really seen any evidence that we have newfound pricing power. It's a big market with lots of folks sort of approaching the market with different business models
column8: everything from retail products that customers invest in
column9: installing themselves and expect free service for
column10: to cable bundling with lots of different offerings. So no
column11: I don't think we've
column12: we're seeing a market that's any less competitive than the one that existed before we completed the acquisition.

column1: Nehal Chokshi: Okay. And I do have a separate question. I want to follow up on Bhavan's assertion that the guidance is conservative. I did notice that the EBITDA
column2: at least for the March quarter
column3: was about $1 million. And I believe that the raise for the full year is about $0.5 million. So what I'm going to have to do with my model here is take the remainder
column4: remaining three quarters down by $0.5 million on the EBITDA. I think it's kind of a similar story on the SaaS as well
column5: though not as much. And just want to understand what's the dynamic there
column6: and why isn't this a forbearer of things are getting a little bit more tough as opposed to just being conservative?

column1: Steve Trundle: Well
column2: starting with the EBITDA component
column3: I think what Steve Valenzuela referenced in his component of the call was some expense shift from Q1
column4: Q2 that
column5: to Q2
column6: which is fairly material expense. We held our all-hands company meetings in the first month of the second quarter. We had all of the new employees
column7: the 121 new employees we talked about it
column8: at those meetings. So that entire event moved from
column9: moved into Q2. And therefore
column10: it's a little
column11: it's not
column12: we can't just sort of extrapolate Q1 EBIT performance and push that out in all the subsequent quarters
column13: just because there's been a little bit of a shift there. With regard to general degrees of conservatism
column14: I don't know if I can comment on us being more conservative or less conservative this quarter than prior quarters. We attempt to guide in a way that we think is consistent with our management plan
column15: and we hope to overachieve. I will say that we are going into our first full quarter now after the acquisition
column16: so we certainly want to make sure we understand all those dynamics
column17: and that's underway.

column1: Steve Valenzuela: Yes. We only have 24 days
column2: really
column3: in the first quarter with the acquisition of Connect and Piper
column4: so it makes sense to take that into account as we look at the guidance for the year.

column1: Nehal Chokshi: Thank you
column2: that’s very helpful. Thank you.

column1: Steve Trundle: So I believe that's our last call
column2: and I understand the conference call provider had some technical difficulties. So we will be posting the prepared remarks on our website or the Investors section of our website. Okay
column3: great. So with that
column4: I think we're done. So.

column1: Operator: Ladies and gentlemen
column2: thank you for participating in today's conference. We do apologize for any technical issues experienced on today's call. Thank you for your participation. You may all disconnect. Everyone

column1: Stephen Trundle: Thanks
column2: Jonathan
column3: and thanks to everyone for joining our call today. I am pleased to report that we continue to deliver solid results this quarter. Our SaaS and license revenue in the second quarter was $58.9 million. This is an increase of 40% from a year ago and includes the first full quarter contribution from our acquisition of Connect that we closed on March 8 of this year. Our non-GAAP adjusted EBITDA in the second quarter was $15.9 million
column4: up 31% over last year. Throughout the quarter
column5: our team continue to focus on delivering innovative solutions for our service providers and their customers. We expanded the Alarm.com platform with new connected devices that will facilitate the deployment of our services and help drive customer engagement and retention
column6: and we continue to integrate Connect and Piper into our operations. Let me begin by discussing some of the enhancements we made to our video product portfolio. Last year
column7: during our first quarter call
column8: I described our strategy for expanding our portfolio of video cameras
column9: such that we can engage a wider set of customers and continue to drive higher video attachment rates. Since that time
column10: we have made good progress on this plan. We successfully added a video doorbell suite that many of our service providers have rapidly integrated into their sales
column11: service and installation routines. We also expanded our portfolio of video cameras. This past quarter
column12: we introduced 2 new residential cameras: the Alarm.com 522 and 722 series indoor and outdoor cameras. These new indoor and outdoor models offer increased capabilities for a superior overall user experience. We improved both the image resolution and performance in high-contrast lighting environments. Importantly
column13: both cameras also have increased onboard computational power for processing advanced video analytics that we plan to deploy
column14: over time
column15: to both new and existing customers. We also introduced new commercial-grade video cameras during the quarter. The Alarm.com 725 and 825 cameras offer performance characteristics and price points aligned for smaller sized properties within our target market of small- to medium-sized businesses. These new cameras round out our existing portfolio and allow our service providers to engage a wider range of commercial customers with their video services. In addition to the new video cameras
column16: we also integrated a new commercial-grade security panel
column17: the 2GIG Vario and a new version of our system enhancement module
column18: which enables existing small- and medium-sized businesses that use the DSC PowerSeries control panel to work with Alarm.com. We believe that these and other investments we are making in our commercial offering will help us broaden our addressable market. And as the year continues to advance
column19: I expect that we will bring additional commercial capabilities to market. Next
column20: I want to spend a moment on the suite of back-end services and tools that we provide to our service providers to help them more effectively market
column21: install and support our solutions. We refer to these resources as our growth and productivity services. On last quarter's call
column22: I spoke about our deployment of business intelligence to help our service providers optimize their businesses to drive greater customer loyalty. Another key program is our CRM layer called Customer Connections. Last year
column23: during our Q1 call
column24: I introduced Customer Connections to you shortly after we had launched the program. In the year since
column25: we've added many additional pre-configured campaigns that our service providers can use to engage with their customers to generate up-sells
column26: generate referrals and drive further consumer engagement. Our service providers can now even use Customer Connections to campaign to their base of customers who do not have Alarm.com services. Today
column27: more than 1
column28: 400 of our service providers participate in our Customer Connections program
column29: and more than 900
column30: 000 of their customers are enrolled. I also want to update you on the progress we're making on the initiatives that we report in our Other segment. While these initiatives are still early-stage opportunities
column31: I'd like to highlight them occasionally as we believe they demonstrate the full reach of our platform. One of our subsidiary initiatives
column32: PointCentral
column33: offers an enterprise-grade property management and unattended access solution. Their market includes vacation rental properties
column34: residential REITs and businesses requiring unattended delivery solutions. One of their partners is a leading residential REIT with a portfolio of more than 30
column35: 000 properties. As this customer has begun to deploy PointCentral's unattended access solution to its properties
column36: they have seen a significant increase in the productivity of their leasing consultants. More than 60% of prospective residents now choose to sell show properties. Potential tenants can select a convenient time based on their own schedules without having to schedule with the leasing agent. An additional side benefit of the deployment has been reduced utility bills as they also deployed our energy management solution. Finally
column37: before I turn things over to Steve Valenzuela
column38: I also want to update you on our integration of the Connect and Piper business units
column39: which we acquired from Icontrol Networks in Q1. We have now had a few months to examine the businesses
column40: meet with customers and employees and learn their operations in more detail. We feel like we have a strong base of key team members in place
column41: and we've initiated several joint development projects with the Connect and Piper teams
column42: as we seek to add velocity and scale to our R&D operations. At the same time
column43: we are very focused on meeting the current and future needs of the key customers of these new units. To conclude
column44: we are pleased with our results and achievements in the second quarter. Our team continues to execute on our growth plans and our focus remains on providing innovative solutions to our service provider partners. With that
column45: I'll turn the call over to Steve Valenzuela
column46: who will review our second quarter 2017 financial results and provide updated guidance for 2017. Steve?

column1: Steve Valenzuela: Thank you
column2: Steve
column3: and good afternoon
column4: everyone. I will begin with a review of our second quarter 2017 financial results and then provide initial guidance for the third quarter and our raised outlook for full year 2017 before opening the call for questions. SaaS and license revenue for the second quarter grew 40% over the same quarter last year to $58.9 million. This includes the first full quarter revenue contribution from Connect
column5: which is in line with our expectations that we outlined when we closed the acquisition. Our SaaS and license revenue visibility remains high with a revenue renewal rate of 93% in the second quarter
column6: consistent with our revenue renewal rate last quarter and the same quarter last year. Hardware and other revenue in the second quarter was $27.1 million
column7: an increase of 21% year-over-year. This increase was largely driven by strong sales of our new video cameras and the new Slim Line Edition of our video doorbell that we introduced in the second quarter
column8: which outpaced our expectations. Total revenue for the second quarter increased 33% over the same quarter last year to $86 million. Gross margin for our SaaS and license revenue was 86% for the second quarter
column9: up about 250 basis points from the same quarter last year. This is mainly due to Connect
column10: which has a higher gross margin percentage than Alarm.com as we have previously discussed. Hardware and other gross margin was 21% for the second quarter. This is up about 100 basis points from Q2 2016 and down about 140 basis points sequentially due to a combination of product mix and costs related to the introduction of our new video and doorbell products. Total gross margin was 65% for the second quarter
column11: up about 100 basis points sequentially from the first quarter and up about 400 basis points from the same quarter last year. The higher gross margin in the second quarter is due to a combination of higher SaaS and license gross margin and a higher mix of SaaS and license revenue accounting for 68.5% of total revenue for the second quarter compared to 65% in the same quarter last year. Turning to operating expenses. R&D expense in the second quarter was $20.1 million compared to $10.8 million in the second quarter of 2016. We ended the second quarter with 457 employees in R&D
column12: up from 290 employees a year ago. Sales and marketing expenses in the second quarter were $11.9 million or 14% of revenue compared to $9.9 million or 15% of revenue last year. G&A expenses in the second quarter were $13.5 million
column13: down from $14.2 million in the year-ago quarter. G&A expense includes non-ordinary course litigation expense of $1.3 million in the second quarter compared to $4.7 million in Q2 2016. Non-ordinary course litigation expenses are part of our adjusted measures and are excluded from non-GAAP adjusted EBITDA. Non-GAAP adjusted EBITDA increased to $15.9 million in the second quarter
column14: up 31% from $12.1 million in the same quarter last year. In the second quarter
column15: GAAP net income was $9.9 million and non-GAAP adjusted net income was $16 million. Our tax provision in the second quarter was a favorable benefit to net income in the amount of $4.5 million. This tax benefit is a result of the combination of additional R&D tax credits and a favorable impact from the new accounting standard for employee share-based payments from employee stock exercises in the quarter. We are required to recognize the tax windfall benefits in the quarter employees exercised stock options under the new accounting standard
column16: and this will cause our effective tax rate to vary from quarter-to-quarter. Turning to our balance sheet. We ended the second quarter with $68.9 million of cash and cash equivalents. In the second quarter
column17: we generated approximately $11.8 million in cash flow from operations and $8.7 million of free cash flow. Turning to our financial outlook. We are providing initial guidance for SaaS and license revenue for the third quarter of 2017 of $60.6 million to $60.8 million. For the full year of 2017
column18: we are raising our guidance for SaaS and license revenue to be between $233.3 million to $233.8 million. This compares to our prior outlook for SaaS and license revenue of $231.7 million to $232.7 million. We are also raising our guidance for total revenue for 2017 to $326.3 million to $327.8 million
column19: up from our prior guidance of $322.7 million to $325.7 million. This includes our raised guidance for hardware and other revenue of $93 million to $94 million. We are also increasing our expectations for non-GAAP adjusted EBITDA for 2017 to be between $66.5 million to $67.3 million
column20: up from a prior range of $65.5 million to $66.5 million. We are also raising our guidance for non-GAAP adjusted net income for 2017 to $47.5 million to $48.3 million or $0.96 to $0.98 per diluted share. This is based on an estimate of 49.4 million weighted average diluted shares outstanding. We expect full year 2017 stock-based compensation expense of $7 million to $7.5 million. In summary
column21: we are pleased with our results for the first half of 2017. We are focused on executing on our business strategy and investing in our growth opportunities while continuing to deliver solid financial results. With that
column22: operator
column23: please open the call for Q&A.

column7: more like 1 out of 5 at this point up from
column8: I think

column12: we haven't seen a lot of that. The cameras are designed to work for a long period of time. So if they're working as designed

column1: Nikolay Beliov: And my second question is around the growth margin framework with EBITDA within the long-term framework you guys provided in the past. How do you think about the trade-off? What are the puts and takes at this point?
Stephen Trundle: Well

column2: which is
column3: yes
column4: higher attach on video is good for business. In addition to - the more value we're providing to the consumer at the end of the day

So we try to sort of juggle those 2 requirements of shifting up ARPU versus keeping our service providers competitive. But you can think about it as opening up another window of opportunity for us to broaden the footprint of the application. There are things you can do with video data that we couldn't do solely with sensor data
column8: so we like the deployment on that front. And it definitely kind of gives us a positive contributor to helping us maintain or

column10: slightly increase ARPU.

column5: can you look back and maybe expand your TAM from the 23 million households that traditionally bought security services

column1: Stephen Trundle: Yes. So those are 2 distinct questions. I particularly like the second one. But with the first one related to Comcast specifically
column2: Comcast continues to be a solid competitor in the market. In the areas they service
column3: they compete with our service providers aggressively. They are good marketers and they have a base of subscribers to market to. So I think in their last quarterly call
column4: they portrayed that they continue to make progress in the home security and automation market. And we definitely continue to see them as a competitor to our service providers and therefore
column5: a competitor to us. We're not seeing them as much really in what I would characterize as more as a wholesale or B2B market yet. I think they're focused on that application as a lever in their business. And to some degree
column6: a little bit more in the cable industry than on the market we service - the capability needs that we service
column7: or the capability needs of the type of service provider we do business with are quite a bit different than the capability needs of a typical MSO. So that's what we see there. With regards to the second question
column8: it's a question that I don't think - and I'll rephrase the question which is
column9: with the competition we're seeing from new entrants and others that are bringing IP video solutions directly to the consumer typically for self-install
column10: are we seeing that more as competition or more as a gateway to a bigger TAM? And I don't think we actually know the answer to that question. I think we can be optimistic that people who have become acclimated to observing their property remotely will
column11: at some point
column12: want the highest quality solution they can put their hands on. And I think the highest quality solution will come from an Alarm.com service provider. So in that regard
column13: you could argue that what we currently characterize as competition
column14: something like a camera coming from a company that may sell it through retail is
column15: in fact
column16: TAM expanding. But I think it's too early for us to say that definitively. It would be an optimistic case
column17: but not something we can state as actually being certain at this point.

column1: Operator: And our next question comes from the line of Jeff Kessler with Imperial Capital.

column3: et cetera
column4: et cetera. What are you doing to move along with your clients as these types of metrics are becoming more important in the way they are going to be judged in their business. You're going to be on the spot

column6: to help them make those numbers look better. And you
column7: obviously
column8: are involved in doing that because they depend on you.

column1: Stephen Trundle: Yes. Excellent question
column2: and it really gets to the gist of why you need a solid platform to provide reasonable service to the service providers. If they're attempting to optimize on Pre-SAC EBITDA

column6: trying to give them a much more transparency into the levels of engagement with the customer base. And from that
column7: the customer's propensity to pay

column10: hey

column18: a little over a year ago. Have seen nice uptake there. That gives us a tool whereby we can actually
column19: on behalf of the service provider

column25: a lot of it gets to how efficiently can they actually service their customers. So how efficiently when a call comes in at 8 p.m. at night with someone that has a control panel that's beeping
column26: can they handle that? Do they need to escalate it? Roll a truck? Or can you log into a mobile app from your home if you're a service provider and make a configuration change to the control panel such that
column27: that issue goes away. One is far more efficient. One approach than the other
column28: and one approach yields a happier customer than the other. And luckily
column29: we
column30: from day 1
column31: have focused pretty heavily on how we would service the customer ourselves if we were in the shoes of our service provider. And we expose those capabilities directly to our service providers through something we call our FX and through an application we call Mobile Tech
column32: but we also expose it through a set of API. So going forward
column33: as we deal with larger and larger customers
column34: taking more of that functionality and exposing it through interfaces that their staff can directly operate against using whatever internal application they may use interface to their customers is a big part of our focus? And I think that also will help them with the Pre-SAC EBITDA metric. So that's a little bit of color on that
column35: Jeff
column36: but if there's something else

column1: Jeffrey Kessler: Sure. I can get you later on other things. Another
column2: I think you call it buzzword
column3: but another thing that is now being discussed in the industry going way past just your - going with just your clients is a notion of a
column4: we'll call it a curated home automation system
column5: one that essentially is much more integrated
column6: one in which is built upon one app working well with the next app
column7: working well with the next app. And I'm wondering what you're doing in that regard to provide your clients with a much more
column8: let's call
column9: a - but we'll call it a ""curated system.""

column1: Stephen Trundle: Right. No
column2: and that's always - on that front
column3: we're sort of trying to do what we've always done
column4: but do it better. We've always had the view that what we put out is a curated home automation ecosystem
column5: whereby each product that we integrate with works with the other products that we also support seamlessly through a single app. So we're not huge fans of making the user switch from app to app. Use this app if you want to open your garage door. Use this app if you want to control your security system. And there's multiple reasons for that. But one is that each time you force them into different application environment
column6: the customer needs to redundantly replicate all their contact information their alerts don't work together. If my garage door is on a different app
column7: then my security system
column8: it's hard to make the garage door closed. When I arm the security system
column9: things of that nature. So we do view that it - has a view that it should all work together and because of that
column10: we're forced to be selective on the hardware that we add to the ecosystem to sort of maintain that state. As we go forward
column11: I think that there's always an opportunity to do that better. So that sounds relatively easy to provide that curated ecosystem
column12: but the consumer is demanding more and more devices and control of more and more things. So there's kind of constant pressure to add to the ecosystem. And every time you add
column13: you're sort of exponentially increasing the test load of making sure that all of this can work together
column14: and that's why you're seeing us continue to invest in R&D
column15: so that we're at a fairly solid pace. So that we can make sure we're able to bring that to consumer. But that's a level of differentiation that we hope that we can fulfill and that we can enable our service providers to message with confidence.

column1: Jeffrey Kessler: Okay. If you've been involved with - you've been involved with Verizon on their G4 LTE program for now sometime. What type of traction are you getting with any of your customers to have them get up to a G4 level
column2: and in doing so
column3: increase the encryption and the
column4: what I call
column5: the hardness of their security
column6: so that the buzzword of security hacking home systems gets a little bit harder to do when you get into a higher-end system - higher-end communications protocol like this.

column1: Stephen Trundle: Right. So the adoption of LTE is - has been pretty fast of late. A lot of service providers
column2: some of the larger ones
column3: have almost mandated that all installations be 4G. And they're doing that - at the moment
column4: I would say less for the encryption benefit and more for the life of account benefits. With 4G
column5: obviously
column6: the half-life of that offering is essentially longer
column7: gets us out at least a decade
column8: probably essentially longer. So we're seeing a shift there. It's a place where we led the market. I think even today
column9: some of our competitors are not out with a solid LTE offering. So we've been pushing it and it's being adopted. With regard to hardening the security system itself
column10: most of the capabilities that we enable through LTE are capabilities that we
column11: in some form
column12: have historically enabled as well So I think the wireless connection has always been a fairly robust and hard connection. I think a lot of the things you may see in the press are related to the RF
column13: between the sensor and the control panel
column14: where we've seen evidence of playback attacks
column15: of breaking into an encrypted sensor communications. And most of that effort or onuses not necessarily on our shoulders
column16: but is instead on the shoulders of our control panel partners. And I think the service providers are gradually demanding that the sensors and peripherals that they deploy speak with a RF that
column17: that is hardened so that they don't have sort of the PR risk of an attack that could come if that's not all encrypted. So that's kind of what we're seeing. That drives us to support more panels
column18: more receivers. But the wireless piece between the control panel and ourselves has always been pretty hard.

column8: early traction. You take a couple steps forward and you learn about a capability that's necessary to really get the offering down in for the channel. So we take a step back and we reengineered it to drive that capability. Here

So continuing to work on it. No big updates this quarter.

column36: while also maintaining an environment
