column51: we have not identified changes at this time
column52: that we believe
column53: would result in a material impact to our revenue recognition policies for the Alarm.com segment. However
column54: this is still under review. We are also in the process of reviewing our customer contracts for our subsidiary
column55: that we report in our other segment
column56: and assessing if there are any accounting changes for their revenue under 606. Also under 606
column57: we are required to evaluate our commissions expense
column58: and capitalize commissions whose benefit can be attributed to a term that is longer than one year. We currently expense commissions as incurred. We have begun to evaluate our commission agreements
column59: and believe we will need to change the accounting for some of our commissions and amortize them over a term longer than one year. We will report final changes required for the new standard in our 10-K for 2017
column60: that we will file in the first quarter of 2018. Moving to our financial outlook; we expect Q4 SaaS and license revenue of $63.7 million to $63.9 million and we are increasing full year 2017 SaaS and license revenue to be between $234.8 million to $235 million. This compares to our prior outlook for SaaS and license revenue for 2017 of $233.3 million to $233.8 million. We are also raising our guidance for total revenue for 2017 to $332.8 million to $334 million
column61: up from our prior guidance of $326.3 million to $327.8 million. This includes our raised guidance for hardware and other revenue of $98 million to $99 million. We are also increasing our expectations for non-GAAP adjusted EBITDA for 2017 to be between $68.5 million to $69 million
column62: up from our prior range of $66.5 million to $67.3 million. We are also updating our guidance for non-GAAP net income for 2017
column63: to exclude the impact of the tax windfall benefits
column64: due to employee stock exercises. Excluding this tax benefit
column65: our updated guidance for non-GAAP adjusted net income for 2017 is $43.2 million to $43.7 million
column66: or $0.87 to $0.88 per diluted share
column67: and if the tax windfall was included
column68: then it would have added approximately $12.5 million to 2017's non-GAAP net income
column69: or $0.25 per diluted share. EPS is based on an estimate of 49.4 million weighted average diluted shares outstanding. We expect full year 2017 stock based compensation expense of $7 million to $7.5 million. Finally
column70: while it is too early to spend much time on 2018
column71: as we still have to execute on the rest of 2017 and report results for the full year
column72: I did want to provide a very early perspective on 2018. Putting aside any changes related to the adoption of ASC 606
column73: the new revenue accounting standard
column74: we are comfortable with total revenue of $375 million to $385 million for 2018
column75: in line with current consensus. We believe we are well positioned to build on our expanding market opportunity for the secured smart property
column76: in both residential and commercial sectors
column77: and we are thankful for a strong base of service provider partners. We will provide our initial guidance for 2018
column78: when we report our fourth quarter and 2017 financial results in the first quarter of 2018. In summary
column79: we are pleased with our performance in the third quarter
column80: and we are focused on executing on our business strategy
column81: and investing in our growth opportunities
column82: while continuing to deliver solid financial results. Before we open the call to questions
column83: we respectfully request that each person ask only one question per analyst
column84: so that we can accommodate all of our analysts in the time allotted for this call. Thank you for joining us on our call today. And with that operator
column85: please open the call for Q&A.

column1: Operator: [Operator Instructions]. And our first question comes from the line of Nikolay Beliov with Bank of America. Your line is open.
Nikolay Beliov: Hi. Thanks for taking my question. Thank you for the 2018 preliminary revenue guidance. How should we think about the margin profile for 2018 directionally
column2: and what are the puts and takes that you guys are considering
column3: before you provide the actual guidance?

column1: Steve Trundle: Hey Nikolay
column2: this is Steve Trundle. Yeah
column3: as you look to 2018
column4: or at least as we look at it
column5: I have said this before
column6: the margin profile is something we have quite a bit of control of. So it's really a business decision
column7: more than it is something
column8: where we are reacting to any particular sales activity. And currently
column9: I think what you are saying is a little bit of a drift. We have talked about a long term range in the 20% to 25% sort of bucket
column10: and we have been drifting up the pad
column11: and I would imagine that type of a trend may stay intact. But we will be looking for ways that we can invest to maintain the growth rate. So we are not going to pull too hard at this time on the margin lever.

column1: Steve Valenzuela: Yeah
column2: with the 2017 guidance
column3: we are coming at a 20.6% adjusted EBITDA
column4: and that's up from 19% in 2016. So you have seen us over the last three years
column5: every year
column6: the adjusted EBITDA has gone up. Not to say
column7: we continue at that rate. Just to be clear.

column1: Nikolay Beliov: Thank you.
Steve Trundle: Thank you
column2: Nikolay.

column1: Operator: Thank you. And our next question comes from the line of Michael Nemeroff with Credit Suisse. Your line is open.
Alex Hu: Hey guys
column2: this is Alex Hu on for Michael Nemeroff. Congrats on the really strong results and thanks for taking our question. Steve T.
column3: just curious
column4: as you look at your business over the next let's say
column5: 12 to 18 months. Among the initiatives you just commented on or have in place
column6: whether it be new products
column7: services international opportunity
column8: the commercial channel
column9: integration of Icontrol
column10: like what excites you the most? What do you think could potentially drive the largest near term upside and maintain the momentum we have seen since our IPO? And how is Alarm positioned to capitalize on that opportunity versus some of your peers? Thanks.

column1: Steve Trundle: Thanks Alex. Good question. I get excited about a lot of things
column2: but I would say
column3: my roots are in technology. So I get probably most excited about the pipeline right now that we have and the enthusiasm that our partners
column4: our service providers have expressed for that pipeline. So I alluded to some of this in my prepared comments
column5: things we are doing with -- to improve the -- really
column6: really improved video experience. Things we are doing to drive some new user experience is up
column7: and things we are doing to expand the growth opportunities that our service providers have in the small business category. So in each of those cases
column8: there is some interesting new development that we are investing in and we are excited about. At the same time
column9: some of the other things you alluded to
column10: the ongoing work that we and the Icontrol team are doing
column11: to support the base of customers that we inherited with that acquisition. Still has a lot of opportunity that I hope to be able to seize upon in the next 12 to 24 months. And then international is still an area where we are growing
column12: each month
column13: seeing some growth there
column14: and I say that and the business hasn't totally kicked in yet internationally yet either. As I have said in the past
column15: it's profitable on a P&L basis
column16: but as one of the major components of the growth
column17: it's not there yet. So I see some reason to sort of be excited and look forward to driving more activity there next year.

column1: Alex Hu: Great
column2: thank you.

column1: Operator: Thank you. And our next question comes from the line of Gabriela Borges with Goldman Sachs. Your line is open.
Gabriela Borges: Great
column2: good afternoon. Thanks for taking my question
column3: and congrats on the solid results. For Steve Trundle
column4: if you don't mind
column5: coming into the year
column6: we talked about on organic growth rate being in the upper teens
column7: and now with the initial look into 2016
column8: coming in right around the mid to high teens levels
column9: would love to get your thoughts on organic normalized growth rates in the core business in the U.S. Where do you feel we are
column10: with respect to the S-curve
column11: in terms of adoption on the home security
column12: smart security side? Is the S-curve even the right way to look at it
column13: or any high level thoughts to normalize growth from here would be helpful? Thank you.

column1: Steve Trundle: Yeah. So I think
column2: yeah you are pointing out [ph] sort of how we are looking at 2018 and in terms of where we are in the S-curve. I think
column3: obviously the company is bigger than it was last year. We have absorbed the material acquisition that we are growing off of at this point as well. As you get bigger
column4: you will see some temperance of the overall growth
column5: that you are growing off of a larger base. But if we look kind of at the overall market
column6: I think one way we had been asked about it in the past
column7: is sort of what inning are we in. And I think if we look at sort of the percentage of homeowners putting business aside for a moment
column8: if we just look sort of residential
column9: and extrapolate out where we are in terms of the adoption cycle
column10: I think it's reasonable to assume that
column11: at least when we talked about our service providers that all security subscribers will be smartphone subscribers at some point in the future
column12: and that's very much the trendline
column13: it's intact. There may be a handful
column14: who don't -- believe it or not
column15: don't use mobile devices
column16: and therefore are happy with the technology that has existed for the last 30 years. But for the most part
column17: at least what we are seeing as we talk to service providers
column18: everyone is adopting smartphone
column19: and yet
column20: if we look at Parks [ph] data and data from other sources
column21: we are probably only about one-third penetrated at the moment
column22: within that kind of narrowly defined TAM. So I would say
column23: we are probably third to fourth inning
column24: if we use that as sort of a basis
column25: and then once we fully penetrate sort of existing TAM
column26: if we assume no TAM expansion
column27: then we will see those -- we will reach sort of a steady state. But we also believe that the TAM will continue to grow
column28: and then of course
column29: we are doing some things around the edges to expand our addressable market as well
column30: and those are very early inning type of initiatives.

column1: Gabriela Borges: Absolutely. Thank you for the color.
Steve Trundle: Thank you.
Operator: Thank you. And our next question comes from the line of Matt Pfau with William Blair. Your line is open.
Matt Pfau: Hey guys
column2: thanks for taking my question. Just wanted to maybe get a better understanding in terms of -- Steve
column3: you talked about how you are seeing or at least your dealers are seeing the demand for more customized expanded smart home deployments. How has this impacted your ARPUs that you are receiving per customer
column4: if at all? And then I guess
column5: as you think about the business longer term
column6: should we expect to see an improvement in retention rates or any other sort of material financial changes from that trend? Thanks.

column1: Steve Trundle: Yeah. Good question Matt. Yeah
column2: definitely as we -- I think I alluded particularly to the very local dealers that are benefitting from a lot of larger
column3: sort of customized installations
column4: and certainly in our case
column5: when a customer adds video services to their solution
column6: that's a higher ARPU customer
column7: than a customer that is just taking sort of smart home without video. We don't try to push a lot of ARPU on what I would call traditional home automation types of capabilities. So someone that wants to be able to tie their lights to their security system
column8: that's not really an ARPU generator
column9: that's just a convenience feature
column10: that we think adds to customer stickiness. So on that front
column11: it's not a big ARPU driver. On the video piece it is. What we are seeing in general
column12: is yes
column13: it's helping us maintain ARPU probably very slight increase in ARPU. But I look at it more as a way to provide more value for the same price. The service providers are telling us they are in a very competitive market. The customer is looking to get value for their dollar. And we therefore
column14: in support of service providers
column15: look to provide more value for sort of the same relative costs
column16: and I would call the -- sort of the increase in services that we are seeing
column17: give this away to kind offset some discounting and other things that we do
column18: to try to make sure that the service provider still have high value offering in the marketplace. So that's kind of how those are working together
column19: I would say. Then some of the activity on the side
column20: with small business and otherwise
column21: also help us drive a little bit of ARPU growth.

column1: Matt Pfau: Got it. Thanks guys.
Operator: Thank you. And our next question comes from the line of John DiFucci with Jefferies. Your line is open.
Julian Serafini: Hi
column2: this is Julian Serafini on for John DiFucci. I had a question about something that Steve Trundle talked about a little bit earlier. You had talked about some of the small resource providers. And I guess I was wondering on your new customer acquisition; would you say that most of your new customers that are coming from these small resource providers instead of the bigger ones

column4: I guess
column5: struggling a little bit in terms of customer additions in the marketplace
column6: is that a fair assessment or like could you quantify
column7: I guess
column8: like where your customers are coming from?

column1: Steve Trundle: Hey Julian. It's a good follow-up. So yeah
column2: the larger service providers are still doing well
column3: and I didn't mean to discount sort of their effectiveness in the market
column4: if I did. But in terms of our mix
column5: I mean
column6: the way we look at it is
column7: the folks I was referring to today
column8: would be sort of about 40% of our new account production. These would be folks that are either highly local or regional
column9: and have been a source of strength. And then the larger players still represent about 60% of our new account production.

column1: Julian Serafini: Okay
column2: thank you. That was helpful.

column1: Operator: Thank you. And our next question comes from the line of Tavis McCourt with Raymond James. Your line is open.
Tavis McCourt: Hey guys. Thanks for taking my question. Steve V.
column2: I just had a couple of follow-ups for you on the accounting front. So if I look at the Q4 guide
column3: it looks like the non-GAAP tax rate you are using is something approaching a 100%
column4: if I am reading that right
column5: I guess
column6: a confirmation of that. And then what should we be using as a go forward GAAP and non-GAAP tax rate with the stock option tax changes? And then secondly
column7: thanks for the clarification on 606
column8: and I guess
column9: I just wanted to confirm that I heard it right. As of this time
column10: we don't expect a material change
column11: but you may end up capitalizing some commission expenses
column12: but I guess
column13: what you are saying is
column14: that's probably small enough not to qualify as being material. Is that the right way -- is that the message you are trying to get across?

column1: Steve Valenzuela: Hi Tavis. Good questions by the way. So on the tax rate
column2: I think last quarter
column3: we talked about this new accounting standard for an employee's share based payments and our companies are doing it in many different ways. We really decided that the best way to treat that on a non-GAAP basis
column4: was really to take it out of our tax rate. So if you look at our non-GAAP tax rate for the year
column5: we are projecting about 30% tax rate. For the GAAP tax rate
column6: because of this
column7: employee share based payments now having to go through the P&L
column8: versus how it used to grow through equity
column9: we are projecting a benefit of 39% to 40% benefit tax to GAAP. Now going forward
column10: I would caution that we usually like the model beyond the year at about a 35% tax rate. Now we know there is discussions about a new corporate tax rate
column11: and we can't predict that. But I would say
column12: to be safe
column13: both for GAAP and non-GAAP
column14: I would say to be in the 35% tax rate. So hopefully
column15: that addresses your questions on the tax. And I did want to make sure that to clarify
column16: again
column17: with the guidance for the year for non-GAAP
column18: it is different than what we did last quarter. If we were to include the non-GAAP in our guidance for the year
column19: our non-GAAP net income would have been $56 million and $1.12 per share. So just want to make sure
column20: people understand that. And so I think that covers your questions on the tax. Let me now go to 606; so there is only so many things that I can say at this point without discussing -- clearing [indiscernible]. But I will say that
column21: we have gone through our major service provider contracts on the Alarm.com segment
column22: and we did say that we do not see any material changes at this time. We obviously have to go through an audit. 606 is a huge
column23: huge new accounting standard that is causing a lot of companies to spend a lot of work on
column24: and we are spending a lot of time on it. The good news is
column25: we are accounting for our revenue for our service providers on a ratable basis
column26: and under the prior guidance which is 605
column27: the new guidance 606
column28: is pretty much the same revenue recognition. Now I will caution that to say
column29: we haven't got through the audit yet
column30: so I just want to be careful there. But that's where we believe we are right now. With regard to our other subsidiaries within our other segment
column31: that's less than 6% of our revenue. So we are still working through that
column32: whether or not there will be some change. That will still need to be determined. But again
column33: it's a smaller part of our revenue. The good news is
column34: the major portion of our revenue
column35: we believe
column36: will simply be accounted for under the same methodology we have been doing a lot. Now your last question was on commission; now commissions is one area we are still assessing
column37: but a lot of people don't realize that there is actually a large impact under the new revenue standard for commissions; because as part of 606
column38: you'd have to take your commission's expense
column39: and you'd have to figure out the portion that benefits more than one year
column40: and of course
column41: we incent ourselves in terms of adding new dealers as well as new subscribers. And so those typically -- a good portion of their commissions actually benefit more than a year. So there will be an impact from that. I would not say
column42: it will not be immaterial
column43: it would probably be a significant impact
column44: but will also have to also take back the commissions going back for the contract. So the net effect will be -- will need to determine
column45: there will be some commissions in the prior year
column46: as we move forward. Commissions in the current year
column48: that will be amortized over a longer period. So the net of all this
column49: is that
column50: there is no change to cash
column51: right? So where cash generation doesn't change
column52: yes our P&L will change a little bit
column53: but the important point is really
column54: from a cash point of view
column55: 606 doesn't impact cash.

column1: Tavis McCourt: Great. And so just to make sure I heard that
column2: on the tax rate for next year
column3: no reason to assume anything different on a non-GAAP basis at this point versus what we were assuming before
column4: which is kind of the mid-30s?

column1: Steve Valenzuela: That's right. I would just assume mid-30s. Now if there is new legislation
column2: we will be happy about that. But I would say to be safe right now
column3: just assume mid-30s.

column1: Tavis McCourt: Great. Thanks a lot.
Steve Valenzuela: Sure. Thanks Tavis.

Jeff Kessler: Thank you. Thank you for taking the question. You talked about some of the services at the edges
column2: which are beginning to impact the revenue of some of your
column3: well basically
column4: some of your smaller and mid-sized service providers

column6: that it ranges everywhere from the beginnings of Telehealth to on the -- if you want to call

Jeff Kessler: Hi Steve. Hi Steve.
Steve Trundle: So I was alluding to EnergyHub
column2: which you referenced. I think EnergyHub is kind of on a positive trajectory. So I don't know that it's a trajectory -- we obviously bit of a positive trajectory as well
column3: so it won't be a giant surprise to us
column4: if we keep having progress on some of these things and on the edges
column5: but we have that effort

column7: that's out now. And then we talked in the past about our PointCentral business

column9: as well as MDUs. They continue to make progress

column12: when we think about the smaller service providers. I think expanding the footprint of what we actually bring to market for them. So in particular in the past

column14: but how the number of service providers
column15: who service both sides of the markets
column16: we even have homeowners

column18: that's mostly new
column19: that's not a part of the business that we can model off a historic trajectory
column20: and I think will be contributing to what see next year in sort of the core business.

column1: Steve Trundle: Commercial as well has a -- there was a question about ARPU. Commercial typically has a 2X ARPU to residential. And while we are still early on commercial
column2: it's about 5% or 6% of our subscribers
column3: as we introduce more features
column4: we think there is opportunity there as well.

column1: Jeff Kessler: So at the moment
column2: 5% to 6% of subs are in that basket?

column1: Steve Trundle: Yes
column2: that's right.

column1: Jeff Kessler: Okay
column2: great. Thank you very much.

column1: Steve Trundle: Thanks Jeff.

Howard Smith: Yes
column2: thank you for taking my question. Good evening. I wanted to ask questions piling up a little bit on Building36 specifically
column3: and you mentioned the new thermostat
column4: our feature with the humidity and the like; and I am curious if that thermostat is in any way tied into Building36
column5: or if you keep those
column6: what you are doing for your traditional security network in Building36 completely separate? Maybe you could address how those might work together or not?

column1: Steve Trundle: No
column2: they do sort of work together. Howard
column3: it's a good question. It's that team that works with actually set of HVAC partners
column4: that designs the thermostat
column5: that designs and implements. For that matter
column6: the thermostat
column7: that works with Alarm.com. On the Alarm.com side of business
column8: we work with a lot of thermostats. So we are willing to work with others
column9: but we have the one that's designed
column10: particularly for service providers to be able to easily install and to work very well
column11: and that's one that is an Alarm.com thermostat really felt by the Building36 team. So a lot of the knowhow actually comes from that team
column12: and they gather that by working directly with the folks that are in the HVAC business. In terms of what the consumer experience is
column13: it is absolutely the case that a consumer that's benefitting from the Building36 service
column14: may at some point say
column15: hey
column16: I'd like to leverage the assets that exist in my home or business. For the purposes of energy management
column17: I'd like to have those assets actually work with my security apparatus. And at that point
column18: that customer would shift more than likely
column19: and go to one of our service providers
column20: and become their customer. But again
column21: using the thermostat that was already installed by the HVAC guys. So it's an effort we have underway to make sure that on some of the core devices like thermostat
column22: we are ceding the market with devices sort of early
column23: and the incarnation of the customer's life
column24: and then creating hopefully downstream opportunities for our service providers to come in and work with some devices that are already integrated in the Alarm.com ecosystem.

column1: Howard Smith: Great. Appreciate the color. Thank you.
Steve Trundle: Thank you
column2: Howard.

column1: Operator: Thank you. And our next question comes from the line of Nehal Chokshi with Maxim Group. Your line is open.
Nehal Chokshi: Yeah. Thank you. So I think you have talked about in the past
column2: that there is an opportunity to have ADT push future interactive security subscribers towards that core alarm platform versus the Icontrol platform
column3: so I am talking about the Pulse subscribers in this case? And that would result in an ARPU lift for Alarm
column4: and that the drivers for that decision is better lifetime
column5: at effectively the same cost for ADT
column6: but would represent lift for Alarm. So I have got two questions here
column7: so sorry for the length here; but first
column8: ADT appears to be successfully driving up customer satisfaction
column9: using the Protection1 brand
column10: load of customer service
column11: and thereby the lifetime value. So
column12: is the assertion of higher lifetime value somewhat diminished by this success? I'd like you to address that? And then the second thing is that
column13: given that ADT is focused on reducing costs and thus
column14: pushing alarm for new Pulse subscribers
column15: would likely require similar overall costs of what ADT does
column16: and what ADT pays
column17: when considering all-in. I'd like to understand
column18: how this transition
column19: if it does happen
column20: will be accretive from an operating profit per user to Alarm perspective?

column1: Steve Trundle: Hey
column2: Nehal. So this is Steve T speaking. I may have to break that one into a couple of parts. And obviously
column3: in the case of a specific customer
column4: I can't necessarily present their data. But I think I understand the two parts; first is
column5: your comment that you are seeing from other sources that
column6: customer satisfaction with a large customer of Icontrol
column7: which purchased ADT
column8: is actually on the increase already. And that would be a positive thing
column9: that would be attributable to their effectiveness in operating the business and focusing on customer service. And I think that's -- from what I have heard
column10: that is actually true. I don't think that undermines the likelihood that
column11: providing the customer an even more advanced solution in the future
column12: whether based on the -- what we call the Icontrol connect platform or the Alarm.com platform
column13: I don't -- in both cases
column14: I think
column15: to the extent that we improve the customer experience and deliver ever increasing reliability and capability to the customer
column16: I do believe and data suggests that the lifetime value of the customer will increase even further
column17: because they will use their system more and they will become more sticky. So I don't think whatever that customer may have done to improve customer service thus far
column18: is -- in any way
column19: conflicts with the possibility of driving further lifetime value in the future. I think the second part of your question was about the way that --

column1: Steve Valenzuela: The economics around -- I think that was -- you were asking your question about
column2: if the customer was going to move from Connect or add new subscribers from Connect on to Alarm.com
column3: what the costs would be. And we have talked in the past about this
column4: that with Connect
column5: the customer has to do with the hosting
column6: they have to pay the cellular fees. They have to pay their people
column7: they have all of the support as well. With Alarm.com
column8: our dealers have that provided for them by Alarm.com
column9: so we have talked about the cost difference. The ARPU is obviously higher for Alarm.com
column10: because of all the services that we are covering
column11: we are paying on behalf of the dealers. So I would venture to say
column12: and this is still to be determined
column13: but we feel pretty strong
column14: given the synergies that we have and a large base of subscribers
column15: with customers on Connect
column16: that would add new subscribers on Alarm.com
column17: they would not have to pay these costs that they are currently paying out of pocket for hosting for the data centers
column18: the servers
column19: the telecommunications charges
column20: their support people. So given the synergies
column21: I would venture to say
column22: and I would expect
column23: that the customer would realize some cost synergies and benefits
column24: as well as Alarm.com
column25: so it would be a win-win-win. Of course
column26: Alarm.com's ARPU would go up compared to what Connect customers are currently paying. But again
column27: those customers would have a benefit
column28: we believe
column29: given the synergies.

column1: Nehal Chokshi: Thank you.
Operator: Thank you. And our next question comes from the line of Darren Aftahi with Roth Capital Partners. Your line is open.

Dylan Heslin: Hi. This is Dylan on for Darren. Thanks for taking the questions and thanks for some of the colors on fiscal 2018 outlook. Just to sort of add on to that a little bit; could you may be talk about some of your top priorities for 2018 and where you will be investing a little bit? I know you mentioned the margins are ticking up a little bit
column2: they are not quite at that long term range. So just a little bit color on top priority in 2018? Thank you.

column1: Steve Trundle: This is Steve T. speaking. So I think

column4: that a lot of these sort of security in a shoebox type of offerings are generating

column2: Brinlea and welcome to everyone joining our call today. We are pleased to report that the fourth quarter exceeded our expectations
column3: closing out a solid 2017. Our SaaS and license revenue in the fourth quarter was $65.2 million
column4: increasing 39% over last year. Our adjusted EBITDA in the fourth quarter was $22.2 million
column5: increasing 55% over last year. During 2017
column6: we set an ambitious agenda for the company. We worked hard to strengthen our position as the leading engine of innovation for service providers in the smart security space. We also further positioned the company to capture new growth opportunities and expand our participation in other emerging business models enabled by the Internet of Things. I want to thank our service provider partners
column7: our ecosystem partners and our employees who all contributed to our progress in 2017. On today's call
column8: I want to review key developments from last year
column9: highlight some of our recent product announcements and discuss trends we’re seeing in the market. Over the course of 2017
column10: we delivered against a robust product roadmap. We introduced new technology to drive growth opportunities for our service provider partners. For example
column11: we enhanced our video service by delivering support for new indoor and outdoor cameras

This included expanding our ecosystem of commercial grade security panels and video cameras and introducing a new system enhancement module to facilitate upgrades from traditional systems to our interactive services. Collectively
column14: these new solutions enabled our service provider partners to further appeal to commercial customers. In 2017
column15: we also continued to pioneer increasingly intelligent and adaptive capabilities through our data analytics program. We launched Insights Engine
column16: which is a machine learning capability that automatically detects anomalous conditions and alert subscribers about unusual activity in their property. We introduced an enterprise grade business intelligent solution to help our service providers optimize their businesses and drive greater customer engagement and retention. And we established ObjectVideo Labs following our acquisition of ObjectVideo. This new team leads our research and development efforts in video analytics and computer vision technology. And lastly
column17: it is worth recalling that around this time last year
column18: we were just about to close the acquisition of the Connect and Piper business units. Today
column19: we have successfully integrated those businesses into our operations. The goals of the acquisition were to scale up our research and development operations
column20: while also increasing our distribution capacity. ADT is the largest customer of Connect
column21: and we are pleased to have been able to expand our partnership with AET as a result of this acquisition. As two of the largest players in the Internet of Things and smartphone market
column22: we are working together effectively on a number of opportunities that will allow us to create more value for the end customer while growing our businesses. To summarize our year
column23: we have masked our long term vision for the business along multiple strategic fronts. We now manage more than $80 million connected devices and sensors and provide service to more than 5.5 million properties around the world. Next
column24: I'd like to spend some time discussing new technologies that we recently introduced in the last few months
column25: as well as some emerging technology trends in the smart home space. I'll begin with a few of our recent product announcements. At CES this January
column26: we unveiled a mix of new hardware and software solutions for energy management. The new software capability is a solution we call HVAC Safeguards. It monitors the HVAC system and alerts service providers and home owners to trouble conditions before they escalate into more expensive
column27: damage or complete system failures. Typically
column28: consumers take a run until fail approach to maintaining their HVAC system. This increases the overall cost of ownership and failures tend to happen during time for the year when heating and cooling is needed most. By feeding our Insights Engine with data from the HVAC system
column29: the local home environment and the local weather conditions
column30: alarm.com can monitor performance over time and detect anomalous conditions that signal a problem. On the hardware side
column31: we announced the new premium version of the Alarm.com Smart Thermostat. As I have indicated in the past
column32: we selectively design and engineer devices where we believe we can strategically address gaps in the hardware ecosystem and provide differentiated value to both our service provider partners and their customers. We developed the new smart thermostat specifically to automate the installation process beyond any device on the market today. Our new thermostat will automatically detect HVAC wiring and dynamically configure the device to the specific systems that the technician is integrating. By reducing installation time and errors
column33: we can lower the overall support burden on our service providers and enhance the customer experience. As we invest in energy management technology
column34: we are well positioned to generate growth through multiple market opportunities. In our core residential business
column35: our service provider partners can bring a highly differentiated product to a growing market. In the commercial space
column36: energy savings is a key value proposition of our integrated solutions. And as consumers increasingly adopt smart thermostat
column37: our subsidiary EnergyHub can orchestrate more devices so that their utility customers can move effectively manage peak demand periods. EnergyHub is already benefiting from consumers increasingly adopting Smart Thermostat. In 2017
column38: customer enrollment and demand response programs managed by EnergyHub exceeded our targets. This contributed to our over performance in SaaS and license revenue in the fourth quarter. EnergyHub has also expanded its enterprise software solution and can now manage a broader range of connected devices and distributed energy resources. This led to a recent partnership with Rheem
column39: a leading manufacturer of heating
column40: cooling and water heating equipment. Integrating Rheem's intelligent water heaters will allow EnergyHub to deliver a richer set of grid services to their utility customers. As EnergyHub continues to expand its platform solution
column41: they can provide more value to their customers
column42: and tap into the growing adoption of a broad range of Internet of Things devices such as electrical vehicle charging infrastructure
column43: energy storage systems and smart inverters. I also want to discuss the emerging trend of audio devices and voice assistance in the smart home space. Two years ago
column44: we launched our integration of Amazon-Alexa. This past year
column45: we added Google Home
column46: Legrand and Sonos. Our strategy for integrating our services with audio interfaces is driven by our belief that consumers want to pick and choose their device based on their own needs and preferences. We therefore need to remain open in this domain. This is similar to the successful approach we have taken with developing apps for mobile platforms. Consumers have an array of voice assistance available
column47: Siri
column48: Alexa
column49: Google Assistant
column50: Cortana and Bixby. Our goal is to deliver a uniform
column51: seamless and secure experience across whatever interface the consumer may choose. Where voice and mobile interfaces defer is in our how our subscribers use them. Lighting control remains the most frequently used voice command with our service. It's interesting. The majority of these voice commands turn off the lights. Most of these commands happen late in the evening
column52: likely right before bed. For most smart home interactions
column53: subscribers who have integrated voice assistance
column54: still use mobile predominantly. For example
column55: when we analyze the representative cohort of users to see which interface they use on arm their security system
column56: we found that they use mobile app 94% of the time and voice assistance only 6% of the time. This makes sense because our users often interact with their property when they are away. So while we see convenient use cases for voices assistance and we will continue to create more of these interactions
column57: we believe that mobile will remain the dominant interface. Our users place significant importance on the ability to monitor and control their property from wherever they are. As we look to 2018

column66: residential REITs and other businesses requiring an unattended access and delivery solution. column2: Steve and good afternoon everyone. I will begin with a review of our fourth quarter and full year 2017 financial results and then provide guidance for 2018 before opening the call for questions. Starting with the fourth quarter
column3: Saas and license revenue grew 39% from Q4 2016 to $65.2 million. Our fourth quarter SaaS revenue included approximately $1.2 million in energy management incentives earned by our subsidiary EnergyHub accounted for in our others segments. We record the seasonal revenue in the fourth quarter each year based on energy savings reported by utility partners. For the full year of 2017
column4: SaaS and license revenue grew 36% from 2016 to $236.3 million. Our SaaS and license revenue visibility remains high with a revenue renewal rate of 93.5% in the fourth quarter
column5: consistent with our historical range of 92% to 94%. Hardware and other revenue in the fourth quarter increased to $23.6 million
column6: up from $22.9 million the same quarter last year. We continue to see strong growth of our video products in the fourth quarter. Total revenue for the fourth quarter increased 27% from the fourth quarter of 2016 to $88.8 million. Total revenue for 2017 reached $338.9 million
column7: up 30% from 2016. Gross margin for our SaaS and license revenue was 85.5% for the fourth quarter
column8: up about 350 basis points from the same quarter in 2016. Gross margin for hardware and other revenue was 21.9% for the fourth quarter. This is up about 150 basis points from Q4 2016 due to product mix. Total gross margin increased to 68.6% for the fourth quarter

column10: accounting for 73% of total revenue for the fourth quarter compared to 67% for the same quarter last year. Turning to operating expenses. R&D expense in the fourth quarter was $18.9 million or 21% of total revenue

G&A expenses in the fourth quarter were $13.6 million

column25: 000 compared to $3 million in the same quarter last year. Going forward

column1: Operator: Thank you [Operator Instructions]. And our first question comes from the line of Gabriela Borges with Goldman Sachs.
Dan Church: In the past
column2: you’ve talked about business intelligence tools helping dealers drive customer engagement and retention improve overall economics. Can you give us an update on the impact this is having? I understand
column3: it is still relatively early. What are you seeing in terms of its ability to drive expand within your install base?

column1: Steve Trundle: So we’ve invested through in business intelligence through time
column2: we’ll continue to do so. It's getting more and more powerful all the time what we can do. The current emphasis is actually helping our service providers use the BI tools to actually reduce their ongoing cost to serve. So been able to pick up very early when there is some installation having for example that's resulting in a disproportionate number of customers having an issue later with the particular product in the ecosystem
column3: getting that feedback back to the management team very quickly. So that they can adjust their processes get more technicians trained up on whatever that device might be. So that's the particular focus. We've also used the product
column4: it's really not just us using it
column5: our service providers are using it to identify what are the things. And I've talked about this a bit in the past
column6: what are the things that I as a service provider can do to drive higher engagement from my customers. And we've identified about $50 or $60 attributes that one might choose to pursue in the way they created customer management customer but then we've boil that down to the top five or six best practices that a service provider can follow when they initiate a new relationship with the customer. And if they follow those things with some of the legend
column7: they will get a higher engaged customer but then it trip at a lower level. So those are a couple of examples of how we’re using the business intelligence infrastructure for the benefit of the service providers. And then there is a lot of stuff going on and really inside the offering itself where we have a technology we call insights engine that I spoke a bit about just a moment ago
column8: but I'm going to leave that for later.

column1: Dan Church: And in terms -- so we've seen a few announcements from Amazon and other DIY vendors. Just can you speak to composition of the DIY market more broadly? Do you see that as potentially being cannibalistic longer term or the driving smart home adoption? Thanks.
Steve Trundle: No
column2: I mean we've seen these really -- we've seen announcements since the beginning of the time in the DIY market. We've seen new entrants like Google come in
column3: by Nest
column4: by DropCam
column5: Amazon by Blink. I think we just saw our announcements before I jumped on this call from Amazon. So I think the reality is that our customer prefers a do it for me solution. They want a relationship with a service provider that's going to maintain whatever apparatus is installed in their home. They want to make sure that the smoke detector that's installed upstairs in their child’s bedroom is installed the right way and is always going to work. And if it's not operational
column6: someone is going to be able to come out there and get is fixed. So we see a lot of these products emerge and generate some interest
column7: generate some cost. We think they primarily appeal to a constituency that’s not our core customer folks that are in a rental property or in a smaller property maybe having need for a point solution. I think our hope is that in many ways what the DIY products are doing is cultivating an interest and the type of solution that we can provide to them
column8: hopefully for the -- at some later point in time. So if I become condition to believe that it is possible for me to remotely monitor my property with a given camera solution. And now I move into a larger home and I want to have a lot of different subsystems all work together
column9: we think that's where our service provider comes in. And we're hoping that a broader group of consumers will be aware of the capability of those solutions like the one we offer. So I don’t think we've seen any real dramatic factory sort of predatory impact from the DIY. I'm sure they are getting their fair share of customers but haven't seen they dramatically affect our service providers.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from the line of Michael Nemeroff with Credit Suisse.
Chris Rochester: We heard from somebody in our network that ADT have the ability to upgrade Pulse customers under the Alarm platform over the air without a truck roll. Is that true? And if not
column2: could you maybe talk about the progress in getting ADT to move over to the Alarm platform?

column1: Steve Trundle: So on the first question
column2: I stay in close touch with my friends at ADT and I don't remember ever hearing that that's something they have actually been able to do. It's not likely that they would upgrade an existing Pulse customer. There may be some outlier I am not considering. But for the most part
column3: I can't think of a scenario where they would upgrade or have upgraded any existing Pulse customer over the year to Alarm.com without some type of services. And so I doubt that and I think that's probably just probably not the case. With regards to the overall relationship I referenced it a bit in my prepared comments. Relationships very healthy
column4: we’re working on a lot of things that I think will let ADT lead with as the year unfolds. And really I think more fully integrated VI control team at this point. They are very solid. The offering has been -- the existing Pulse offering I think has been well handled. It is more robust than it's ever been. And the two groups are working together really on a longer term set of initiatives now that we think will be good for both businesses.

column1: Chris Rochester: And then maybe a quick follow up for Steve
column2: if I may. Looking at the adjusted EBITDA guidance and the implied margin expansion is lower than we’ve seen over the past couple of years. I mean would we have seen a similar step up in operating expenses if it weren’t for the benefit in the tax code?

column1: Steve Trundle: So I think we’re showing about 40 basis point increase in 2018 guidance. If you look at 2017
column2: we came it at 21.2%
column3: which is -- 21.1%. So with the guidance we’re providing for '18
column4: we are taking that up a bit. But as Steve said on his call
column5: we’re really taking the opportunity to invest further in marketing and also in R&D. And so you’ll see that the obviously the non-GAAP net income is of course going up substantially over the consensus. So we’re letting some of that flow through the balance sheet. But in terms of EBTIDA where we invest in marketing where in the past if you look at 2017
column6: we said only 12% on marketing and sales and marketing
column7: which was historically very low. So we’re taking that up to 14% to 15% and we’re taking -- continue to make some investments in R&D. So we think that's right given all the opportunities in the marketplace.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from the line of John DiFucci with Jefferies.
John DiFucci: A quick question for Steve Trundle and for Steve Valenzuela. Steve
column2: just a question on the commercial and thanks for all the detail you went through and the opportunities going forward this year. Back at the Analyst Day
column3: you had talked about introducing new product called an access control product
column4: tailored to the commercial SMB market. Can you assure any progress on bringing this product to market and how you think could unfold going forward?

column1: Steve Trundle: We’re anxious to get that product fully generally available and announced properly. But as you saw at the Analyst Day
column2: we've made a lot of progress. The product is in
column3: what I would call
column4: full robust late data stage now where I believe over 100 of service providers are actually installing the product. We’re making sure you get all the details right. The reception has been very good. So we've been -- I've been particularly pleased I guess I would say with the part of the feedback that we're getting from the service providers and where their commentary on the quality of the product. So that's all good. And I think you will see us in the middle part of the year
column5: if not a little before
column6: announce that product formally and bring it to market.

column1: John DiFucci: And I guess as to Steve Venezuela
column2: that question that Steve Trundle talked about the benefits and what you might do with the extra cash from the lower tax rate. And I'm just curious if you could quantify that and some anyway when we look at across our coverage universe just given that your front at least today primarily in the U.S. and you are comfortably profitable and have been for very long time. We see you as one of the few in our coverage anyway that's see meaningful impact here?

column1: Steve Venezuela: If we look at in profitability that the company has delivered has been quite good again with 21.1% EBITDA in 2017. But what's interesting to look at again is the way that EBITDA
column2: we’re increasing the EBITDA growth over 2017 of 40 basis points. Again
column3: it's because of the investments we’re making really are more in the marketing area
column4: given that we’re coming off as a really low
column5: if you will
column6: year in marketing investments and then in R&D we’re continuing to make investments in R&D. If you look at in 2017
column7: which is the acquisition of Connect and ObjectVideo and those really help to set us up in terms of significant opportunities with regard to a video analytics with connect working with ADT. And so it's interesting to see the way the tax works out. EBITDA is obviously before tax. And so we're making those investments. As Steve said on his prepared remarks
column8: we're letting some of that flow to the balance sheet and also the P&L as we're taking that income up quite a bit compared to what we’ve seen in the past. So we're balancing both and we think the right thing to do is to make those investments. Given that we're really participating in a very large market opportunity with the smart home and the Internet of Things.

column1: John DiFucci: We come up though like we have double-digit growth in free cash flow just from the tax alone. But I guess we’ll see how it plays out. Thanks a lot guys. Nice job.
Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from the line of Nikolay Beliov with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
Nikolay Beliov: Just wanted to get an update on the international front from you guys
column2: exiting 2016 you were running 34
column3: 000 subscribers additions per month. What is that number currently and generally speaking in light of the opportunity in the domestic market
column4: how much of your priorities internationally at this point?

column1: Steve Trundle: How much of a priority is the international market going forward. So yes
column2: I think if you roll back to '16 I stated we had a goal of getting the 4
column3: 000 a month basically quadrupling production inside the year that year we were -- and then I think at the end of the year
column4: I updated that we were just shy of that number. We kept pushing in '17 and where I can say comfortably well north of that goal now. So the team is doing very well. And I think we’ve also turned the corner on some of the things that created latency in our ability to really expand globally. And most of those were product related. We have the right set of ecosystem components
column5: different certifications for each market
column6: we need to get different carriers set up. And sometimes it felt like you’re taking two steps forward and one back all of the time in various markets. But at this point as we indicated
column7: we feel very good about couple of the early markets
column8: which were Australia and Turkey. We’re adding some European markets in the first half of this year. Our partnership with Securitas remained strong. So it's taken a little longer for us to get everything up to speed and get them rolling out
column9: but that's going well. Lat-Am is doing well. So at the moment I guess I would say we’re enthusiastic about the year ahead and rest of world. We feel like this will almost certainly be our best year ever there. And in terms of relative priority
column10: because the pipeline looks good to us and because things are beginning to really move towards being even more of the contribution
column11: I think we think that it's pretty darn high priority for us. So it's a high priority for our technology team
column12: getting the right control panels in place is always a high priority. So I would say on a relative basis it's in probably the top three.

column1: Nikolay Beliov: And a question for the other Steve. Can you give us a sense
column2: if you can
column3: the breakdown of the 5.5 million subscribers between Alarm.com and maybe Steve if you could help us with the model?

column1: Steve Venezuela: In terms of the 5.5 million subscribers
column2: again most of those are residential. And I didn't hear the back part of your question. We have been increasing and seeing good growth rates at commercial
column3: but it's also the lower base. We talked about at the Analyst Day that we were going to be introducing more features for the commercial market
column4: including access control. The pilot on that is going very well. So we think that there will be good opportunity in commercial
column5: but it’s still I would say relatively early and is still small part of the 5.5 million subscribers
column6: and most of those by the way as well. Again
column7: I didn't hear the last part of the question. But if you are asking about the breakup between international and between domestic
column8: most of those are also domestic North America.

column1: Nikolay Beliov: Actually my question was if you split that up between ADT
column2: Pulse subscribers and Alarm.com subscribers?

column1: Steve Venezuela: So the last time ADT updated that number
column2: I believe it was about a year ago. And I had said
column3: I believe they said their subscriber base is over 2 million and we don’t feel that we should really be talking about ADTs numbers unless they publicly have produced that. So obviously
column4: they've grown over the last year and certainly part of the 5.5 million subscriber base of Alarm.com is connect and good portion of that is ADT.

column1: Operator: Thank you. And our next question comes from the line of Matt Pfau with William Blair.
Matt Pfau: I wanted to dig a bit more into the sales and marketing investments. And so I guess
column2: number one why was I guess less spent on in terms of percentage of revenue on sales and marketing in 2017 relative to prior years. And then as you think about the investments in 2018
column3: what are the main areas of where those incremental dollars are going. Because I guess theoretically now that you have relationships with many of the more significant dealers
column4: especially in North America that you can have relationships with
column5: they would seen that there was potentially be a decent amount of leverage in the sales and marketing line item?

column1: Steve Trundle: So looking at '17
column2: the question is why we take it down. The reason is that at the beginning of the year
column3: we were trying to complete a material acquisition. There is a lot of expense around that. We work positive or 100% of exactly what all of the integration expenses would be. And I think we felt like we needed to let the dust settle a little bit on that and see what steady state condition of the business would be afterwards in terms of cash flow production before we open this ticket fully on marketing. At the same time
column4: we took advantage of that opportunity to test. You are constantly running various marketing programs and sometimes you need the base line how they are doing by testing what happens if you do nothing. So how much Web site traffic are you getting if you’re not running that digital campaign and then when you lay your digital campaign on
column5: you can usually see what incremental contribution it make. So we were doing some of that in the back half of the year as well. We made a big move with adding our VP of Marketing towards the end of the year. And at this point
column6: we feel like we have pretty good visibility on the way the engines working in terms of cash production. And we’re therefore comfortable beginning layer back on some sales and marketing spend
column7: especially on the marketing side
column8: I would say. In terms of how we deploy
column9: we’re not going to get into some brand lower with in the market. I think we're going to look selectively as we tend to do as the audiences that we want to reach. We feel like we have pretty good data on what type of person becomes an Alarm.com customer. So you'll see us be more targeted probably more digital than big brand type of advertising. And then we do a lot with our service providers with the program
column10: we call NDF where we work with the service providers to help them with their local direct response marketing initiatives. And I think we’ll continue to do some of that probably at a higher scale in 2018.

column1: Steve Venezuela: And I think it’s important to put in perspective again the numbers -- again the guidance rate is taking up the adjusted EBITDA quite nicely up over 2017 by over $14 million -- $11 million in terms of the guidance and increasing the adjusted EBITDA percentage as well by 40 basis points. So that's -- I think there is many SaaS companies out there that would love to be have that level of profitability of 21.5% adjusted EBITDA and $82 million of adjusted EBITDA at the midpoint of the guidance. So I think those are very good numbers.

Matt Pfau: And then the other thing I wanted to ask about is in terms of the guidance and your expectations for the commercial business in 2018. I guess how -- is there a decent amount of success built into the guidance in terms of with the commercial business or should we think of commercial as more of potential upside to the guidance that you've provided?
Steve Trundle: So as consistent with the prior practice
column2: we're doing a certain amount in commercial today and there we with an interactive smart commercial solution but we don't have the full product in that we want to have in the market. And as I answered the question earlier from John
column3: I think I talked about a midyear entry point for the access product. So our practice is we don’t attempt to assign upside the things that are not yet really in the market. And we build our estimates and our model off of things that currently have traction that we feel we can have a reasonable chance of projecting. So that's how we look at it.

column1: Operator: Thank you. And our next question comes from the line of David Gearhart with First Analysis.

David Gearhart: My first question I wanted to ask about litigation expenses. Litigation expenses were down over $5 million in '17 versus '17. And I think some of that had to do with IP and exhibits and patents in review. Just wondering if we should expect a pick-up in litigation expenses in '18 if you could provide an update there?
Steve Trundle: So '17 there is some lows in the activity at various points and measures off the litigation expenses lower. I think what I would do
column2: we can't comment specifically on what we’re going to spend on there. We don’t actually even know often times. But I think that I would look to '16 as an indicator as a better base line for what you probably should be modeling for '18.

column1: David Gearhart: And then going back to guidance
column2: previously you provided a preliminary outlook for '18
column3: 375 to 385 and top line
column4: 380 at the midpoint
column5: new guidance is 381 at the midpoint so 1 million uptick there
column6: would have expected a little bit more just given the strong Q4 and you are investing more in the sales and marketing
column7: primarily the marketing side but would have expected a little bit more of a pickup. Can you talk a little bit about why we’re not getting as much of a pickup? Is it more related to the hardware issue that you talked about or the substitution of embedded modules for that part of the business and maybe quantify that impact to better gauge where revenue could have been? That's my question.

column1: Steve Trundle: Well first
column2: we did move it up a little bit. I think the -- it's early in the year. I think we also now put out a number
column3: gave you some guardrails around the hardware number. So I think you probably interpret from what we put out an improved revenue mix now with the updated guidance that is important to us in terms of the mix of SaaS and license versus hardware. On the hardware side
column4: we’ve never gotten overly concerned with hardware revenue. And what we’re seeing is more of our service providers adopting control panels where we’ve licensed the technology for the radio and it's embedded on the main board of the control panel. So that in terms of new installations those are using our radio versus that radio that we’ve manufactured versus using one that a third party manufacturer. As we look to '18
column5: we see that number moving from 41%
column6: 42% in '17 using radios that we made to a 33% type of level for '18. So you see some -- and that's not a great -- there's no spread. So that’s not really an upsetting dynamic
column7: but it's a trend that has unfolded I think particularly in the last couple of months we’ve seen a couple of guys shift their purchase habits so little bit there. And then beyond that I think I would just say it's early in the year.

column1: David Gearhart: And then lastly from me
column2: you provided some commentary in prior quarters on HVAC channel. I think you had mentioned previously you had 20 partners
column3: it's early days obviously. Just wondering if you could provide an update in terms of number of partners there and what you are seeing in terms of sales activity and also cross selling with HVAC and maybe even selling security and other offerings?

column1: Steve Trundle: So that effort -- don’t have the exact number of new signs there in front of me. But my guess is we’re probably up to 40 maybe even 50 at this point. That team has then super productive for us and was really the team that produced the thermostat that we just announced at CES. So we continue to see uptick of the Alarm.com thermostat across the business
column2: not just in Building36 but also in Alarm.com and elsewhere
column3: which is a positive. With the HVAC channel
column4: it’s still a channel that we are enthusiastic about. I would say wer’e still very
column5: very days. So of the things in our other segment that we talk about
column6: I think more mature are PointCentral and EnergyHub
column7: both at a predictable pace at this point with Building36 and the HVAC channel some of it’s still trying to get them the exact right product
column8: so working with that first set of partners
column9: but earlier in their formation and a little less predictable still at this point.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from the line of Jeff Kessler with Imperial Capital.

Jeff Kessler: And in the past you've been rightly proud of the imager that you've had out there if you want to call it the motion detector video imager that you put in as a means of reducing of supplemented verification
column2: increasing the customer experience at a recent long conference that we were at
column3: couple of your customers were talking about a new line coming out in the next several months. And I'm wondering if you could -- well not
column4: you probably not going to go into the details of the enhancement. Is this the type of thing that will further improved the ability to effectively justify the use of law and professional warrant companies as verification providers in the end or does this enhanced verification capability?

column1: Steve Trundle: So we refer to that product as the image sensor. It's something we pioneer the goal at the time of initially crafting the product was can we find a way to deliver a consumer a sensor that also takes pictures very
column2: very inexpensively and in a way that the pictures can actually been translated via a fairly low bandwidth cellular connection up to the central station. So that was the goal. We met that goal with the first in connection with products. There is a new -- and if you stop and think about it
column3: PIRs has been around forever and you actually saw why would I even want an infrared motion detector that doesn’t take pictures. If someone is in my home or business
column4: I would like to see who it is. And it’s incremental cost for that is fairly modest than that's possible. The product continues to work in a cell only format
column5: which is unique if you compare that there are lots of ways to get imageries and content out of a property base
column6: primarily with the broadband connection and video cameras. But image sensors are still well positioned for all of those properties where either the consumer doesn't want us to cater to the broadband connection or the service provider doesn't want to mess with it. So still a good product. We see it on -- installed on a healthy number of accounts. The new version is going to extend the battery life further
column7: improve the image quality
column8: give us an ability to increase to maybe even take short form videos with the lens. So lots of different things we’re doing there. And I think what you’re referring to is then back the integration that we get with the simplification is an area where it's impossible for sometimes. We just keep shifting away at the 1
column9: 000 different central stations that we’re actually connected to and get them up to a point that they can actually handle the content that we’re able to provide when there's an alarm condition in the property. So it's a constant effort that we’re engaged in. And if we get all the central up to a common base line of capabilities then I think that definitely helps with the positioning of our professional service providers.

column1: Jeff Kessler: A couple of things that you got involved in toward the beginning of the year that you mentioned
column2: but you didn't really go into very much
column3: stuff like the group of folks that you’ve got from ObjectVideo. They are obviously working on analytics and things like that. Could you delve a little bit more into not necessarily the primary stuff you probably won't talk about. But what is the goal of this team toward -- what end are they going to be used for again differentiating this company from its competition?

column1: Steve Trundle: So the first goal is to provide an outstanding consumer experience around our video offering. And to do that
column2: I think we need to cut down on the noises consumers getting the amount of -- I actually even tested other products. And the number of clips you get relative to the amount of valuable content you get that ratio should be fairly low right now
column3: it's generally very high. You get lots of clips and lots of noise for the one thing that you actually want to see. So with our video analytics team
column4: we’re attempting to discern what those things are that the consumers are interested in. We’re doing a lot of object classification work and a lot of trip wire work to make sure that when we deliver a clip and we’re even a period reporting to the consumer
column5: we can point to them
column6: point out the events that should be relevant
column7: it’s important. If we do that
column8: then the overall -- especially if they can do that with low cost cameras. So the other big challenge here some of this capability has been available traditionally in a very high cost format where we’re either running massive server infrastructure or you’re running a fairly expensive camera that is $300
column9: $400 camera. So we’re trying to make this possible with cameras that are going to fit a price point that our service providers tell us they can take into the residential markets successfully and that's really the goal there.

column1: Jeff Kessler: Most of my other questions were answered. However
column2: if you could just go into a little bit of any developments internationally
column3: I know you have again you’ve talked about it generally. But what are the things that you need to do to in addition to making EnergyHub a contributor? You’re focusing on geographic areas. Can you bring some of the new projects you’re working on to the international arena yet or is it still in the stage of just making sure that the cut that the service groups out there be they in Australia or in Sweden are just simply comfortable with you. And at what point are you with these guys?

column1: Steve Trundle: So we're definitely more at the early point where there is one-to-one play that we’ll have at some point where when we really feel good about with our service provider partner in a country like Australia we’ll bring in other products that we already perhaps didn’t find it here in North America. But for now there is so much interest in just smart home for doing that well that’s what the consumer want
column2: doing that with the equipment that they have. But that's very much still our focus with these early relationships and we're not getting distracted by bringing in EnergyHub or brining in the PointCentral offering. We've got enough up take with those here in North America at the moment. But if you roll the clock forward by six years and we get to the point that in rest of the world where similarly positioned as we are here today in North America
column3: then at that point it makes sense to take the businesses that we've crafted in the other segment and roll those rest of world as well. But at the moment
column4: we’re really more in beachhead mode where we're getting set up
column5: getting people productive
column6: getting them trained
column7: getting supply chain straightened out and trying to drive numbers on smart home.

column1: Operator: Thank you. And our next question comes from the line of Darren Aftahi with Roth Capital Partners.

Darren Aftahi: Just if any follow-up on the marketing spend. Can you handicap the incremental and the absolute where you plan to spend that? And I guess what I'm getting at is some of your smaller or relative install bases
column2: i. e. commercial or international like what are your plans to step up spending in those segments. And then if you do plan to spend more aggressively on marketing and international
column3: any geographies you call out? Thanks.

column1: Steve Trundle: The step up is a step up
column2: but it's not a dramatic step up from where we were. Of course ‘16 these we’re talking a few million dollars I think in discretionary spend increase. And the focus there is first some additional brand work in a very targeted way against some audience that we think would have a high proclivity to take services like those offered by Alarm.com. So we’ll be surgical there that will be brand work where we’re trying to drive interest in the technology so that we can then refer those who are interested back to our service providers or so that they've already heard about Alarm.com when the service provider shows up on the door step. Second is to do some additional local marketing with our service providers
column3: which is a little bit more of a direct response where we’re helping them to get a program stood up. It might be that we actually we generate the content they use I mean the TV ads or the radio spots then they go deploy that with their own phone numbers and their own brand
column4: some work there. And then third is we’re going to do a little bit more in industry marketing this year than we've done. We've got some new offerings that we've alluded to on the video side on the commercial side and on the access side. With each of those
column5: we have a duty to get the word out so you'll see us spend a bit more on industry marketing back out to our service providers and to new service providers. So that folks are aware of what we have in the product arsenal and those will be really the three places we focus
column6: not so much international. International remains an opportunity but probably won't be a heavy focus other than getting all of our collateral and our basic marketing infrastructure in place. I don't think we’ll go out and try to -- as an example dominate any given Latin American country with consumer market. And I think we’ll be helping our service providers in those markets get the right infrastructure in place so they can do their own marketing.

column1: Darren Aftahi: And then just as a follow-up
column2: I mean as we think about the cadence
column3: you’ve shown pretty nice operating leverage historically and you’ve investing in '18. There we look a little bit more intermediate term. Is that the cadence which we should expect from you guys or is this continued operating leverage is more of a one-time step up and truing up your marketing spend?

column1: Steve Trundle: I think we’ll assess each year as the year unfolds and see how we field out the market. But generally -- directionally I think what we’ve done this year or what we’re projecting this year is probably congruent with what we have at this moment and anticipate to be cadence where there's slightly more operating leverage being let out of the business
column2: but at the same time not -- that's coming from higher revenues and improved revenue mix. And we’re still pretty focused on taking advantage and being well positioned for the opportunity that we see unfolding over the next decade. So we definitely don't think we’re at the point yet where we want to fully pull the operating leverage lever in the business
column3: we’re looking longer term.

column1: Operator: Thank you. And our next question comes from the line of Mike Latimore with Northland Capital.
Mike Latimore: On the commercial side of things
column2: over the long term
column3: is there any inherent difference in mix
column4: hardware service versus what you’re seeing on the residential side?

column1: Steve Trundle: Difference in mix in terms of -- commercial does have some more hardware components to it. It also had a good SaaS component. I think we’ve talked about in the past that commercial actually has a higher ARPU because there tends to be more video
column2: it tends to be a little bit different configuration. So you tend to see ARPU on average twice as high as residential
column3: and sometimes three times as high. So there will be more hardware. I think as we -- as Steve talked about earlier in this call
column4: when we talked about the guidance for the year again we’re talking about what we know today. And so we’re looking at the year and figuring out exactly the timing of when commercial will be ramping up. And so typically with hardware as you’ve seen in the past
column5: we’re fairly cautious about the numbers we give out for that in advance in terms of the guidance. But certainly there is a good hardware component related to commercial.

column1: Mike Latimore: And then just last on the quarter just reported. After video
column2: what was the second and third additional device or sensor that was in demand in the quarter?

column1: Steve Trundle: So
column2: first is for what we call professional video
column3: second after that is locked
column4: door lock and I believe third would be probably thermostat followed closely by image sensor and then you get down into like garage door and so many other things.

column1: Operator: Thank you. And that concludes our conference call for today. We thank you for your participation and you may now disconnect. Everyone have a great day.";[0.0
52;ALRM;2018-05-05;"Operator: Good day
column2: ladies and gentlemen
column3: and welcome to the Alarm.com Q1 2018 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] And I would now like to introduce your host for today’s conference
column4: Mr. David Trone
column5: Vice President of Investor Relations.

column1: David Trone: Thank you. Good afternoon
column2: everyone
column3: and welcome to Alarm.com’s First Quarter 2018 Earnings Conference Call. As a reminder
column4: this call is being recorded. Joining us today from Alarm.com are Steve Trundle
column5: President and CEO; and Steve Valenzuela
column6: CFO. Before we begin

Reconciliations between GAAP and non-GAAP metrics for our reported results can be found in the financial statement tables of our earnings press release
