column25: and a telephone replay will also be available on our website. With these formalities out of the way
column26: I’d now like to turn the call over to Steve Trundle. You may begin.

column1: Steve Trundle: Thanks
column2: David
column3: and welcome to everyone joining our call today. We are pleased to report a strong start to 2018 as our first quarter results exceeded our expectations. Our SaaS and license revenue in the first quarter was $68 million
column4: up from $50 million in Q1 of 2017. Our adjusted EBITDA in the first quarter was $23 million
column5: up 63% over last year. In the first quarter
column6: our team continued to execute on initiatives to extend our position as the leading platform for the intelligently connected property. Starting with our commercial platform
column7: we announced Alarm.com for Business. This new integrated solution is unique in the market and will help our service providers expand their opportunities in the small and medium-sized business marketplace. We released Alarm.com for Business to our service providers for general availability in early April. As part of the offering
column8: we designed and implemented a comprehensive training and certification program for our partners
column9: which they must complete in order to distribute and install the offering. We expect that this new platform will give our service providers an opportunity to grow their addressable market by attacking the small and medium-sized business space. Key capabilities of Alarm.com for Business include proactive commercial-grade security
column10: video surveillance
column11: sophisticated user management
column12: multi-location awareness and intelligent operational reporting all delivered via a single integrated platform. In parallel and as part of our Alarm.com for Business solution
column13: we also introduced a series of enhanced video cameras. These include the commercial-grade 726 mini bullet and 826 dome video cameras as well as the 736 outdoor bullet and 836 turret cameras. Lastly
column14: we added a major new offering with the release of our new Smarter Access Control solution. Smarter Access Control is a complete access control solution designed specifically for small and medium-sized businesses. We developed this solution based on lots of feedback from our service providers. It is innovative in the way that it fully integrates with the Alarm.com cloud-based platform and works with our entire spectrum of services including video surveillance
column15: monitored security and energy management and automation services. The solution is also innovative in the way we designed the user management software. From a simple mobile interface
column16: subscribers can intuitively establish permissions for all access points of a business and for multiple employees. Permissions span both access control and intrusion detections systems
column17: and employees can be granted access to a facility with traditional access cards or directly with the Alarm.com mobile app. Facility managers and security personnel can review the video associated with access events
column18: receive door-specific alerts and create scheduled lock and unlock rules. During the first quarter
column19: we conducted a beta program that included over 150 businesses. We then publicly unveiled our Alarm.com for Business platform in April at the International Security Conference and Exposition known as ISC West. The reaction that we’ve seen thus far is encouraging. We believe that by integrating access control with video
column20: intrusion and energy management
column21: we and our service providers can provide a unique range of highly valued capabilities at a very competitive price point. At ISC West
column22: we also showcased our new line-up of devices for the residential ecosystem. This included new locks
column23: appliance switches
column24: audio system integrations with Sonos and Legrand
column25: our next-gen smart thermostat
column26: a new streamed video recorder for 24x7 video recording and a 180-degree field of view indoor Wi-Fi camera with push-to-talk capability. And of equal importance
column27: we demonstrated a wide variety of partner growth and productivity services and executed training programs on these services onsite
column28: all with a focus on strengthening our value proposition to our partners. As in prior years
column29: the highlight of the show
column30: for me
column31: was hearing how our service provides appreciate our strong support operation. Providing great partner support through both innovative technology and hands-on service is a key component of our strategy. We believe that we remain best-in-class in this area. This belief was further validated when ICMI
column32: a leading call center consulting firm
column33: named our partner service center as a finalist in the category of Best Strategic Value to the Organization. We know how important it is to support our service provides when they need help
column34: and we place a high level of emphasis on customer service. It is our belief that our commitment to this part of our business helps our service providers sell more
column35: helps them provide a better experience for the end customer and makes it more likely that they will remain our partner and continue to feature our products and services through time. I want to turn next to what we are seeing in the market. We continue to see our service providers performing well. Through the first four months of this year
column36: our service providers have collectively originated more new accounts than in the first four months of any prior year. This excludes contributions from Connect
column37: which Alarm.com did not own in prior years. The most successful service providers are those who focus on building a well-branded
column38: service-oriented relationship with the customer. They emphasize their ability to make it easy for a potential customer to purchase an integrated smart home system that has best-in-class dependable security at its core. I am frequently asked about the impact of new entrants on our market. It was 2014 when Google purchased Nest
column39: Apple launched HomeKit and Samsung purchased SmartThings
column40: so we have been watching the retail space carefully for over four years. Over these years
column41: we have seen many DIY products from both startups and large technology companies. Such products are typically positioned as cheaper alternatives to the products and services that our service providers offer. There are customers for these offerings as the market is very diverse
column42: but the customer for retail products is not often our customer. Our customers want a security system with smart home capabilities that is well-designed
column43: cleanly installed
column44: certain to work when needed and
column45: perhaps most importantly
column46: doesn’t create a new burden on their time. Our customer views their smart home system as a permanent investment in their home or business. They value the fact that a local servicing company will stand behind the installation. They value the fact that the system will serve its purpose regardless of whether their broadband connection is up
column47: their power is on or whether they are available to receive an emergency text message. Our customer also wants to be sure that the data from their home is used solely for the purposes of keeping them safe and in control. So if a potential customer wants to have a professional security system and wants to enjoy the best of today’s smart home capabilities
column48: then our service providers offer the best available option in the market. And this is why we believe we are seeing continued growth along with our service provider partners. We don’t dispute that there is also a market for cheaper
column49: typically retail DIY-oriented security alternatives as we ourselves dabbled in that market after acquiring the Piper product business. This market is very competitive and the customer tends to be less interested in a comprehensive security system or a relationship with a service provider. They also tend to be more price-sensitive and interested in solving a specific narrow monitoring or automation need. Because the lifetime value of these customer relationships is much lower
column50: if positive at all
column51: the retail market is generally not appealing for our service provider partners. Next
column52: I want to provide more specifics about our planned marketing investments
column53: as discussed last quarter. We are investing more heavily in marketing programs this year to support the new release of Alarm.com for Business and to continue to differentiate our technology and our service provider partners with consumers in our target segments. We will also continue to help our service providers with co-advertising campaigns. Most of these initiatives will get rolling in the second quarter and will continue through the rest of 2018. We do not view our 2018 marketing investments as a major new initiative
column54: but rather as a resumption of a steady marketing effort and well-established programs. In conclusion
column55: we are off to a solid start to 2018 and we’re looking forward to the year ahead. Along with our service provider partners
column56: we have a broad set of opportunities to execute against in both the residential and commercial markets. Before turning the call over to Steve Valenzuela

SaaS and license revenue in the first quarter grew 35% from the same quarter last year to $68 million. column7: 2017. I’d like to remind everyone that our Connect software offering has a slightly different deployment model than our Alarm.com platform. Both solutions generate monthly fees charged to service providers sold on a per-subscriber basis. For Connect

column9: network operations bandwidth and cellular services among other expenses they must incur. With Alarm.com

The higher hardware gross margin in the quarter was mainly due to mix as we were supply-constrained in the first quarter on a few products that carry lower gross margins. We expect hardware margins to moderate in the future consistent with our historical range of 20% to 22%. Total gross margin increased to 69% for the first quarter

Non-ordinary-course litigation expenses are part of our adjusted measures and are excluded from our measurement of our non-GAAP financial performance. Non-GAAP adjusted EBITDA increased to $23 million in the first quarter
column26: up 63% from $14.1 million in same quarter last year. In the first quarter

column2: on the success that you’re having with the marketing spend that you’re upticking this year
column3: how do you think about measure – well
column4: how do you think about measuring the success on the marketing campaigns that you’ve put in place for this year? And what are some of the key messages that you’re focused on communicating in that marketing to consumers?

column1: Steve Trundle: Yes. The measurement on marketing
column2: especially if you’re in a channel or in a business – we don’t sell directly to customers so when we do marketing we’re not attempting to drive a lot of direct response activity. We want our service providers to be more successful selling. So it’s therefore hard for us to really get great measurements on the efficacy of the spend. That said
column3: we do believe that – we have service providers all over the spectrum. Some are very small without any marketing budget. Others have meaningful marketing budgets and have really created a great brand in certain markets. So I think the things we hope to do are
column4: first
column5: we want to begin to get the word out on Alarm.com for Business. We feel like
column6: much as we educated the market three
column7: four
column8: five years ago on what a smart home system with security should do
column9: where we spent fairly heavily on that
column10: we want to educate the small business owner in particular on what a smart business security system should do. And we feel like that’s going to take a mix of various formats to get that message out. And that will make it easier for our service provider to walk into that small business and make the sale if the owner has seen the brand and has seen the differentiation that we’re trying to drive. So that would be the first goal. The second would be to be a little more supportive. At this point
column11: we don’t need to educate the residential consumer on what the IoT enables
column12: but we do need to probably
column13: in my opinion
column14: do a better job informing them of the various paths to purchase that they can take and make sure that they’re aware of the ability to kind of go with a low-risk
column15: kind of lower-effort deployment of their smart home system by contacting one of our service providers. So we likely will highlight some of the investments in time that one needs to make on a persistent basis to keep a system working
column16: probably highlight some of the deficiencies in some of the other alternative products that are out there and again
column17: give our – some of this is training the service provider personnel themselves. If you’re a salesperson at one of our dealers
column18: you feel better about what you’re selling and you’re better equipped with the talking points to make the sale if the technology provider
column19: which
column20: in this case
column21: is Alarm.com
column22: is messaging those same points and you’re hearing them on the radio or you’re seeing them online. So we want to make sure we get those points across and that we’re amplifying some of the messages of our service providers. Then the last is really just
column23: in certain markets at times
column24: we will support a service provider with a co-marketing campaign that is partially branded Alarm.com. And that’s been successful. Our service providers can implement direct sort of calls to action so those become more measurable. And when we see those sort of being good investments
column25: we’ll make them over and over. So those are the three real goals there.

column1: Gabriela Borges: Do you have a sense for what the average lag time is between marketing dollars going up and subscriber growth going up?

Steve Trundle: I really don’t. That’s – it’s not – I don’t know that we’ll necessarily see it in the near term. I think if we had a lever like that that was sort of easily discernible and we could see that an incremental $5 million in marketing generated
column2: six months hence
column3: an extra 25
column4: 000 subscribers or something like that
column5: then our job would be much easier and we’d be much more confident putting more investment on the marketing side. The reality of our business is things with the channel that we operate through
column6: it takes a while and it’s very hard to measure exactly the source of the incrementally positive results.

column1: Steve Valenzuela: Gabriela
column2: I would say if you look at our marketing spending. Sorry. If you look at our marketing spending
column3: typically the magic number is one and payback is 12 because the amount of marketing spending in a prior year is less than the actual incremental SaaS and license revenue we generate in the following year. So we typically have a very good payback period for marketing
column4: but it’s hard to tell exactly of what programs are driving those numbers
column5: but just give you an overall stat for marketing that we kind of look at.

column1: Gabriela Borges: I appreciate the color. Thank you very much.
Steve Valenzuela: Sure. Thank you.
Steve Trundle: Thanks.
Operator: Thank you. And our next question comes from the line of Matt Pfau with William Blair. Your line is now open
Matt Pfau: Hey guys
column2: thanks for taking my questions. First
column3: I was hoping if we could get an update on the international business and perhaps what geographies you’re seeing the most traction in. And then also you mentioned previously entering some new geographies this year
column4: so maybe just an update on how that’s progressing as well.

column1: Steve Trundle: Sure. Yes
column2: good question
column3: Matt. I didn’t touch upon that. But international has continued. I think I touched upon it a little bit after the fourth quarter that we were feeling better about the progress that our international team was making. We were beginning to see some of the what I had previously described as impedance in the system
column4: some of that impedance being resolved in terms of getting the right ecosystem of products
column5: the right actual hardware products and carriers integrated to support a wider number of markets and then to enable our service providers to have optimal installation experiences. So that’s going – continues to go pretty well. I believe
column6: at this point
column7: we’re in approximately 30 different geographies outside of North America. The dominant ones continue to be Latin America
column8: Australia
column9: New Zealand
column10: Turkey
column11: and then I think we’re seeing some uptick now in Western Europe. We’ve talked in the past on this call about one partner in particular
column12: which is Securitas
column13: and it’s taken some time to really begin to get the deployments underway there
column14: but I think they’re now underway in a few more markets. So we’re generally seeing a nice
column15: expected but nice – it’s nice when you have an expectation and it actually occurs – an expected result from our international team. And to give you one data point
column16: at this point
column17: we’re over 100
column18: 000 subscribers outside of North America.

column1: Matt Pfau: Got it. And then also wanted to hit on the commercial business. And so if you look at a lot of small businesses out there
column2: I mean my guess would be most of them have a security system installed due to requirements from their insurance policy
column3: most likely. So I guess when you think about your dealers going out there and targeting businesses and further penetrating smart systems into the commercial market
column4: is it driven more by new business formation or businesses opening up new locations and then needing a security system? Or how do you get existing businesses with security systems to switch over to a smart system?

column1: Steve Trundle: Right. So I think that the service providers will go to their existing base of subscribers. And it’s in the interest of our partner to try to drive higher value to their customer. And a couple of things now that are coming together that I believe
column2: and we believe
column3: can drive much higher value for a commercial customer are the combination of our access control offering and the video offering
column4: particularly when you note that those capabilities can be tightly integrated with the intrusion system whether it’s new or existing. So I suspect therefore that there will be a lot of upsells on the existing base of commercial customers. But beyond that
column5: it will be a mix. There are also new business formations
column6: folks that maybe didn’t think they needed an intrusion system
column7: but do need an access control system. So I think we’ll see kind of an overall mix. I think
column8: though
column9: that there is plenty of room in many existing small business accounts that may have an access – or
column10: I’m sorry – an intrusion system that’s sort of a relic of the 1990’s to go in and say
column11: ""Do you like what you have? Is it working for you? Does it add a lot of value to your business?"" and if the customer flinches on one of those questions
column12: be in a position to present a much higher value proposition that would actually help them more effectively operate their business. So I think that’s what we’ll be doing.

column1: Operator: Thank you. And our next question comes from the line of Jeff Kessler with Imperial Capital. Your line is now open.
Jeff Kessler: Thank you. And Thank you for taking my question. A question for Steve and one question for Steve Valenzuela. Getting back to commercial again. There is
column2: I think most of the non-security marketplace doesn’t understand how much – what percentage of penetration there already is with regard to commercial. And as you said
column3: it goes from 5% to 100%. Many
column4: many of you
column5: I think
column6: of your better and mid-sized clients already have a significant amount of commercial in there. And they’ve bought from
column7: in the past
column8: they’ve bought from companies who claim to have integrated product
column9: unified product. There’s a lot of words that go around it. It doesn’t always – these don’t always integrate. Sometimes they do. How are you going to go in there and get your value proposition across that it’s really easy
column10: it’s really – it’s easy to install
column11: easy to use? And up to what point can you push that value proposition?

column1: Steve Trundle: Right. It’s a good question
column2: Jeff. Yes
column3: I think it starts actually with something I commented on in my prepared comments
column4: which is what type of company are we in the way that we provide service to our service providers? Do they trust us? Are we the type of company they want to do business with? And my experience thus far and when I talk to the service providers is that the investments we are making in supporting our dealers are second to none. We really do try to work very hard on that. And that
column5: before you ever get to the product features
column6: often times that’s the most important thing. A person that’s out there trying to get an installation done or having a problem wants to know that a company they’re dealing with is going to treat it as a priority and get it resolved. So we’re lucky that we’ve built that reputation. It allows us to go to a service provider and start with that as the value proposition. Before we ever get to the features
column7: we can talk about how much they like using the dealer site
column8: how it makes their business better
column9: how all the reporting we do makes their business better. And then they say
column10: ""Well really
column11: if Alarm.com is comparable even on some of these other features
column12: all of the other value-add they’re doing for me justifies trying to put more in that basket."" That basket meaning the Alarm.com basket. And we start there and then
column13: of course
column14: we can get into some specific capabilities. And I think one of the things I highlighted in my comments is the ability
column15: for example
column16: to let a facility manager simultaneously manage codes on an intrusion panel and access to the facility all in sort of one integrated way is something that we’re not seeing too many other places. The ability to control a v-way block that may be appropriate for one facility in the context of the overall access control system is something we’re not seeing too many places. So we find those use cases. We get them to do at least one installation. And then hopefully
column17: and what we’ve seen thus far
column18: is that the installation is easy. That’s the most important thing. And they can envision it being easy for their consumers and we can begin to drive some replacements in that base.

column1: Jeff Kessler: Okay
column2: great. Steve Valenzuela
column3: you began to talk a little bit about the other businesses. You folks mentioned one that seemed to be doing well. Could you go through – I mean you have a number of
column4: quote-unquote
column5: other businesses
column6: some of which you talked a lot about last year
column7: some of which you haven’t talked about lately. If you could just update us on everything from second homes to hotels to power
column8: things like that.

column1: Steve Valenzuela: Hi
column2: Jeff. It’s Steve Valenzuela. Yes
column3: within our other segment we have PointCentral
column4: which provides unattended access for vacation rental property managers. And last quarter we actually announced a large REIT
column5: the expansion of a large REIT with Invitation Homes
column6: which we’re quite excited about. That will take some time to roll out. But PointCentral is doing quite well. Then we have EnergyHub
column7: which provides an energy management system
column8: demand response
column9: energy management for the utilities. And that’s actually had a good contribution in the fourth quarter from a seasonal energy savings that comes in the summer
column10: but we record it in the fourth quarter. And then
column11: Building 36 with HVAC is a smaller piece of the other segment
column12: but an opportunity we see given the opportunity to do some of the similar things we’ve done for security with HVAC. So we see good opportunities in all those other segments. Again
column13: those are still very small and less than 5% of our overall revenue
column14: but we are seeing a good growth
column15: as I mentioned earlier in our call.

column1: Jeff Kessler: Okay. One quick final question. For the providers
column2: the service providers
column3: their margin on installation for commercial industrial stuff
column4: as we call it
column5: is usually a real margin as opposed to an investment in a customer. Is there some type of financial model that you have to look at now when you talk to your service providers who may actually be making money on an installation?

column1: Steve Trundle: Yes. So that’s a good question. They do typically have lower creation cost on a commercial installation. In some cases
column2: I think what you’re alluding to is the actual integration of a bunch of disparate products can be a fairly profitable exercise so there may be some reluctance to take on a product that doesn’t drive that kind of less than necessary activity. But so far what we’ve seen
column3: and again it’s early days
column4: is when the – the service providers are busy. They don’t have much time. They’ve got – they’re constrained by the number of technicians they have. So generally speaking
column5: when the service provider sees a more efficient path to get to a recurring revenue stream
column6: even if that means perhaps he or she is able to do a little bit less integration work because it’s not necessary
column7: they still will generally favor the product that gets them most efficiently to the recurring revenue stream. So I think we’ll probably be okay there.

column1: Jeff Kessler: Okay
column2: great. Thank you very much in quarter.

column1: Steve Trundle: Thank you.
Operator: Thank you. And our next question comes from the line of David Gearhart with First Analysis. Your line is now open.
David Gearhart: Hi
column2: good afternoon. Thank you for taking my questions and congratulations on the strong quarter. So just on the last questions on the other business areas
column3: just wondering if you can give me an update on the HVAC channel. I think you had mentioned before that you’ve signed up 40 to 50 dealers in HVAC to push your offerings
column4: whether it’s Building 36 or energy management home automation. Just wondering if you could give us an update on the number of dealers and the traction you’re seeing there
column5: even though it’s small.

column1: Steve Trundle: Hi
column2: David. Yes. The number of dealers
column3: I don’t know if I have that data point in front of me. I probably can speak in generalities and just say that the team has been pretty busy with our next-gen smart thermostat
column4: which – the Building 36 team
column5: in addition to building their channel
column6: is also sort of an expert group on how to develop a thermostat that will work with all of these different HVAC systems
column7: which is then resold through the Alarm.com channel
column8: through the PointCentral channel and others. So they’ve been somewhat occupied with that effort. They have continued to build their channel. I would say
column9: though
column10: that we still don’t feel that we have completely hit the nail on the head in terms of the platform that we are making available for them to take out to the market. So while we’re working with an ever-growing number of service providers there on the HVAC side
column11: we’re not yet to the point where we really want to take a full swing
column12: if you will
column13: at that channel until we feel like we’ve got everything developed correctly. So you see some features that we’ve kind of alluded to. I think we talked
column14: at some point
column15: about HVAC safeguards as an example. Maybe that was at CES I believe we announced that capability. You can imagine that would be super valuable to that channel. And until you’re really putting it out there and you’re able to take sort of the first 50 to 100 service providers and get them successful with it
column16: you don’t want to necessarily pile on a ton more. So it’s still
column17: in that case
column18: with that business
column19: probably early days. And I would say that we’re still at a point where we’re intentionally constraining
column20: at some level
column21: the rate of growth of their dealer network until we feel like we’ve hit the nail on the head with the capability set.

column1: David Gearhart: And then sticking with the channels
column2: in the past
column3: I think you’ve mentioned that there are some additional channels that you could target
column4: whether it’s insurance. I think of smart entertainment or areas like that
column5: that could be an interesting channel
column6: whether it’s audio/visual dealers and what not. Just wondering if you can give us quick thoughts around alternative channels or just enough on your plate an opportunity that not really looking to add on anything at this point.

column1: Steve Trundle: Yes. I think we’re always open-mined about new kind of channel opportunities. We do apply a kind of an economic filter to each opportunity. So two that you’ve referenced; insurance
column2: we think there is tremendous value in the data that we are able to generate from a home. And we think that that data set can make not only the customer safer
column3: more aware of their property
column4: but also can allow the insurance company to be more precise in how they underwrite a property. So there we think there’s a ton of economic value that can be generated with various types of partnerships. And particularly outside of the U.S.
column5: our international team has been successful in cultivating and then closing a couple of partnerships that do exactly that. A/V and that sort of thing
column6: I think the A/V space is a little bit more crowded. It is almost purely an automation play. And I think we need to provide ample functionality to sort of allow the customer to control everything in their home. But I likely would not move to drive to really fully adopt that channel. We haven’t come up with a play that we think passes the economic filter to justify heavy investment in A/V
column7: as an example.

column1: Operator: Thank you. And our next question comes from the line of Adam Tindle with Raymond James. Your line is now open.
Adam Tindle: Okay
column2: thanks
column3: good afternoon. Steve
column4: you alluded to the retail lifetime value of a customer being low and maybe not even positive in that space. What is it for Alarm.com new subs? And can you maybe tie that into justifying increased spending or customer acquisition costs in light of that?

column1: Steve Valenzuela: Yes. This is Steve Valenzuela. We’ve looked at the LTV to CAC ratio. Typically over six for us. And the lifetime value of our subscribers tends to be quite long. Usually they will start with a 36-month or a 60-month contract and they will then tend to renew. We have a high renewal rate. So we actually believe that there is a good amount of average eight to 10-year life for a typical subscriber. Of course
column2: there is churn that does occur from time to time. But I think we’re pretty lucky that we have such a high revenue retention rate.

column1: Adam Tindle: Okay
column2: that’s helpful. And there was a question earlier regarding ADT. I just wanted to ask about that. Just to clarify
column3: they’re investing in a lot of the new commercial offering. Are they using Connect or Alarm.com for that? Can you help us with that? And if not Alarm.com
column4: why not
column5: with what would appear to be a new offering?

column1: Steve Trundle: Yes. So a couple different things there on that question
column2: Adam. In terms of what ADT is using
column3: as I think we’ve
column4: in the past
column5: said that there is use of both the traditional Alarm.com platform and the Connect platform. That continues to be the case. It varies a bit by
column6: at times
column7: even by their dealer. So that – and some of their dealers in some part of their business may use Alarm.com for commercial. Other parts are still primarily on the Connect platform. And Connect
column8: at the moment
column9: we have not implemented a commercial set of capabilities on the Connect
column10: but they’re more than likely using the residential plans
column11: which still offer quite a bit of capability for a small business on the Connect side. In terms of their direction
column12: we obviously would hope to have the opportunity to work with ADT if we can add value to their commercial strategy
column13: but I can’t say
column14: at this point
column15: that they’ve gone through any sort of RFP or otherwise
column16: and that we’ve won any incremental new business there that’s tied specifically to commercial.

column1: Operator: Thank you. And our next question comes from the line of Darren Aftahi with Roth Capital Partners. Your line is now open.
Dillon Heslin: This is Dillon on for Darren and thanks for taking my question. I wanted to touch really quickly on international and see if you – sort of what your outlook is there
column2: if you’ve made any progress. Or sort of a lot of the investment has been on commercial in rolling that out and then also the access control updates. And then also with sort of some of your video products
column3: you’ve had machine learning implemented
column4: and I was wondering if there’s also some new use cases there with machine learning across the whole platform.

column1: Steve Trundle: Sure. On the international side
column2: I had a question on that a little earlier and went into some detail on that. We are making progress. It continues to be growing. The geographies are expanding. So generally positive there
column3: feeling pretty positive on the – this quarter
column4: I think with the breadth of announcements we had at ISC West
column5: it made sense for us to focus a little bit more on what we’re doing. And each quarter we’ll focus on something different
column6: but this quarter the timing was right to spend some time on the commercial offering. With regard to machine learning and AI
column7: in a sense
column8: Alarm.com has long implemented at least some form of machine learning. We’re collecting a ton of data about a ton of different properties and then
column9: in some cases
column10: making predictions based upon that data set even before we get to video. Currently
column11: the focus
column12: though
column13: is very much on video analytics and convolutional neural network deployments on the edge in the devices. So that’s where most of the AI/machine learning type of investments are being made. And we’ve talked about the capacities of the team we acquired from ObjectVideo to work in that domain
column14: and they’re making good progress and we’re excited about some of the things that we hope to deploy later this year.

column1: Operator: Thank you. And our next question comes from the line of Mike Latimore with Northland Capital. Your line is now open.
Unidentified Analyst: This is Rushif [ph] for Mike Latimore. Thanks for taking my call. What percent of hardware sales included alarm radio in this quarter?
Steve Valenzuela: I’m sorry. The question was hardware sales in the quarter?
Steve Trundle: Hardware sales where the Alarm.com manufactured radio was included.
Steve Valenzuela: Oh
column2: I see. Okay. I got you. Okay. Yes
column3: we actually haven’t broken that out in the past. I think what you’re alluding to
column4: perhaps
column5: is we’ve talked about the modules. Some modules going forward will be embedded in some control panels. We didn’t see a major change in the quarter. We said we would expect to see more of that impact in the second quarter for hardware revenue.

column1: Steve Trundle: Yes. I guess would probably – we don’t have that data point directly in front of us
column2: but I think what we said is if we rolled the clock back a couple years
column3: about half of the new installations were coming with the radio manufactured by Alarm.com. We saw that dropping to something in the 35% to 40% range
column4: and that trend is underway but didn’t impact us much in the first quarter. We expect it
column5: though
column6: to kind of continue at a slow pace
column7: to see a higher percentage of accounts on a going-forward basis likely coming from controls that where we’re not making the radio.

column1: Unidentified Analyst: And one more on the commercial side. So do you see you commercial offering exceeding 5% of revenue by this year end?
Steve Trundle: I am guessing
column2: but the guess would be no
column3: given the base that we have and given the place where we are with the product at the moment. I would not expect 5% to be from commercial
column4: no.

column1: Operator: Thank you. And our next question comes from the line of Jack Vander Aarde with Maxim Group. Your line is now open.
Jack Vander Aarde: Steve V.
column2: you provided Connect SaaS revenue for the first time in a while. Did I hear you correctly
column3: it was $9.1 million?

column1: Steve Valenzuela: The actual number for Connect revenue for Q1 was $9.9 million compared to $2.3 million in the quarter last year.

Jack Vander Aarde: Okay. So that’s ahead of my kind of internal estimate. I just want to touch upon the kind of the ARPU/subscriber dynamic with Connect. Is there a – is that solely driven by subscriber growth? Or is there ARPU lifts in/ARPU growth within the Connect subscriber base?
Steve Valenzuela: There are different levels of plans in terms of various different levels of plans for the Connect platform. But again
column2: keep in mind
column3: as I said on the prepared remarks that Connect we license the software to our service providers
column4: for the most part
column5: and the service providers have to incur the whole hosting
column6: their people
column7: managing the service
column8: the cellular fees. And so it’s a different type of deployment than an Alarm.com platform offering from our other service providers.

column1: Steve Trundle: So within the world
column2: though
column3: of that software
column4: a customer that takes
column5: for example
column6: a rich video subscription would be on a different plan than a subscriber who is really just doing interactive security or interactive security and automation.

column1: Jack Vander Aarde: Got it. So that holds true for both the core Alarm platform and the Connect platform then?
Steve Trundle: That’s correct.
Jack Vander Aarde: And then just a follow-up for Steve T. With over
column2: I think you mentioned over 100
column3: 000 subscribers are located outside North America. Are international subscribers entirely supported by the Alarm core platform? Or is there any Connect mix in there?

column1: Steve Trundle: That’s 100% Alarm.com.
Jack Vander Aarde: Okay
column2: thanks. And then are the ARPU pricing dynamics between Alarm North America and international dealers the same in terms of like the basic plan per month that Alarm receives and then premium ARPU lifts for attached services?

column1: Steve Trundle: Generally in the same ballpark and definitely the same structure.
Jack Vander Aarde: Okay. But the dollar amounts might vary?
Steve Trundle: You get into like currencies. Obviously
column2: the size of service provider
column3: I think
column4: is probably more of an impact than the market. But
column5: as is the case
column6: even in North America across service providers
column7: there will be variance. But we’re not really doing kind of market-specific pricing schedules.

column1: Operator: Thank you. And that does conclude today’s Q&A session. Ladies and gentlemen
column2: thank you for participating in today’s conference. This does conclude the program and you may all disconnect. Everyone

column27: I’d now like to turn the call over to Steve Trundle. You may begin.

column1: Steve Trundle: Thanks
column2: David
column3: and welcome to everyone joining our call today. We’re pleased to report another solid quarter that exceeded our expectations. SaaS and license revenue in the second quarter was $71 million
column4: up 20.4% from $58.9 million in Q2 of 2017. Our non-GAAP adjusted EBITDA in the second quarter was $23.4 million
column5: up 47% over last year. Our service provider partners continued to compete effectively in the market and were more successful in the second quarter than we anticipated. Most potential residential and business customers continue to demonstrate a preference for a professional-grade smart security solution that comes with the commitment to ongoing service and support from a reputable provider. I want to thank the Alarm.com team as well as their service providers for their contribution to our positive results. This is the first quarter in our company’s history that we have exceeded $100 million in total revenue. On today’s call
column6: I want to update you on a few of our business initiatives and recent product introductions. As most of you know
column7: we continuously integrate new hardware and peripheral devices into our ecosystem. This gives us an ever improving set of intelligent
column8: useful and convenient capabilities for the subscriber. It also equips our service providers with an expanding set of solutions to market and sell. This quarter
column9: we launched a new smarter heating control solution that integrates a number of new devices. It provides an easy retrofit for boiler systems that are popular in Europe. The hardware kit includes a new EU version of the Alarm.com Smart Thermostat as well as third-party devices for managing hot water cylinders and individual radiators for room-to-room temperature control. Domestically
column10: we introduced the integration of the DSC iotega from Johnson Controls. The iotega is a versatile headless security control panel for residential installations. We also expanded our portfolio of smart locks with the addition of the Yale Assure
column11: Kwikset Convert as well as the August Smart Lock Pro for customers who don’t want to change their existing door hardware. Earlier this year
column12: we introduced the Danalock V3 for the European market. As we grow our ecosystem
column13: our service providers tend to expand the range of solutions that they offer so they can service more of the market. Next
column14: I want to talk about the home builder program that we announced during the second quarter. As I have mentioned on previous calls
column15: new homebuyers tend to have a high adoption rate on smart security and automation systems. Many of our service providers work with builders and their local market
column16: and one of our goals is to help facilitate these partnerships. Our program gives builders a full range of support through efficiently deploying smart home solutions in new home communities. The best-in-class hardware products in our ecosystem allow builders to tailor solutions to the target buyers and the design aesthetic of a given community. Working with one of our service provider partners
column17: builders can also minimize the risk and cost of deploying new smart home technology. Our service providers manage the required product inventory
column18: install and configure the systems and then service the systems through years after the builder has delivered the property and move-in has occurred. Early in the second quarter
column19: we also launched our new commercial platform
column20: Alarm.com for Business
column21: including our new Smarter Access Control solution. I discussed this initiative on our last quarterly call and
column22: I want to give a brief update on our progress. As a reminder
column23: our commercial platform integrates interactive security
column24: video surveillance
column25: access control and energy management into a unified
column26: intelligent solution. It’s designed to address the needs of small and medium-sized businesses. We see a meaningful opportunity for our service provider partners to attack this segment in both the domestic and international markets. Since launching our commercial platform in April
column27: we have initiated marketing
column28: sales and training activities to increase awareness with our service provider partners. While interest is strong and sales are beginning to flow
column29: it was not the reason for our outperformance in the second quarter. It typically takes a longer period of sustained solid execution to get our partners comfortable with routinely selling and installing new products like the Alarm.com commercial platform. Next

column31: we proceeded to execute our plan to increase our marketing presence this quarter. We are focused on a couple of things in our marketing initiatives. First
column32: we want to properly launch and raise awareness for our commercial platform. There
column33: we are focused on the security channel. Second
column34: we want to better position our service providers and our technology with home and small business owners. Here
column35: we are focused on the consumer. We are educating them about the value of our more robust integrated solution and our go-to-market approach. Our message often distinguishes the benefits of working with our service provider partners. We believe that these efforts help our service providers as they engage in sales discussions with potential customers. I also want to update you on some of our longer-term growth initiatives. Beginning with our international business
column36: we see continued progress and momentum. We reached the total of 100
column37: 000 active international accounts during the second quarter
column38: not including Canada. Today
column39: we have 151 active service provider partners in 37 countries outside of North America. Our services are currently localized for 40 countries. This quarter
column40: our services launched in South Africa through ADT Fidelity. ADT Fidelity is the leading security provider in South Africa
column41: with approximately 35% of the residential intrusion market. We also continued to expand in Europe through our partnership with Securitas and others. Our European presence now includes Spain
column42: the Netherlands

column44: Belgium
column45: Sweden and Norway. One other new partnership I want to highlight is our relationship with Aviva. Aviva is a large European insurance company with more than 33 million customers globally. They will introduce Aviva Smart Home
column46: a professionally installed and monitored smart home security solution in Ireland this fall. Our partnership with Aviva is built around a first-of-its-kind application for IoT services. Many insurance providers have offered discounts and affinity programs for smart home security products. Aviva sees a broader opportunity in offering an Aviva-branded and customized solution that is tailored to their policyholders. With our full scope of advanced property protection capabilities
column47: Aviva’s solution can take preventative action to reduce claims while also generating more customer engagement. To give you a better feel for the growing breadth of our global presence
column48: our updated investor deck now includes a list of some of our key service providers
column49: along with links to some of their marketing assets. We founded the company based on the idea that people universally value peace of mind and protection for their loved ones. It’s gratifying to see the diverse range of brands that are echoing this message and the values of our technology to a growing global market. We also operate several growing subsidiary businesses that we report in our Other segment. This includes PointCentral
column50: Building 36 and EnergyHub. Their SaaS and license revenue grew 59% in the second quarter. EnergyHub recently announced that it will manage National Grid’s full-scale bring your own device demand response program. National Grid is one of the largest investor-owned utilities in the world with more than 3 million homes in its target market in the Northeast. The program will leverage the breadth of EnergyHub’s Mercury platform by including multiple device categories
column51: including residential battery energy storage. We continue to see solid ongoing progress with all of our long-term growth initiatives. We will continue to update you as these efforts further develop and contribute to our growth trajectory. To summarize

Moving to our financial outlook. We expect Q3 SaaS and license revenue of $72.2 million to $72.4 million. column24: compared to our prior guidance of $97.5 million to $99 million. We expect Q3 hardware revenue to be sequentially lower than Q2
column25: coming off a seasonably strong Q2. We also expect hardware revenue for Q4 to be seasonally lower than Q3
column26: consistent with historical trends. We are increasing our expectations for non-GAAP adjusted EBITDA for 2018 to be between $85.1 million to $85.9 million
column27: up from our prior guidance of $82.5 million to $83.2 million. We expect adjusted EBITDA to be lower in Q3 and Q4 compared to Q2
column28: reflecting our planned investments in marketing and R&D

column4: which is a low-powered version of LTE that you can envision enabling us to reach locations where there may not be a power supply
column5: there may not be a hub
column6: et cetera. So there’s a fair amount of focus there as well as on CATM

column8: I think 5G is a little further out. I think
column9: though
column10: the ambitions we have around 5G are to be able to give our service providers a wider range of flexibility when they go in and sell in high-bandwidth IoT devices like high-def video cameras. So there
column11: I think
column12: we’re waiting on the bandwidth and the cost and really the deployment. Sometimes
column13: these marketing terms
column14: by the way

column19: you could do it with a 5G version of our product set and even accommodate the higher bandwidth parts of the application. So those are a few of the things that I think we’re excited about there.

John DiFucci: Thank you. I have a question for Steve Trundle and then a follow-up for Steve Valenzuela. Steve Trundle
column2: my question is on the builder program. I just want to make sure that I understand this. These relationships are still going to be owned by the service providers

column1: Steve Trundle: Yes. So good set of questions and it requires that I distinguish Toll Brothers from some of the other builders. So let me start with that and then come back to kind of the broader vision for builders. Toll Brothers is a bit unique in that they’re actually a service entity themselves. So they own a security division. They have for years. This isn’t a new thing. They made a decision some period of time ago that they would operate a security division that services their model homes as well as their new customers. And therefore
column2: they’re more like – I think they bought a security company probably to enable that. They’re more like a traditional service provider to us that is just highly affiliated with a builder
column3: being – meaning Toll Brothers. But I would put them in a little different bucket than other builders where the builder is not simultaneously engaged in being a security service provider. And this program that we’ve announced is more focused on a vision of getting builders to specify into every home some piece of the Alarm.com ecosystem or multiple pieces of the Alarm.com ecosystem. And ideally
column4: it’s not a buyer option. It’s something that just comes with the home. And luckily
column5: we encourage it some
column6: but the consumer is encouraging the builder to make – the builder needs to distinguish a new home from a legacy home
column7: and an integrated set of smart home components can be a distinguishing characteristic that’s attractive to the consumer. So the demand is there from the builder. And then
column8: the trick is for us
column9: I think
column10: we benefit from a fairly fragmented service provider base
column11: but at times
column12: it makes us – difficult for us to put on sort of a unified face to a builder
column13: particularly a national builder. So in this case
column14: we’re not servicing
column15: no. The service provider is always brought in to the relationship or the builders introduce the various service providers and then the service providers compete for the relationship. But we’re really more focused on with the builder
column16: marketing and selling the merits of our platform and the versatility of the platform to scale from simple smart home applications like automating lights and the thermostat and the garage door to moving on up and to an integrated automation and security solution to moving on up with integrated audio
column17: energy
column18: video and automation. So we’re promoting the merit to the technology. If the builder then adopts and standardizes on the Alarm.com ecosystem
column19: it benefits all of our service provider partners. And they
column20: in turn
column21: work with the builder to iron out the mechanics. And they add a lot of value to the builder as well. And as I put in my comments
column22: they derisk the smart home process for the builder. And we have partners that are national in scale that can work with national builders and we have local partners that work with locals. And we’ve put a few setups in place to make it more valuable for our service providers to compete with us for that builder business.
