column2: it would’ve been flat. But even then
column3: I would have thought it would grow. I mean
column4: the business is doing really well and earnings are growing. And like I said
column5: you did have working capital here that was – I’m not sure why accounts receivable jumped in this particular quarter. It jumped by a lot more than it usually does
column6: at least it looks on a seasonal basis.

column1: Steve Valenzuela: What happened there
column2: John
column3: was we had a strong outperformance in the hardware sales
column4: and so what happened is that tended to be more nonlinear toward the end of the quarter. So our AR DSOs were 46 days in Q2 compared to 43 days Q1 of 2018
column5: and we expect that to convert to cash in the second half
column6: in Q3. So that’s why we’re guiding or indicating for the second half of 2018
column7: the free cash flow to actually be higher in the second half of 2018 compared to the second half of 2017. So that was a temporary – when you have such hardware sales versus SaaS
column8: which is tends to be linear
column9: hardware is not as linear and that affects your AR and your DSOs because if we have more of those sales back-ended
column10: you don’t have time to collect within the payment period. So it’s more of a timing difference. So hopefully that helps you.

column1: John DiFucci: Yes. That’s helps a lot
column2: Steve. Thank you very much. Nice job guys.

column1: Steve Trundle: Thanks
column2: John.

column1: Operator: Our next question comes from Jeff Kessler with Imperial Capital.
Jeff Kessler: And Steve
column2: about a year ago
column3: you absconded
column4: or I should say
column5: bought a whole bunch of talents from ObjectVideo
column6: all their human assets
column7: so to speak. And since then
column8: we haven’t heard much about them. You’ve been hiding them somewhere on sand or rock
column9: without us even – they’ve been obviously doing some work for you
column10: but I’m just wondering if you could update us the types of things that are coming out of video analytics
column11: skunkworks at Alarm.com?

column1: Steve Trundle: Sure
column2: Jeff. Yes. So we’re very pleased with the team
column3: obviously
column4: that we were able to acquire from ObjectVideo. And we’re kind of in between skunkworks and deployment at this moment
column5: I would say. So our goals for video analytics have been really to make the quality of the alerts even more relevant to the consumer and to make sure that we’re recording things that matter. And by being intelligent and training a set models around video
column6: we can be more intelligent in the delivery of content to the consumer. And the bigger
column7: the more data you have in those models
column8: the more model powerful the model become. So that’s kind of what we’re trying to achieve there. And I guess
column9: the update is we’re testing externally certain amounts of optionality right now and are not going to put it into our standard offering until such time that it’s ready
column10: but we’re making progress. I’d love to have it out already
column11: but we don’t. But the team is heads down working hard against the set of internal deadlines to get a release of our residential analytics package out this year.

column1: Jeff Kessler: Okay. Your other businesses were up 59%. And I realize you’re talking about a small number
column2: but could you give us some more color with regard to those businesses since they obviously could become material at some point in the future?

column1: Steve Trundle: Yes. So I think I highlighted a bit more on EnergyHub in my comment. They recently won a nice deal with National Grid. Their business is expanding from being really a thermostat-driven type of DVR program to being a program that enables a utility to manage load coming from a wider variety of consumer devices
column2: including
column3: I think
column4: I put in the note or in my comments
column5: even battery chargers where being selective about – or battery being selective about what time you actually recharge a residential battery can have a meaningful impact on load for utilities. So they’re managing a whole array of diverse forces in the field. The business is clicking along. I think
column6: we’re beginning to realize the vision we have for EnergyHub when we acquired it. And the other one is PointCentral is focused on unattended access and at times unattended delivery
column7: but really drilling down and focused on making it easier for people who are going on vacation and going to be staying in a vacation home or making it easier for a REIT that owns a lot of rental properties to remotely manage energy consumption
column8: temperature and really awareness and access of all of those properties. So they’re not really delivering a security solution per se
column9: but there’s – they’re evidence of a need – they’re evidence of us taking the platform
column10: which is primarily sold as a security platform and position it more as a base IoT platform for certain vertical applications that have more nuanced requirement. And PointCentral is building on that and they’re a big contributor to that number. And then
column11: the last one I talked about the past in that segment is our HVAC business. And I’m still at the point where I have to say the same thing
column12: which is that business is still more in its nascent phase where we’re seeing demand but we’re building a channel. And what we’re trying to do there is take the concept of remote monitoring and apply it to everyone’s HVAC system and protect people from outages
column13: help the service provider know when a unit may need service
column14: that sort of thing. So all are kind of novel concepts and making good progress
column15: I would say.

column1: Jeff Kessler: One of the – I guess
column2: one of the questions that are being asked a lot is about
column3: I would say
column4: technology that is being developed inside the monitoring center itself
column5: more analytics obviously
column6: eventually moving toward AI
column7: which some people think of as a threat to the traditional dealer if everything else is equal and everything else is a commodity. Is there a way for you to work with the technology that is being developed or spent on monitoring centers given that a lot of your clients are going to have to probably upgrade their own monitoring centers over time?

column1: Steve Trundle: Right. So kind of two parts. One
column2: is AI a threat to the traditional business of our service providers? And we don’t believe it is. We think it enhances the range of capabilities that our service providers can yield to a consumer. And at the end of the day
column3: the reason – one of the reasons we’re successful is if the customer wants service first. And service sometimes can be AI. But more often than not
column4: it’s more rudimentary. It’s I need someone to come get this thing working in the next day or two. So our guys – our team is good at that. With regard to how we partner with the central stations
column5: yes
column6: we’re always open to leveraging the assets that a central station has in a way that would result in better functionality for the consumer. You have to keep in mind that the data though coming in
column7: the volumes of data coming into Alarm.com pretty significantly exceeds the volumes that would typically become an end to a central station for the same account. I mean
column8: we’re basically dealing with every event and every video fragment. And if you’re trying to train an AI model
column9: there is some merit in training it with a large volume of data because the model becomes actually more effective and more predictive. So I would think
column10: in most cases
column11: we’re going to be pushing some intelligence down to the central station and then hopefully providing them the tools needed to react to that intelligence and deal with it in the most coherent way with the consumer. But there may be cases where we can benefit from a model sitting in the central as well.

column1: Jeff Kessler: Okay. Thank you. And one quick final question. With regard to the commercial business
column2: can you talk in terms of real life practices where some of your clients are
column3: where you would like them to be? Are there a group that are further ahead of others in taking on the commercial product? And there – is there a group that is essentially coming on and taking a little bit longer to do this? Where are you – how was that – how is in practice this coming down here in terms of time as well?

column1: Steve Trundle: So I would say that it’s consistent with what we’ve seen with other products in terms of the adoption cycle. There are a set of early adopters that tend to be very entrepreneurial companies oftentimes run by a single owner
column2: and so these are what we would call our carriage. Some people refer to them are carriage straight dealers or smaller dealers. They’re typically the fastest adopters of anything because they can make a decision very quickly. One person makes a decision
column3: they move out. So we’re seeing that the most – and by the way
column4: that’s kind of good for us because those folks tend to be very hands-on and they also tend to be fairly vociferous with their feedback. And so we’ve got a set of more than 100 early adopters
column5: I believe
column6: that are selling not just commercial but the commercial integrator with access solution. The feedback has been very positive and we’re looking – watching kind of the repeat sales. So not do they just sell one
column7: or they sell one every week
column8: they sell every two weeks
column9: et cetera. And then
column10: the sales cycles that takes longer and take more training more work tend to be the larger service providers that will evaluate things
column11: will take more time to consider where they’re going. And those are all – those discussions are probably about where we thought they would be
column12: which is we’re in discussions but it just takes some time to kind of break through inertia and drive change in a larger service provider. So most of the adoption
column13: thus far
column14: has been from the smaller partners we have.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from Gabriela Borges with Goldman Sachs.
Gabriela Borges: Good afternoon. I appreciate you letting me to ask a question. On the ARPU
column2: I’d love to get an update
column3: either from Steve Trundle or Steve Valenzuela
column4: on what you’re seeing directionally in the residential piece of the business as you get more attach rates on new functionality? And is there any update on the mix that you’re seeing in the ADT channel from customers coming on board on Alarm.com versus Connect
column5: given the benefits that it has of an on-premise system? Thank you.

column1: Steve Trundle: Sure
column2: Gabriela. So I’ll start and Steve can help me if I need it. But with ARPU trends
column3: we haven’t seen any significant change there. The internal dynamics are still pretty much the same
column4: which are that we’re continuously kind of evolving the capabilities and sometimes new capabilities like commercial are – won’t yield a higher ARPU than our basic residential services. So at the same time
column5: there’s always price pressure on the residential services. So the combination of sort of continuing to try to drive more value to our service providers and the higher-volume residential segment offset by higher ARPU coming in from either enhanced services like video or from commercial has resulted in more or less a steady-state kind of ARPU trend. And the second part of the question was regarding ADT’s plans and their transition or not. And I guess
column6: I’d say there
column7: probably what I’ve said in prior quarters
column8: which is we’re aligned with ADT
column9: working together obviously
column10: especially on the technology side. We think they have – are taking a set of kind of exciting steps
column11: and we don’t want to usurp the message. We think that ADT will message it’s kind of plans for what it’s going to bring to market in due time when they’re ready and we’re going to leave it to ADT.

column1: Gabriela Borges: That’s helpful. And a follow-up
column2: if I may
column3: for Steve Valenzuela as well. I wanted to revisit the hardware outlook. Your comments on seasonality made a lot of sense. I also wanted to look at it maybe on a year-over-year basis. I think
column4: guidance implies a little bit of a decline in the second half year view. It seems counter to the trajectory of pretty consistent growth if I look back a couple of years. How should we think about the trajectory of hardware business from here? And is there any reason why it would actually decline year-over-year? Thank you.

column1: Steve Valenzuela: So it’s very possible too that some of the Q2 hardware sales may have been pulled forward from Q3. So we can’t tell that for sure because given the supply shortages. So we just have to be aware of that from a guidance point of view. But typically
column2: if you look in the past
column3: and it is hard to tell because there are new product introductions and there are timing things occur that could skew that
column4: but if you take that out
column5: typically
column6: Q4 is usually our seasonably weakest quarter for hardware. So if I was modeling this
column7: I would probably look at Q4 to be about 10% lower sales in Q3 2018. If I was doing the model
column8: we’ve given you the annual guidance
column9: I think you can model it that way. So that’s – because that’s the way I would look at this. Again
column10: hardware
column11: we just have to be careful with when we guide because it’s not recurring. It’s not necessarily predictable. There’s so many things that occur in the past. We introduced new cameras. We introduced new commercial cameras and so that can kind of skew. We try to take that out when we give guidance and we try to think
column12: okay
column13: what’s the steady-state
column14: what’s reasonable not trying to guide with all the different fluctuations that occur quarter-to- quarter. Overall
column15: the trend
column16: as you’ve seen
column17: we’ve taken the guide up on hardware for the year because it is actually very hard to guide on a quarterly basis.

column1: Gabriela Borges: I appreciate the color
column2: thank you.

column1: Steve Valenzuela: Thank you.
Operator: Our next question comes from David Gearhart with First Analysis.
David Gearhart: Hi
column2: good afternoon. Thank you for taking my questions. My first question is just in regards to the litigation expense nice – actually not nice but a sequential increase from here. You said in your earlier remarks that it’s hard to predict with litigation expense. How should we model the year? Can you give us some sort of baseline to model for the rest of the year?

column1: Steve Valenzuela: Yes. The hardest questions
column2: David
column3: are questions about litigation expense because we can’t really telegraph – not in our interest or shareholders’ interest to telegraph exactly what we may be doing on the litigation side. And – but I guess what I’d say at a very high level is there’s a bit of a lull in 2017
column4: and we think that 2018 will look a little more like 2017. When we’re all-in
column5: we don’t think that what you saw in the second quarter is indicative
column6: at least at the moment
column7: of any kind of one-time blip. It’s probably more indicative of the fact that various matters are progressing at a point where there are costs that are higher as we go through sort of the ebb and flow of these matters.

column1: David Gearhart: Okay. And then
column2: you’ve talked about SLA agreements and having to kind of put that in your guidance and forecast that. You’ve been public for a while now. Every quarter
column3: you’ve exceeded the high end of your SaaS and license revenue guidance. Just wondering if you can give us some sense of how often these SLA issues where it would violate an agreement occur and roughly how much you’re sizing those so we can maybe kind of get a sense for it and how that’s factoring into guidance?

column1: Jack Vander: Well
column2: there are a few different variables that can come into play that are sort of volatile and probably three or four different variables. And I would say
column3: roughly
column4: this is an approximation
column5: but one out of every – we hope that they don’t happen at – there’s a negative outcome on negative outcome on one of these variables
column6: you hope that not all three sort of align in the same quarter and we don’t discount to that point. But we do have to allow for the possibility that something could occur. And I would say
column7: one out of every four quarters or so
column8: something does occur. And that causes some unpredictability in the SaaS and license revenue stream. And our goal is to make sure that a modest fluctuation driven by one or two SLA variables doesn’t sort of lead people to lurch. So we have to – or leave them surprised. So we have to account for that. And if everything goes well
column9: then we do outperform slightly. But anyway
column10: that’s probably about what I – how we think about it
column11: I guess
column12: I would say.

column1: David Gearhart: Okay
column2: that’s it from me. Thank you for the color.

column1: Steve Valenzuela: Thank you.
Operator: Our next question comes from Brad Reback with Stifel.
Brad Reback: Great
column2: thanks very much. Just real quickly back on litigation. Can you remind us what the – sort of the key issues here
column3: what the key cases that are sort of progressing and when you expect trial?

column1: Steve Trundle: I think
column2: most of our litigation that’s material would be in our public financials and probably the full update when the 10-Q goes up
column3: we would refer people to that just because we’re limited in how much we can say about any current litigation on a call like this. But there are several different matters on the IP front
column4: I think
column5: that are reflected. There’s a little matter. There’s – I think there’s one other one that’s in the 10-Q. And we’re always dealing with sort of trolls that sometimes make it on the 10-Q
column6: sometimes don’t. There is couple of TCPA matters
column7: I think
column8: one of them being bigger than the other that is approaching litigation. So I guess what I’d say is those – that’s probably about it right now. We’re on – we’ve got a body of IP matters that our legal team is handling
column9: and then a body of – and in some cases is assertive and then a TCPA matter
column10: and probably would just say the best situation we can provide there is going to be what we disclose in the 10-Q.

column1: Brad Reback: Great
column2: thanks very much.

column1: Steve Trundle: Thank you.
Operator: Our next question comes from Mike Latimore with Northland Securities.
Matt Shea: Hi guys
column2: Matt Shea on for Mike. First question
column3: how much SaaS revenue did the Other category contribute? And how fast was that growth?

column1: Steve Valenzuela: Other – this is Steve Valenzuela. The Other segment accounted for about $2.9 million of SaaS revenue in the quarter and it grew 59% year-over-year. The other thing we should note is that the Other segment as a total revenue now accounts for 7% of our total revenue
column2: including hardware
column3: whereas a year ago
column4: it accounted for 6% of our revenue. So we saw 100 basis point increase in contribution from our Other segment.

column1: Matt Shea: Okay
column2: great. And then when might ObjectVideo officially launch a video analytics service? And will there be separate offerings for the residential versus business segments?

column1: Steve Trundle: Sure. I’ll be disappointed if we don’t launch video analytics this year with residential segment. And I’m not sure exactly – there will eventually. Or there will be slightly different flavors for commercial. You can imagine that different commercial verticals have different analytic use cases. So I would expect that through time
column2: there will be some more niche- oriented – commercially oriented analytics packages
column3: but we’re focused right now on the broadly applicable base analytic package for residential customers
column4: and we expect to have it in market this year.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from Jack Vander with Maxim Group.
Jack Vander: Hey guys
column2: great quarter by the way. In response to an earlier question
column3: you mentioned that the overall ARPU changed too much. But if I were to try to zone in on the Connect portion
column4: revenue is up 20% year-over-year from that business. Can you split that
column5: those drivers up between subscriber strength and ARPU just directionally?

column1: Steve Valenzuela: We don’t really break out Connect ADT is a customer there and a few other customers
column2: but we don’t want to get into details because ADT has their business. And they’re a public company. If we start breaking out that detail
column3: it would be
column4: I think
column5: sensitive to them. So we provided the breakout of the total revenue for Connect for software license revenue of $10.2 million in the quarter. But in terms of breaking it further down
column6: we probably shouldn’t be doing that.

column1: Jack Vander: Okay
column2: just a follow-up with the ADT Fidelity partnership. This – I guess
column3: you guys said 35% share of the residential intrusion market. How large is the South American – or South African intrusion market relative to the U.S.?

column1: Steve Valenzuela: Yes. So not nearly as big as the U.S. market. On a relative basis
column2: I would probably say
column3: it’s probably 5% to 10% of the U.S. market in terms of TAM in that country alone. So my recollection
column4: I have to look at my notes
column5: my recollection is you’ve got around 12 million households and you’ve got a take rate there
column6: you have a wider disparity of demographics and you have a take rate of residential security services of between 10% and 15% and then
column7: of that TAM
column8: folks taking residential security services
column9: ADT Fidelity
column10: which by the way
column11: is not part of what we say ADT in the U.S.
column12: a different company. ADT Fidelity is the same brand and is a relic of when Tyco owned ADT and international ADT
column13: but ADT Fidelity is a different sort of stand-alone independent company
column14: and that’s roughly what I would say the TAM is that 35% there of that number.

column1: Jack Vander: Okay. That’s helpful. And then
column2: just real quickly
column3: was – with the partnership there with Alarm powering ADT Fidelity’s residential offering
column4: is the idea is that it would be like a slow uptake of Alarm’s core platform providing the back end system for that? Or is it an all-in-one kind of overnight change?

column1: Steve Valenzuela: No. We wish it were the latter but it’s not. We haven’t figured out how to do that. So it will be a long- term partnership where we’re focused on with ADT Fidelity servicing that market
column2: and you’ll gradually see or we will gradually see that engine crank up and begin to produce as they sell new systems and then
column3: over a longer period of time
column4: upgrade existing systems.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from Darren Aftahi with Roth Capital Partners.
Darren Aftahi: Yes
column2: thanks for taking my question. On international
column3: I think you called out 100
column4: 000. Could you characterize how fast it grew in 2Q versus 1Q? And then
column5: on the homebuilder program
column6: I know you called out Toll Brothers is having a sort of their own service arm. But can you talk about just the general sales cycle for trying to gauge more the national builders?

column1: Steve Trundle: Sure. So let me start with international. I think
column2: international
column3: we just – what we see is slow
column4: steady quarter-over-quarter sequential growth. Occasionally
column5: there will be a step event if we bring on a new market and a service provider is particularly active in that market. But largely
column6: we’re just sort of continuing to chip away at things
column7: add markets. Frankly
column8: fix problems at times
column9: deal with problems. It’s not a – the path of rendering global security services is not one without some potholes
column10: so smooth over the potholes and try to maintain our relationships and let it build over time. So I don’t remember Q-over-Q international
column11: but I would just say that it’s – each quarter is higher volume than the prior quarter. With regard to the builders and those sales cycles
column12: this is a new initiative for us
column13: where we made a determination that we needed to do a better job interfacing with our partners to builders and we needed to promote the platform to builders ourselves
column14: always with the service provider along. But these – and there’s nothing really
column15: if you think about what we’re selling
column16: we’re not asking the builder for a check. We’re asking them to make the most prudent decision in choosing the platform they want to put in their properties. And then the check is going to one or several of our service providers. So these are sales cycles that are sort of a cross between selling and marketing. And I would say that builders
column17: the length of the cycle is a function of the size of builder. Again
column18: if you got a local builder that’s building four or five homes a month
column19: they can do very quick sales cycle. And oftentimes
column20: our service provider handles that entirely without our involvement. If you have a national
column21: like some of the ones you mentioned
column22: you have to catch them at the right time and catch the right person
column23: and that’s a six-month-plus type of sales cycle.

column1: Darren Aftahi: Great
column2: thank you.

column1: Operator: Well
column2: ladies and gentlemen
column3: there are no further questions at this time. This does conclude today’s presentation. You may all disconnect and have a wonderful day.";[0.14321040911513694

column2: ladies and gentlemen and welcome to the Alarm.com Q3 2018 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder
column3: today's conference is being recorded. I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference call
column4: Mr. David Trone. You may begin.

column1: Dave Trone: Thank you. Good afternoon
column2: everyone
column3: and welcome to Alarm.com’s third quarter 2018 earnings conference call. As a reminder
column4: this call is being recorded. Joining us today from Alarm.com are Steve Trundle
column5: President and CEO; and Steve Valenzuela
column6: CFO. Before we begin
column7: a quick reminder to our listeners. Management’s discussion during the call today will include forward-looking statements
column8: which include projected financial results or operating metrics
column9: business strategies
column10: anticipated future products and services
column11: including future innovation and video analytics
column12: computer vision and artificial intelligence; anticipated investment and expansion; anticipated market demand or opportunities
column13: including expectations regarding our new video analytics offering and our other video services; and other forward-looking statements. These forward-looking statements are based on our current expectations and beliefs and on information currently available to us. Statements containing words such as anticipate
column14: believe

Please note that these forward-looking statements made during this conference call speak only of today’s date
column22: and Alarm.com undertakes no obligation to update these statements to reflect subsequent events or circumstances
column23: except to the extent required by law. Also during this call
column24: management’s commentary will include non-GAAP financial measures and provide non-GAAP guidance. Management believes that use of these non-GAAP financial measures provides an additional tool for investors to use in understanding the company’s performance and trends
column25: but note that the presentation of non-GAAP financial information is not meant to be considered in isolation or as a substitute for the directly comparable financial measures prepared in accordance with GAAP. Reconciliations between GAAP and non-GAAP metrics for our reported results can be found in the financial statement tables of our earnings press release
column26: which we have posted to our Investor Relations website at investors.alarm.com. This conference call is also being webcast and is also available on our Investor Relations website. The webcast of this call will be archived
column27: and a telephone replay will also be available on our website. With these formalities out of the way
column28: I’d now like to turn the call over to Steve Trundle. You may begin.

column1: Steve Trundle: Thanks David. And welcome to everyone joining our call today. We are pleased to report another solid quarter that exceeded our expectations. SaaS and license revenue in the third quarter was $74.3 million
column2: up 20% from $61.9 million in Q3 of 2017. Our non-GAAP adjusted EBITDA in the third quarter was $25.8 million
column3: up 32.6% over last year. During the quarter
column4: we saw both higher-than-expected account origination and a slightly expanded breadth of services being sold and installed. These strengths drove our better-than-expected results. I want to thank our service providers as well as the Alarm.com team for their contributions during the quarter. Beyond our financial performance
column5: I also want to highlight some of the recent progress we have made in our product portfolio. We achieved a major milestone with our release of video analytics
column6: which was formally announced just last week. I want to give you an overview of these new capabilities and also update you on the broader development program we've established for ongoing innovation in the fields of computer vision and artificial intelligence. Our video analytics service is built on object tracking and object classification technology. Object tracking analyzes each frame of video to determine an object's direction of movement and duration of activity. The object classifier identifies people
column7: vehicles and animals. Combined with virtual zones and tripwires
column8: we can now alert subscribers about highly specific events around their property. For example
column9: instead of sending an alert about routine movement or changes in the scene
column10: we can now watch for people lingering near a front door for a specific duration. We can also watch for a pet getting on to a sofa or for kids leaving the backyard. For commercial applications
column11: a business manager can confirm that a delivery truck arrived at the loading dock without being notified each time a customer exits the building. These insights can
column12: in turn
column13: be used to trigger devices to respond. So if we spot a person entering the backyard at night
column14: we can turn on lights to provide an additional security deterrent. Meanwhile
column15: if an animal such as a deer enters the same area
column16: the user can opt not to turn on the lights but instead to turn on the sprinklers. The combination of our video analytics player with our automation capabilities demonstrates the power of a fully integrated platform. Our video analytics offering is now available for both existing subscribers and new installs with our popular 522 and 722 cameras
column17: and we'll be expanding camera support over time. The new capabilities are packaged in a new video service plan that includes additional video content storage and is offered for a modest additional subscription fee. We believe that video analytics will generate more value and engagement for subscribers which
column18: in turn
column19: support sales and reduces churn for our service providers. This is the first market release of technology that has been derived from our acquisition of ObjectVideo in January 2017. Since the acquisition
column20: we developed and deployed a deep learning architecture called a convolutional neural network. To train the system
column21: we use real-world smart home data from video clips captured in the field. This required processing and analyzing millions of frames of video. The result is a proprietary neural network that is optimized for indoor and outdoor applications. As our subscribers adopt video analytics at scale
column22: our neural network will continue to benefit from direct user feedback and from a continual process of training
column23: validation and testing. Beyond video analytics
column24: we also recently enabled Apple's new Siri shortcuts feature for our subscribers. These capabilities were part of the expanded voice assistant functionality that came with the release of iOS 12 by Apple. Subscribers can now create custom Siri phrases to trigger actions through their Alarm.com system. With our Scenes feature
column25: they can quickly and easily engage their system to adjust multiple devices with a single voice command. This capability allows us to combine the convenience of voice control with the higher value away-from-home use enabled by mobile interfaces like the iPhone. In October
column26: we held our annual Partner Summit here in Washington D.C. We hosted a number of our service provider partners and presented our latest products and R&D priorities. Overall
column27: the conversations that I had during the summit reinforced that we are well aligned with our service provider partners and presented our latest products and R&D priorities. Overall
column28: the conversations that I had during the summit reinforced that we are well aligned with our service provider partners and what they are seeing in the market. We heard additional positive feedback about the Alarm.com for business platform and we learned about new opportunities that we can address through future product enhancements. Meanwhile
column29: in the residential market
column30: our service providers continue to see strong demand for a professional grade fully integrated security-first smart home service. We also discussed video analytics and how this new feature set can help increase sales of video services. A number of the initial video analytics use cases are for outdoor applications where we see professional installation as a significant additional differentiator. Our service providers appreciate this alignment
column31: and they see good opportunities for additional growth with video. Our service providers also shared positive feedback on the consumer marketing program we implemented this year. As I have mentioned before
column32: our message informs consumers that they can turn to a licensed professional for a well-designed and reliable smart home and business system that provides long-term value. We believe these campaigns help our service providers as they market and sell our solutions. It was encouraging to hear feedback from the field validating our approach. I also want to highlight one event from our Other segment businesses this quarter. EnergyHub expanded its partnership with the Arizona Public Service
column33: the largest electric utility in Arizona. EnergyHub's platform will manage Arizona Public Services full-scale ""bring your own device"" program which will include a broad range of grid edge devices
column34: including battery energy storage
column35: smart solar inverters
column36: water heaters and connected thermostats. The expanding breadth of connected devices enables EnergyHub to provide increasing value to its utility customers with services like peak demand reduction
column37: load shifting and renewables matching. Next
column38: I want to spend a moment reminding investors of our high-level strategic framework as we focus on wrapping up 2018 and look into 2019. We remain committed to an adjusted EBITDA margin target range of 20% to 25% and to driving fast recurring revenue. We view hardware as a key enabler of our services
column39: but we are not overly focused on either the amount of hardware sales or the margins of our hardware business. This gives us the flexibility to run discounted or subsidized hardware promotions that drive the adoption of a new service or an upgrade cycle with existing subscribers. To summarize
column40: I'm very pleased with our performance this quarter and the progress we've made to introduce new products
column41: particularly our video analytics offering. Thank you again to our service provider partners and the Alarm.com team for their hard work and to our investors for their trust in our business. And with that
column42: let me turn things over to Steve Valenzuela. Steve?

column1: Steve Valenzuela: Thank you Steve. And good afternoon everyone. I will begin with the review of our third quarter 2018 financial results and then provide guidance for the fourth quarter and our raised outlook for the full year of 2018 before opening the call for questions. SaaS and license revenue in the third quarter grew 20% from the same quarter last year to $74.3 million. This includes Connect software license revenue of approximately $10.5 million for the third quarter compared to $9.3 million for Q3 2017. Our SaaS and license revenue visibility remains high with a revenue renewal rate of 94% in the third quarter at the high end of our historical range of 92% to 94%. Hardware and other revenue in the third quarter was $37.6 million
column2: up 34% from Q3 2017 revenue of $28 million. The increase in hardware revenue was primarily due to an increase in sales of our video cameras. We believe approximately 25% of video sales are for existing subscribers as they upgrade to our newer cameras or add video to their systems for the first time. Total revenue of $111.8 million for the third quarter grew 24.3% from Q3 2017. SaaS and license gross margin for the third quarter was 84.5%
column3: consistent with our gross margin in the same quarter last year. Hardware gross margin was 18.8% for the third quarter compared to 20.5% for the same quarter last year
column4: primarily due to mix. Total gross margin was 62.5% for the third quarter
column5: down from 64.6% for the same quarter last year due to the hardware margins along with the higher mix of hardware revenue. Turning to operating expenses. R&D expenses in the third quarter were $22.9 million compared to $19.3 million in the third quarter of 2017
column6: as we continued our planned investment in R&D
column7: given the significant opportunities we see in our markets. We ended the third quarter with 496 employees in R&D
column8: up from 441 employees in the same quarter last year. Total headcount increased to 866 employees compared to 774 employees at the end of Q3 2017. Sales and marketing expenses in the third quarter were $14.1 million or 12.6% of total revenue
column9: compared to $10.4 million
column10: or 11.6% of revenue in the same quarter last year. Our G&A expenses in the third quarter were $43.7 million which includes a legal settlement of $28 million as we previously announced. Excluding this
column11: our G&A expenses in the third quarter were $15.7 compared to $13 million in the year ago quarter. G&A expenses in the third quarter includes non-ordinary course litigation expense of $5.2 million and the legal settlement of $28 million compared to $1.9 million for Q3 2017. Non-ordinary course litigation expenses are part of our adjusted measures and are excluded from our measurement of our non-GAAP financial performance. Non-GAAP adjusted EBITDA increased to $25.8 million in the third quarter
column12: up 32.6% from $19.5 million in the same quarter last year. In the third quarter due to the legal settlement
column13: we had a GAAP net loss of $7.7 million
column14: compared to GAAP net income of $15.1 million in the year ago quarter. Non-GAAP adjusted net income increased to $18.2 million in the third quarter compared to $13.3 million for the third quarter of 2017. Turning to our balance sheet. We ended the third quarter with $124.2 million of cash and cash equivalents. Note
column15: we expect to pay the legal settlement in future quarters. Therefore
column16: ending cash balance had not been reduced for this amount as of the end of September 2018. In the third quarter
column17: we generated approximately $19.8 million of cash flow from operations compared to $13.8 million for the third quarter of 2017. Our free cash flow for the third quarter was $16.6 million
column18: up $4.7 million from our free cash flow of $11.9 million for the same quarter last year. Through the nine months ended September 30
column19: we generated $25.7 million of free cash flow compared to $30.9 million for the same period in 2017. Moving to our financial outlook. We expect Q4 SaaS and license revenue of $76.3 million to $76.5 million. We are increasing our expectations for full year 2018 SaaS and license revenue to be between $289.5 million to $289.7 million
column20: up from our prior outlook for SaaS and license revenue of $286 million to $286.5 million. We are also raising our guidance for total revenue for 2018 to $407.5 million to $409.7 million
column21: up from our prior guidance of $388 million to $390.5 million. This includes our increased guidance for hardware and other revenue of $118 million to $120 million
column22: compared to our prior guidance of $102 million to $104 million. We expect hardware revenue for Q4 to be seasonably lower than Q3 consistent with historical trends. We are increasing our expectations for our expectations for non-GAAP adjusted EBITDA for 2018 to be between $91 million to $91.5 million
column23: up from our prior guidance of $85.1 million to $85.9 million. We are also raising our guidance for non-GAAP net income for 2018 to $63.8 million to $64.2 million or $1.28 per diluted share
column24: up from our prior guidance of $59.4 million to $59.9 million or $1.19 to $1.20 per diluted share. This is based on our non-GAAP tax rate of 21% as we have previously indicated. EPS is based on an estimate of 15 million weighted average diluted shares outstanding. We expect full year 2018 stock-based compensation expense of $13.5 million to $14 million. Finally
column25: while it is too early to spend much time on 2019
column26: I did want to provide a very early perspective. At this time
column27: we are comfortable with total revenue of $430 million to $440 million for 2019
column28: in line with current consensus. While we considerably outperformed our own expectations for sales of hardware during Q3
column29: it can take several months for those sales to work in the channel. We anticipate that some of the behavior that led us to raise the 2018 guidance is indicative of future sales patterns. But until we're able to fully track the sale through of these incremental sales

column31: consistent with our past practice

column33: Alarm.com for Business and our Access Control products

column35: we are pleased with our performance and excited about the opportunities ahead for us and our service providers. We are continuing to invest in our business to capitalize on the expanding opportunities in both residential and commercial markets for the intelligently connected property. Thank you for joining us on our call today. And with that operator please open the call for Q&A.

Operator: Our next question comes from the Nikolay Beliov with Bank of America.
Nikolay Beliov: Hey guys this is Nikolay from Bank of America. Thanks for taking my questions. Question for Steve Trundle. There seems to be a new trend in the industry with service providers
column2: the hardware financing being down by third parties like banks. Steve Trundle
column3: what is your kind of impression of that? Is it making the industry a little bit healthier? And kind of like how that might impact the business?

column1: Steve Trundle: Yes good question Nikolay. So lots of different opinions on that. I'm not sure mine is any more valuable than others
column2: but my personal opinion is that it's a healthy dynamic for the industry. Anytime you have the customer
column3: we've always said
column4: and all of our service providers have told us for a long time
column5: that if a customer makes an investment in their system upfront
column6: that those are typically better customers than customers who received the system for free and now are basically repaying for the upfront capitalization cost in the form of their monthly service bill. So we like a mix. We like to see customers that are invested up front. We think that the financing piece
column7: if I were to spend $5
column8: 000 on my system in my own home
column9: I could choose to finance that anyway and dealers are now increasingly making that financing more available and easier to sort of obtain for the consumer. I think that allows the service provider or the dealer to offer a wider range solution of the consumer. It's more likely to meet their complete need. I think that probably generates some downstream value to us and that the customer – if we roll the clock back 10 years
column10: the typical customer might only have a handful of intrusion sensors in a control panel. And if you try to sell that same system today
column11: there still is a market for it
column12: but it's a much smaller market. The majority of the folks want to have a more powerful system that includes intrusion and includes some level of smart home functionality and cameras. So there's just a higher upfront cost
column13: and that cost has to be borne by someone
column14: either the service provider or the customer or potentially the customer through a financing mechanism. So I think that the financing element makes it more attainable and more possible for our service providers to sell a complete system to a customer without sort of wrecking the balance sheet by basically giving away a much bigger system today for free than what they may have needed to do 5 to 10 years ago.

column1: Operator: Our next question comes from Gabriela Borges from Goldman Sachs.
Gabriela Borges: Good afternoon and congrats on the quarter. This is more of a macro question for Steve Trundle
column2: which is how sensitive do you think your business is to the housing market. Just wondering what you're hearing from the dealers on the ground in terms of new customers coming to the platform because they've moved homes or because they bought a new home for the first time versus maybe upgrading as part of their renovation budget or for some other reason. Thank you.

column1: Steve Trundle: Right. No. I think we've lived through a few housing cycles
column2: and in the last one sort of the 2008-2009 time frame
column3: we really weren't impacted by the negative housing cycles. So – but the business was a little less mature then. The theory and what we've learned from our service providers is that in a negative economic cycle
column4: the desire for protecting what you have tends to go up
column5: and folks are a little bit more focused on getting an intrusion system because they're seeing people hanging around the neighborhood. It might not be working
column6: that sort of things. So it tends – there tends to be some positive effects
column7: unfortunately
column8: from a – let's say
column9: some offsetting effects from a negative housing cycle if that is driven by negative or bad economy. I'd say we're a little bit more exposed at this point
column10: though
column11: than we were six or seven years ago because we have a healthy – we have a fairly healthy program now with builders
column12: and we like to see them doing well. And then in terms of how that cycle's going to unfold
column13: I think our view is there's still quite a bit of room for growth in the housing market. But I wouldn't say it's going to – we're not enormously volatile there
column14: but I would say that it'd probably be more noticeable if we had a negative cycle today than it might have been for us seven
column15: eight years ago.

Operator: Our next question comes from Saliq Khan with Imperial Capital.
Saliq Khan: Hi
column2: guys. Just a couple of quick questions on my end. We would see – with the launch of the video analytics
column3: is it essentially the first step towards you guys being able to provide professional verification for the dealers? And how would you envision that playing out for the marketplace? And is it too early for us to kind of think about data analytics for monitor alarm or event verification?

column1: Steve Trundle: Thank you for the question. So we already do
column2: Saliq – so video verification is already a part of our value proposition and a number of our service providers make use of the video cameras already. In the current dynamic
column3: if there is an alarm event
column4: the service provider determines that time of installation
column5: how that will be handled. And if the customer is comfortable with the video from the cameras coming to the central station during the event
column6: then that is turned on. That helps the operator adjudicate the matter and make a decision on how to handle the alarm. So that's been there for some time. And in terms of video analytics impacting that
column7: I think this would be a step – what we're doing now would a step towards a couple of things
column8: first
column9: potentially driving events to the central station that are not necessarily alarm events but that are still noteworthy events. We can increasingly drive intelligence from video to identify other things of interest that may be of interest to the consumer or business owner and may prompt a central station monitoring activity. We may also be able to more effectively provide the operator
column10: the person to headline the decision
column11: of whether or not dispatch
column12: provide that operator with more insight into the events that they're actually trying to make a judgment on. So if we see something that is routine
column13: we may at least want to notify the operator that everything looks routine. But for an alarm event that came off by the given intrusion sensor. So I think there will be richer data sets that we can derive with video analytics
column14: and I think it's been in our interest and in the interest of our service providers for us to make use of those data sets as much as possible with the consumers' consent and still protective of their privacy but to make use of those data sets to improve the efficacy of the decision on whether it is to dispatch or not with the first responders.

column1: Saliq Khan: That's very helpful
column2: Steve. And then just a follow-up on my end
column3: we're seeing an increased amount of conversations with the insurance providers out there
column4: some of the utility providers and then more meaningfully for the traditional security industry
column5: the SMB market that has traditionally been okay from a security perspective. There's a very large runway ahead for these guys. So could you highlight your plans for helping upgrade those SMB customers to more integrated and advanced analytics? And then my thought process is advanced analytics are eventually more business analytics solutions as well. How are you guys thinking about that?

column1: Steve Trundle: Right. So we're turning our focus to that sort of in real time. I think our first goal with analytics was to get a solution out that would work for a broad range of customers
column2: including residential and commercial
column3: and would solve the most common use cases. But when we look at SMB in particular
column4: there's an opportunity to drive down different verticals that have slightly different types of analytical templates and be even smarter. So for example
column5: a store is going to look a little different than a bar and a restaurant and the types of things you're observing are going to be different
column6: the types of accounts you're doing are going to be doing. And then the way you integrate with the point-of-sale data in that case can be different between those two different types of SMB location. So we're – I guess I should say shifting now to sort of what the next- gen opportunities are with the analytics layer. And here
column7: I think
column8: we're
column9: at the moment
column10: listening to our service providers. First and foremost
column11: what are they seeing as the opportunity set
column12: what's not being currently addressed at an effective level in the market and beginning to derive where we're going to go with some more specifics sort of vertically-oriented analytic templates for the SMB market.

column1: Saliq Khan: Great. Thank you
column2: Steve.

column1: Steve Trundle: Thank you.
Operator: Our next question comes from Darren Aftahi with ROTH Capital Partners.
Darren Aftahi: Hey
column2: good afternoon. Thanks for taking my questions and congratulations. Just two
column3: if I may. Just first back to analytics. So Steve
column4: you talked about the convolutional neural network. So I'm sort of curious. When you think about long-term differentiation with video analytics and data analytics in general
column5: like there are other solutions out there that have been trained on video images
column6: et cetera. Like how do you differentiate the product long-term? And then embedded within that question
column7: we use that as kind of lead gen to differentiate the product. My second question to Steve Valenzuela. I know you had talked about increasing marketing spend
column8: and that was up pretty substantially year-on-year. I'm just kind of curious if you under spent relative to plan on 3Q. Thanks.

column1: Steve Trundle: Sure. I'll let Steve take that second piece. It's right up his alley. And the first piece is differentiation in video analytics. I have opinions on this that I'll cover. First is there's a real scale advantage. And when you're driving a neural net and you're training that AI engine
column2: the more
column3: the better. The more information and content you can feed it
column4: the smarter it becomes. So there is a scale that we think we're reasonably well positioned to take advantage of
column5: maybe not against every competitor but against the majority of the folks. The second is we're focused and always have been on trying to take cutting-edge capabilities and make them fit an economic envelope that still works for the average sort of affordable premium type of customer. And in this case
column6: if we look at our acquisition of ObjectVideo
column7: a lot of what we rolled out are capabilities that they've done a decade ago almost
column8: got it a little differently. But the real challenge was figuring out how to make that technology work without a ton of compute on the edge and with a modest amount of sort of supplemental commute – compute in the crowd such that we can price it at a level that is affordable for the average even residential consumer. So that's a place for today I think as of right now
column9: we have an advantage
column10: and we will stay focused on maintaining that advantage. Of course
column11: the cost of compute on the edge will steadily come down
column12: but that's the focus. The third is more interesting – a lot more interesting but a more – a different sort of level differentiation
column13: which I think is going to come from the business model of the companies who are involved in providing the capability. And what I mean by this is our business model allows us to be very transparent with the customer on how we treat their information and how we protect their privacy. We don't need to take metadata from a video analytics layer and push that in to our marketing database or any other database that we may maintain on the consumer. I think some of the other folks that are potentially in the market can't make that same commitment to the consumer and still have a viable business model. So I think that can actually be – the third part is trust. And you operate long enough and you do well by the consumer and hope that their trust in our approach would become a third-level differentiation. I'll leave the second piece for Steve.

column1: Steve Valenzuela: Hey Darren
column2: the question on the marketing. So the marketing spend for Q3 was actually about 12.6%. At the beginning of the year
column3: we did say we expected marketing to be around 14% to 15% of revenue. And so we're pretty much right on track. Another thing to think about
column4: too
column5: is Q4
column6: we do have in October our annual dealer – national service provider conference in Washington D.C.
column7: which does increase the marketing spend a bit in the fourth quarter. But I would say from a planned point of view
column8: we're right on track with the marketing spend
column9: as we laid out at the beginning of the year.

column1: Darren Aftahi: Helpful. Thanks.
Steve Valenzuela: Thank you.
Steve Trundle: Thanks
column2: Darren.

column1: Operator: Our next question comes from David Gearhart with First Analysis.
David Gearhart: Hi
column2: good afternoon
column3: thanks for taking my questions. First question I wanted to ask
column4: you mentioned in your prepared remarks that the video analytics offering would be a modest increase in pricing. Just wondering if you can give us some sense of how much of an uplift it would be on a per-subscriber basis
column5: on the analytics piece itself and on the storage side.

column1: Steve Trundle: On the analytics piece and on the storage
column2: okay. Well
column3: that's two parts actually. They're very related
column4: which is we have wanted to introduce this in a way that we think it is conceivable for our service providers to offer it at a modest additional sort of rate to the consumer. And what we've included – our typical today basic video plan is – includes 30 – roughly 30 clips of storage per day on up to four cameras. That's our plan today
column5: and that does not include video analytics. And we're not getting rid of that plan. So we're not going to sort of drop out of that market. That's probably the most sort of price competitive part of the market. We want to keep our entry-level offering available there. With this offering
column6: we're including 100 clips per day for each property on up to four cameras in aggregate. So we're tripling the storage that comes with the plan that includes video analytics
column7: and then we're including the analytic capabilities that we've currently released. And the incremental cost
column8: there's sort of what's the consumer is going to pay and what do we expect. I think our expectation
column9: I don't want to get into a ton of detail because I want to leave our service providers a lot of freedom to place how it makes sense for them. But our expectation is that the incremental revenue to us from one of these would be roughly an extra $1
column10: $1.5 per month.

column1: David Gearhart: Okay
column2: that’s helpful. And then just wondering if you can give us a quick update on international and what you're seeing there in terms of traction and trajectory.

column1: Steve Valenzuela: Yes. International is – I think I spent a little bit of time on that last quarter
column2: and at that time
column3: I think we said we were up to sort of in the 37 different countries with service providers. And kind of moving along
column4: I don't think much changed. The momentum on international is about the same. Let me see if I have anything – growth is healthy
column5: but still sort of early days. In the third quarter
column6: I think we're getting to the point where more of our partners internationally where we're sort of shifting from testing
column7: pilots and early sort of efforts to sort of getting to the point where folks are really beginning to institutionalize what we do into their offering. I expect that will continue to drive uptake on international. Particularly
column8: there are some markets that are a little more mature. But particularly when I look at Europe as an example
column9: I think we're kind of on the cusp from a shift that will be positive. The big thing was the announcement with the insurance company
column10: though
column11: with Aviva last quarter and just generally seeing positive trends there
column12: but haven't focused on it as much this quarter.

column29: requires a concerted sales

column46: vehicles

column48: we plan to expand the analytics capability to our full range of cameras and continue to train the system to address additional high-value use cases
