column1: Operator: Our question comes from the line of Adam Tindle with Raymond James. Your line is now open.
Adam Tindle: I just wanted to start about Steve Trundle
column2: you've talked about being very thoughtful about the investments that the Company makes. In the past
column3: you’ve talked about every dollar of marketing typically brings about dollar or more of incremental SaaS revenue. But I know you have a number of initiatives and vertical market expansion that you outlined. So
column4: I'm just hoping that you can touch on how do the payback rules of thumb change because kind of to the point of last question
column5: it seems like a step function decline in payback and SaaS growth rate based on 2019 guidance versus what you would expect to pay back
column6: it's still less than 1. I acknowledge that you outperformed initially in 2018
column7: but hoping you can touch on those dynamics?

column1: Steve Trundle: Sure
column2: yes. First
column3: keep in mind that ‘18 had a partial benefit from the Icontrol acquisition. But looking at those other segments
column4: the payback is just a lot longer and then more material. So
column5: there's certain investments we can make where we’re looking inside of the year and we can see sort of instantaneous results -- not instantaneous
column6: but you can see certain customer creation activity result from certain sales activity. And then
column7: with the other segment businesses
column8: these are more R&D investments at some levels
column9: where as our experience with the Alarm.com is an indicator
column10: we're looking out over a 10-year horizon and thinking about where we want to be in half a decade and then a decade
column11: and which markets we want to be in. So
column12: it's much harder to sort of do an NPV calculation on the investments we’re making there. But
column13: we think that the upside merits
column14: more speculative investment and likewise. We think that the strength of the Company has enhanced with adding sort of increasing breadth of markets that we’re able to serve and enable. So that's sort of how we look at. I think we're probably a little less focused on spreadsheet mechanics when we think about our other segment businesses and sort of the long-term goals that we have there.

column1: Steve Valenzuela: I would say that the other segment is growing faster than overall Alarm.com. And If you look at in 2018
column2: the other segment
column3: which includes EnergyHub
column4: PointCentral and Building 36
column5: contributed 8% of total revenue
column6: that's up a 100 basis points from 2017
column7: when they contributed 7% of total revenue. So
column8: while they’re still early stage
column9: they are contributing more revenue and becoming more significant to overall Alarm.com total revenue.

column1: Adam Tindle: Maybe just a quick follow-up. I wanted to touch on kind of more near-term differentiated results. We've seen significant weakness from the publicly traded DIY players
column2: like in the security camera market
column3: even the pro-install players at the high-end and the CEDIA channel have experiences slowness. So
column4: I'm just hoping that you can maybe reflect on the different channels around you
column5: and how you’ve been able to navigate with strong double-digit growth while they’ve seen turbulence?

column1: Steve Trundle: Yes. It's a good question
column2: Adam. We are not in those markets that much. So
column3: we don't see sort of a day-to-day pressures in activities that exist there. We have noted some of the results that have come in. I think
column4: what we've been sort of stating fairly consistently is it really isn’t all one market. There is a market that prefers what we characterize as real security
column5: robust security where the homeowner views the implementation of the smart home system and particularly the smart security system to be an investment in their property. And therefore
column6: it's important for them to have a trusted relationship with a special service provider
column7: and that market has been robust. And so
column8: I think we've been probably less exposed to some of the volatility. If you think about the DIY markets
column9: they tend to be affected by where you are in the early adopter versus mainstream sort of adoption curve. And you never really know where you are on that curve at any given point in time. So
column10: it's easy to extrapolate that you are already in the mainstream and you are sort of kicking along at a certain rate and then you really realize you're sort of at the tail end of an early adopter stage and you've got
column11: you don't -- it's much harder to predict those businesses I think. So
column12: fortunately
column13: our business is proven and it's been around for a while and we have a lot of confidence in our service providers. If I think about the high end
column14: I think probably the reason we've -- maybe not seeing some of the same indications there as what we've heard there are first where slightly we’re less exposed to new construction starts and second
column15: I think that the buyer is still -- at least our buyer
column16: our buyer is a security first customer. And people always have a need for security and safety and through thick and thin. So
column17: I think
column18: again
column19: we've been able to maybe not see as much volatility there as some of the others.

column1: Operator: Our next question comes from the line of John DiFucci with Jefferies. Your line is now open.
Julian Serafini: Hi. This is Julian Serafini on for John. So
column2: I guess
column3: I just want to touch back on the guidance again. I know
column4: you've touched on earlier
column5: and Steve
column6: you talked about not factoring in all the upside necessarily. I guess
column7: I just want to confirm that
column8: the core business is still going strong and going well
column9: because even if you factor in some upside
column10: there is still a bit of decel from 2017
column12: I just want to confirm that
column13: things are going well in the core business at least?

column1: Steve Trundle: Yes. We’re still very busy. I think
column2: we've seen sort of mid-teens growth coming. We provided initial outlook last year. And actually
column3: I think on the total side
column4: we’ve raised that number with this outlook. So
column5: business is still doing well
column6: we’re growing nicely on a percentage basis
column7: we’re not growing it quite the way we were when we were a smaller company but we’re still improving the outlook about the growth we see and the outlook for the year and then about a lot of the upside you are seeing
column8: some of the emerging opportunities. So
column9: generally
column10: our billings are pretty positive right now.

column1: Julian Serafini: And then
column2: just the second question is on the video product. I think
column3: you talked about
column4: driving some of the video products and video analytics going forward this year. Are you going to do anything in terms of like incentivizing subscribers
column5: maybe discounts in the video hardware or something to like incentivize
column6: you want to upgrade to video products?

column1: Steve Trundle: That’s a really -- that's a good question. And I’m chuckling because it's question that reflects a conversation we've been having in the last week
column2: which is exactly what is the upgrade cycle on video cameras and what if a customer has video cameras that are 3
column3: 4 years old
column4: is there a sufficient sort of gain and the capability that we really should do more to drive adoption. We're already seeing
column5: Steve V said moment ago where he’s seeing one out of four of the new cameras going into existing customer account. So
column6: my belief is the functionality is still materially -- so much better with the new cameras and with the analytics capability that we probably don’t have a need to do just for the purpose of video to do any sort of inducement to purchase. But
column7: I think that there may be reasons to package up the new video analytics capability with something like an LTE upgrade offer and use it to generate pull-through for some other types of goals we may have in the Company.

column1: Operator: Our next question comes from the line of Kevin McVeigh with Credit Suisse. Your line is now open.
Kevin McVeigh: Great
column2: thanks. Hey. You spoke a little bit about the commercial initiatives. I wonder if you could give us just an update on that
column3: any thoughts as you kind of roll that out
column4: maybe more so in ‘19. And specifically
column5: as you think about the dealer network
column6: is it an expanded dealer network given it's a bit of a different skillset from an installation perspective
column7: or do you still focus on the core dealers in the residential that offer both type of services?

column1: Steve Trundle: It's both actually. So
column2: the existing base of service providers
column3: quite a few of them have serviced commercial in one frame or another
column4: in one way or another historically
column5: and some have not. But in any case
column6: all of them have one thing in common
column7: which is hopefully they have a trusted relationship with Alarm.com
column8: and they therefore will be open to levering our capabilities on the commercial side or developing a commercial business around our capabilities
column9: so that's what I'd say about the existing partners. There are a set of players in the industry that are purely commercial that really aren't residential
column10: and now
column11: we have a reason to have a dialogue with those parties
column12: so we anticipate some expansion of the partner base. I think we even saw that a bit toward the end of last year where we're in discussions and going through the process with service providers that focus really on the SMB segment where we've designed this offering to focus. And it's still fairly early
column13: but we did see meaningful uptake last year of the commercial service plans and made a lot of progress I think also in getting the access control component of that commercial plan embedded in the market.

column1: Kevin McVeigh: And then
column2: should the traditional relationship between the SaaS and the hardware lines across the revenue stay constant as you get more commercial
column3: or should we expect that to flex up or down a little bit?

column1: Steve Trundle: That one's a bit of a hard one for us to predict because it's a little bit partner-dependent or ecosystem-dependent
column2: and at various points
column3: we will engage with the other parties that are in the ecosystem in different ways. Sometimes we'll make a product; sometimes we'll introduce a new partner. So
column4: the long-term trend there is challenging for us to really predict. What I will say is in the near-term
column5: obviously
column6: with the commercial plans
column7: we're creating more value. There's a wider range of services
column8: and therefore
column9: the arc through there is a bit higher. At the same time
column10: those customers tend to not be satisfied with one camera but instead need several
column11: and there's a more meaningful hardware component as well as they build out a full solution. So
column12: I don't know that I have an exact prediction for you
column13: but I would probably say something in line with historical numbers is probably the right place to be right now.

column1: Kevin McVeigh: Great. And then just one last one if I could. With ADT's partnership with Amazon
column2: have you started to see any impact on that in terms of flow-through to your business from ADT
column3: or are we still too early in that process?

column1: Steve Trundle: We're still too early in that process.
Operator: Our next question comes from the line of Matt Pfau with William Blair. Your line is now open.
Matt Pfau: I wanted to get a little bit more detail on the video analytics product. And so
column2: in terms of initial uptake of video analytics
column3: has that primarily been from new customers or have you seen uptake from existing customers? And then [inaudible]
column4: I believe that's only available on two of the cameras that you deploy
column5: so as you make that more broadly available
column6: maybe you could give us an idea in terms of maybe percentage of your base of video customers that would potentially be able to adopt the product as you implement it into more video cameras?

column1: Steve Trundle: I'd say we've seen the adoption on both existing subscribers who have video cameras that have the processing power required to support our analytics offering. There were a number of folks that were waiting. And then we're definitely seeing the adoption on new installations because they're using a mix of cameras that are more likely to support the capabilities. You're absolutely correct though that at the moment in the camera portfolio
column2: there are a handful of our cameras
column3: especially the POE cameras that are not yet generally available in a way that supports analytics capabilities. So
column4: I think as the full portfolio supports the video analytics' ability
column5: we'll continue to see a rise in the adoption rate there
column6: but it's already at a rate that I can almost envision over the next few years that some base level of functionality will become standard table fare that's sold into every installation.

column1: Matt Pfau: And then
column2: have you been working with your partners to educate them more on the offering and get them to push it through to customers
column3: or is there more of an opportunity there from a marketing perspective with your dealers?

column1: Steve Trundle: I definitely think there's more of an opportunity there to educate the service providers and also the consumer
column2: and there is always a bit of a lag. People hear about it
column3: but until they have actually done a few installations
column4: watch what happens to their customer service intensity
column5: get comfortable that the customers are happy
column6: it just takes a while. It takes a while for us to train
column7: and we're still in a pretty early part of that cycle
column8: so we definitely have an opportunity to do more there.

column1: Operator: Our next question comes from the line of Gabriela Borges with Goldman Sachs. Your line is now open.
Gabriela Borges: Good afternoon. Thank you for taking my question. Steve Trundle
column2: I wanted to follow up on some of the earlier comments. I understand that you're limited on what you can say about ADT
column3: so I'll focus instead on the implications for your business model. How should we think about the RPU and gross margin on some of the new SaaS-like architecture product versus the classic SaaS business? Thank you.

column1: Steve Trundle: Gabriela
column2: you're comparing our tradition SaaS business to which product?

column1: Gabriela Borges: The new ADT interact -- the new ADT SaaS-like stack.
Steve Trundle: Oh
column2: I see. I see
column3: okay. The new model is more like our traditional Alarm.com model in that we're trying to deliver a fuller range of services that include all the operations of hosting the offering or redundantly hosting the offering
column4: managing a set of carrier and communication relationships
column5: and doing as much as we can to provide the maximum amount of efficiency and leverage from our abilities as we can. So
column6: it's more like the traditional Alarm.com business model.

column1: Gabriela Borges: That's very helpful. Thank you. And the follow-up is a high-level question on the earlier comment on early adopters versus maybe interactive technology becoming a little more mainstream. So
column2: maybe for Steve Trundle
column3: I would love to get your thoughts
column4: where do you think we are in terms of adoption on the transition from classic
column5: traditional security to something more interactive like what Alarm.com offers? Thank you.

column1: Steve Trundle: I was almost speaking about the adoption curve. Someone had asked me about the DIY products and trying to know where you are
column2: why are we seeing the turbulence there
column3: and I was sort of speculating that we just don't know where they are on the curve. In our case
column4: I think we do know a little bit more about where we are on the curve just because we've been at it for a decade
column5: and I think we're into the mainstream and have been into the mainstream for the last couple of years and are gradually executing the process of moving
column6: hopefully
column7: the entire market from one that was dominated by a POTS-based not-always-connected solution to one that is always connected. I guess rough math would be that there're somewhere between 20 million and 25 million of those historic customers
column8: and we're probably 8 million or 9 million into that base at this point with interactive capabilities
column9: and then of course we're working to increase the size of that market as well. So
column10: it all depends on how you define the market
column11: but I think in the space that we serve
column12: which is really the professionally serviced customer on the residential side
column13: we're in sort of the mainstream component of the curve. On commercial
column14: we're probably still in the early adopter part of the curve at the moment.

column1: Operator: Our next question comes from the line of Jeff Kessler with Imperial Capital. Your line is now open.

Jeff Kessler: Thank you and thank you for taking my call. First question would be on the introduction of Smart Signal and what you're going to do with it. Can you give us some type of timeline with regard to
column2: number one
column3: how are you going to train and get Smart Signal out into the marketplace because it seems like Smart Signal is the first part of a maybe ASAP to PSAP type of jump start
column4: but it's also obviously a lot more of a personal item to be able to actually make things convenient for the end use. So
column5: the first question is around Smart Signal and what you're going to do to get greater adoption and how you're going do it.

column1: Steve Trundle: Good question
column2: Jeff. So
column3: we're excited with the award we were able to get on that capability at CES. The whole goal here is to give the user control and at the same time
column4: in this case
column5: to really cut back on the false dispatches and false alarms that central stations
column6: unfortunately
column7: and first responders have to deal with. So
column8: with Smart Signal
column9: we're giving the customer a lot of control in terms of their ability to cancel out alarms and do that from their mobile app and the process there. And then of course the second thing is also very important
column10: which is we're giving the customer the ability to initiate a panic from their mobile device and route that into both the control panel and into the central station
column11: and ultimately
column12: to the PSAP. So
column13: in both cases
column14: the way it works is the app
column15: the functionality is actually built into the platform and it's now available essentially to any subscriber with one caveat. Their service provider and then the underlying central station has to be comfortable with the functionality and be ready to turn it on because the way the signals come in
column16: there are new types of signals that they may not have previously needed to deal with. There are new types of response regimens that they need to train their operators on. So
column17: what we're seeing is everyone's enthusiastic about it. The initial service providers that have deployed are confirming that we're seeing a reduction in the number of signals hitting the central that require the operator to make calls
column18: and we're also seeing a reduction in the number of false dispatches
column19: but each central and each service provider will have to go through our training program and really test the functionality
column20: then train their folks on how to handle these signals so that there's no deviation from protocol. So
column21: that's what we're doing right now. Longer term
column22: you're correct
column23: it's part of an overall goal we have to make more efficient the way that with the wealth of information
column24: the wealth of content that we have about a location and about what typically happens at that location
column25: to provide better content and better information to the first responder so that everyone in the entire value chain is able to work most efficiently
column26: so it's part of that cycle.

column1: Jeff Kessler: As a follow-up to that
column2: as you know in December
column3: a federal court upheld an ordinance from a small community in Georgia against the local alarm companies. And while it is a good
column4: probably deserved
column5: kick in the butt for some of these alarm companies who have been cruising on this for a while
column6: it brings up
column7: I would say
column8: the need for an accelerated verification capability on the part of the leading companies in the industry who want to avoid the problems of these ordinances. And the question to you is beyond Smart Signal
column9: what are you doing or what can you do to essentially become more of a verifier and obviously increase the value proposition for Alarm.com? I mean
column10: I'm seeing beyond the integrated companies
column11: it is also some of the independent monitoring companies that are monitoring the DIY guys are beginning to incorporate some of your stuff along with some other people's verification stuff because they realize that this is not something that is going to be for four or five years from now. This is something they've got to do in the next year or two.

column1: Steve Trundle: So
column2: two thoughts on that. I think that's a good point. I think that's probably a constructive trend for us in that folks do want to make sure that what they're passing to the first responders is a valid alarm signal
column3: so what can we do about it and how does that help Alarm.com? First
column4: for a long time
column5: we've used machine-learning to differentiate between routine activity and unexpected activity
column6: so we're at a point where you can imagine with the data we have on a property
column7: and if you take the algorithms we're using
column8: for example
column9: in healthcare
column10: we can predict the likelihood that a signal is false or real and provide one more data point there. The second relates directly to the video analytics that I've already spoken to which we can tell a lot about what's actually happening on a property
column11: give people a first view of that
column12: and I think we'll see our service providers move to increasingly lay on verification layers to increase the value of what they're providing to the first responders.

column1: Jeff Kessler: Thank you. One final question. What can you do to integrate and become part of the ecosystem of some of those companies that have been involved in both access control and video for mid-size and larger commercial companies but are trying to come down into the marketplace now? And come down meaning into the smaller commercial area. It could be competition for you
column2: but they could also be partners with you as well. I mean
column3: the names are well known in the security industry
column4: and it seems to me that you have the opportunity here to not just integrate with smaller camera folks and smaller access-control folks but with people who have some larger systems out there to get your applications into a just slightly higher level of the small business and commercial area.

column1: Steve Trundle: Good question
column2: again. So
column3: definitely
column4: we're starting with a SMB focus. I think you have to focus and you have to train in one area. That said
column5: the platform is not limited by the square footage of the facility in any certain way
column6: and we're seeing a few installs that are 100 access point plus that demonstrate an ability of the platform to scale up
column7: but if we think about our base of service providers
column8: we think that initially
column9: the sweet spot for them is in the SMB
column10: and then we'll move from hopefully what we will build as a position of strength
column11: we'll begin to move up market after that.

column1: Jeff Kessler: And I'm sorry
column2: one last question and I will make it quick. You've got four or five businesses in the other category
column3: you've gone from 7% of your total revenues to 8% of your total revenues. Can you talk about which of those businesses are actually seeing the greatest traction right now?

column1: Steve Trundle: At the moment
column2: the greatest traction is from EnergyHub and PointCentral.

column1: Operator: Our next question comes from the line of David Gearhart with First Analysis. Your line is now open.
David Gearhart: So
column2: my first question has to do with the homebuilder channel. You recently announced the relationship with DR Horton
column3: and earlier in 2018 in June
column4: you announced a revised program and you had a relationship already with a large builder
column5: I believe Toll Brothers. Just wondering if you could talk about adoption since that revised homebuilder program in 2018 and how we should think about attach rates for recurring service on new builds. Is there a percentage that you're seeing that we could use as a proxy to kind of handicap DR Home -- DR Horton builds and try to get a sense of how that could shape?

column1: Steve Trundle: I'd say that roughly
column2: so assuming you have a relationship with the homebuilder and you have the opportunity to speak to the customer
column3: that the range of the take rate or the acceptance rate is between 40% and 50% is what you're generally seeking to obtain there. And it may be you have a higher percentage that are using more of an automation-only type of offering
column4: but when we get to security
column5: that's the take rate that we'd like to be seeing as a minimum.

column1: David Gearhart: And then in terms of ADT
column2: you're supporting their new platform and their prior platform. The company recently announced earlier this month that it actually acquired a do-it-yourself solution
column3: so I just wondered if you could provide some color
column4: how you're thinking about DIY in terms of their having a solution? Is it something that Alarm.com can support
column5: or is it just something that's too early to kind of discuss in terms of where you could fit in with that offering with ADT?

column1: Steve Trundle: Yes. I guess
column2: what I'd say
column3: David
column4: is it's probably a little early for us to discuss much there. I think we've seen for a long time
column5: if I roll the clock back a year or two
column6: there was a DIY partnership there with Samsung. I think it's not really a new dynamic that ADT is growing their business in a number of different dimensions. Our role today has been more on the professional services side
column7: so we haven't really focused much on the DIY component. It's probably a little early for me to comment any further on that one.

column1: David Gearhart: And then lastly
column2: litigation obviously picked up in '18 versus '17. How should we think about the direction of litigation expenses in '19? Should it be flat
column3: up
column4: down? Just for modeling purposes. Thank you.

column1: Steve Valenzuela: Hey
column2: David. It's Steve Valenzuela. I would look at it at about the same level as 2018
column3: not including the $28 million TCPA settlement. So
column4: if you take that out of litigation
column5: litigation expense was around $17.5 million or so in 2018 compared to about $7 million in 2017. So
column6: I would model right around the same level. And I have to say
column7: litigation is hard to predict but I would use about the same level as 2018
column8: not including the $28 million TCPA settlement.

column1: Operator: Our next question comes from the line of Darren Aftahi with ROTH Capital Partners. Your line is now open.
Darren Aftahi: I just want to follow up on the homebuilder question and kind of two parts to it. First
column2: of the other major homebuilders you kind of haven't maybe publicly said you were working with. Is there any pushback to working with you or just kind of a function of time? And I'm kind of curious if there's more of a broader strategy with some of the commercial property side folks that build on that side in terms of breaking into your SMB as part of a long-term strategy. And I think last year
column3: you guys disclosed your ending sub number for 2017
column4: and I'm curious what that was for 2018.

column1: Steve Trundle: Sure. I'll start with the last question. In my prepared remarks
column2: I commented that we had entered the year with more than 6.1 million subscribers
column3: and that's not inclusive of any subscribers that are IP license only. And then back to the former question on the builder business
column4: there are a lot of builders that are big-name builders. There happen to also be a lot of local builders
column5: and there's a lot of activity there that it wouldn't really rise to the top of being press-release worthy but is happening every day. I don't think yet there's a standard. I think builders are still experimenting with what their strategy should be
column6: and some are beginning to move. I think one indicator of a mover is DR Horton where they've probably moved and been maybe a little more visionary
column7: but I think there's not yet an answer. If I'm a builder
column8: it's not yet known or the market hasn't said
column9: this is what you do if you are a builder. They're still sort of trying to figure out what they should be doing around smart home
column10: experimenting with a lot of things
column11: and therefore
column12: the sales cycles can be drawn out as opposed to
column13: say
column14: in other markets where folks know they need to do something
column15: and we're simply trying to win versus one of our competitors. Your question on commercial and can we parlay that offering into a builder oriented program
column16: to answer your question
column17: we have not gotten that far. We're not doing that today
column18: but one can envision if we have strength
column19: for example with REETs on the resi side that perhaps we could build strength with the REETs on the commercial side and try to do more there
column20: but we're not doing that today.

column1: Operator: Our next question comes from the line of Mike Latimore with Northland Capital Markets. Your line is now open.
Unidentified Analyst: Hi
column2: guys. This is Pavan [ph] on for Mike Latimore. I have two questions. Like
column3: how many distributors are now selling your commercial offering?

column1: Steve Valenzuela: So
column2: the question is how many distributors are currently selling our commercial offering?

column1: Unidentified Analyst: Yes.
Steve Valenzuela: So
column2: we have a total of service provider partners of 8
column3: 000 plus that we've announced. We've typically added about a thousand service providers per year. If you look at a number of those service providers that are coming up going through our training program
column4: we haven't actually disclosed a number. It's still a relatively small number relative to the overall 8
column6: but basically
column7: each quarter
column8: we're going through a training program. We're training the service providers and their technicians on a regular basis. We haven't really disclosed that number though.

column1: Steve Trundle: I don't know if we know the exact number. I think maybe the color that I gave in my prepared remarks was on the access side. We had trained 1
column2: 500 technicians
column3: and then I think on the broader commercial line
column4: I stated a number of individual companies we've trained
column5: to that would be a pretty good indicator. Roughly right now
column6: the commercial is still a small part of our base
column7: but around 3% of the base in terms of those who are paying for commercial subscription plans.

column1: Unidentified Analyst: And could commercial revenue surplus 10% of gross revenues this year? Can we expect that?
Steve Valenzuela: So
column2: 10% of revenue
column3: certainly the opportunity is there for the future. I wouldn't say that that would be a realistic goal for this year. Certainly
column4: the potential is for commercial to contribute given that it's their early stage. Keep in mind
column5: we just launched Alarm.com for Business a little bit
column6: actually
column7: less than a year ago and smarter access control. While we're seeing good performance there
column8: it's still off of a small base. The longer-term opportunity clearly is quite significant given that there's over 4 million properties just in North America that we think actually are a valid tempera for us for commercial. But as Steve said
column9: today
column10: about 3% of our subscribers are commercial-paying businesses. Now
column11: the RPU there is about two times that of the residential
column12: two to three times
column13: so there is a higher amount of RPU from commercial
column14: but I would say a 10% number would be an aggressive percent of revenue for 2019.

column1: Operator: Our next question is from the line of Jack Vander Aarde with Maxim Group. Your line is now open.
Jack Vander Aarde: Steve Trundle
column2: so
column3: given earlier commentary regarding Connect platform enhancements and the new ADT offering. Do these enhancements to the Connect platform create potential for new or multiple pricing tiers within the existing Connect business model?

column1: Steve Trundle: So
column2: the existing Connect model
column3: it's SaaS-like
column4: but just to be clear
column5: it is an on-premise deployment of the Connect software
column6: and the new offering is more like the traditional Alarm.com-hosted SaaS offering. If I speak about Connect
column7: on that
column8: I think we're going to take direction from our customer on what capabilities they feel are most important for their base of more than 2 million subscribers on Pulse and really let the customer drive the way they want to implement pricing tiers
column9: so I probably don't have an answer for you there.

column1: Jack Vander Aarde: Can you answer if the new enhancements to the Connect platform result in higher operating costs to you guys as Alarm?
Steve Trundle: So
column2: the new offering is just
column3: for clarity
column4: it's not a Connect-based offering. It's a different software offering. And the new offering
column5: it will have
column6: for us
column7: higher operating costs because we're rendering the full stack of services with that offering. Yes.

column1: Jack Vander Aarde: That's helpful. And then do you plan to continue to break out this Connect versus core Alarm SaaS profile going forward?
Steve Valenzuela: So
column2: we've broken it out for 2018. We haven't decided whether or not we're going to be breaking out going forward
column3: honestly
column4: at this point in time. We provided that in the past. It may not be as relevant breakout for the future given the change to the new Command platform
column5: but we'll update you on the first quarter conference call.

column1: Jack Vander Aarde: And if I could just ask one more
column2: is there any change
column3: given that hardware GM was flat Q-for-Q but down year-over-year
column4: strong video sales again. Is there a change in the margin profile or the cost structure of the new video hardware versus last year's models of hardware that were sold?

column1: Steve Trundle: Probably a bit of a change. It's mainly mix driven. It's what are the higher volume products that are being sold. And then I think someone earlier asked a question about analytics and are we anxious to get analytics more broadly deployed. The answer there would be yes. So
column2: you can imagine if you're in our shoes
column3: we want to do as much as we can to lower the impedance of getting that capability in the market. And as I've said before
column4: our goal is to help our service providers create new customers. The customer lifetime value we think is very high
column5: so there will be times where we're not that worried about the hardware margins if we think we're going in the right direction in terms of creating customer lifetime value.

column1: Operator: And that concludes today's question-and-answer session. Ladies and gentlemen
column2: thank you for your participation in today's conference. This concludes the program. And you may now disconnect. Everyone
column3: have a great day.";[0.0

column1: 56;ALRM;2019-05-09;"Operator: Good day
column2: ladies and gentlemen
column3: and welcome to Alarm.com’s First Quarter 2019 Earnings Conference Call. At this time
column4: all participants are in a listen-only mode. Later
column5: we will conduct the question-and-answer session and instructions will be given at that time.  As a reminder
column6: today's program may be recorded. And now I’d like to introduce your host for today's program David Trone
column7: Vice President of Investor relations. Please go ahead.

column1: David Trone: Thank you. Good afternoon
column2: everyone
column3: and welcome to Alarm.com’s first quarter 2019 earnings conference call. As a reminder
column4: this call is being recorded. Joining us today from Alarm.com are Steve Trundle
column5: President and CEO; and Steve Valenzuela
column6: CFO.

column1: Steve Trundle: Thanks
column2: David
column3: and welcome to everyone joining our call today. We are pleased to report a strong start to 2019 as our first quarter results exceeded our expectation. Our SaaS and license revenue in the first quarter was $80.1 million compared to $68 million in Q1 of 2018. And our adjusted EBITDA in the first quarter was $24.3 million
column4: compared to $23 million a year ago. During the quarter
column5: we continued to focus on expanding our solutions with new capabilities for our service providers and their customers. We made significant enhancements to both our commercial services platform
column6: called Alarm.com for Business and our residential solution. We also released a new award-winning capability to help our service providers deploy our technology more efficiently. Let me begin with our commercial offering. Last year at this time
column7: we launched Alarm.com for Business and we've steadily expanded the offering since. This past quarter
column8: we introduced a few significant new software-based capabilities. First
column9: we continued to enhance our Access Control solution. We integrated Access Control into our enterprise console dashboard to enable customers with many locations to manage everything in one place. From a single web view
column10: users can add and delete users
column11: manage access points and user permissions and define schedules across multiple locations and security partitions. This capability significantly expands the range of installations our Access Control solution can handle. In addition
column12: we applied our market leading AI engine that we call the Insights Engine to the high volumes of data coming from our Access Control solution. Leveraging machine learning
column13: our solution can intelligently detect and alert the right personnel about irregular or unexpected events
column14: pre-determining and configuring all the different conditions that might warrant receiving an alert can be challenging. Our Insights Engine now does this on behalf of the commercial subscriber. This will be a valued capability for any business and its value increases with the scale of the installation in terms of the number of access points
column15: the number of employees and the number of locations. During the quarter
column16: we also significantly enhanced our commercial video service. As with Access Control
column17: we have integrated live video into our enterprise console
column18: enabling subscribers to manage and monitor video feeds from multiple geographic locations using a single interface view.

column1: Operator:  Our first question comes from the line of Adam Tindle from Raymond James. Your question please.
Adam Tindle: Afternoon. I just want to start
column2: Steve Trundle
column3: the moving parts
column4: the competitive landscape in adjacent channels
column5: you probably noticed a sizable acquisition announced this morning in the premium home automation space. I know one of the growth drivers for Alarm.com is adding more service provider partners and that's not a direct comparison
column6: it's a different channel
column7: but just thinking about new dealers choosing a channel
column8: does this get more challenging with the Control4-SnapAV entity and any broad comments on competitive landscape changes?

column1: Steve Trundle: Sure
column2: Adam. Yes
column3: I did notice the announcement this morning. It -- from our perspective
column4: it's sort of a non-event
column5: in that we're not really seeing competition from either Control4 or SnapAV. I think both are in a bit more of the custom integrator space
column6: doing higher-end systems typically and also doing systems that are less sort of security-first
column7: or security-centric. So
column8: at times
column9: we have request to integrate with various products from both of those providers
column10: but we haven't really heard of service providers sort of standing on the doors of a customer and hearing that the customer is trying to make a choice between us and
column11: as an example
column12: Control4. In fact
column13: some customers probably have both. They're using us for security and video and Control4 for automation and maybe even using SnapAV components for a high-end AV system. So on that front
column14: I would say
column15: it's interesting
column16: but it's not really a material event from our perspective
column17: and I think the rest of the competitive landscape has sort of remained the same over the last -- over the last quarter.

column1: Adam Tindle: Okay. That's helpful. Maybe just as a follow-up
column2: I wanted to touch on guidance for Q2. The SaaS and license revenue would suggest a lower than seasonal sequential uplift. I think it's typically 4% or 5% when you strip out Icontrol historically
column3: and you're implying more like flattish. You now have the Command platform nationwide for a full quarter. Any incremental benefit from video
column4: analytics and commercial
column5: if you could just maybe speak to why we wouldn't see at least the same seasonality as before. Is there an underlying aspect of challenges in the core that's offsetting
column6: is there some conservative approach to guidance. Just trying to understand what the message implies. Thank you.

column1: Steve Trundle: Sure. Now
column2: good question. So those things you mentioned are all going relatively well. So those are -- those are thus far looking positive
column3: but I mentioned in my prepared comments that we had a nice win with SoCalGas and then they were very effective in -- actually in the first quarter
column4: adding a lot of subscribers very quickly and that generated a pretty meaningful revenue event for us in the first quarter that -- that is partially responsible for our first quarter beat. But that revenue is seasonal revenue that we would expect to see again
column5: hopefully in Q1 of 2020. It comes around once a year
column6: because it's tied to those points in time when people are actually using their heating systems
column7: and we're not going to see that revenue repeat in the second quarter. So with that sort of a drop
column8: some of those other things that you mentioned as positives are making up some of the gap
column9: but that -- that sort of is a function of the lumpiness in this demand response revenue more than anything.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from the line of Nikolay Beliov from Bank of America Merrill Lynch. Your question please.
Nikolay Beliov: Thanks for taking my questions. A question for Steve Trundle positive. Steve
column2: how do you track your progress in the commercial space? What are the key underlying metrics you look at on a regular basis to evaluate how you're guys progressing there and if you can give us the update on the percentage of service providers that you've trained to sell your commercial offering? And lastly
column3: how important is this STANLEY relationship? How big -- if you could just give us an idea of how big their market presence is.

column1: Steve Trundle: Sure. Yeah
column2: several questions there. So I'll do the best I can. I may not have all of the metrics right at my fingertips
column3: but at a high level
column4: we're watching sort of the percentage of customers coming on
column5: who we believe are commercial enterprises. And then what percentage of those are taking one of our commercial plans. And we've seen growth in both of those metrics
column6: meaning the gross commercial acquisition rate is higher
column7: some of those customers come on one of our base residential plans
column8: but a growing percentage of them are coming on one of the commercial plans. So we're watching that. And then on the Access Control side
column9: we're watching the actual number of doors being activated on the network per day
column10: or per week and we obviously -- that can't grow fast enough. The faster that's growing the better. So that's a metric we watch. I'm not going to break out exactly what that number is at this point
column11: but it's going in the right direction. With regard to STANLEY
column12: each of these -- each of our large partners
column13: it takes a while to get them trained up to speed
column14: get them -- separate their pricing and whatnot. But STANLEY is a very sophisticated operator in the commercial space and is known for real focus on operational excellence. And we therefore we're pleased with ourselves in a way that we were selected as the platform for their SMB offering. I think it's validating that a lot of the investments we've been making over the last year
column15: and that I talked about -- when I talked about our 2019 strategy
column16: are beginning to -- are beginning to come to fruition. So I would view at this point as a nice validation of our efforts. And then it will take some time to -- to really be contributing as a revenue source
column17: just like any new relationship does.

column1: Nikolay Beliov: Thanks
column2: Steve. And a really quick question for Steve Valenzuela. Steve
column3: can you help us in terms of how to model cash flow for the year? Is EBITDA less some estimate of litigation expenses
column4: less the TCPA payment kind of like a proxy of where cash flow should come in more or less?

column1: Steve Valenzuela: Yes. Nikolay
column2: this is a very good question. So if you look at last quarter
column3: we indicated that we had made the $5 million payment for the TCPA settlement in Q1. So that certainly affected the cash flow from operations and the free cash flow. Even though we recorded the expense last year
column4: it doesn't affect your cash flow statement
column5: until you actually making a payment. So if you took out that cash flow amount from Q1
column6: you would see that we were actually up year-over-year in cash flow. And then keep in mind
column7: we have an additional $23 million payment that's going to be made
column8: the remainder
column9: at some point later this year. That will affect the cash flow. But if you adjust for that
column10: let's say
column11: if you take out the $28 million one-time event here for the -- for the settlement
column12: the cash flow should be up slightly year-over-year. Whereas
column13: last year
column14: we did about $49 million in free cash flow
column15: the year before we did $47 million. And so
column16: it's still early in the year
column17: the things that could go affecting the cash flow
column18: but where we sit today
column19: we would expect cash flow to be up slightly year-over-year
column20: taking the legal settlement out of that consideration.

column1: Nikolay Beliov: Got it
column2: got it. Thanks so much.

column1: Steve Valenzuela: Sure. Thank you.
Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from the line of John DiFucci from Jefferies. Your question please.
Unidentified Analyst: Hi
column2: thanks. This is Parthiv on for John. Just a quick follow-up on the STANLEY announcement. You guys talked about the size of the commercial installed base over there. I'm just curious
column3: is there room for any of that existing installed base on the SMB side to port over to Alarm over time
column4: or is this a new bookings opportunity looking ahead?

column1: Steve Trundle: No
column2: I think over time it will be both. Our hope is that
column3: that we can provide enough value with the platform that a system manager  solution provider like STANLEY would have a vested interest in putting the majority of their customers on the platform. They get more efficiencies when they do that
column4: they're able to use the platform for a lot of business intelligence reporting
column5: customer engagement reporting
column6: customer exception reporting. So we hope that we create incentives that would allow us to compete for upgrades into the existing base. That obviously takes some time
column7: customers become acquainted with the system they already have
column8: that their employees are trained on and you don't just sort of go in overnight and switch them all up. But you look for opportunities to present to the customer additional value you can provide with an improved offering and then you make that upgrade. So I think we'll see some contribution from both parts of that business.

column1: Unidentified Analyst: Okay. And then is there any contribution from STANLEY baked into sort of the current revenue guide?
Steve Valenzuela: Typically
column2: when we actually provide guidance
column3: we are cautious not to include future programs or new programs
column4: it's still as -- just recently announced
column5: right. This is Steve Venezuela
column6: by the way
column7: so our guidance strategy is not to include new programs that are at the early stages.

column1: Unidentified Analyst: Okay
column2: got it. Thank you so much.

column1: Steve Valenzuela: Sure. Thank you.
Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from the line of David Gearhart from First Analysis. Your question please. David
column2: you might have your phone on mute.

column2: good afternoon. Sorry about that
column3: my phone was on mute. Thank you for taking my questions. My first question has to do with one of your large customers MONI or Brinks Security. Just wondering if you've seen any change in your relationship or how you're thinking about working with that client.

column1: Steve Trundle: No

column5: in some domains
column6: sort of right-sized
column7: I would say
column8: and they have focused on creating higher quality customers that are more engaged with their system. So we like that and we are treating them and acting in a way where they are just sort of a regular customer
column9: obviously a very important one. But we are not really involved in their restructuring effort and it doesn't really affect the way we work with them.

column1: David Gearhart: Okay. And then lastly
column2: could you provide an update on either -- on actually both excuse
column3: ADT and their new platform

column1: Steve Trundle: Sure. Yeah
column2: on that front
column3: what I would say is ADT reported a couple days ago
column4: I believe
column5: their results and they did spend some time speaking about the launch of their new platform. And in summary
column6: I think they are satisfied. It's early days
column7: obviously
column8: but they indicated satisfaction with how it's going and early signs of a lot of positive activity. And my perspective is
column9: if they're satisfied
column10: then we're satisfied. So that's probably about the most I can share
column11: since it's really their system at this point
column12: but I'm happy to see that it's going well and that they're satisfied with it.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from the line of Darren Aftahi from ROTH Capital Partners. Your question please.
Darren Aftahi: Hey
column2: guys. Thanks for taking my question. One think I didn't hear in the call

column4: love to get an update there

column1: Steve Valenzuela: So
column2: Darren. It's the Venezuela. So international
column3: we typically don't break out every quarter
column4: but what we can say is year-over-year we've seen good growth. And in terms of the actual accounts have been accredited
column5: the creation is up over 50% year-over-year. And so we're seeing progress. Last quarter actually Steve Trundle talked about a number of new programs in international. I think what we've mentioned in the past is these programs do take longer to launch
column6: because you're dealing with different standards
column7: different requirements in different countries
column8: but we've seen good strategic momentum internationally
column9: it just takes time to really -- to have those agreements really start generating revenue. But we have seen good growth in terms of the account creation year-over-year.

column1: Steve Trundle: One thing I would add there is
column2: is the win at STANLEY is -- STANLEY is a brand that's known well in North America
column3: but it's also -- that business is actually larger in rest of world
column4: in the security space than it is in North America. So we treat that as an international win and it's sort of good on two fronts and that it's validating on the commercial side. And then
column5: you wouldn't be able to win that business if you weren't able to scale globally. So it's validating on some of the investments we've made to build out our Rest of World presence as well.

column1: Steve Valenzuela: And I think one of your other questions was quantifying the SoCalGas program. So obviously
column2: we can't provide details of our customers' revenue. What I would say is
column3: point you to our 10-Q
column4: where we do break out the Other segment. We've seen good growth within PointCentral
column5: EnergyHub and also our other segment vertical businesses in our Other segment. Actually
column6: this quarter the Other segment
column7: which includes those businesses
column8: account for about 8% of total revenue
column9: a year ago they account for about 6.5% of revenue
column10: and achieved very strong SaaS revenue growth year-over-year. So I think that would probably help you.

column1: Darren Aftahi: Thank you.
Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from the line of Mike Latimore from Northland Capital. Your question please.
Unidentified Participant: Yeah
column2: hi. This is Pawan  on for Mike Latimore. Like
column3: can you please give an update on your video analytics service? Is there any qualitative or quantitative information related to the residential or business market?

column1: Steve Trundle: Sure
column2: so the updates are
column3: we saw the uptake steadily increasing during the first quarter. We're probably not going to break out the exact percentages of people that are taking video analytics
column4: but the adoption
column5: I would say is going the way that we had hoped it would go and I think that's because the user experience with that offering is very differentiated right now and is far superior to an offering that doesn't use intelligence to be more selective in surgical
column6: in the content that you present to the end user. So
column7: it's going well. In my prepared comments I talked about expanding the lineup of cameras that are able to work with our video analytics engine to include the rest of our commercial cameras. So we got that done in the -- in the first quarter and really until you can support the full lineup of cameras with a software feature like that
column8: you're a bit hamstrung in how quickly you can roll out
column9: but we've gotten that done in the first quarter and things are generally going pretty well with it. I think I also spoke about the Highlights feature
column10: which is only really enabled with video analytics with subscribers. So that's something we've done on the residential side
column11: primarily
column12: where we've really made an effort to give someone a short perform
column13: very quick view of everything important that's happened around their home during the day all in about 20 seconds and we're using the video analytics engine do that. So you're seeing us continue to invest in it
column14: and I think those investments will continue to drive adoption.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from the line of Jack Vander Aarde from Maxim Group. Your question please.
Jack Vander Aarde: Yeah
column2: hey guys. How many homebuilder partners do you guys now have or is that something you can share?

column2: Toll Brothers and D.R. Horton
column3: there may be others.

column1: Steve Trundle: Yes
column2: I think that's what we have spoke -- I would just say this
column3: if we -- if we do a relationship with a large national homebuilder
column4: we will attempt to announce it in some way
column5: shape or form. And if we haven't announced it
column6: you can probably assume we don't -- we're probably not in a big -- we are not really engaged with someone. And then what I would add is
column7: there are thousands of smaller homebuilders in the different local markets
column8: custom builders that may only build five homes a year. And this is a place where our service providers are very strong and that they oftentimes have relationships with those local builders and there are more relationships there than we would even know about
column9: but I would say it's a pretty high number
column10: we just don't even know what the number is.

column1: Jack Vander Aarde: Okay

Can you just discuss what specific products had a drag on gross margin and if your guidance -- maintained guidance for the year on EBITDA assumes gross margin will return to the 20% or 22% range?

column1: Steve Valenzuela: Yeah
column2: Jack
column3: typically hardware margins have ranged from 18% to 20% more recently. I know it's been -- sometimes they have been higher. The interesting thing is there is a mix even within cameras of different margin. So it really depends on the mix in that quarter. So it really is related to product mix
column4: that really is driving it
column5: even within cameras drives their product mix. I would say probably in Q1
column6: we probably had a little bit more mix of the lower margin cameras than we would probably expect. Again
column7: I would think that -- I would think that modeling 18% to 20% for hardware margins is probably a reasonable way to going forward.

column1: Jack Vander Aarde: Okay. That's helpful. Thanks
column2: guys.

Jeff Captain: Hey
column2: guys

column1: 57;ALRM;2019-08-09;"Operator: Good day
column2: ladies and gentlemen
column3: and thank you for standing by. Welcome to the Alarm.com's Second Quarter 2019 Earnings Conference Call. At this time
column4: all participants are in a listen-only mode. . Now
column5: it's my pleasure to turn the call to David Trone
column6: Vice President
column7: Investor Relations.

column1: David Trone: Thank you. Good afternoon everyone and welcome to Alarm.com's Second Quarter 2019 Earnings Conference Call. As a reminder
column2: this call is being recorded. Joining us today from Alarm.com are Steve Trundle
column3: President and CEO
column4: and Steve Valenzuela
column5: CFO.

column1: Stephen Trundle: Thanks
column2: David
column3: and welcome to everyone joining our call today. We are pleased to report another solid quarter that exceeded our expectations. SaaS and license revenue in the second quarter grew to $82.3 million
column4: up 16% year-over-year. Our non-GAAP adjusted EBITDA in the second quarter was $27.7 million. During the quarter
column5: our service providers continued to have success in the market. They added new subscribers and increasingly deployed our more advanced services. One particular area of strength for our service providers
column6: continues to be with our video services. For the first six months of the year
column7: the number of subscribers electing a video service plan is up about 40% from the first half of 2018. Adoption of our video analytics service
column8: which we initially released at the end of last year
column9: continues to grow as well. The improved user experience and quality of service enabled by video analytics is driving increased overall demand for video. Overall
column10: I am pleased with our progress in the video category. As I have stated previously
column11: we have been steadily increasing our focus in this area. We have both ramped up our internal R&D investments and made select acquisitions to strengthen our tech stack and provide a solid product to service providers. The market is highly competitive
column12: but we are competing well. In order to continue to innovate in the video category and in other growth categories like commercial and access control
column13: we have worked hard to further build out our R&D team. We ended the second quarter with an R&D team of 554 employees
column14: not including contractors. As the rest of the year unfolds
column15: we expect to continue to invest in strengthening our capacity to drive best-in-class products and innovation into the markets we serve. During the second quarter
column16: we also expanded the ecosystem of supported third-party hardware products that work with the Alarm.com platform. A particular focus was on the IoT devices that our builder channel partners desire. We added devices  Eaton and Leviton which are brands that we see builders frequently installing for lighting control. These additions fit nicely with existing integrations for audio
column17: video
column18: lock control
column19: shape control and smart thermostats. With the array of best-in-class devices available in our ecosystem
column20: builders can tailor solutions for the target buyers and the design aesthetics of a given community. This quarter
column21: we also significantly expanded our lineup of supported security control panels to give our service providers additional options to install in their customers properties. Importantly
column22: we advanced the capabilities available to our service providers
column23: by working with our existing control panel partners on new models that they are bringing to market. With expanded touch screen interfaces and our LTE dual-path gateways
column24: we can now offer new capabilities to subscribers such as display and video feeds on the control panel.

column1: Steve Valenzuela: Thanks
column2: Steve. I will begin with a review of our second quarter 2019 financial results and then provide guidance for the third quarter and our raised outlook for the full year 2019 before opening the call for questions. SaaS and license revenue in the second quarter grew 16% from the same quarter last year to $82.3 million. This includes Connect software license revenue of approximately $11 million for the second quarter compared to $10.2 million for Q2 2018. Our SaaS and license revenue renewal rate was 94% in the second quarter
column3: at the high end of our historical range of 92% to 94%. Hardware and other revenue in the second quarter of $39.3 million
column4: up 17.3% over Q2 2018. The increase in hardware revenue was primarily due to an increase in sales of our video cameras. As Steve mentioned
column5: we continue to see increasing adoption of video by both new and existing subscribers. Total revenue for the second quarter was $121.7 million
column6: up 16.4% over the same quarter last year. SaaS and license gross margin for the second quarter was 84.6%
column7: consistent with prior quarters. Hardware gross margin was 18.9% for the second quarter compared to 24% for the same quarter last year primarily due to product mix. Total gross margin was 63.4% for the second quarter compared to 65.1% for the same quarter last year
column8: mainly due to lower hardware margins.

column1: Operator: . Our first question is from Nikolay Beliov with Bank of America.
Jacqueline Cheong: Hi
column2: this is actually Jacqueline Cheong on for Nikolay. Quick question on when do you think international and commercial revenues will inflect and what is the adoption curve of customers in regards to those 2 segments?

column1: Stephen Trundle: Sure. Hi
column2: Ashley. I don't know that you'll see sort of an overnight type of inflection move in the chart. We're seeing steady sort of quarter-over-quarter increases in the number
column3: both the absolute number of customers we're putting on in both of those segments and that's sort of with a nice growth rate. But I don't think you're going to see sort of a big bang moment
column4: partially a reason for that is we're building basically a long-term path to market by educating service providers in those various segments
column5: making sure they're trained. You've got a fair amount of set-up required which of course creates its own nice barrier to entry. But we think we're making good progress long term. We can see
column6: if we think about international
column7: we've always said we think international can and eventually will be as much as a third of the business and we're sort of tracking early days at the moment
column8: but tracking towards that goal.

column1: Jacqueline Cheong: And any comment on the adoption curve of customers?
Stephen Trundle: Customers -- do you mean our commercial customers. The adoption curve of customers. I'm not sure I understand what you meant
column2: Ashely.

column1: Jacqueline Cheong: Like
column2: how do they typically roll out with Alarm.com? How does that trend over time?

column1: Stephen Trundle: Okay. So if we go -- really
column2: when we think about customers
column3: there are 2 levels. There is the service provider and that adoption cycle is typically a year of evaluation of testing of maybe some piloting
column4: some in-house work towards the end of that period. I think we
column5: of course
column6: are working to complete contracts and we are beginning the training. They're preparing their go-to-market pricing. So
column7: you're basically looking with typical meaningful service provider
column8: whether it'd be domestic going into the commercial segment or international
column9: a year
column10: maybe a little more in some cases of preparation and everyone getting comfort. You have to remember that what we offer is sort of core to their business and core to how they present themselves. So
column11: it can be a meaningful transition. Once we get that work done most partners will de-risk the process by sort of gradually turning the lights on and that process itself may take another year to year and a half as they literally go from one geography to the next
column12: to the next
column13: and begin the deployment. When you get into sort of non-US markets
column14: you do see some additional obstacles
column15: which would be
column16: regulatory environments by country may vary. So
column17: you may have a service provider that's doing business in 2 different countries that are adjacent to each other. One has different set of regulatory requirements and the other one may take a little longer
column18: but generally
column19: we think about sort of a -- from day 1 to sort of fully deployed ramp being 2 year
column20: 2.5 year type of ramp at the service provider level. Then
column21: obviously at the customer level
column22: it gets turned on
column23: it works and they're happy on day two. So once you create the end customer
column24: that adoption is very quick.

column1: Operator: Thank you. And our next question comes from Adam Tindle with Raymond James.
Adam Tindle: Steve Trundle
column2: I just wanted to start
column3: first
column4: by acknowledging obviously SaaS and license revenue growth quite healthy versus expectations. And I don't think the macro environment is great based on the results in the channel around you

column6: just hoping you could maybe take a second to parse through some of the drivers of that moderation between churn
column7: ARPU trends
column8: gross adds
column9: maybe just go through each
column10: how it's impacted so far this year
column11: and some of the potential drivers to those as the year progresses with the initiatives that you have.
