column3: we're only 6 months into the year
column4: but so far the year has progressed at a -- I'd say
column5: at a better rate than probably we expected at the beginning of the year. I think we began the year forecasting sort of a 13% growth rate on the SaaS line anyway and with the increase on guide that we have out now
column6: we've moved that up to 14.5%. So the year is -- things are probably better than we expected. I think if we go sort of to the internal market drivers
column7: it's such a diverse market and you can have parts that are doing very well while you have other parts that are a little soft. I think as you look at us
column8: you have
column9: I think
column10: Steve just commented. As example
column11: rev retention is actually going pretty well. We're at the high end of our range at 94% but you have to keep in mind that each year
column12: the base that you're attempting to retain is also getting bigger. So the impact of even that 6% is more meaningful and that's of course
column13: revenue attrition that we have to replace each year. So you have that as a driver. If we look
column14: sort of
column15: at the market right now
column16: I think
column17: we've seen slightly tighter credit market than what we're historically used to
column18: especially in North America and that can be somewhat constraining for our service providers and this really gets to sort of what -- how much will a lender loan against subscriber acquisition cost
column19: the number's a little lower now than it was probably 2 years ago. I think everyone sort of sorting out exactly what the new entrants are doing
column20: whether they are having an impact on the market. Our take is
column21: really not. I mean we've always said that the DIY and sort of the point product segment has existed. It hasn't really had an impact on our core addressable market of those people who want to have professional monitor security. That continues to be the case
column22: but folks are trying to sort that. So
column23: you've got a bunch of
column24: kind of
column25: inside the market drivers and then you have
column26: in our case
column27: certain amount of latency as we configure and operationalize various segments associated with our growth initiatives. So
column28: it's hard to predict exactly when. I think
column29: the question a moment ago was
column30: when's the inflection point. It's hard to sort of predict exactly when that inflection point will be. And there's really not ever an absolute inflection. It just takes some time to build into those initiatives. So those are some of the things we're seeing
column31: but like I said so far
column32: on a year-to-date basis
column33: we're pleased with the market being -- probably
column34: the market being a bit healthier than we would have thought at the beginning of the year.

column1: Adam Tindle: Okay. That's really helpful. And maybe just a follow up
column2: obviously acknowledging revenue performance has been very strong and raised. The adjusted EBITDA guidance is actually
column3: I think
column4: been kept at this level for a couple of quarters after some solid performance on that number and I think the benefit from the impairment charge reversal this quarter. I imagine maybe there is some exogenous factors in there. I don't know if maybe tariffs are impacting or indication for appetite for increased spending. So
column5: maybe just some of the buckets that lead you to keep the adjusted EBITDA guidance at the same level.

column1: Stephen Trundle: I think
column2: it's kind of a couple of things. So first
column3: on the opportunity side
column4: we an internal struggle for us is we're excited enough about the different opportunities that we see
column5: especially when we think about where we want the business to be in 5 to 10 years. That we really sometimes struggle to prioritize and make decisions on which domain is best to invest in. Do you invest in creating commercial for international or do you invest in additional capabilities for video for your average domestic customers. Sort of that constant tug of war that we face. And we think
column6: actually
column7: all of those or nearly all of those things that were staring at represent good places to deploy capital. So
column8: we already have sort of a natural internal tension that makes me a little bit reticent to want to put ourselves in a place where we're more constrained in the amount of investment that we can actually make to go after long-term opportunity. So
column9: I have a natural sort of desire to preserve our capacity
column10: if you will
column11: to build the company over the long haul. So you got that tension. This year's been a little bit special
column12: and probably in terms of how we've moved relative to what we initially guided. This has been a year where we've needed to keep an eye on Twitter literally and we have had some uncertainty emerge around tariffs and what those cost will be to the business. The mere sort of presence of that dynamic has at times created some disruption in the supply chain. So
column13: we've been reticent
column14: I think
column15: to get comfortable that all of those issues just sort of go away in the next month. And I think
column16: we're pleased that we've been able to stick by our prior guide but we're kind of reluctant to jump out in front of it while there is so much still going on in that domain.

column1: Operator: Our next question is from Kevin McVeigh with Credit Suisse.
Kevin McVeigh: Hey
column2: Steve
column3: I wonder if you could just flush out the approach on tariffs? Can you just remind us kind of where you are in the process today and then to the extent we get this next round
column4: how should we think about kind of sourcing and other areas versus maybe an ability to pass that on to customers?

column1: Stephen Trundle: Right. So the way we think about it
column2: yeah
column3: we've had some exposure already on a year-to-date basis with products like the Alarm.com Smart Thermostat with some of our cameras. About a third of our overall hardware product is actually produced in China. A larger component of the
column4: I mean
column5: when you get down the component level
column6: so even things that we produce in our Utica
column7: New York facility or that we produce in Mexico
column8: one of the componentry is coming from China specifically Baoding and recently we've seen List -- we know List 4 is in development. There is an emerging set of tariff costs there. So I think we're all sort of trying to figure it out
column9: but the way we think about it
column10: first
column11: we are seeing indications from our suppliers that in most cases there
column12: they're making real efforts to move effective parts of their operations to other countries that where the tariffs wouldn't apply. So we're seeing some of that transition. We are looking occasionally shifting things around. So I think
column13: if everyone had a year and knew this was coming
column14: then you'd probably see a lot of preparation for it and supply chains would have been sort of ready. I think the fact
column15: you just can't move something
column16: especially proprietary product
column17: you can't move it overnight from one place to the other. So that's the dynamic we see. In terms of the way the that costs flow through in our -- I think each company treats it differently. You try to get it out of your suppliers. So
column18: if you can't get it there
column19: at some point
column20: either the company
column21: meaning we or the end customer
column22: or someone in the middle has to absorb the tariff cost and it's sort of on a case-by-case basis by product. But generally I think our service providers understand that this is not -- you look at the gross margins
column23: we run on hardware and you look at which are intentionally low and you look at this additional cost and most are understanding that there is a new tariff cost and as long as we call that out
column24: we can pass through the bulk of it.

column1: Steve Valenzuela: Kevin
column2: one thing we've done as well is we have set up a warehouse in Taiwan for international customers. So
column3: we don't have to ship it through the U.S.
column4: bear the tariffs. So
column5: we'll go directly from Taiwan to Europe and Asia.

column1: Kevin McVeigh: That's super helpful. And then just
column2: if I heard right
column3: did you say the commercial opportunity could be about a third of revenue. If so
column4: is that primarily just based on the STANLEY deal you signed already or would that assume some penetration in the U.S. as well. And what type of time frame you think
column5: would it take to kind of get to that level of contribution?

column1: Stephen Trundle: Yeah
column2: Kevin
column3: it's Steve Trundle. I hope I said on
column4: when I threw out the third number
column5: I meant to say that we saw long-term international being about a third of our of revenue. So I think that's not a new kind of guidepost for us. We've always felt that would be the case. I don't think we've really put out an estimate on percentage of revenue long term that will be commercial. What we have said is
column6: it's kind of early days. It's a growing category. It's growing nicely right now
column7: but I don't think we're at the point of -- to project long-term percentage of revenue there.

column1: Operator: Our next question comes from Reed Motulsky with Imperial Capital.

Reed Motulsky: As the provider of the back end of the Command and Control system what will be Alarm.com's responsibilities and possibly fees regarding providing education and back up customer service for those installing the new system.
Stephen Trundle: Hi. So
column2: what are our responsibilities to -- you said to educate those installing the new Command and Control system?

column1: Reed Motulsky: Yes.
Stephen Trundle: Basically in that case
column2: Command and Control is ADT's new system and ADT is really owning the deployment of that technology and they're doing a great job with it and they take ownership of training the installers and the technicians and have been training installers and technicians for years. So it's right in their wheelhouse. Our role is really to support them the best we can making sure we're getting them any information they might need from us
column3: but we're not front and center in that educational process.

column1: Reed Motulsky: Nice and what types of pipeline discussions Alarm.com having regarding its EnergyHub subsidiary and what are the types of clients and the types of services that the company is discussing?
Stephen Trundle: So with EnergyHub
column2: it's really more of the same and I think we've indicated in prior quarters that's a place where we have some momentum. We're pleased with the management team and the entire team there and what we're trying to build out are essentially the benefits of scale. We add on each quarter. We tend to add on meaningful additional utilities who want to reduce carbon emissions and who want to be able to level load their production. And at the same time
column3: we go back and we work with the IoT companies and including almost anyone that wants to work with EnergyHub to make sure that we're able to connect to and gather information from each of those devices. So
column4: those are the basic two marching orders for that business. They're doing a good job on both of those vectors and as they continue to make progress
column5: I would say
column6: they become relevant to more utilities and likewise relevant to more IoT device makers and that's sort of what we have going on. So we didn't talk about them specifically
column7: but it's been continuing to see good progress there
column8: and those are the 2 things they're really focused on.

column1: Reed Motulsky: Got it. And can you -- I know you guys touched on Europe a bit earlier
column2: but can you guys also talk about Australia and Asia
column3: if there's any progress being made there or if it's slowed down the priorities list here?

column1: Stephen Trundle: Sure. So Australia continues to
column2: I don't think I have a meaningful update this quarter. As far as I can remember
column3: it's been sort of continued progress. We did set up an office there in Sydney. So we're beginning
column4: I think
column5: high level. You're seeing us begin to get comfortable with the long-term opportunities and markets when we make the decision to put physical offices in the ground and a location. We did that in the prior quarter in Australia. Southeast Asia's still very early
column6: more of a pipeline stage there where we are talking to service providers in each of the geographical markets
column7: but don't have any. I wouldn't say we don't have traction
column8: we're happy with the pipeline
column9: and the testing and what not
column10: but we're not driving a lot of revenue out of Southeast Asia yet.

column7: with our partners through normal course. So we've run some different types of campaigns. I think in most cases

column13: we're talking about 2022 time frame

column1: 58;ALRM;2019-11-05;"Operator: Good day
column2: ladies and gentlemen
column3: and thank you for standing by. Welcome to the Alarm.com Q3 2019 Earnings Conference Call. At this time all participants are in a listen-only mode.  I would now like to introduce host of today’s conference call Mr. David Trone
column4: Vice President of Investor Relations. You may begin.

column1: David Trone: Thank you. Good afternoon everyone and welcome to Alarm.com’s Third Quarter 2019 Earnings Conference Call. As a reminder
column2: this call is being recorded. Joining us today from Alarm.com are Steve Trundle
column3: President and CEO
column4: and Steve Valenzuela
column5: CFO.

column1: Steve Trundle: Thanks
column2: David
column3: and welcome to everyone joining our call today. We are pleased to report another solid quarter that exceeded our expectations. SaaS and license revenue in the third quarter grew to $84.9 million
column4: up 14.3% year-over-year. Our non-GAAP adjusted EBITDA in the third quarter was $26.3 million. We've had an active quarter and early fall. We introduced a number of smart home solutions and devices. In September
column5: we gathered the entire company together over the course of several days to review our long-term strategy
column6: product roadmap
column7: and progress against our goals and to better connect as a team. We also recently hosted a number of our service provider partners here in Washington DC for our Annual Partner Summit to present our latest products and R&D priorities. And in late October
column8: we announced the acquisition of OpenEye
column9: a leading provider of video management software for commercial applications. On today's call
column10: I'll focus on the new smart home products we launched and the acquisition of OpenEye. I'll close by providing some initial thoughts on our planning process for 2020. Starting with our product pipeline
column11: we launched two new residential video cameras that significantly upgrade our indoor and outdoor lineup. Both cameras
column12: presents sleek industrial designs
column13: offer increased field of view and provide enhanced picture quality even in highly variable lighting conditions. They also have substantially increased onboard compute capacity. This improves their overall performance and gives us an edge computing environment that we can use to support the more advanced video analytic capabilities that we plan to deploy in the future. A common challenge with deploying and supporting most video cameras or other IP devices is their dependence on the subscriber's Wi-Fi network. Our two new cameras have isotropic antennas that create a more uniform and efficient wireless connection. We also recently launched the Smart Gateway
column14: a device that provides a private and secure Wi-Fi network dedicated to Alarm.com video cameras. The Smart Gateway makes instillations easier and faster and reduces the likelihood of subsequent support issues caused by changes to the subscribers Wi-Fi network. These new products are examples of our ongoing goal to minimize inefficiencies associated with unmanaged Wi-Fi networks and to make it as easy as possible for our service provider partners to deploy our video services.

column1: Steve Valenzuela: Thanks Steve. I will begin with a review of our third quarter 2019 financial results and then provide guidance for the fourth quarter and our raised outlook for the full year of 2019. Before opening the call for questions
column2: SaaS and license revenue in the third quarter grew 14.3% from the same quarter last year to $84.9 million. This includes Connect software license revenue of approximately $10.8 million for the third quarter
column3: compared to $10.5 million for Q3 2018. Our SaaS and license revenue renewal rate was 94% in the third quarter at the high end of our historical range of 92% to 94%. Hardware and other revenue in the third quarter was $43 million
column4: up 14.4% over Q3 2018. The increase in hardware revenue was primarily due to an increase in sales over video cameras. Total revenue for the third quarter was $127.9 million
column5: up 14.3% over the same quarter last year. SaaS and license gross margin for the third quarter was 85.4%
column6: up approximately 90 basis points from the prior quarter
column7: mainly due to improved efficiencies we have been able to achieve in our network operations centers.

column1: Operator:  Our first question comes from Adam Tindle with Raymond James.
Madison Suhr: Hey
column2: good afternoon. This is Madison on for Adam and thanks for taking my question. I know you've been expanding your presence internationally in areas such as Brazil and Chile and also adding SaaS to existing markets. As this has expanded recently
column3: I was hoping you could talk about how this has progressed relative to your expectations and any early learnings that you can share with us. Thanks.

column1: Steve Trundle: Sure. Madison
column2: this is Steve Trundle speaking. I would say that generally the progress we've made internationally has been in line with our expectations at this point. We've had a few positives and a few bumps here and there
column3: but I think we're probably more excited about the way it's shaping up for the next 12 to 15 months than – at any period in the past it's growing
column4: it's growing at a faster rate than the rest of the business. We're – I think closing the gap on small
column5: on the set of – we're closing the gap on all the little things that you have to get right to really deploy at scale in the international market. So in general
column6: we're pleased and feel like its tracking about where we expected it to begin the year.

column1: Madison Suhr: Okay
column2: thanks. That's helpful. And then just on hardware revenue
column3: it looks like guidance implies a pretty meaningful decline on a sequential basis. I know there's a little bit of seasonality there
column4: but it's obviously above what we've seen historically. Can you just talk to some of the drivers on the hardware revenue guidance? Anything outside of just typical kind of conservatism there would be helpful? Thanks.

column1: Steve Valenzuela: Sure. This is Steve Valenzuela. Typically Q4 is seasonably the weakest quarter for hardware. If you look at past Q4 is typically the lowest hardware contribution in the quarter for the year. And that's typically tied to the holiday season and people focus on a number of other things. And so it's just typically seasonably a weaker quarter of the year for hardware.
Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from Nikolay Beliov with Bank of America.
Nikolay Beliov: Hi
column2: thanks for taking my questions. When you guys look at your business for the next 12 months
column3: I know you're still doing the plan for 2020. And look at the incremental business
column4: is there a way for you to start rank for us the major contributors by size to the incremental subscription revenues over the next 12 months. And I'm referring to maybe the new dealers you signed up
column5: expansion with existing dealers
column6: international
column7: commercial
column8: just go down the key revenue drivers. That will be helpful I think.

column1: Steve Valenzuela: Sure. I don't know if I can give you an absolutely discreet breakdown by each of those domains
column2: but I can give you some thoughts on how we think about it. And you got some of the first parts right. So we have the core North American business that's growing at a certain clip. One of the big drivers there really has been – really there are a couple of drivers that also play internationally. But especially in North America
column3: the success we've had with the video offering. And then the recent addition of analytics to the package is helping. The commercial piece in North America growing a little bit faster even this year than the residential piece for us in terms of percentage growth and still is growing off a small base but is becoming increasingly relevant. So it will be a focus next year. And obviously
column4: with the acquisition of OpenEye
column5: we're increasing our focus in that domain and even moving a bit further up the food chain to what's called the enterprise space. The international itself is a driver and growing at a nice clip and I think probably will accelerate more next year than any year in the past. I feel like a lot of things are sort of about ready at the moment. And then we have the PointCentral business where I would think our – as a growth driver will be sort of steady state
column6: next year continue to grow there. That team is moving into a couple of new segments. The biggest one being the multi-dwelling unit segment and I guess
column7: I forgot EnergyHub is the other driver where – EnergyHub benefits from scale
column8: the larger they become
column9: the more relevant they become
column10: the more utilities that are on the network. The more relevant they are to all the device makers. So that also is a growth driver for us. So those are kind of the key components of the picture that we look at. And we do a lot of bottom up modeling and then we do some top-down analysis on the segments and those are the segments that we're really focused on.

column1: Nikolay Beliov: And my second question is about margins
column2: EBITDA margins for 2020 in light of the investments. Steve
column3: you talked about
column4: I mean
column5: should we model EBITDA flat margins next year or should we model EBITDA margins down. Can you give us some clear directional sense?

column1: Steve Trundle: Yes
column2: directionally. So I definitely wanted to cover that this quarter as we start thinking about next year. And I think the way I'm thinking about it
column3: Nikolay is I'm thinking basically about where we are today. Good solid cash flow and I think solid EBITDA and I'm happy with the level we're at today. If I think about the contribution that would come from incremental growth
column4: I start – so we do plan to grow next year that will generate some incremental contribution. And I think about basically accelerating some of our growth investments by plowing that incremental contribution back into the businesses is sort of the way I'm thinking about it.

column1: Nikolay Beliov: Thank you.
Operator: Our next question comes from Kevin McVeigh with Credit Suisse.
Kevin McVeigh: Great. Hey
column2: Steve
column3: any sense of how much OpenEye impacted the quarter and then ultimately the rest of 2019?

column1: Steve Trundle: So this is – Steve
column2: you may correct me here. This is Steve Trundle. Had no impact on Q3 on the results we just reported because…

column1: Steve Valenzuela: Yes
column2: we closed it toward the end of October. This is Steve Valenzuela. So it didn't impact Q3 at all. And then in terms of how we looked at Q4
column3: I think we've only sort of been in there for a couple of weeks. So modest – very
column4: very modest impact on our model as we look at Q4 maybe a couple of million dollars were sprinkled in on the hardware and other side but not much. So really not much there. And then I think as Steve said
column5: when we kind of think about the initial picture for 2020
column6: we did model in some meaningful revenue from OpenEye on the hardware and other line into our 2020 initial look.

column1: Kevin McVeigh: Got it. And then obviously there
column2: would you think of kind of the EBITDA impact
column3: would that be reinvested as well or that would be kind of growth in 2020?

column1: Steve Valenzuela: Good question. Yes. Currently sort of – it's a business that is well run and has been run to conserve cash. And in some ways that drives a focus on selling software licenses as opposed to selling fast because you get your cash upfront. So it's sort of a nice break-even business at the moment. I think the way we think about it is we would say it's probably little under capitalized and we would prefer to capitalize the business better. Try to accelerate the growth and try to accelerate a shift to an economic model that drives down the upfront cost for the service providers and/or the end customer by shifting some of the software costs into a SaaS model that's more reflective of the way Alarm.com works.  So the way we're looking at it is
column2: while good healthy kind of could be a no impact type business where we're likely to accelerate investment into the business and would not be a massive headwind to EBITDA
column3: but would be one of the things when I talked about
column4: it’s not only some incremental profits back into the business
column5: that would be one of the areas where I would expect to be plowing.

column1: Kevin McVeigh: Got it. And then just to finish it out
column2: how should we think about this within the context of the STANLEY partnership earlier in the year and how has that been scaling on the commercial side?

column1: Steve Valenzuela: Yes
column2: good question. I don't know that we've sort of matched those two initiatives just yet. I think in the case of OpenEye there
column3: there are about 400 existing service providers and system integrators who are their partners. And there's very little overlap in that group. So the great thing is similar business model to us
column4: but very little overlap in the actual established partnerships. And I honestly can't remember whether STANLEY is one or not. But what I would say is as we think about our service providers
column5: we feel like and this is inclusive of all of them. We feel like the product that we're adding to our stack with OpenEye will be relevant particularly to those on the high end of the space. And you've identified one where they're needing to install in some cases a couple of hundred cameras on a given customer site. So that's where it's particularly relevant and there may be a fit there
column6: but I don't think we've connected that just yet.

column1: Kevin McVeigh: Great. Thanks so much.
Steve Valenzuela: Thanks.

David Gearhart: Hi
column2: good afternoon. Thank you for taking my questions. I wanted to come back to OpenEye just briefly
column3: a mix between hardware and license. Should we expect directionally a lift on the hardware and other gross margin side
column4: as we go forward into Q4 and maybe in the next year?

column1: Steve Trundle: Yes
column2: good question. Steve
column3: do you want to take that one?

column1: Steve Valenzuela: Yes
column2: I think the gross margins for OpenEye for hardware are higher than our typical gross margins. So there would be a little bit of a lift in the overall gross margins for Alarm.com. But basically I think it's around 25% of what we're going to be taking from OpenEye or what's contributing there is software
column3: which is pretty high margin revenue relative to what we see on typical hardware revenue. So their contribution would provide us a bit of a tailwind on the gross margins on the hardware and other line item because such a meaningful component of it is actually software.

column1: Steve Trundle: That's right.
David Gearhart: Okay. Got it. And then I wanted to ask
column2: Steve V
column3: in terms of the tariff issue that's been talked about the last couple of quarters
column4: what are you seeing on that front. And would you say directionally you're more positive on guidance or you're maintaining your expectations on the tariff front and in your current outlook?

column1: Steve Valenzuela: We certainly have
column2: as we've talked about in the past
column3: we certainly have been incurring costs related to tariffs. We've been absorbing some of those. We've been able to pass some of that on. And so we still take a cautious view on tariff
column4: we don’t know when the next tweet is going to come out
column5: so we have to be careful. But I would say
column6: we're just – we're being cautious when it comes to tariffs.

column1: Steve Trundle: I would add a little color though
column2: which is
column3: it hasn't quite been the big event that maybe we expected it could be
column4: there are material additional costs. We're incurring some of those costs
column5: but does not seem to have affected demand. And I think that's probably because we and our service providers sort of figured out the right amount of these incremental costs that we should absorb and what sort of the right amount that the customer may be willing to absorb without materially altering demand. So
column6: while they're still relevant and we look forward to them potentially going away
column7: it hasn't really been the big event that I think maybe we were fearful of three
column8: six months ago.

column1: David Gearhart: Okay. And then last for me
column2: litigation expense
column3: roughly $2 million
column4: from the quarter down sequentially. Can you give us any sense of what we should expect
column5: just in absolute dollars for litigation should we model flat for the next year on 2020? That's it for me. Thank you.

column1: Steve Valenzuela: Yes
column2: it's a really hard to predict litigation expense as you said for Q3 it was $2 million down compared to $5 million Q3 2018 if you exclude the TCPA settlement. So it does kind of bump around at around a $3 million to $5 million per quarter level depending upon when the events concur. So it's always hard to predict when litigation matters come to the higher level of the case. But I would say if you look at in 2018
column3: litigation expense was around $17 million not including the TCPA settlement. In 2017
column4: it was $7 million. And then in 2016
column5: it was around $14 million. So going forward
column6: I think if you're modeling around the historical range around the $14 million to $17 million
column7: but again
column8: that's a caveat with
column9: it's very hard to predict what cases will come forward. It's hard to predict when the costs will be incurred.

column1: David Gearhart: Got it. Thank you.
Steve Trundle: Sure.
Operator: Our next question comes from Darren Aftahi with Roth Capital.
Darren Aftahi: Hey guys
column2: thanks for taking my questions. A couple if I may. First
column3: I guess for Steve Trundle. You talk about investments
column4: why strategically is now the right time to kind of reinvest in all of these areas of the business you kind of mentioned?

column1: Steve Trundle: Yes
column2: I think it's
column3: because we have tipped our toes in the water in a number of domains. I think
column4: one being commercial
column5: one being international. I can say the same thing about the HVAC segment. So
column6: so in a few cases that an energy hub for that matter
column7: we have
column8: we have been kind of playing delicately and not fully committing
column9: but I think you do that and you basically wait for the business to show you that it's worthy of being filled. And I think we're at a point now where we feel more confident that a number of these efforts are worthy of capital allocation and will drive positive results with some additional scale. So that's one thing. The second I would say is
column10: I feel like we've gotten to a healthy level of cash production that allows us to be sort of forward leaning at with our Corp Dev activities and I don't want to go to the point that we're entirely driving growth with Corp Dev when we have so many great organic initiatives that are also worthy of capital allocation. So
column11: I think we're at a nice point in terms of mix of cash production in of positive points with a number of these efforts. And therefore
column12: I thought now is a good time to
column13: I think we're not saying tomorrow by the way. We still have three
column14: four months of this year to go through and then we'll really get into the details of planning out next year. But I felt like now is a good time for us to begin to think about how we're going to operate the business next couple of years in terms of the...

column1: Steve Valenzuela: And I would add to that
column2: we've built a very good balance sheet. We have strong – Steve talked about strong cash flows. And again
column3: if you look at last year
column4: for 2019
column5: the EBITDA is I think – as I had around the guide is over a $100 million
column6: over $102 million about which is a good amount of EBITDA. This year
column7: if you exclude the TCPA payments
column8: we're going to probably generate about $65 million of cash flow
column9: which is very good amount of cash generation. So
column10: I think we're at the point where we've got the business with good balance sheet
column11: good cash flow generation and so the opportunity there is given all the opportunities with commercial
column12: with video analytics
column13: with international
column14: EnergyHub and PointCentral all of those are really coming to the forefront of being ready for investment that we think will yield growth for the future.

column1: Darren Aftahi: Great. That's helpful. A couple more if I may. Just with the integration of OpenEye
column2: how do we think about your service provider base? I think in the past you've talked about I think it's well over a thousand and be  on your core commercial
column3: but when you integrate these two platforms together
column4: going into 2020
column5: like it'd be a lot. How do we think about your service provider base vis-à-vis type commercial strategy?

column1: Steve Trundle: Yes. So
column2: I think that by early part of next year we will be providing a path for a set of service providers to become certified in the OpenEye solution as efficiently as possible and will enable those folks who service markets that are relevant to OpenEye to become OpenEye service providers. We'll make that easy for them. We'll do some integrations with various parts of our offering back into the OpenEye platform and vice versa. So we'll begin a couple things. There are some fairly low hanging fruit that we can go after initially in terms of simple integrations and then we'll get to work on probably the more sophisticated integrations on things like the video analytics piece. But so the nice thing is there's not a ton of overlap right now. I think there will be some service providers that we enable by the first quarter
column3: second quarter assuming that they're interested and adding the OpenEye offering to their solution set. And that's kind of how we're thinking about it. The same time we think the business is good on its own and we want to avoid sort of interfering with the business or doing things that would cause it to change trajectory on where it is other than maybe what I discussed a moment ago where I talked about the value we see in driving down some of the upfront costs by shifting to a bit more of a SaaS model.

column1: Darren Aftahi: That's helpful. Thank you. And then lastly
column2: just what was the other SaaS revenue in the quarter?

column1: Steve Valenzuela: It was $5 million up about 45% year-over-year for other SaaS
column2: for the other segment.

column1: Darren Aftahi: Great. Thank you guys.
Steve Trundle: Sure.
Operator: Our next question comes from you Nehal Chokshi with Maxim Group.
Nehal Chokshi: Yes
column2: thanks. So this OpenEye acquisition is a pretty exciting
column3: I think. And so a lot more questions on this first
column4: was this a competitive process?

column1: Steve Trundle: I'm sorry
column2: what?

column1: Steve Valenzuela: Was it a competitive process?
Steve Trundle: A competitive process? Yes
column2: what I would say is that they had retained
column3: they had a retained banking relationship that was exploring a few options. I think in terms of a strategic
column4: we were the
column5: we were sort of the only one that was invited to consider the situation. So yes
column6: it was sourced. It wasn't
column7: a big action but yes
column8: so.

column1: Nehal Chokshi: Understood. That's helpful. And then who would you consider OpenEye’s biggest competitor today?

Steve Trundle: There are a set of folks I want to avoid naming any single one but a set of fairly established traditional MDR players who deliver software and MDRs that normally sit onsite and allow you to monitor hundreds of cameras without really a lot of cloud apparatus included. So OpenEye already is a cloud oriented provider and that's really the big piece of differentiation is they allow you to manage the entire deployment through the cloud. If you want to share resources
column2: you do that through the cloud. So it's already implemented as a hybrid cloud/on premise model. They've gravitated to more of an on premise traditional pricing scheme primarily because of the cash flow benefit that drives through a company that's self funded. But there are three or four large players that are in the traditional space. And then there are a handful of startups like OpenEye. I think on the destructor list OpenEye is probably the leader and there are a couple of others that are driving entirely cloud driven architectures. But I would say they'd probably have more traction than any of them.

column1: Nehal Chokshi: Right. Are any of those established players Chinese vendors that have been recently put a place on the restricted list and maybe be creating some disruption that you guys can go and take advantage of?
Steve Trundle: Well
column2: I think that – that dynamic creates some additional opportunity in that OpenEye is also is open
column3: which means while they have eight to 10 of proprietary cameras that they offer
column4: they support probably 12
column5: 15 different partners who – when you go to a large commercial site
column6: they don't want to be told that you need to replace all of the cameras they've installed over the last three or four years around the location so that you can run the OpenEye software. They want you to work with what's there. And that's driven the company to be fairly open and partner oriented
column7: support a wide range of cameras
column8: including a number who are not on any type of list or having
column9: that may have any of those liabilities associated with them. So
column10: that was another attractive element of this opportunity.

column1: Nehal Chokshi: Got it. And then finally has the lack of the VMS or the VSaaS been an issue for driving the adoption of Alarm’s other commercial offerings?
Steve Trundle: I would say that not entirely
column2: because we have not gone after the segments that they're focused on. So we've probably
column3: we're working within a small
column4: slightly smaller TAM than what is conceivable with the OpenEye solution. And in our case
column5: a typical installation will be anywhere from two to 30 cameras. And the way the video is on the commercial side is consumed is normally through an iPad or an iPhone or some other mobile device.  In their case
column6: a typical installation could be hundreds of cameras that all need to be managed through a similar or through a single software stack. And the majority of it will be consumed by a person that's sitting in a guard station
column7: with 30 or 40 different cameras alternating in the proprietary user interface. So
column8: that part of the market that they serve
column9: customers like Gonzaga University or Olive Garden
column10: some of these large sort of distributed players
column11: Bed Bath & Beyond that's a segment that we haven't really targeted with our commercial offering today. And therefore
column12: I wouldn't say we've been hindered
column13: but now we have an opportunity through OpenEye to target more of that segment.

column1: Nehal Chokshi: Okay. Thank you.
Steve Trundle: Thank you.

column1: 59;ALRM;2020-02-25;"Operator: Ladies and gentlemen
column2: thank you for standing by and welcome to the Alarm.com Fourth Quarter 2019 Earnings Conference Call. At this time all participants are in a listen-only mode. After the speaker's presentation
column3: there will be a question-and-answer session.  Please be advised that today's conference is being recorded.  I will now hand the conference over to the Vice President of Investor Relations
column4: David Trone.

column1: David Trone:
Steve Trundle: Thank you
column2: David. Good afternoon
column3: and welcome to everyone. We are pleased to report that fourth quarter results were above our expectations. Our SaaS and license revenue in the fourth quarter was $90.1 million
column4: up 15.7% over last year. Our adjusted EBITDA in the fourth quarter was $30 million. Our fourth quarter results helped close out a strong 2019 with annual revenue exceeding $0.5 billion for the first time in our company's history. I want to thank our service provider partners
column5: our ecosystem partners
column6: and our employees who enabled us to achieve this revenue milestone. Today
column7: more than 9
column8: 000 service providers sell and service our technology to their customers in more than 6.8 million properties in over 40 countries around the world. Alarm.com manages more than 100 million connected devices and sensors through our cloud services. On our last call at the end of Q3
column9: I spoke about our increasing confidence in several growth areas as well as our intent to step up our level of organic investment to more fully capitalize on the opportunities we see. That process is underway. On today's call
column10: I will review some of the elements of our strategy in 2020 and touch upon the growth areas where we are investing. First
column11: we are working hard to extend our position as the most innovative platform provider for service provider businesses that want to capitalize on the wide set of emerging IoT-driven monitoring applications. This requires that we continue to build the scale across our technology stack and operations. We are aiming to fully address opportunities across the single-family and multifamily residential markets
column12: the small business market
column13: and the enterprise commercial market. For each property type
column14: we are aiming to provide fully integrated
column15: fully supported best-in-class applications in the areas of security
column16: automation
column17: energy management
column18: water management and health. And we will deliver these applications across geographies and languages
column19: such that
column20: we can drive growth in both our North American and international businesses.

column1: Steve Valenzuela: Thank you
column2: Steve
column3: and good afternoon
column4: everyone. I will start with a review of our fourth quarter and full year 2019 financial results and then provide guidance for 2020 before opening the call for questions. SaaS and license revenue in the fourth quarter grew 15.7% from the same quarter last year to $90.1 million. This includes Connect software license revenue of approximately $10.6 million for the fourth quarter
column5: down from $10.7 million in the year-ago quarter. The drop in Connect license revenue is expected as our customer who we licensed the Connect software too is focused on rolling out their new platform on Alarm.com SaaS software that we operated host for the service provider.

column1: Operator: Thank you.  And our first question is from Nikolay Beliov with Bank of America.
Jacqueline Cheong: Hi
column2: this is Jacqueline Cheong on for Nikolay. Thanks for taking the question. Can you please double-click on how commercial is doing and the progress there? And when would we expect it to kind of ramp up and hit some sort of inflection point?

column1: Steve Trundle: Sure Jacqueline. This is Steve speaking. So
column2: yes
column3: commercial is doing pretty well. We -- it grew at an accelerated pace last year. We obviously made the OpenEye acquisition to further strengthen our commercial story and particularly
column4: strengthen our story in the enterprise market. So
column5: when was -- when is it going to be sort of a real down move
column6: I'd say it's already positively impacting our business. And as we build the base of service providers who promote install of a commercial offering
column7: we should see it continue to accelerate. I would say we're at roughly 10% of service providers right now are trained and marketing the offering in the commercial space and we expect that number to continue to grow.

column1: Jacqueline Cheong: Got it. Thank you. And could you talk about like what training is required? And how -- why aren't we seeing more sort of providers trained on the commercial platform?
Steve Trundle: Well
column2: first
column3: just keep in mind
column4: sheer numbers. So
column5: with 9
column6: 000 service providers when they say 10%
column7: that means that in a relatively short period of time
column8: 900 have come up and are actively beginning to solve the offering. Second is a lot of them are busy in the residential space. If you're a service provider
column9: you have to make a decision do I want to stay focused on the business that's good in the residential space or I wanted to begin to divert resources into the commercial space quite a few have a preference for sort of saying where they're strong and focusing on the residential space. And that's fine with us. That's a great market. But with the improvements to the offering we're continuing to recruit more service providers that already have a history of competing in the commercial enterprise space. And in terms of training
column10: it's a lot of block and tackle execution. It's trading on everything from how to install door strikes to how to price
column11: how to sell
column12: it really depends on the experience of the service provider with -- or in the commercial space already how much of that training is actually necessary. But with our products
column13: we do take a service provider through a certification process.

column1: Jacqueline Cheong: Got it. Got it. Thank you. And if I could just put in one more. Just also wanted to hear about how international is doing? It sounds like we're seeing a little bit of a ramp
column2: but when do we expect an inflection in this segment as well?

column1: Steve Trundle: Yes. So I think we're definitely seeing a ramp. Our service providers internationally are executed well in 2019 I would say and some of the investments we have made in prior years. I think in prior years people have asked well how long does it take? What do you have to do? What are the steps? And I sort of went into a refrain of similar types of things. You have to train you have to get your pricing set. You have to make sure all the ecosystem products are working for a given market. A lot of that came together in 2019 and we saw enough service providers really succeeding on the execution side that we gain confidence in that part of the business partially in the back half of the year. And we expect rough numbers we ended the year with well over to -- or very close to or over 200
column2: 000 non-North American subscribers and we're seeing an acceleration of kind of installed rate. So
column3: I don't know what we necessarily characterize as an inflection
column4: but we see good solid momentum there and that's one of the drivers for why we are going to continue to step up our efforts to cater to the international markets.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from Adam Tindle with Raymond James. Please go ahead.
Adam Tindle: Okay. Thanks and good afternoon. I just wanted to start with the 2020 guidance
