column93: as expected. And as we move ahead into the March quarter
column94: I'd like to review our outlook
column95: which includes the types of forward-looking information that Nancy referred to at the beginning of the call. We expect revenue to be between $51.5 billion and $53.5 billion. This guidance range includes a $1.2 billion year-over-year headwind from foreign exchange. We expect gross margin to be between 38% and 39%. This guidance range includes an 80 basis points sequential headwind from foreign exchange. We expect OpEx to be between $6.5 billion and $6.6 billion. We expect OI&E to be about $400 million
column96: and we expect the tax rate to be about 26%. Also today
column97: our Board of Directors has declared a cash dividend up $0.57 per share of common stock
column99: 2017 to shareholders of record as of February 13
column101: I'd like to open the call to questions.

column1: Nancy Paxton: And we ask that you limit yourself to one one-part question and one follow-up. Operator
column2: may we have the first question
column3: please?

column1: Operator: Your first question will come from Katy Huberty with Morgan Stanley.
Kathryn Lynn Huberty: Yes
column2: thank you. First
column3: Luca
column4: what are the factors that caused you to widen the gross margin guidance for the March quarter? And what are the one or two factors that put you at the low end versus the tailwinds that might put you at the high end of that range? And then I have a follow-up
column5: thank you.

column1: Luca Maestri: Sure
column2: Katy. If you look back at our history
column3: 100 basis points range for gross margin is not unusual. Clearly during a period when foreign exchange is very volatile
column4: we think it's more prudent to broaden the range a bit. I've mentioned that we expect – assuming that rates don't move too much
column5: we expect foreign exchange to be a major negative as we move from the December to the March quarter. You know that the dollar has appreciated significantly toward the end of the December quarter
column6: and so we've got 80 basis points of sequential headwind from foreign exchange. We also have the sequential loss of leverage
column7: which is typical of our seasonality
column8: but we expect to offset these two impacts with cost efficiencies and also with our mix of products and services. So obviously if the dollar is a little less strong than it is today
column9: we could do a bit better on gross margins. Obviously
column10: we continue to work very hard on our cost efficiency
column11: so we'll see where we land.

column1: Kathryn Lynn Huberty: Thank you. And
column2: Tim
column3: there's a reasonable probability that you may get access to the $200 billion-plus of cash that's been locked overseas. So I think it would be helpful to just get an update on your views around potentially larger M&A and some of the areas of interest that you've noted in the past like owning more original content to penetrate more of the TV opportunity that the company has long talked about addressing. Thank you.

column1: Timothy Donald Cook: Katy
column2: I am optimistic given what I'm hearing that there would likely be some sort of tax reform this year
column3: and it does seem like there are people in both parties that would favor repatriation as a part of that. So I think that's very good for the country and good for Apple. What we would do with it
column4: let's wait and see exactly what it is. But as I said before
column5: we are always looking at acquisitions. We acquired 15 to 20 companies per year for the last four years. And we look for companies of all sizes
column6: and there's not a size that we would not do based on just the size of it. It's more about the strategic value of it. In terms of original content
column7: we have put our toe in the water with doing some original content for Apple Music
column8: and that will be rolling out through the year. We are learning from that
column9: and we'll go from there. The way that we participate in the changes that are going on in the media industry that I fully expect to accelerate from the cable bundle beginning to break down is
column10: one
column11: we started the new Apple TV a year ago
column12: and we're pleased with how that platform has come along. We have more things planned for it but it's come a long way in a year
column13: and it gives us a clear platform to build off of. Two
column14: embedded in the 150 million paid subscriptions that I mentioned in my opening comments
column15: there are a number of third-party services that are a part of that
column16: where we participate economically in some of that by offering our platform in selling and distributing. And then thirdly
column17: we are obviously
column18: with our toe in the water
column19: we're learning a lot about the original content business and thinking about ways that we could play at that. Thanks for the question.

column1: Kathryn Lynn Huberty: Thank you.
Nancy Paxton: Thanks
column2: Katy. Could we have the next question
column3: please?

column1: Operator: We'll go to Amit Daryanani with RBC Capital Markets.
Amit Daryanani: Thanks a lot. Good afternoon guys. I guess the first question
column2: I really appreciate the information you guys are providing around your Services business
column3: which is up 18% year over year. Can you just talk about? How much of that do you think is growth in your installed base versus increased monetization on a per iOS to iOS basis? And so we are to think about those in two separate tranches?

column1: Luca Maestri: I think you're absolutely right
column2: Amit. We look at it that those are the two key elements for us. And what is particularly interesting to us is to see that the number of people that are transacting on our stores is increasing strong double-digits
column3: and we're also seeing that the ARPU per paying customer is increasing double digits
column4: right. So it's a combination of the two. Obviously
column5: the quality and the quantity of content that we make available in our services improves all the time. And we also see that as people getting to the platform and start transacting on the platform
column6: and we keep track of their behavior over time
column7: we actually see that they tend to spend more and more over time. And that's why we are excited about the future of the Services business. And that's why
column8: as Tim said
column9: we have a goal that – it's already become a very large business. It's going to be a Fortune 100 company this year
column10: but we have a goal to double it over the next four years.

column1: Amit Daryanani: Perfect. And if I could just switch gears on a follow-up
column2: there has been a fair amount of discussions around your market share in China and what's happening over there. Your numbers actually look fairly impressive in Greater China
column3: China specifically. So could you just talk about what are the demand trends you're seeing there on the ground
column4: and how do you see that transpire through the year?

column1: Timothy Donald Cook: Yeah
column2: I'll take this one. If you look at how we did in the quarter
column3: as I think Luca shared
column4: our Greater China revenue was down 12%
column5: and about 4 points of that was currency related
column6: so it's an 8 point decline in constant currency. And then within Greater China
column7: if you look at the PRC
column8: our revenue was flat year over year
column9: and that was against the all-time record quarter. And if you look at that on a constant currency basis
column10: it was actually up 6%. So it's a significantly better performance on every way you look at it versus what we had experienced the prior three quarters. Underneath that
column11: what we've seen is that iPhone 7 was the best-selling smartphone in China during the quarter
column12: according to Kantar. Singles Day
column13: which is a huge day in China
column14: as you know
column15: we were the most popular U.S. brand on Alibaba. We set a new record for Services in China
column16: as the company did. And Mac revenue was up double digit year over year. iPad units were also up double digit in Mainland China
column17: which was obviously different than the trend that we saw in the balance of the world. We also saw 50% of our iPhone sales in China were to switchers and first-time buyers
column18: which is a very high number that we're pleased with. And obviously
column19: our total installed base continues to grow there in the strong double digits. That said
column20: the challenges that are there are
column21: one
column22: the currency has devalued 6% year over year. And two
column23: Hong Kong remains a very
column24: very difficult market. And so I look at it in – I'm encouraged with the significant improvement
column25: but we're not without challenges there. And I wouldn't want to imply that
column26: although I do like many
column27: many things that I've seen and how broad-based the pluses were across our product line.

column1: Nancy Paxton: Thank you
column2: Amit. Could we have the next question
column3: please?

column1: Operator: From Cross Research
column2: Shannon Cross.

column1: Shannon S. Cross: Thank you very much for taking my question. Can you talk a bit more about the Services business? And what I'm trying to figure out is I think the number was you're going to be doubling within the next four years
column2: at least that's your expectation. So what gets you there? I don't know
column3: maybe if you talk about geographies and how penetrated you are in certain geographies. And then
column4: as you grow your Services business
column5: is there anything we should keep in mind from a margin perspective? Would these be lower margin services or similar
column6: just so we can think about the trajectory and the contribution to the bottom line.

column1: Luca Maestri: Yeah
column2: Shannon
column3: I'll take it. Obviously
column4: within the Services business
column5: we have a number of categories. The App Store is the one that is driving significant growth right now. I said in my opening comments that we grew 43% 13 weeks over 13 weeks
column6: a little even more for the quarter
column7: right. And what we like about the App Store is that it's truly a global platform. So we are seeing significant growth not only in the developed markets
column8: where you expect to see a lot of transaction volume
column9: but we see great growth in places like China
column10: for example. And we know that there are parts of the world where we can do better. We can grow
column11: for example
column12: our developer community in a number of emerging markets. And so as we look
column13: as I was explaining earlier
column14: as we look at the number of people that transact growing double digits
column15: we see the amount spent per paid account growing so well
column16: we think that the App Store is going to be a significant driver of growth. On the music front
column17: we are the market leader in digital music. Obviously now
column18: by having the combination of the download business with the streaming service
column19: which we didn't have until recently
column20: we've been able to bring our music business back to growth. We've grown over the last three quarters
column21: and we feel very good about that. Tim has talked about original content. We've had very good success with exclusives. So we know that it's another business that we can grow. Our iCloud storage business is growing very quickly
column22: and so that is a business that also at a geographic level we can continue to grow significantly. Our AppleCare business is growing very well. A lot of it comes from the fact that our install base of devices around the world continues to grow very well
column23: strong double digits. And as we've explained in the past
column24: the vast majority of the services that we provide is not driven by what we sell during the last 90 days. It's much more driven by the install base
column25: and that gives us a tailwind. We're also opening up several new markets because we are accepting new forms of payment. And therefore
column26: it's easier particularly for international customers to take advantage of our services. You were asking about the margin profile. We said many times
column27: in aggregate our Services business tends to have margins that are above company average. They are accretive
column28: so they help us quite a bit from a margin standpoint. Within the Services business
column29: we have very different margin profiles
column30: also because
column31: as you know
column32: we account for some of these services in different ways. In some cases
column33: we transact on a buy/sell basis. In other cases
column34: we perform as agents
column35: for example
column36: to our developers
column37: and that drives different margin percentages.

column1: Shannon S. Cross: Thank you. And then my follow-up is just in terms of the elasticity of demand and some of the moves from a currency perspective. I think in the past there was some concern in some of the emerging markets the you were basically not able to – you weren't you're getting the volumes because you had to raise ASPs given the currency. But you talked about a lot of the emerging markets actually doing pretty well this quarter. So I'm just curious. You raised the price on the iPhone 7 Plus and that. What are you seeing
column2: and what are your customers saying in terms of willingness to pay up?

column1: Luca Maestri: Shannon
column2: I was looking back. Since June of 2014
column3: so we're talking about 2.5 years ago
column4: the dollar has strengthened 25% against the basket of currencies where we do business. And so obviously
column5: it is a difficult situation for us. I've mentioned that foreign exchange is a significant headwind for us
column6: both at the revenue level and at the gross margin level. In emerging markets
column7: it's incredible. The level of interest for our products continues to be phenomenal. The brand continues to be very aspirational. There are more and more people that can afford our products around the world. The middle class is growing in places like China
column8: India
column9: Brazil
column10: but certainly the strong dollar doesn't help us. And therefore
column11: when we make pricing decisions
column12: we need to be very careful. We always want to find the optimal balance between units
column13: revenue
column14: and margin
column15: and it becomes more difficult as the dollar appreciates.

column1: Nancy Paxton: Thank you
column2: Shannon. Could we have the next question
column3: please?

column1: Operator: Moving on
column2: we'll hear from Brian White with Drexel.

column1: Brian J. White: Luca
column2: I'm wondering if you could talk a little bit about gross margins. Sales obviously beat the high end of your revenue range. It looks like gross margin was dead down the middle. Can you talk about the puts and takes in gross margins in the quarter
column3: please?

column1: Luca Maestri: Sure. We were actually at the high end of the range for gross margins. We had guided 38% to 38.5%
column2: and we came in at 38.5% exactly. And really
column3: the slight improvement over the midpoint of the guidance range was due to the fact that our revenue was ahead of our expectations
column4: and so we got a bit more leverage out of the increased revenue levels. We felt very good about the gross margins for the quarter. Again
column5: keep in mind the strong dollar doesn't help us on that front.

column1: Brian J. White: Okay. And
column2: Tim
column3: I didn't hear much mentioned about India. How did India perform with the iPhone? And how should we think about it for 2017
column4: especially with the 4G network going up?

column1: Timothy Donald Cook: That's a really good question. Despite the demonetization move in India that created lots of economic pressure there last quarter
column2: despite that
column3: we had all-time record revenue results
column4: and so we were very happy about that. The demonetization impact has not worked its way through yet. It's still definitely having some overhang. But I think in the longer term
column5: it's a great move
column6: and I feel really good about how we're doing there. We are in discussions on a number of things
column7: including retail stores
column8: and fully intend to invest significantly in the country and believe it's a great place to be.

column1: Nancy Paxton: Thank you
column2: Brian. Could we have the next question
column3: please?

column1: Operator: From Goldman Sachs
column2: we'll hear from Simona Jankowski.

column1: Simona K. Jankowski: Hi
column2: thank you. I wanted to dig in a little bit more into the iPhone upside in the quarter with record revenues in every region except for Greater China. I think you touched on the percent of switchers in China. But can you give a little more color on the split of upgrades and switchers in some of the other regions and overall as well?

column1: Timothy Donald Cook: Simona
column2: it's Tim. We did have an exceptional quarter with iPhone
column3: and that was with the backdrop of not predicting the demand very well on the iPhone 7 Plus and therefore being in constraint on it through the quarter. If you look at the absolute number of upgraders
column4: it was the highest that we've seen in any quarter. And if you look at the switcher number
column5: it's the highest that we've seen in any quarter. If you look at the upgrade rate
column6: it's similar to last year. However
column7: I think the big asterisk – I share all this with you for transparency's sake. I would tell you that the way we look at this is in a quarter where you have a supply constraint
column8: it's difficult to draw too many conclusions from it. But I wanted to share that with you anyway so you have the backdrop.

column1: Simona K. Jankowski: Thank you
column2: and then just one follow-up on China specifically. As your comps get easier this year
column3: I was curious if you think you're going to be returning to growth in that region. And then just to give us the context
column4: I know you talked about the 6% constant currency increase in revenue in Mainland China. But curious if you strip out the double-digit increase in iPad and MacBook and potentially the mix shift to the iPhone 7 Plus
column5: I'm curious what underlying iPhone units did in Mainland China.

column1: Timothy Donald Cook: That's a big question
column2: and I don't have the answer in front of me. If you look at iPhone 7 Plus
column3: it was the most popular Plus model that we've ever had. It set a unit record
column4: so that I can share. In terms of how are we going to do
column5: we don't provide guidance at the segment level. But sitting here today
column6: for Q2
column7: I wouldn't expect the year-over-year performance to be dramatically different than the year-over-year performance in Q1. The real comp really begins in the following quarter to a more significant degree
column8: and we'll have to see how that plays out as we get closer to it.

column1: Simona K. Jankowski: Thank you.
Timothy Donald Cook: Yes.
Nancy Paxton: Thank you
column2: Simona. Could we have the next question
column3: please?

column1: Operator: From Bernstein
column2: Toni Sacconaghi.

column1: Antonio M. Sacconaghi: Yes
column2: thank you. I just wanted to better understand the upgrade rate dynamics. So I think iPhone units on a sell-through basis were up about 8%. You had an extra week
column3: which gave you about 8%. I understand there were differences of the timing of the launch. So making all those adjustments
column4: it looks like iPhone units were probably up low single digits. But
column5: Luca
column6: you alluded to the fact that your install base was growing double digits. So that would suggest to me that the upgrade rate
column7: the upgrade percentage is actually declining. And more specifically
column8: I'd just like your broader perspective on how investors should think about upgrade rates. It looked like they peaked in the iPhone 6 cycle
column9: and it looks like they've been extending – going lower. Replacement cycles have been extending over the last couple years. I think some of the U.S. carriers alluded to that as well. So I'm wondering if you could step back and just talk a little bit more broadly about how investors should think about or what the trajectory has been over the last two years and how investors should think going forward. Do you believe there are opportunities for that upgrade rate to improve or replacement cycles to accelerate going forward? And what are some of the considerations we should think about?

column1: Luca Maestri: I think it's a good question
column2: a number of points that I want to make. Starting with the growth in the install base of iPhones
column3: yes
column4: it's growing strong double digits
column5: and that's very good for us for a number of reasons
column6: including the fact that it's a big driver for our Services business. When we look at it geographically
column7: I think we see different developments. For example
column8: we felt very
column9: very good about the unit growth that we had in many markets around the world. You've been quoting an overall total company growth rate. But when we look at a country-specific level
column10: there were a lot of countries
column11: I would say the majority of the countries
column12: where iPhone units grew strong double digits
column13: starting here in the United States
column14: where for example
column15: the fact that annual upgrade programs are becoming more and more popular is proving to be a positive for us. Same happened in a number of countries around the world
column16: starting with Canada and Australia but also many places in Western Europe as well. Japan grew double digits in terms of units. So I think geographically we are seeing very
column17: very good performance. The point that I think I need to make when you think about upgrade rates
column18: clearly
column19: this issue of the strong dollar doesn't help us. Could we sell significantly more and significantly faster from an upgrade cycle standpoint in places outside the United States
column20: where we've been forced to increase prices by up to 20%
column22: 40% in certain countries? And you think about the impact that this is having on local demand
column23: obviously that doesn't help us. But overall
column24: I would say as Tim said
column25: when we look at the upgrade rate for and we look at it from the standpoint of the new phones
column26: right
column27: the new generation phones
column28: the upgrade rate
column29: the percentage of people that have upgraded to the new phone has been very similar to what we've seen last year. The 6 cycle was certainly a phenomenal cycle. There was pent-up demand for the larger screen phones. And certainly as we look ahead
column30: we have a role to play. The more we're able to innovate with new generations of products
column31: clearly that plays a role in the upgrade rate.

column1: Antonio M. Sacconaghi: Okay
column2: thank you. Tim
column3: I have a question for you. Back in April 2012
column4: you said on one of these earnings calls that I've always hated litigation and I continue to hate it
column5: and I highly prefer to settle versus battle. Yet you recently decided to initiate a lawsuit against Qualcomm. I'm wondering if you can comment on the ostensible change or departure from this viewpoint
column6: and what would be a successful end result of this litigation
column7: and whether you can confirm whether there's any potential gross margin risk in the future as a result of this litigation.

column1: Timothy Donald Cook: I feel the same way I did in April of 2012. I don't like litigation and view it as a last resort. And so you should take from our filing that we viewed it as we didn't see another way forward. They were insisting on charging royalties for technologies that they had nothing to do with. And so we were in a situation where the more we innovated with unique features like Touch ID or advanced displays or cameras
column2: just to name a few
column3: the more money Qualcomm would collect for no reason and the more expensive it would be therefore for us to innovate. And so it's somewhat like buying a sofa
column4: and you charge somebody a different price depending upon the price of the house that it goes into. Just from our point of view
column5: this doesn't make sense
column6: and we don't believe it will pass muster in the courts. In addition to that
column7: as a part of their increasingly radical steps they were taking to try to hold up that model
column8: they withheld $1 billion in payments that they owed us. And so we felt like we had no choice was the net of it. In terms of where it goes
column9: we'll see. I don't like litigation. And so if there's another way
column10: then that would be great
column11: but at this point I don't see it. I fully expect at this point in time that it will take some time
column12: but in the end I think common sense will prevail and the courts will see it for what it is. And so that's the way I see it. Thanks for your question.

column1: Nancy Paxton: Thank you
column2: Toni. Could we have the next question
column3: please?

column1: Operator: We'll go to Steve Milunovich with UBS.
Steven M. Milunovich: Thank you. First
column2: I wanted to ask about the iPad. It looked like it was about to turn possibly even positive. You said it was above your plan
column3: but I think it was pretty well below the Street's expectations. And the ASP deteriorated pretty significantly. I don't know if it's a mix shift. But maybe you can talk about the iPad and what you see going forward.

column1: Timothy Donald Cook: The iPad
column2: Steve
column3: we had a 1.6 million-unit swing on channel inventory between the years. In the year-ago quarter we increased by 900
column4: 000. In this quarter we decreased by 700
column5: 000. On top of that and from an ASP point of view
column6: in the year-ago quarter we launched the iPad Pro 13 Edge. That would be the iPad with obviously the highest price on it. We would have done the channel fill plus the launch of the product
column7: and so that would have bolstered the ASPs in that particular quarter. In addition to all of that
column8: we did under-call the number of iPads that would be in demand for the quarter
column9: and that compounded a shortage issue that we had with one of our suppliers. And so all in all
column10: there were quite a few things going on there. If I zoom out of the 90-day clock and look at it
column11: we've got some exciting things coming on iPad. I still feel very optimistic about where we can take the product. When we look at the number of people buying iPads for the first time
column12: which is a good thing to look at from a point of view of whether things are reaching a penetration point or not
column13: the numbers indicate that it's not close to that kind of thing. The customer sat numbers are through the roof. Literally
column14: the customer sat for the iPad Pro is 99%. It's stunning. And so I see a lot of good things and hope for better results
column15: but we are still currently in this shortage issue now
column16: and I'm not projecting to get out of that totally during the quarter. And so it will damper this quarter somewhat. But again
column17: beyond the 90-day clock
column18: I'm very bullish on iPad.

column1: Steven M. Milunovich: Okay
column2: that's great
column3: thank you. And then
column4: Tim
column5: investors tend to think of the iPhone as mature and technology improvements as incremental
column6: yet I believe you said there's plenty of runway left in terms of appealing new features. Do you think there are future enhancements coming that will be viewed as material by users
column7: and particularly changes beyond form factor
column8: beyond the way the phone looks? Are there functional things coming over time that you think could surprise people?

column1: Timothy Donald Cook: I think the smartphone is still in the early innings of the game. I think there's lots more to do. I think it's become – every year it becomes more important to people's lives and there are more things people are doing with it. I talked a little bit about home automation
column2: but I could have talked about health. I could have talked more about CarPlay. The use of it in the enterprise is growing significantly. And so when I look at all of these things
column3: usage going up
column4: app developers still innovating
column5: we've got some exciting things in the pipeline
column6: I feel really
column7: really good about it. So this is one that we think different about a bunch of things
column8: but maybe this is just one more.

column1: Steven M. Milunovich: Thank you.
Timothy Donald Cook: Yes.
Nancy Paxton: Thank you
column2: Steve. A replay of today's call will be available for two weeks as a podcast on the iTunes Store
column3: with a webcast on apple.com/investor

And these replays will be available by approximately 5:00 PM Pacific Time today. Members of the press with additional questions can contact Kristin Huguet at 408-974-2414. And financial analysts can contact Joan Hoover or me with additional questions. Joan is at 408-974-4570

column1: 65;AAPL;2017-05-03;"Operator: Good day
column2: everyone
column3: and welcome to this Apple Incorporated second quarter fiscal year 2017 earnings release conference call. Today's call is being recorded. At this time for opening remarks and introductions
column4: I would like to turn the call over to Nancy Paxton
column5: Senior Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead
column6: ma'am.

column1: Nancy Paxton: Thank you. Good afternoon and thanks to everyone for joining us. Speaking first today is Apple CEO Tim Cook
column2: and he'll be followed by CFO Luca Maestri. After that
column3: we'll open the call to questions from analysts. Please note that some of the information you'll hear during our discussion today will consist of forward-looking statements
column4: including without limitation those regarding revenue
column5: gross margin
column6: operating expenses
column7: other income and expense
column8: taxes
column9: future business outlook
column10: and plans for capital return and debt issuance. Actual results or trends could differ materially from our forecast. For more information
column11: please refer to the risk factors discussed in Apple's Form 10-K for 2016
column12: the Form 10-Q for the first quarter of 2017
column13: and the Form 8-K filed with the SEC today along with the associated press release. Apple assumes no obligation to update any forward-looking statements or information
column14: which speak as of their respective dates. I'd now like to turn the call over to Tim for introductory remarks.

column1: Timothy Donald Cook: Thanks
column2: Nancy. Good afternoon and thank you for joining us. Today we are reporting strong March quarter results
column3: with accelerating revenue growth and earnings per share up 10% over last year. We feel great about this performance. Revenue was $52.9 billion
column4: near the high end of our guidance range. Global revenue was up 5% year on year
column5: with growth accelerating from our December quarter performance. That's despite a $1 billion year-over-year revenue headwind from foreign exchange in the March quarter and a larger iPhone channel inventory reduction this year versus last year. iPhone sales were line in line with our expectations
column6: and we're thrilled to see the continued strong demand for iPhone 7 Plus with its beautiful large display and dual-camera system. Our active installed base of iPhones grew by double digits year over year. And based on the latest data from IDC
column7: we gained market share in nearly every country we track. Late in the quarter
column8: we released the stunning (PRODUCT)RED Special Edition versions of iPhone 7 and iPhone 7 Plus in recognition of 10 years of our partnership with RED. This relationship has given our customers an unprecedented way to contribute to the global fund and bring the world a step closer to an AIDS-free generation. We've seen wonderful customer response to these eye-popping new iPhones. For the second quarter in a row
column9: our Services revenue topped $7 billion
column10: and it's well on the way to being the size of a Fortune 100 company. We're very happy to see the deep level of customer engagement with the Apple ecosystem across all of our services. App Store momentum is terrific
column11: with revenue growing 40% year over year to an all-time quarterly record. The number of developers offering apps for sale on our store was up 26% over last year
column12: and we're thrilled to see their success. column4: we're seeing what we believe to be a pause in purchases on iPhone

column2: Steve. Can we have the next question

column1: Operator: From Bernstein
column2: we'll go to Toni Sacconaghi.

column1: A.M. Sacconaghi
column2: Jr.: Yes
column3: thank you. I have two as well. First
column4: Tim
column5: I'm wondering if you can comment on your recent decision and the rationale for withholding royalty payments to Qualcomm. And really specifically
column6: I wonder what you believe is the risk that Qualcomm could have a detrimental response
column7: such as withholding modem chip sales or potentially even getting an injunction on iPhones in select geographies around the world. And I'd like to understand your perspective on whether either of those are real risk to any degree. And why would Apple potentially take on those risks just in advance of what will arguably be your most significant and largest product launch in history?

column1: Timothy Donald Cook: Anyone that has a standards-essential patent has a responsibility to offer it to everyone that would like it under what are called FRAND terms. FRAND stands for fair
column2: reasonable
column3: and non-discriminatory terms. That's both the price and the business terms. Qualcomm has not made such an offer to Apple. And so I don't believe that a – I don't believe anyone is going to decide to enjoin the iPhone based on that. I think that there's plenty of case law around that subject
column4: but we shall see. In terms of why we're withholding royalties
column5: you can't pay something when there's a dispute about the amount. You don't know how much to pay. And so they think we owe some amount
column6: we think we owe a different amount
column7: and there hasn't been a meeting of the minds there. And so at this point
column8: we need the courts to decide that. Unless we are able to
column9: over time
column10: settle between us on some amount
column11: but right now we're depending upon the courts to do that. And so that is the thinking. The reason that we're pursuing this is that Qualcomm's trying to charge Apple a percentage of the total iPhone value. And they do some really great work around standards-essential patents
column12: but it's one small part of what an iPhone is. It's not – it has nothing do with the display or the Touch ID or a gazillion other innovations that Apple has done. And so we don't think that's right
column13: and so we're taking a principled stand on it. And we strongly believe we're in the right
column14: and I'm sure they believe that they are. And that's what courts are for. And so we'll let it go with that.

column1: A.M. Sacconaghi
column2: Jr.: Thank you. I was wondering if I could just follow up a little bit on iPhone demand. If I try and adjust for the drawdown in inventory and the extra week last quarter

column6: I think
column7: when you adjust for the extra week. And then you made a final comment around a pause on iPhones. So I'm wondering if you could maybe elaborate on
column8: was the below sequential
column9: at least by my calculation
column10: growth rate in Q2 attributable to a pause? And can you characterize what you think upgrade rates are doing

column14: again
column15: might be contributing to that pause and that sequential decline that I referenced? Thank you.

column1: Timothy Donald Cook: There are a lot of questions there. Let me give you some color as I see it. In this quarter

column4: we grew sell-through on a year-over-year basis. Last quarter
column5: I'm sure other folks remember
column6: was a 14-week quarter
column7: and so you have to adjust the rates last quarter to get at what the underlying sell-through growth was. And so I think that when you do that
column8: you're going to find that actually the year-over-year performance is similar between the quarters. In terms of upgraders
column9: we saw the largest absolute number of upgraders ever in any six-month period in the first half of this year
column10: first half of this fiscal year to be precise. And we saw the largest absolute number of switchers outside of Greater China in the same period that we've ever seen. And so in four of the five operating segments
column11: as I think Luca mentioned in his comments
column12: we had very good growth. And it was really propelled by the demand for iPhone 7 Plus
column13: which is growing incredibly fast around the world. And so that's kind of the color I would add there
column14: and hopefully some of that is useful for you.

column1: Luca Maestri: As you know
column2: Simona
column3: we do not provide guidance around units and around channel inventory reduction
column4: but our goal is always to have the right amount of weeks of inventory in the channel. And if you look at our history over the last several years

column6: so I think it's a fair expectation to have.

column4: manufacturing
column5: and R&D presence there. So just curious as you look at that market and the rollout of 4G there
column6: is it reasonable for us to assume that Apple can sell something on the order of 10 million to 20 million iPhones there next year and then grow from there?

column1: Timothy Donald Cook: We make it a point not to forecast by geo. We just provide a current quarter forecast. But as hopefully you've seen as we began to give you more information about India

column3: and it is the third largest smartphone market in the world today behind China and the United States. And so we believe
column4: particularly now that the 4G infrastructure is going in the country and is continuing to be expanded
column5: that there is a huge opportunity for Apple there. And so that and the demographics of the country is why we're putting so much energy there.

column2: and maybe a question for both Tim and Luca. As you outlined on this call and at the Developer Conference in June
column3: there is an unprecedented number of products that either ramped volume or launched in the back half of this year. So appreciating you only formally guide a quarter out
column4: I wonder if there's any qualitative commentary you can provide to help us think about the back half of this calendar year and how all those new products that come into the model could impact either revenue seasonality versus past years or could impact just the costs associated with ramping that many products all at once. Thanks.

column1: Timothy Donald Cook: Katy
column2: as Luca mentioned
column3: we did assume some transitional costs in our guidance for the quarter
column4: as is typically the case. And we're looking very much forward to the product rollouts.

column1: Nancy Paxton: Thank you
column2: Katy. Could we have the next question
column3: please?

column1: Operator: We'll go to Shannon Cross with Cross Research.
Shannon S. Cross: Thank you very much for taking my question. Tim
column2: could you talk a bit about what you're seeing in China? I think obviously
column3: there continues to be strong demand for smartphones. But perhaps mix shift
column4: I think you brought back the iPhone 6 this quarter to be a bit more price aggressive. And then can you just talk a bit about how you see that market developing with the growth of WeChat and some of the other developments that are happening there? Thank you.

column1: Timothy Donald Cook: Yeah. Thanks
column2: Shannon. We were very encouraged by the results this quarter. We improved as we thought we would from the previous quarters a little more than I thought we would. If you look underneath the numbers
column3: mainland China was actually flat year-over-year during Q3. And in constant currency terms
column4: we were actually up 6% in mainland China. And so we're very encouraged about that. iPad grew dramatically more than the market. The Mac grew much more than the market. iPhone was relatively flat year-on-year
column5: similar as the market was. And so we see all of those as very encouraging signs. On top of that
column6: Services grew extremely strongly during the quarter. Hong Kong continued to drag down the total Greater China segment. But on a sequential basis
column7: we're probably at the trough of that
column8: which is nice. With the peg to the dollar there from a currency point of view and tourism being what it is
column9: I don't really know when that market will come back. But what we see on the mainland is definitely much more encouraging. It's interesting to note that upgraders both for the quarter and actually for the full fiscal year to-date was our highest ever
column10: and so that we felt very good about. In terms of WeChat
column11: the way that I look at this is because our share – because iOS share is not nearly a majority of the market in China
column12: the fact that a lot of people use that
column13: it makes the switching opportunity even greater. And I think that's more the case than the risk that a lot of folks have pointed out. And so I see Tencent as one of our biggest and best developers. They've done a great job of implementing a lot of iOS features in their apps and we're looking forward to working with them even more to build even greater experiences for our mutual users in China.

column1: Shannon S. Cross: Great. Thank you. And then can you talk a bit about the composition of the installed base of iPhones at this point
column2: as obviously we're getting close to a refresh? Just you brought in the iPhone SE. You've obviously had strength at the high end. I'm just trying to think about what percent do you think have upgraded in the prior generation
column3: any color you can give us on that?

column1: Timothy Donald Cook: From an absolute quantity point of view
column2: the upgrades for this fiscal year are the highest that we've seen. And so we feel good about that. However
column3: if you look at it from an upgrade rate point of view instead of the absolute number
column4: the rate is similar to what we saw with the previous iPhones
column5: except for iPhone 6
column6: which as we called out in the past had an abnormally high upgrade rate. We do think that based on the amount of rumors and the volume of them that there is some pause in our current numbers. And so where that affects us in the short-term
column7: even though we had great results
column8: it probably bodes well later on.

column1: Nancy Paxton: Thank you
column2: Shannon. Could we have the next question
column3: please?

column1: Operator: Steve Milunovich with UBS.
Steven Milunovich: Thank you. I wonder if you wanted to make any comments about switching this quarter.
Timothy Donald Cook: Sure. Switching outside of China was up year-on-year
column2: and so we're happy with that. We continue to see people moving over to iOS and it helped with us making the results that Luca announced earlier
column3: including the channel inventory reduction.

column1: Steven Milunovich: Okay
column2: and then a government question. First of all
column3: the President suggested that you may build three big beautiful plants. I wonder if you can comment on if that's a possibility either directly or indirectly. And then in China
column4: I think
column5: we all understand that you have to work within the regulations
column6: but maybe you could comment a bit on how you feel your working relationship is with the government and if there is certain lines that you can't cross.

column1: Timothy Donald Cook: Sure. Starting with the U.S.
column2: let me just take this question from what are we doing to increase jobs
column3: which I think is probably where it's rooted. We've created 2 million jobs in the U.S.
column4: and we're incredibly proud of that. We do view that we have a responsibility in the U.S. to increase economic activity
column5: including increasing jobs
column6: because Apple could have only been created here. And so as we look at that 2 million
column7: there are three main categories of that
column8: and we have actions going on in each of them to further build on that momentum. The first category is app development. About three-quarters of the 2 million are app developers. And we're doing an enormous amount of things to deliver curriculum to both K-12 with Swift Playgrounds in the K-to-6 area
column9: other curriculum as you proceed beyond grade 6 under the Everyone Can Code area. And just a couple months ago
column10: we announced a new curriculum that's focused on community schools and community colleges
column11: junior colleges
column12: technical colleges
column13: for kids that did not have coding in their elementary and high school years. And so we're excited about that because we think it could increase the diversity of the developer community and the quantity. And I think this area in general and all the things we do for the developer community will be the largest contribution that Apple can make because this is the fastest growing job segment in the country
column14: and I think will be for quite some time. If you look at the second area
column15: we have purchased – or we purchased last year about $50 billion worth of goods and services from U.S.-based suppliers. Some significant portion of those are manufacturing-related
column16: and so we've asked ourselves what can we do to increase this. And you may have seen that at the beginning of the quarter
column17: sometime in April I believe
column18: we announced a fund
column19: an Advanced Manufacturing Fund
column20: that we're initially placing $1 billion in. And we've already deployed $200 million of that. And the first recipient is Corning in Kentucky
column21: and they'll be using that money to expand the plant to make very innovative glass. And we purchase that glass and essentially export it to the world with iPhones and iPads. We think there's more of these that we can do. I think there are probably several plants that can benefit from having some investment to grow or expand or even maybe set up shop in the U.S. for the first time
column22: so we're very excited about that. And then the third area is we have about two-thirds or so of our total employee base is in the U.S. despite only a third of our revenues being here
column23: and we'll have some things that we'll say about that later in the year. And so that's what we're doing from a job growth point of view
column24: and we're very
column25: very proud of that. Now turning to China
column26: let me comment on what I assumed is at the root of your question about this VPN issue. Let me just address that head on. The central government in China back in 2015 started tightening the regulations associated with VPN apps
column27: and we have a number of those on our store. Essentially
column28: as a requirement for someone to operate a VPN
column29: they have to have a license from the government there. Earlier this year
column30: they began a renewed effort to enforce that policy
column31: and we were required by the government to remove some of the VPN apps from the App Store that don't meet these new regulations. We understand that those same requirements are on other app stores
column32: and as we checked through that
column33: that is the case. Today there are actually still hundreds of VPN apps on the App Store
column34: including hundreds by developers that are outside China
column35: and so there continues to be VPN apps available. We would obviously rather not remove the apps
column36: but like we do in other countries
column37: we follow the law wherever we do business. And we strongly believe that participating in markets and bringing benefits to customers is in the best interest of the folks there and in other countries as well. And so we believe in engaging with governments even when we disagree. And in this particular case
column38: now back to commenting on this one
column39: we're hopeful that over time the restrictions that we're seeing are loosened because innovation really requires freedom to collaborate and communicate
column40: and I know that that is a major focus there. And so that's what we're seeing from that point of view. Some folks have tried to link it to the U.S. situation last year
column41: and they're very different. In the case of the U.S.
column42: the law in the U.S. supported us
column43: which was very clear. In the case of China
column44: the law is also very clear there. And like we would if the U.S. changed the law here
column45: we'd have to abide by them in both cases
column46: that doesn't mean that we don't state our point of view in the appropriate way. We always do that. And so hopefully that's a little bit probably more than you wanted to know
column47: but I wanted to tell you.

column1: Steven Milunovich: Thank you.
Nancy Paxton: Thank you
column2: Steve. Could we have the next question
column3: please?

column1: Operator: We'll hear from Kulbinder Garcha with Credit Suisse. Kulbinder S. Garcha - Credit Suisse Securities (USA) LLC Thank you
column2: a question for Tim maybe on the iPhone install base. At various points in the past you've told us the rate at which that was growing. At the end of the first half
column3: what is that up year on year? At what rate is it growing? Can you give us some sense of that? And on upgrade rates over the longer term
column4: there are lots of moving parts
column5: and I get that there's I guess geographic mix shift of your base. There's many new phones that you may or may not bring out. There's how carriers promote your products. But do you think this upgrade rate is sustainable? Do you think it gets faster all the time? How should we think about the major drivers that you want to see for it? Many thanks.

column1: Timothy Donald Cook: I think the upgrade rate is a function of many
column2: many different things
column3: from the size of the installed base
column4: the age of the installed base
column5: the product that is new at the time
column6: the regional distribution
column7: the upgrade plans that are in various markets around the world. And so I think there are many
column8: many factors in that. It's not a simple thing that you can apply a set formula to or one variable or a couple of variable formula in my opinion. But I think in general
column9: because our installed base was up strong double digit once again
column10: there's a lot of factors that are very positive for us. And between the upgraders and the switchers that we see
column11: and the first-time buyer category is still out there too in several countries
column12: including some that you may not think there is
column13: there's still a sizable base in some. Between those three areas
column14: I think we have a lot of opportunity. Kulbinder S. Garcha - Credit Suisse Securities (USA) LLC Thank you.

column1: Timothy Donald Cook: Yes.
Nancy Paxton: Thank you
column2: Kulbinder. Could we have the next question
column3: please?

column1: Operator: Toni Sacconaghi with Bernstein.
Antonio M. Sacconaghi: Yes
column2: thank you. I have one for Luca and one for Tim
column3: please. Luca
column4: typically in the fiscal Q4
column5: Apple builds considerable iPhone channel inventory
column6: like 2 million or 3 million units. You're starting from a very low point at the end of fiscal Q3
column7: as you mentioned on the call
column8: with the drawdown. As we think about what's embedded in your guidance for fiscal Q4 for channel inventory for iPhone
column9: should we be expecting a normal seasonal build
column10: or is it likely to be significantly higher given the very low starting point?

column1: Luca Maestri: As you know
column2: Toni
column3: we do not guide on channel inventory. We've never done that. We are providing a fairly wide range from a revenue standpoint
column4: so obviously that also has an impact on potential channel inventory levels. One thing that I would tell you is that we feel very good about the performance of the business right now. We think that our Services business will continue to grow well. We've got a lot of momentum on iPad and Mac because we refreshed the lineups of those products. Watch and AirPods are doing incredibly well. We're getting a lot of positive customer feedback. And I think in general
column5: even the performance in China
column6: Tim has mentioned it. We think that the performance will continue to improve. So those are the drivers of our guidance range for the quarter.

column1: Antonio M. Sacconaghi: Okay
column2: thanks. Tim
column3: I was wondering if you could maybe talk a little bit about two things that you mentioned in public before. One is television
column4: which you have described as an area of intense interest
column5: but I don't even think there was an update on Apple TV on this call. So perhaps you can talk to us about how you're thinking about content. I know you're doing some original content creation
column6: and how that area is evolving in your thinking. And then recently you talked about how Apple is focusing on autonomous systems for automobiles. And there has been press reports that Apple has been testing autonomous vehicles for potentially up to a year. I was wondering if you could talk a little bit more about Apple's interest in autonomous vehicles and whether self-driving is really likely to be Apple's principal focus in the near to medium-term.

column1: Timothy Donald Cook: On the first part of your question about original content
column2: we have done some original content. It's focused on Apple Music. Currently
column3: we have some more that's launching in a week or so that will be made available on Apple Music. The objective of this is really twofold. One is for our own learning
column4: given that we're new in the video space in terms of creation. And two is to give the Apple Music subscriber some exclusive content and hopefully grow our subscriber base. And we've recently hired two great folks with lots of experience in creating content like Breaking Bad and The Crown and some really top-notch content. And so we'll see how this area goes
column5: but it is still an area of great interest. In terms of autonomous systems
column6: what we've said is that we are very focused on autonomous systems from a core technology point of view. We do have a large project going and are making a big investment in this. From our point of view
column7: autonomy is the mother of all AI projects. And the autonomous systems can be used in a variety of ways and a vehicle is only one. But there are many different areas of it and I don't want to go any further with that. But thank you for the question.

column1: Nancy Paxton: Thank you
column2: Toni. Could we have the next question
column3: please?

column1: Operator: That comes from Mike Olson with Piper Jaffray.
Michael J. Olson: Good afternoon. I just have one question for Tim. This may be a hard question to answer in a condensed way
column2: but how would you describe what you expect the most near-term applications will be for developers to target using ARKit? Will it be consumer iPhone and iPad applications
column3: enterprise applications
column4: or I guess some combination of the two? And basically
column5: how does this come to market in the most significant way in the next few quarters as Apple becomes the largest global platform for AR as you've talked about? Thanks.

column1: Timothy Donald Cook: Mike
column2: that is a great question. And I could not be more excited about AR and what we're seeing with ARKit in the early going. And to answer your question about what category it starts in
column3: just take a look at what's already on the web in terms of what people are doing and it is all over the place. From entertainment to gaming
column4: I've seen what I would call more small business solutions. I've seen consumer solutions. I've seen enterprise solutions. I think AR is big and profound and this is one of those huge things that we'll look back at and marvel on the start of it. So I think that customers are going to see it in a variety of ways. Enterprise takes a little longer sometimes to get going. But I can already tell you there's lots of excitement in there. And I think we'll start to see some applications there as well. And it feels great to get this thing going at a level that can get all of the developers behind it
column5: so I couldn't be more excited about it.

column1: Michael J. Olson: Thank you.
Nancy Paxton: Thanks
column2: Mike. Could we have the next question
column3: please?

column1: Operator: We'll go to Amit Daryanani.
Amit Daryanani: Thanks a lot. Good afternoon
column2: guys. I guess to start off with
column3: on your Services segment
column4: revenues actually I think accelerated by 400 basis points to worse than what you guys had in the first half of this year. Could you just help us understand what's driving this? Is there a way to think about ARPU in a traditional manner within that Services business versus the installed base growing?

column1: Luca Maestri: Amit
column2: Luca. Our Services business is very broad. We've got multiple categories in the Services business
column3: so it's difficult to talk about ARPU in general. It doesn't make a lot of sense. The reason for the acceleration also here is multiple factors. One that is very
column4: very important for us is the fact that the App Store
column5: which is the largest of our Services categories
column6: is seeing an increasingly larger amount of paying accounts. On a year-over-year basis
column7: the number of accounts that are actually transacting and paying on the App Store is growing very
column8: very well. It is happening for a variety of reasons. One of them
column9: for example
column10: is the fact that we are making it easier for customers to pay on the App Store. Outside the United States
column11: in many markets
column12: not every form of payment is accepted. We are making it easier all the time. We launched on Alipay
column13: for example
column14: in China during the December quarter. That has obviously helped a lot with the growth in the number of paid accounts. And we continue to bring more and more forms of payment in the App Store around the world. That's a big reason for that. The other reason why the number of paying accounts is growing is the fact that the quality and the quantity of content continues to improve. And so there's many more ways of experiencing games and entertainment and other apps on the store. We have other businesses like the Apple Music streaming service
column15: which is growing very fast because we just started it a couple of years ago
column16: so we are getting a lot of new subscribers there. Our iCloud storage business continues to grow very
column17: very fast. So it's multiple services. The number of people transacting on our stores continues to grow. In terms of ARPU
column18: maybe I can make a comment on ARPU specifically related to the App Store. What we're seeing and we've seen over a long period of time as we keep track of these cohorts of customers
column19: we see that as customers get on the App Store and start spending on it
column20: we see the spending profile is very similar across generations of customers. People tend to spend more over time. Obviously
column21: you have different spending profiles in different geographies around the world
column22: but in general you see that trend across the board.

column1: Amit Daryanani: Got it
column2: that's really helpful. And if I could just follow up
column3: on the iPhone side
column4: there's been a large amount of discussion in blogs and among your component suppliers that the timing this time may be somewhat different and delayed versus past. Your guide almost seems you're more excited about this iPhone launch versus historically because the sequential growth is better. So I guess beyond the fact we probably shouldn't read every blog and believe every blog
column5: what do you think is different with this product launch or product availability through the cycle versus what you've seen historically?

column1: Timothy Donald Cook: We have no comment on anything that's unannounced.
Amit Daryanani: Fair enough
column2: I figured it was worth a shot. Thank you.

column1: Nancy Paxton: Thank you
column2: Amit. Could we have the next question
column3: please?

column1: Operator: That will come from Brian White with Drexel.
Brian J. White: Yes. Tim
column2: growth in the smartphone market is now crawling along at about a low single digit percentage. I know iPhone grew about 2% year over year this quarter
column3: and it looks like you had about a mid-teens market share in units in 2016. So as we look forward maybe three to four years
column4: do you think Apple can expand its unit market share? And if so
column5: what will be the drivers be? And my second question is just about India
column6: general thoughts about India in the quarter. Thank you.

column1: Timothy Donald Cook: The answer to your first question is yes. I do think that we can grow both in units and market share. We don't predict those things
column2: but yes
column3: if you ask me what I think
column4: that's what I think. And so what are the drivers? The installed base is growing. It's still growing very strongly. That will generate more upgrades over time. I feel good about our ability to convince people to switch. And where the developed markets the first-time buyer rates are down other than places like Japan perhaps
column5: the emerging markets
column6: we haven't even gotten started yet
column7: really. From a revenue point of view
column8: we had very strong growth there. Emerging markets ex-China were up 18% year on year. It was a record for us
column9: so we see a lot of opportunity in these markets. We are investing in India. As you mentioned in your second point
column10: we've already launched an app accelerator center. That's on top of working with the channel and looking at expanding our go-to-market in general. And we began to produce the iPhone SE there during the quarter
column11: and we're really happy with how that's going. And so we're bringing all of our energies to bear there. I see a lot of similarities to where China was several years ago. And so I'm very
column12: very bullish and very
column13: very optimistic about India.

column1: Brian J. White: Great
column2: thank you.

column1: Nancy Paxton: Thanks very much
column2: Brian. A replay of today's call will be available for two weeks as a podcast on the iTunes Store
column3: as a webcast on apple.com/investor
column4: and via telephone. And the numbers to the telephone replay are 888-203-1112 or 719-457-0820. Please enter confirmation code 6376964. And these replays will be available by approximately 5:00 PM Pacific Time today. Members of the press with additional questions can contact Kristen Huguet at 408-974-2414. And financial analysts can contact Joan Hoover or me with additional questions. Joan is at 408-974-4570 and I'm at 408-974-5420. Thanks again for joining us.

column1: Operator: Ladies and gentlemen
column2: that does conclude today's presentation. We do thank everyone for your participation.";[nan

column1: 67;AAPL;2017-11-03;"Operator: Good day everyone and welcome to this Apple Inc. Fourth Quarter Fiscal Year 2017 Earnings Release Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. At this time for opening remarks and introductions
column2: I would like to turn the call over to Nancy Paxton
column3: Senior Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead
column4: ma'am.

column1: Nancy Paxton: Thank you
column2: good afternoon
column3: and thanks everyone for joining us. Speaking first today is Apple CEO Tim Cook and he'll be followed by CFO Luca Maestri
column4: and after that we'll open the call to questions from analysts. Please note that some of the information you will hear during our discussion today will consist of forward-looking statements including
column5: without limitation
column6: those regarding revenue
column7: gross margin
column8: operating expenses
column9: other income and expense
column10: taxes and future business outlook. Actual results or trends could differ materially from our forecast. For more information
column11: please refer to the risk factors discussed in Apple's most recently filed periodic reports on Form 10-K and Form 10-Q
column12: and the form 8-K filed with the SEC today along with the associated press release. Apple assumes no obligation to update any forward-looking statements or information which speak as of their respective dates. I'd now like to turn the call over to Tim for introductory remarks.

column1: Timothy D. Cook: Good afternoon
column2: and thanks to everyone for joining us. As we closed the books on a very successful fiscal 2017
column3: I have to say I couldn't be more excited about Apple's future. This was our biggest year ever in most parts of the world with all-time record revenue in the United States
column4: Western Europe
column5: Japan
column6: Korea
column7: the Middle East
column8: Africa
column9: Central and Eastern Europe and Asia. We had particularly strong finish this year
column10: generating our highest September quarter revenue ever as year-over-year growth accelerated for the fourth consecutive quarter. Revenue was $52.6 billion
column11: above the high end of our guidance range
column12: and up 12% over last year. We generated revenue growth across all of our product categories and showed all-time record results for our Services business. As we expected
column13: we returned to growth in greater China
column14: with unit growth and market share gains for iPhone
column15: iPad
column16: and Mac. In fact
column17: it was an all-time record quarter for Mac sales in mainland China as well as an all-time high for Services revenue. And revenue from emerging markets outside of greater China was up 40%
column18: with great momentum in India
column19: where revenue doubled year over year. We also had great results in enterprise and education with double digit growth in worldwide customer purchases of iPad and Mac in both markets. Gross margin for the September quarter was at the high end of our guidance range
column20: and thanks to exceptional work by our teams
column21: we generated record fourth quarter earnings per share of $2.07
column22: up 24% from a year ago. iPhone sales exceeded our expectations. In the last week and a half of September
column23: we began shipping iPhone 8 and iPhone 8 Plus to customers in more than 50 countries. They instantly became our two most popular iPhone models and have been every week since then. As we speak
column24: the launch of iPhone X is now underway as stores open across Australia and Asia. iPhone X is packed with innovative new technologies that chart our path for the next decade
column25: technologies like the TrueDepth camera system
column26: Super Retina Display
column27: and A11 Bionic chip with neural engine
column28: which has been in development for years with a focus on deep machine learning. iPhone X enables totally new experiences like unlocking your iPhone with Face ID
column29: taking photos with studio-quality lighting effects
column30: or playing immersive augmented reality games. We can't wait for people to experience our vision of the future. Orders have already been very strong
column31: and we're working to get iPhone X into customers' hands as quickly as possible. Turning to Services. Revenue reached an all-time quarterly record of $8.5 billion in the September quarter. A few quarters ago
column32: we established a goal of doubling our fiscal 2016 services revenue of $24 billion by the year 2020
column33: and we are well on our way to meeting that goal. In fiscal 2017
column34: we reached $30 billion
column35: making our Services business already the size of a Fortune 100 company. We're also delighted to report our second consecutive quarter of double-digit unit growth for iPad. Customers have responded very positively to the new iPad lineup. And with the launch of iOS 11
column36: the iPad experience has become more powerful than ever
column37: with great new features for getting things done like the new dock
column38: Files app
column39: drag and drop
column40: multitasking and more power than most PC notebooks. The launch of iOS 11 also made iOS the world's largest platform for augmented reality. There are already over 1
column41: 000 apps with powerful AR features in our App Store today
column42: with developers creating amazing new experiences in virtually every category of apps aimed at consumers
column43: students and business users alike. Put simply
column44: we believe AR is going to change the way we use technology forever. We're already seeing things that will transform the way you work
column45: play
column46: connect and learn. For example
column47: there are AR apps that let you interact with virtual models of everything you can imagine
column48: from the human body to the solar system. And of course
column49: you experience them like they're really there. Instantly
column50: education becomes much more powerful when every subject comes to life in 3D. And imagine shopping when you can place an object in your living room before you make a purchase
column51: or attending live sporting events when you can see the stats on the field. AR is going to change everything. iOS 11 is also allowing developers to integrate machine learning models into their apps with Core ML. Pinterest is already using Core ML to deliver fast and powerful visual search. PadMapper uses Core ML to provide intelligent features that make it easy to find or rent your apartment. And VisualDx is even pioneering new health diagnostics with Core ML
column52: automating skin image analysis to assist dermatologists with their diagnoses. These are just a few examples. There's so much more to come. Next
column53: I'd like to talk about the Mac
column54: which had its best year ever
column55: with the highest annual Mac revenue in Apple's history. It was also the best September quarter ever
column56: with Mac revenue growth of 25% driven by the notebook refreshes we launched in June and a strong back-to-school season. The Mac experience has become even better since the September launch of macOS High Sierra
column57: with new technologies to make Mac more reliable
column58: capable and responsive and lay the foundation for future innovation. Moving on now to Apple Watch. With unit growth of over 50% for the third consecutive quarter
column59: it continues to be the best selling and most loved smartwatch in the world. We began shipping Apple Watch Series 3 just six weeks ago and customers love the new freedom of cellular. The ability to go for a run with just your Apple Watch or go for a quick errand without your phone while staying connected is a game changer. Now more than ever
column60: Apple Watch is the ultimate device for a healthy life and is already making a big difference in our customers' lives. We're very excited about the upcoming launch of the Apple Heart Study
column61: which will use data from Apple Watch to identify irregular heart rhythms and notify users when unusual patterns are detected. Earlier this week
column62: we introduced watchOS 4.1
column63: bringing 40 million songs to your wrist through Apple Music. The combination of music streaming on Apple Watch and AirPods is truly a magical experience for people on the go. We're thrilled with the momentum of these products. In fact
column64: our entire wearables business was up 75% year over year in the fourth quarter and in fiscal 2017
column65: already generated the annual revenue of a Fortune 400 company. Late in the September quarter
column66: we also launched Apple TV 4K
column67: delivering a stunning cinematic experience at home. So now users around the world can watch movies and shows in 4K HDR quality and stream live sports and news on the Apple TV app. There's already a great selection of 4K HDR titles available through iTunes and other popular video services with many more movies and shows on the way. We're also very excited about the opening of Apple Michigan Avenue two weeks ago on Chicago's riverfront. This is the first store that brings together our complete vision for the future of Apple retail
column68: providing a welcoming place for everyone to experience our products

column1: Timothy D. Cook: Yes
column2: it's a great question. The reason I'm so excited about AR is I view that it amplifies human performance instead of isolates humans. And so as you know
column3: it's the mix of the virtual and the physical world and so it should be a help for humanity
column4: not an isolation kind of thing for humanity. As I go through different countries as I've been traveling lately
column5: and looking at some things in the market
column6: other things that are coming
column7: the very cool thing is they're all over the place. I see things that the consumer's going to love because it's going to change shopping. I see things that consumers will love on the gaming side and the entertainment side. I see business-related AR apps as well. They're going to be great for productivity and between small and large business. And I see apps that makes me want to go back to K-12 again and repeat my schooling because I think it changes the game in the classroom a lot. And so the real beauty here is that it's mainstream. And of course
column8: Apple is the only company that could have brought this because it requires both hardware and software integration
column9: and it requires sort of making a lot of – or giving the operating system update to many people at once. And the software team worked really hard to make that go back several versions of iPhone so that we sort of have hundreds of millions of enabled devices overnight. And so there's 1

column11: when we fired the gun in the overall App Store. And so that's what it feels like to me
column12: and I think it will just get bigger from here.

Steven Milunovich: Thank you. I wanted to try to push a little bit more on the mix. Could you comment whether the 8 Plus outsold the 8 in the quarter? There seems to be some data that suggests that. And the 451 Research survey that you're alluding to also finds that over the next 90 days
column2: those buying an iPhone

column5: nobody would've imagined selling a phone at this price and obviously
column6: you're pretty confident that you can do it.

column1: Timothy D. Cook: Obviously
column2: I'm not going to talk about mix. That's something that we've done in the past. If you look at the 8 and 8 Plus
column3: when we launched them
column4: they instantly became our top two selling products. If you look at 8 Plus in particular
column5: to provide a little color there
column6: 8 Plus for the period of time that we can measure to date
column7: has gotten off to the fastest start of any Plus model. That for us was a bit of a surprise
column8: and a positive surprise
column9: obviously. And so we'll see what happens next. As I've mentioned before
column10: we've never had three products and it's only today that the first customers can sort of look at all three of those and I'm sure there's been some people that wanted to do that before deciding even which one. And so we'll see what happens there. But in terms of price elasticity
column11: I think it's important to remember that a large number of people pay for the phone by month. And so if you were to go out on just the U.S.
column12: since that tends to be more of the focus of this call
column13: you look at the U.S. carriers
column14: I think you would find you could buy an iPhone X for $33 a month. And so if you think about that
column15: that's a few coffees a week. It's let's say less than a coffee a day at one of these nice coffee places. The other thing to keep in mind is that many people are now trading in their current iPhone on the next iPhone. And the residual value for iPhone tends to be the highest in the industry and many people pick up $300
column16: $350 or so for their iPhone and so that even reduces the monthly payment less. And then obviously
column17: some carriers also have promotional things going on. And so I do think it's important to try to place it in that context. In terms of the way we price
column18: we price to sort of the value that we're providing. We're not trying to charge the highest price we could get or anything like that. We're just trying to price it for what we're delivering. And iPhone X has a lot of great new technologies in there that are leading the industry
column19: and it is a fabulous product and we can't wait for people to start getting it in their hands.

column1: Steven Milunovich: And then I wanted ask
column2: the Street historically has been a little skeptical about continued innovation and you've suggested there is more to go. Historically
column3: you weren't first to large screens
column4: you weren't first to OLED. Now though
column5: you're leading in AR
column6: you're leading with face ID
column7: which the all-in a year ago
column8: as some of your guys have suggested
