column1: Timothy D. Cook: I think
column2: Steve
column3: we've been in a competitive position. And so I probably maybe have a different view than you do or the folks that you're quoting. There's always doubting Thomases out there. And I've been hearing those for the 20 years I've been here and suspect I'll hear about them until I retire
column4: right. So I don't really listen to that too much. There's lots of fantastic people here and they're doing unbelievable things. And yes
column5: I view AR as profound. Not today
column6: not the app that you'll see on the App Store today
column7: but what it will be
column8: what it can be. I think it's profound and I think Apple is in a really unique position to lead in this area.

column1: Nancy Paxton: Thank you
column2: Steve. Could we have the next question
column3: please?

column1: Operator: We'll go to Toni Sacconaghi with Bernstein.
Antonio M. Sacconaghi: Yes. Thank you. Just following up a little bit on that question
column2: Tim. You talked a bit about providing a lot of value and that Apple sets its prices according to value. And I think given the uniqueness of the product you have with the iPhone X in particular
column3: that makes a lot of sense. I guess the question is given the uniqueness of the value that you have in the marketplace
column4: why shouldn't we – should we
column5: or why shouldn't we expect gross margins to improve this cycle versus previous ones? And perhaps you can talk a little bit about how you think about pricing in the context of gross margin. And I have a follow-up
column6: please.

column1: Luca Maestri: Toni
column2: I'll take that one. When – you said we price our products for the value that we deliver. We also said that every time we launch new products
column3: the cost structures of the new products tend to be higher than the products that they replace. It's inevitable. We are adding new technologies
column4: new features
column5: and therefore the cost structures go up. We have a very good track record of taking those cost structures and over the life cycle of the product
column6: we are able to bring them down. There are a lot of elements in the gross margin line that we have good control over and there are also elements that we don't control. Take for example foreign exchange
column7: which has been a significant headwind for the company for the last three years now. Also
column8: the mix of products that we sell into the market tends to change over time
column9: and that also has an impact on the overall gross margin for the company. There are situations where the commodities markets are in good shape. There are situations where commodity markets can be a bit out of balance. We have a case right now around memory pricing
column10: which is a headwind for the time being. So there's many puts and takes. The fact that our Services business is growing
column11: it should be a positive because our Services margins tend to be accretive to company margins. So there's many puts and takes. We tend to think about maximizing gross margin dollars because we think that's the most important thing for investors at the end of the day. When we look at our track record over years
column12: I think we've found a good balance between unit grow and gross margins and revenue
column13: and we will continue to do that as we go forward.

column1: Antonio M. Sacconaghi: Okay. Thank you for that. And then I wanted to revisit this notion of supply and demand
column2: and I realize it's very early and you can't make predictions. I think a common investor question is
column3: the iPhone X was made available for sale. It quickly had pushed out availability levels to unprecedented levels versus history. And so I think the really significant question is
column4: is that initial push-out really a function of uniquely strong demand versus history or is that push-out in availability really a function of much weaker supply versus history? So it'd be really helpful. You have in the past commented on first 24-hour orders
column5: for which there were 4 million plus for the iPhone 6 and 6 Plus. You have very often on this call talked about targeting when you think you could reach supply/demand balance. So it'd be really helpful if you could provide some context in terms of what you know
column6: either about initial orders or about a supplies versus history that can help investors try and better understand the little data points that they're seeing in terms of availability of the device. Thank you.

column1: Timothy D. Cook: The truth is we don't know. We've put our best estimate into the guidance
column2: and you can see from the guidance that we are very bullish. And so
column3: and we feel really great about the product lineup. We just sold the first units minutes ago. And so we'll see how things go. Until you get all of them out there where customers have the ability to demo and support
column4: I think any kind of mix discussion is very much estimating. And so we put our best estimates in
column5: but grantedly
column6: we've never done this before. So there's no comparison here
column7: with either the three iPhones nor the staggered launch. So we're going to learn something.

column1: Nancy Paxton: Thank you
column2: Toni. Could we have the next question
column3: please?

column1: Operator: That is Jim Suva with Citigroup.
Jim Suva: Thanks very much. And I'll ask my original question and follow-up at the same time because they're slightly different topics. But you'd mentioned great success in India. I believe
column2: Tim
column3: in your prepared comments you mentioned
column4: I think
column5: India doubled year over year. Based upon market analysis
column6: it looks like Apple's still just a relatively small sliver of the pie there. So Tim

column8: or how should we think about that? And then the follow-up question is on the AR/VR

column1: Timothy D. Cook: In terms of India
column2: many of the things that you mentioned are correct. Growing a market like India is a result of all of those things and doing them all well. And so it's analogous to the many years that we put into China. It's building stores. It's building channels. It's building markets. It's building the developer ecosystem. It's having the right product lineup for the market. And I feel like we're making good progress there and are gaining understanding of the market
column3: but we still have a long way to go
column4: which I sort of see as an opportunity instead of a problem. And I do feel great about the growth rate. And so that's India. I think it's all of those things. As you know
column5: as I think we talked about before
column6: we started manufacturing the iPhone SE there six
column7: nine months ago so. And the majority of the iPhone SEs that we sold in the domestic market last quarter were manufactured there. And so we also have that going and are hoping that that winds up saving some amount of money over time and avoiding some of the compounding of taxes
column8: et cetera. The bandwidth issue has also been an issue
column9: but as you point out
column10: it is being addressed and between the large carriers there with Bharti and now Jio investing the way they are
column11: the service in India is materially better than it was just 12 months ago. So there's been a sea change there in a short period of time. So I feel good about all that
column12: but we have a long way to go. In terms of the monetization question on AR/VR
column13: we tend to focus first and foremost on customer experience. And so we're all about making sure the experience is great. And we think that if we get the experience right
column14: that revenues and profits will be a result of getting that right. And so we're very much focused on the experience right now.

column1: Nancy Paxton: Thank you
column2: Jim.

column4: gross margin will be down a little. Could you just tell us what are the puts and takes on that? And are yield inefficiencies broadly much more severe this time versus what you've seen historically?

column1: Luca Maestri: Yes. Amit

Let me explain the factors that we took into consideration as we came up with our iPhone units and ASP that are embedded in our guidance. Historically
column7: because the channel fill and the holiday season
column8: our selling volume during the December quarter is generally higher than sell-through. This year
column9: the difference was further magnified
column10: because we shipped iPhone X in November rather than the September quarter. We had a very successful product ramp. We were able to reach supply/demand balance in December
column11: which placed the entirety of our channel fill for iPhone X in Q1 and this will have an effect on both units and ASP in Q2. Now
column12: for units
column13: there is a second point to consider. We typically reduced channel inventory for our newest iPhones in Q2
column14: because they enjoy very large demand in the initial weeks of sales
column15: which are compounded by the holiday season in Q1. So we anticipate doing that in Q2 this year as well. For ASPs
column16: there's also another element that we need to consider. As you know
column17: our newest products this year have a higher ASP than they had in the past. And so as a result
column18: as we reduce inventories of these newest products
column19: the overall ASPs for iPhone in Q2 will naturally decline sequentially by a higher percentage than we have experienced historically. So in summary
column20: our guidance for iPhone; we got double digit year-over-year growth and acceleration of sell-through growth on a year-over-year basis. For the balance of the Company
column21: in the aggregate
column22: we expect to grow strong double-digits year-over-year and particularly very strong performance in service and in wearables like we’ve seen during the December quarter. I hope this helps.

column1: Katy Huberty: Yes
column2: that's great color. Just a follow-up on gross margin. Guidance for flat gross margin in March is pretty seasonal
column3: but you do have the tailwind from currency. And so if you can just comment on how you think that flows into the model over the next couple of quarters
column4: the weaker dollar. And what your outlook might be around component costs in the near future. Thank you.

column1: Luca Maestri: Let me walk you through the sequential first. So we’re guiding about flat sequentially in spite of the loss of leverage. That is the largest element that we need to take into account because of our typical seasonality. And we expect to offset the seasonality impact with cost improvements and with mix. FX on a sequential basis is fairly muted
column2: because as you know
column3: we've got a hedging program that protects us from the volatility of currencies in the short term. Certainly
column4: weaker dollar in the long term
column5: if it holds
column6: will be a positive but it's not something that you're going to be seeing translating to gross margin tailwind quickly. And so I think we need to keep that in mind. We also need to keep in mind that we continue to experience a difficult memory pricing environment
column7: which we think is going to start improving as we move into the second half of our fiscal year. But it still has a negative impact in the March quarter.

column1: Operator: Mike Olson from Piper Jaffray has our next question.
Mike Olson: I know you don't talk about future products
column2: which is often presses to questions about future products and I'll give it a shot. When you think conceptually about the path for iPhone X Style devices going forward. Is there any reason the roadmap wouldn’t consists of multiple devices as we’ve seen with past iPhone upgrades? In other words
column3: the 10 was unique amongst recent iPhone launches
column4: because it's a singular device
column5: potentially limiting the shots on go for upgrades given limited options. How do you think about that
column6: going forward? And then I have a follow up.

column1: TimCook: Mike
column2: you did a good job of answering your question. I think at the beginning
column3: we don’t really comment on future products. But I would tell you that we’re thrilled with the reception of iPhone X. And as we said when we launched it
column4: we were setting up the next decade. And that is how we look at it. And so that's the reason it's chockfull of incredible innovation. And so you can bet that we're pulling that string.

column1: Mike Olson: And then how you're think about AR beyond iPhone? You've created the world's largest AR platform. You've got developers generating a wide variety of apps. I realized it's still early days. But do you see Apple as a provider of a larger ecosystem of AR-enabled device beyond iPhone and iPad in the coming years? Or should investors focus on the opportunity within your existing device portfolio for at least the foreseeable future? Thanks.
TimCook: I see AR as being profound. I think
column2: AR has the ability to amplify human performance instead of isolating humans. And so I am a huge
column3: huge believer in AR. We put a lot of energy on AR removing very fast. We've gone from ARkit 1.0 to 1.5 in just a matter of months. I couldn't be happier with the rate and face of the developer community
column4: how faster developing these things. And I don’t want to say what we may do. But I could not be happier with how things are going right now.

column1: Operator: And next we’ll go to Toni Sacconaghi from Bernstein.
Toni Sacconaghi: I have a question and follow-up. You commented on how your install based over the last couple of years has grown 30%. And iPhone is clearly the largest component of that
column2: and so iPhone install base is probably growing close to that number perhaps last
column3: call it 20% through 25%. Yet
column4: if we look at iPhone unit growth for fiscal ’18 what’s implied with your guidance fiscal ’17 and fiscal ’16
column5: it’s been relatively flat. So you have an install base that’s 20% plus higher
column6: and a unit growth that relatively flat
column7: which would suggest that your upgrade rate is going down or your replacement cycle is elongating. And I’m wondering whether you agree with that and whether investors should be worried about that. And maybe if I could just add one other wrinkle to potentially get your response on is. Given consumers’ heightened awareness of their ability to replace batteries going forward as opposed to upgrades. Isn’t that also something that investors should potentially be concerned about in terms of its impact on upgrade rate going forward? And then believe or not
column8: I have a follow-up.

column1: TimCook: This is up to investors as to what things they would like to focus on

But generally what we see with iPhone is the reliability of iPhone is fantastic. The second or the previously owned market has expanded in units over the years. And you see in many cases
column3: carriers and retailers having very vibrant programs around trading an iPhone in. And because iPhone has the largest residual rate on it
column4: it acts as a buffer for the customer to buy new one and it lines up with another customer somewhere else that is perfectly fine with having a previously owned iPhone. And so I view all of that to be incredibly positive. It’s more people on iPhones the better. I would like to point out that the ever year major product hit a high on the active install base. And so that’s iPad
column5: it’s Mac and those are huge numbers as well. And so as we’ve always said

column9: shape
column10: or form
column11: what it would do to upgrade rates. We did it because we thought it was the right thing to do for our customers. And sitting here today

column3: Luca

column1: Tim Cook: I think on the replacement cycle

column3: the answer is

column1: Operator: Next we'll go to Steve Milunovich from UBS.
Steve Milunovich: Tim
column2: you said you don't want to tell investors what to do. But the first point you made was talking about the size of the install base. Later you've talked about the importance of customer satisfaction. Given that this doesn't look like a super-cycle in terms of unit growth

column1: Tim Cook: What I said on the investor part is that I think every investor has to look at their own situation and conclude the things that they think are important. What I think is important
column2: I think the active devices are hugely important and that's the reason that we released the number two years ago
column3: and the reason that we’re releasing that again today. That number speaks to the strength of the product the loyalty of the customer
column4: the strength of the ecosystem. And so we do put a lot of weight behind that. And it obviously also fuels the services business. So I have long believed that on 90 day clock on unit sales is a very surface way to view Apple. I think that the far bigger thing is to look over a longer period of time. And customer satisfaction and engagement and number of active devices are all part of that.

column1: Steve Milunovich: And could you address the positioning of HomePod? What category is it in
column2: is it a music speaker
column3: is it a home system
column4: since people seem to be trying to position it versus Amazon and Google’s offerings? And is the target market primarily Apple Music users?

column1: Tim Cook: HomePod is an incredible product that is a unbelievable audio experience in a very small form factor with a super digital assistant in Siri that knows an enormous amount of music. But also can handle request to like home automation to close your garage door
column2: open your door
column3: turn the light on
column4: turn the fireplace on
column5: change the thermostat
column6: all of the things that you would like to do in home automation. But takes it further
column7: because we think do it right from the home app instead of seeing. So you can see
column8: hey Siri
column9: I’m reading and your room will change to the things you would like happening in that particular room for when you read
column10: maybe it’s a particular light
column11: maybe it’s a type of light
column12: maybe it’s the fireplace
column13: so on and so forth. It also
column14: obviously
column15: you can also do things with HomePod like use it as a speaker phone. And so if you’re talking to your parents or they’re talking to their grand kids
column16: its unbelievable audio quality for speaker phone. You can also have Siri call for you
column17: you can send messages
column18: you can get a Uber car or a Lyft car. And so there is just a whole variety of things. And so I think the use cases on this much like our phones will be broad based. Some people will use it significantly for music and others may use it significantly for as a digital assistance; and I think the majority of people will likely use all of it and use all of the functionality of it.

column1: Operator: Our next question comes from Amit Daryanani from RBC Capital Markets.
Amit Daryanani: I have two questions as well. I guess first one. Could you just touch on what you’re seeing in China in terms of underlying trends
column2: right now? I think growth was up double-digit year-over-year but essentially in line to what you saw in September. I would have thought that would have accelerated a little bit with iPhone X. Just the puts and takes in China will be great.

column1: Tim Cook: It’s a good question. Keep in mind that this year had 13 weeks
column2: last year had 14 weeks. And so even though we were reporting a similar year-over-year growth for Greater China
column3: if you change that reporting to an average weekly sales
column4: which probably is much better way to look at it
column5: there was actually a really nice acceleration. And specifically the numbers this quarter as reported are 11% increase for Greater China year-over-year but on an average weekly revenue basis
column6: we were up 19%. Also Mainland China
column7: we had an all-time record for revenue in Mainland China. And of course a key part of that was iPhone. And as I’ve mentioned before
column8: Kantar reported that the top five selling smartphones in urban China were all iPhones. And so we could not be more pleased with how we're doing. And if you look at the other -- we obviously grew share for iPhone in the quarter
column9: but we also grew share in iPad and Mac during the quarter and wearables were extremely strong there in the quarter. And so everywhere I look
column10: I feel really good about how we're doing in China.

column1: Amit Daryanani: Luca
column2: maybe a question for you. When you talked about reducing Apple's net cash levels to zero effectively over time
column3: I think that implies -- the number goes from $163 billion today to something like zero. What does over time mean for Apple? Is that one year
column4: three years
column5: 10 years
column6: or how do you define over time? And does this change your thoughts around M&A at all
column7: and is that one reason to get that number from $163 billion to zero. Does it change your M&A thought process?

column1: Luca Maestri: Let me answer
column2: Amit
column3: starting with M&A. Our thought process around M&A has always been the same
column4: and really doesn't change. We've been acquiring companies over the years. In calendar 2017
column5: we've acquired 19 companies. And the thought process is always to acquire something that allows us to either accelerate our product roadmaps
column6: filling gap in our portfolio
column7: providing a new experience to customers. So it's always with the customer experience in mind that we make acquisitions. We look at all sizes
column8: and we will continue to do so. We have plenty of financial flexibility
column9: of course. We had that even prior to tax reform. And as I said
column10: we will talk about capital allocation plans when we report at the March quarter and that will include talking about timeframes and pace and so on. And so we’ll try to be to be very thoughtful. As we said
column11: $163 billion is a large amount and there are even practical considerations around it. So we'll see.

column1: Tim Cook: And just for clarity
column2: let me add one thing. What Luca is saying is not cash equals zero. He's saying there's an equal amount cash and debt
column3: and that they balance to zero. Just for clarity.

column3: EPS up 30%. Starting with revenue

column11: up $2.8 billion over last year and a March quarter record. Diluted earnings per share were $2.73
column12: up 30% to a new record for Q2

column33: and that's up more than $2 billion from last year
column34: an increase of 31% and double the services revenue we generated in the March quarter just four years ago. Our services business is growing at a very fast pace all around the world
column35: with revenue up more than 25% year-over-year in each of our five geographic segments. The App Store set a new all-time revenue record in the March quarter and Apple Music reached a new record for both revenue and paid subscribers
column36: which have now passed 40 million. iCloud storage revenue was up by over 50% year-over-year to a new all-time record
column37: and AppleCare revenue grew at its highest rate in five quarters
column38: setting a new March quarter record. Our other product category also set a new record for the March quarter with revenue of almost $4 billion. We began shipping HomePod in February and unit sales of both Apple Watch and AirPods reached a new high for the March quarter. When we combine all our wearables and home products
column39: they accounted for over 90% of the total growth in the other products category. Next
column40: I'd like to talk about the Mac which set a new March quarter revenue record including new records in both the Americas and Greater China. We sold 4.1 million Macs
column41: generating year-over-year growth in many emerging markets including Latin America
column42: the Middle East and Africa
column43: Central and Eastern Europe and India. We were happy to see double digit growth in our active installed base of Macs to a new all-time high
column44: with almost 60% of March quarter purchases coming from customers who are new to Mac. iPad grew both units and revenue for the fourth consecutive quarter. We sold 9.1 million iPads and about half of purchases were by customers new to iPad. Growth was particularly strong in Japan
column45: in Latin America
column46: Middle East and Africa and Central and Eastern Europe. All markets where iPad sales were up double digits compared to a year ago. We gained share of the global tablet market based on the latest estimates from IDC and our active installed base of iPads reached an all-time high. NPD indicates that iPad has 53% of the U.S. tablet market in the March quarter
column47: up from 40% share a year ago. And the most recent customer survey from 451 Research measured iPad customer satisfaction ratings of 95% and among business customers who plan to purchase tablets in the June quarter
column48: 73% plan to purchase iPads. We continue to make great strides in the enterprise market. In February
column49: we announced a new cyber risk management solution for businesses with Cisco
column50: Aon and Allianz. This combined approach is an industry first that integrates the most secure technology from Apple and Cisco
column51: cyber resilience evaluation services from Aon and options for enhanced cyber insurance coverage from Allianz. Organizations will now be able to better manage and protect themselves from cyber risks associated with ransomware and other malware-related threats. We are thrilled that insurance industry leaders recognize that Apple products provide superior security. In March
column52: we announced two new services with IBM to bring more dynamic and intelligent insights into apps. IBM Watson services for Core ML and IBM Cloud Developer Console for Apple will enable developers to more easily build native iOS apps that bring together machine learning with artificial intelligence and cloud services. In healthcare
column53: iPhones are being used across leading health systems including Cedars-Sinai
column54: the Mayo Clinic and HCA Healthcare with iOS apps to support clinical workflows
column55: communications and care delivery. In fact
column56: HCA Healthcare recently announced they plan to deploy 100
column57: 000 iPhones across their hospital sites within the next three years. We had great performance from our retail and online stores which produced their highest March quarter revenue ever. Year-over-year growth was led by iPhone as well as strong performance from AirPods and introduction of HomePod. Our stores hosted more than 250
column58: 000 of our very popular Today at Apple sessions with a particular emphasis on coding and app design. During the quarter
column59: we opened beautiful new stores in South Korea and in Austria
column60: our first in both countries
column61: and three weeks ago we opened our newest store in Tokyo
column62: bringing us to 502 stores across the world today. Let me now turn to our cash position. We ended the quarter with $267.2 billion in cash plus marketable securities
column63: and we had $110 billion in term debt and $12 billion in commercial paper outstanding for a net cash position of $145 billion. We returned nearly $27 billion to investors during the quarter. We paid $3.2 billion in dividends and equivalents and spent $23.5 billion on repurchases of 137 million Apple shares through open market transactions. We also retired 5.7 million shares upon the completion of our 13 ASR during the quarter. We have now completed over $275 billion of our current $300 billion capital return program
column64: including $200 billion in share repurchases against our cumulative $210 million buyback program. We will complete the $210 billion program during the June quarter
column65: three full quarters sooner than initially planned. The biggest priorities for our cash have not changed over the years. We want to maintain the cash we need to fund our day-to-day operations
column66: to invest in our future
column67: and to provide flexibility so that we can respond effectively to the strategic opportunities we encounter along the way. As we said 90 days ago
column68: the new tax legislation enacted in December gives us increased financial and operational flexibility from the access to our global cash. It allows us to invest for growth in the United States more efficiently and it also provides us the opportunity to work towards a more optimal capital structure. As we said in February
column69: our goal is to become approximately net cash neutral over time. Given our strong confidence in Apple's future and the value that we see in our stock
column70: our board has authorized a new $100 billion share repurchase program which we will start executing during the June quarter. Considering the unprecedented size of this new authorization
column71: we want to be particularly thoughtful and flexible in our approach to repurchasing shares. Our intention is to execute our program efficiently and at a fast pace. As in the past
column72: we will provide regular updates on our capital return activities at the end of every quarter. We're also raising our dividend for the sixth time in less than six years. As we know
column73: it is very important for our investors who value income. The quarterly dividend will grow from $0.63 to $0.73 per share
column74: an increase of 16%. This is effective with our next dividend which the board has declared today
column75: payable on May 17
column77: to shareholders of record as of May 14
column78: 2018. With over $13 billion in annual dividend payments
column79: we are proud to be among the largest dividend payers in the world and we continue to plan for annual dividend increases going forward. We will continue to review our capital allocation regularly
column80: taking into account the needs of our business
column81: our investment opportunities
column82: and our financial outlook. We will also continue to solicit input on our program from a broad base of shareholders. This approach will allow us to be flexible and thoughtful about the size
column83: the mix and the pace of our program. We expect to provide a new update to our capital allocation plans approximately 12 months from now. As we move ahead into the June quarter
column84: I'd like to review our outlook which includes the types of forward-looking information that Nancy referred to at the beginning of the call. We expect revenue to be between $51.5 billion and $53.5 billion. We expect gross margin to be between 38% and 38.5%. We expect OpEx to be between $7.7 billion and $7.8 billion. We expect OI&E to be about $400 million. And we expect our tax rate to be about 14.5%. With that
column85: I'd like to open the call to questions.

column1: Nancy Paxton: Thank you
column2: Luca. And we ask that you limit yourself to one one-part question and one follow up. May we have the first question
column3: please?

column1: Operator: Your first question will come from Shannon Cross with Cross Research.
Shannon S. Cross: Thank you very much. I wanted to ask about your thoughts on sort of iPhone and positioning now that we're a couple of quarters out from the launch of the iPhone X. Given the $1
column2: 000 price point
column3: and it's clearly selling but there's been a lot of questions in the market about sustainability of that price point and how you're thinking about it as you look out sort of holistically across your lineup. So if you could talk a bit about what you're hearing from your customers and then I have a follow up. Thank you.

column1: Timothy Donald Cook: Sure. Shannon
column2: it's Tim. As Luca mentioned earlier
column3: our revenues are up 14% year-over-year on iPhone and that's a combination of single digit unit growth and ASP growth that is mainly driven by iPhone X. I think that our iPhone line shows that there's a variety of different customers in a market that is as large as a smartphone market and so we're going to continue to provide different iPhones for folks to meet their needs. On iPhone X specifically
column4: I think it's important to maybe emphasize again one of the things I mentioned in my opening comments
column5: that customers chose iPhone X more than any other iPhone each and every week in the March quarter
column6: just as they did following its launch in the December quarter. Also
column7: since we split the line with the launch of iPhone 6 and 6 Plus back in 2014
column8: this is the first cycle that we've ever had where the top of the line iPhone model has also been the most popular. And so with the customer set that Luca referenced as well
column9: the 99%
column10: the iPhone X is a beloved product. And so I think that it's one of those things where like a team wins the Super Bowl
column11: maybe you want them to win by a few more points but it's a Super Bowl winner and that's how we feel about it. I could not be prouder of the product.

column1: Shannon S. Cross: Okay. Thank you. And then
column2: Luca
column3: can you talk a bit about working capital
column4: specifically inventory which went up pretty significantly quarter-over-quarter? What's driving that and how are you thinking about
column5: I mean
column6: it's one of the uses of cash obviously
column7: so how are you thinking about inventory and maybe working capital in general as you're going forward?

column1: Luca Maestri: Yeah
column2: Shannon
column3: you know that we've always generated significant amount of cash through working capital. We've got a negative cash conversion cycle and we plan to continue to have that. Our inventory level has gone up. It's just a temporary event. We have decided to make some purchasing decision
column4: given current market conditions
column5: and that should unwind over time.

column1: Shannon S. Cross: So that was essentially component purchases?
Luca Maestri: Correct.
Nancy Paxton: Thank you. Shannon.
Shannon S. Cross: Okay. Thank you very much.
Nancy Paxton: Can we have the next question
column2: please?

column1: Operator: From Morgan Stanley
column2: Katy Huberty.

column1: Kathryn Lynn Huberty: Thank you. Good afternoon. The services growth acceleration is really the highlight this quarter in my mind. Can you talk about what the biggest drivers
column2: whether it be products or regions that drove the acceleration and do you think that we can continue to see growth north of 30%? And then I have a follow-up.

column1: Timothy Donald Cook: Hi
column2: Katy. It's Tim. The services grew 31%. We hit an all-time record at $9.2 billion
column3: first time we cleared $9 billion. The great news about it is
column4: it's not a single geo or a single service. If you look at it
column5: each of the geos
column6: the minimum was at 25%. So each of the geos did extremely well and we set records from the App Store to the Apple Music to iCloud to Apple Pay and more. And underneath that
column7: if you look at the subscriptions
column8: the number of subscriptions
column9: I think I mentioned this in my comments
column10: paid subscriptions had moved up over 100 million on a year-over-year basis to over 270 million by the end of the quarter. And so it's very broad-based in terms of type of service and geographic region. It's sort of exactly what we would like to see. In terms of forecasting moving forward
column11: we've obviously made assumption for our guidance that Luca provided earlier and in terms of longer term
column12: we're on target to our 2020 goal of doubling the services revenue of 2016 as we had talked about previously.

column1: Kathryn Lynn Huberty: And it doesn't look like the threat of a trade war with China slowed down that business. In fact
column2: growth accelerated. But anything anecdotally that you see in the business in recent weeks that would suggest that that is having an impact on demand and any actions that Apple is taking as a company to preempt any risk of tariffs going forward?

column1: Timothy Donald Cook: Yeah
column2: I think my own view is that China and the U.S. have this unavoidable mutuality where China only wins if the U.S. wins and the U.S. only wins if China wins and the world only wins if China and the U.S. win. And so I think there's lots of things that bind the countries together and I'm actually very optimistic. I think history shows us that countries that embrace openness and diversity do much
column3: much better than the ones that are closed. And so I'm a big believer that the two countries together can both win and grow the pie
column4: not just allocate it differently. And so that's our focus
column5: and I'm optimistic that – I don't know every play by play that will happen
column6: but over time
column7: I think that view will prevail.

column1: Nancy Paxton: Thank you
column2: Katy. Could we have the next question
column3: please?

column1: Operator: And that will come from Mike Olson with Piper Jaffray.
Michael J. Olson: Hey. Good afternoon
column2: and thank you for taking my question. Just following on the services question
column3: I'd be curious what the next drivers of services revenue are. Will it be continued penetration of Music and Pay that you see as kind of the largest future categories of incremental growth? Or maybe when could augmented reality become a material part of services? And then I have a follow up.

column1: Timothy Donald Cook: Well
column2: Mike
column3: it's Tim. Again
column4: the great thing about services is there are several services that make up the total that are growing nicely. And I think the other good news is that because our active installed base is at such a level
column5: that last quarter we said that we had exceeded 1.3 billion. This year – we're not going to release this number every quarter
column6: but we've obviously grown again. And it's growing at a double digit number on a year-over-year basis. And so with that kind of change in the installed base and with the services that we have now and others that we are working on
column7: I think this is just a huge opportunity for us and feel very good about the track that we're on.

column1: Michael J. Olson: Okay. And then any potential tariff issues aside
column2: what's working for Apple in China right now? You talked about it being the strongest year-over-year growth in 10 quarters. I guess
column3: what's driving that? Is it iPhone X specifically
column4: or something else that's behind that improvement? Thank you.

column1: Timothy Donald Cook: It's a good question. iPhone X was the most popular smartphone in all of China last quarter. And so iPhone X has done well there. In order to hit a number like 21% on the growth that you see on your data sheet there
column2: there has to be several things working well. And the things that have huge growth rates there are the other products category
column3: which is our wearables business in China and the services business
column4: which you and I just spoke about. The iPhone obviously had to do extremely well to get a 21% number. And we gained share in the market for the Mac as well. And so there's actually several vectors there that are working well for us. We also – more broadly on the iPhone
column5: the iPhone was the top three selling phones in China. And so it's iPhone X was number one
column6: but we had several in the top.

column1: Nancy Paxton: Thanks
column2: Mike. Could we have the next question
column3: please?

column1: Operator: From RBC Capital Markets
column2: Amit Daryanani.

column1: Amit Daryanani: Thanks a lot. Two questions from me as well. I guess first one
column2: just touching on the gross margin dynamics
column3: if I look at the guidance for June on a year-over-year basis
column4: I think sales are up double digit but gross margins are still flat at the high end
column5: maybe down 20 basis points at the midpoint. Can you just talk about what's driving the lack of leverage on a gross margin basis on a year-over-year basis for June?

column1: Luca Maestri: Yeah
column2: Amit
column3: it's Luca. We tend to look at our gross margin dynamics on a sequential basis
column4: and essentially we're guiding to about flat on a sequential basis. On a year-over-year basis
column5: it's less relevant for our business. But in general
column6: I would say that this year we are seeing a more difficult cost environment
column7: particularly we're still dealing with about 70 basis points of impact from the memory pricing environment that we're working through.

column1: Amit Daryanani: Got it. And if I could just follow up. Tim
column2: you've been fairly vocal I think talking about the need for better privacy protection and well-crafted regulation over time. Could you just maybe help us understand
column3: how does Apple protect consumer data? And how does this ongoing debate around data protection translate into a positive for Apple over time?

column1: Timothy Donald Cook: We protect it by encrypting it
column2: and we keep the bulk of information or a significant amount of information on the device so that the user is in control of it. We also collect much less overall than others do. Because if you look at our model
column3: if we can convince you to buy an iPhone or an iPad
column4: we'll make a little bit of money. You're not our product. And so that's how we look at that. In terms of benefit
column5: we don't really view it like that. We view that privacy is a fundamental human right and that it's an extremely complex situation if you're a user to understand a lot of the user agreements and so forth. And we've always viewed that part of our role was to sort of make things as simple as possible for the user and provide them a level of privacy and security. And so that's how we look at it.

column1: Nancy Paxton: Thank you
column2: Amit. Could we have the next question
column3: please?

column1: Operator: We'll go to Steve Milunovich with UBS.
Steven Milunovich: Great. Thank you. Luca
column2: could you talk a bit more about the capital allocation? The dividend increase of 16% was relatively low relative to what you could have done
column3: so are you really thinking the stock price is attractive here? And you said you would execute the buyback at a fast pace. Can you give us any timeframe of that $100 billion and how much debt do you think about in terms of net cash zero?

column1: Luca Maestri: Yes. Let's start with the dividend. We're increasing it by 16%. This is the largest increase that we've done since we've reintroduced the dividend back in August of 2012. So we think it's a very meaningful increase for all the investors that value income. Obviously
column2: when we come down to capital allocation decisions
column3: we obviously also keep in mind that the opportunity for us to do some M&A activities which we do in an ongoing basis. But when it comes down between dividends and buyback
column4: our view is that for a variety of reasons we see a lot of value in the stock. We believe the stock is undervalued and so we have a bias towards the buyback. So the dividend is a very large component of capital return because we're going to be returning more than $13 billion a year to investors through dividends but we believe that given where we are with the valuation of the stock
column5: we think that we continue to do the buyback primarily. We are not giving an end date to the program this time because the amount is very
column6: very large and so we will try to execute it. As you've seen from our track record during the last five years
column7: we will do it at a very fast pace but we also want to do it efficiently. We want to make sure that we buy back the stock at the right time. And so with that in mind
column8: we have done $23.5 billion of repurchases during the March quarter. We will give you an update to our activities at the end of every quarter and then 12 months from now we will actually talk about an update to the entire program. So you will be able to keep track of our progress every 90 days.

column1: Steven Milunovich: Thank you. And
column2: Tim
column3: could you talk a bit about your healthcare opportunity? Is it merely selling watches over time or do you think more broadly about it? Is there a services play? You're doing some things for your employees. Could that potentially broaden out? How do you think about the opportunity there?

column1: Timothy Donald Cook: We think about it very broadly and you can tell that a bit by some of the things that we've had going with ResearchKit and CareKit and most recently the health records that I had referenced in my initial comments and those all came out of getting significantly engaged in the Apple Watch and sort of pulling the strings
column2: so to speak. And we also have a heart study that is going on currently
column3: and so I don't want to give too much away. But it's an area of great interest where we think we can make a big difference in. And so it's a major strategic thrust of ours.

column1: Nancy Paxton: Thanks
column2: Steve. Could we have the next question
column3: please?

column1: Operator: We'll go to Brian White with Monness
column2: Crespi.

column1: Brian J. White: Yes
column2: Tim
column3: I think there is China numbers are actually phenomenal in the quarter and third consecutive quarter of growth. I think there's been a lot of concerns just Apple in China and maybe misinformation out there. But what do you see as the drivers for Apple in both Mainland China and Greater China over the next few years? And also if you could just give us an update on what you're seeing in India.

column1: Timothy Donald Cook: Yeah
column2: good question. Let me start with India
column3: and then I'll talk more about China. India
column4: we set a new first-half record. So we continue to put great energy there and try to – our objective over time is to go in there with all of our different initiatives from retail and everything else. And so we're working toward those things. It's a huge market and it's clear that many people will be moving into the middle class over time
column5: as we've seen in other countries. China
column6: I continue to believe is a phenomenal country with lots of opportunity from a market point of view
column7: but also lots of opportunity from a app developer point of view. We have almost 2 million application developers in China that are writing apps for iOS and the App Store
column8: and they're doing unbelievably creative work and innovative work. So we look at China holistically
column9: not only as a market. On the market side
column10: we've seen iPhone X
column11: as I had mentioned before
column12: as being the top selling smartphone during the quarter. We gained share during the quarter. I read some notes here and there about the market itself not being good. I think on any kind of
column13: on a 90-day clock
column14: lots of different things can happen. But my own personal view of China is that it's a great market
column15: and we are certainly looking far beyond 90 days and feel very bullish on the opportunity and the environment there. I would say that the market for us is more than iPhone. The Mac gained share there as well. The Watch is getting some traction there. Services is doing extremely well. And so it has several catalysts and I'm very pleased with the results that we were able to show during the quarter.

column1: Brian J. White: Great. Thank you.
Nancy Paxton: Thanks
column2: Brian. Could we have the next question
column3: please?

column1: Operator: Next we'll hear from Wamsi Mohan with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
Wamsi Mohan: Thank you. Good afternoon. Tim
column2: can you comment on the price elasticity of demand at the high end for iPhones
column3: if that was in line with your expectations? Do you have a preference for unit growth versus ASP growth when it comes to maximizing that gross profit dollar growth? And I have a follow-up for Luca
column4: please.

column1: Timothy Donald Cook: We price for the value that we're delivering
column2: and iPhone X is the most innovative product on the market. And I've said a few times
column3: we have there sort of jam-packed with technologies that really set up the smartphone for the next decade. And so that's how we priced it. We were surprised somewhat that through all of this period of time that the iPhone X winds up at the most selling
column4: most popular for every week of the time since the launch. And so that's I think a powerful point. And it's number one in China
column5: which is another powerful point. And so obviously at some point if those technologies move to lower price points and that there's probably more unit demand. But the way we think about it is trying to price a reasonable price for the value that we deliver and I feel that we did that.

column1: Wamsi Mohan: Thank you
column2: Tim. And
column3: Luca
column4: your gross margins have been very robust despite the headwinds that you absorbed on commodities
column5: which you quantified
column6: and frankly
column7: also from the FX hedges that are limiting somewhat the FX upside that a lot of other companies are seeing. So as you
column8: one
column9: when do you expect these to turn into tailwinds? And when they do turn into tailwinds
column10: would you consider reinvesting some of those into pricing or should we think about you flowing those through to the bottom line?

column1: Luca Maestri: Well
column2: Wamsi
column3: I think
column4: let me start with where we are right now. I think you're right. I think we've been able to navigate a difficult foreign exchange environment for a number of years and now
column5: as you know
column6: because we have this hedging program as the dollar has weakened a bit in recent months
column7: although during the last week it's actually started to turn the other way again
column8: we've got the hedging program that works both ways. And also on the memory front
column9: we feel that for NAND
column10: we're going to be turning the corner very soon. For DRAM
column11: we also think that we are near the peak
column12: possibly at the end of this year. And so that should provide some level of stability. As I said earlier this year
column13: I think we are experiencing in total a more difficult cost environment and so hopefully that can turn into a positive for us. At the same time
column14: it's very difficult for me to give you an indication of what is going to happen in the future because every product cycle is different
column15: and as you know
column16: we don't provide guidance past the current quarter. There are some elements that we understand quite well and we tend to manage well over the course of the cycle. For example
column17: our cost structures that we are able to manage throughout the year. But there are also elements that are not entirely under our control like foreign exchange. And the mix of products and services that we sell to our customers also has an impact on the overall gross margin. Our primary consideration is always around maximizing gross margin dollars
column18: and that is the approach that we take around for example pricing decisions.

column1: Nancy Paxton: Thank you
column2: Wamsi. Could we have the next question
column3: please?

column1: Operator: From Citi
column2: we'll hear from Jim Suva.

column1: Jim Suva: Thank you very much. And I'll ask actually both my questions at the same time
column2: one for Tim and one for Luca. Tim
column3: strategically when we talk to investors they often say
column4: oh
column5: iPhone market is saturated. There's not much room for growth. Yet when we do our analysis
column6: we kind of still see emerging markets like India and all those still are growth. When you think about India and those markets
column7: do you kind of believe that some of those markets could get to much higher or a more normalized market share that you have in some of the developing countries over time? And can you talk a little bit about some of those efforts you may be doing? And then
column8: Luca
column9: on the question for you
column10: is about the gross margin. When we think about if component prices start to stabilize
column11: seeing how Apple services have been so successful and accretive to margins
column12: should we start to look for some potential margin
column13: gross margin upside
column14: again should components stabilize? Thank you
column15: gentlemen.

column1: Timothy Donald Cook: Yeah
column2: Jim
column3: thanks for the question. In terms of the – let me address the smartphone market a bit and then I'll mention iPhone. In terms of the market in general
column4: if you look at last year
column5: which is the last data point we have on the full market
column6: there were still 0.5 billion feature phones sold in the world. And so many of those were sold into emerging markets
column7: not all of them
column8: but many of them. And we still believe that over time every phone sold will be a smartphone. And so it seems to us that with that many feature phones being sold
column9: that's a pretty big opportunity. In terms of the iPhone itself
column10: even though we sell quite a few phones across the course of a year
column11: our market share globally is low compared to the – our sales are low compared to the full market of smartphones. And so our task is to convince people that currently – or have another type of phone to switch
column12: while really taking care of people that have an iPhone so that they choose – when they elect to buy another phone
column13: that they buy another iPhone. And so we've spent quite a bit of time on that
column14: as you might guess. I do think that India
column15: India is the third largest smartphone market in the world. There's obviously huge opportunities there for us
column16: and we have extremely low share in that market overall. And so we're putting a lot of energy there and working with the carriers in that market
column17: and they're investing enormously on the LTE networks. And the infrastructure has come quite a ways since we began to put a lot of energy in there because of their leadership and so forth. And so I do think – I don't buy the view that market's saturated. I don't see that from a market point of view or – and certainly not from an iPhone point of view. I think the smartphone market is sort of like the best market for a consumer product company in the history of the world and – but that's how I feel about it. It's a terrific market
column18: and we're very happy to be a part of it.

column1: Luca Maestri: Jim
column2: on the gross margin side
column3: I think I'll repeat what I said earlier
column4: but you're right. Our services business
column5: and I've said it in the past
column6: is accretive to company margins. And so as we are able to grow the services business
column7: that should provide a positive
column8: a tailwind. At the same time
column9: within the services portfolio that we have
column10: we have services that have different levels of profitability
column11: so we also need to take into account the mix of services that we're going to be selling. At a macro level
column12: because about two-thirds of our company is outside the United States
column13: a weak dollar is a positive for our gross margins; a strong dollar
column14: as it's been during the last four years
column15: has been a bit of a headwind for the company. We try to make it more stable through the hedging program. And in general
column16: when we look at our process to innovate our products
column17: typically when we launch a new product
column18: that product tends to have a higher cost structure than the product it replaces. And so that is something that we need to work through every time we launch a new product and we have a pretty good track record and history of taking those cost structures down over time. So we need to balance all these different elements. I think we've done a pretty remarkable job during the last several years at managing all these different variables and coming out with a level of gross margins that we think is really good for investors and certainly it is our plan to continue to manage them that way. But it's very difficult for me to give you a prediction of where gross margins are going to be six months or 12 months from now.

column1: Nancy Paxton: Thank you
column2: Jim.

column1: Jim Suva: Thank you for the details and congratulations.

column14: but you also have to analyze the purchases that you're making through other companies that are not related to revenue. Maybe they're related to data centers and this sort of thing and so we're going through that now and we'll be sharing our results later on those and feeding back public comment. Of course the risk associated with more of a macroeconomic issue such as an economic slowdown in one or more countries or currency fluctuations that are related to tariffs is very difficult to quantify. And so that
column15: and we're not even trying to quantify that
column16: to be clear about it. All of this said
column17: we're optimistic
column18: as I've been the whole time
column19: that this will get sorted out because there is an inescapable mutuality between the U.S. and China that sort of serves as a magnet to bring both countries together
column20: that each country can only prosper if the other does and of course the world needs both U.S. and China to prosper for the world to do well. That said
column21: I can't predict the future
column22: but I am optimistic that the countries will get through this and we are hoping that calm heads prevail.

column2: Tim. I'm wondering if you could talk a little bit about the multi-year partnership with Oprah Winfrey and what that says about your original content strategy and also Apple Music. If you can give us a little more colors or an update maybe around paid subscribers or total subscribers around Apple Music and how you feel that's rolled out.

column1: Timothy Donald Cook: Yeah sure
column2: Brian. Thanks for the question. We're very excited to work with Oprah. We think that her incomparable ability and talent to connect with audiences around the world
column3: that there's sort of no match and we think that we can do some great original content together and so we could not be happier in working with Oprah. As you know

column5: but I couldn't be more excited about what's going on there and we've got great talent in the area that we've sourced from different places and feel really good about what we will eventually offer. In terms of the sort of the key catalysts and the changes
column6: the cord cutting in our view is only going to accelerate and probably accelerate at a much faster rate than is widely thought. We're seeing the things that we have on the periphery of this like Apple TV
column7: units and revenue grew by very strong double digits
column8: very
column9: very strong double digits in Q3. As I mentioned in my opening comments
column10: we're seeing different providers pick up the Apple TV and use it as their box to go to market with their subscription service. There are
column11: within the 300 million-plus paid subscriptions
column12: some of these are third party video subscriptions and we see the growth that is going on there. It's like 100% year-over-year. And so all the things from a – all the forcing functions here from the outside all point to dramatic changes speeding up in the content industry
column13: and so we're really happy to be working on some of them
column14: but we're just not ready to talk about it in depth today. In terms of Apple Music
column15: we're well over 50 million listeners now when you add our paid subscribers and the folks in the trial
column16: and so we're moving along at a very

column19: but really
column20: the key thing in music is not the competition between companies that are providing music. It's the real challenge is to grow the market

column22: it's
column23: outside of China
column24: it's less than 200 million probably around the world. And so it does seem to me there's an extraordinary opportunity in that business to grow the market well and I think if we put our emphasis there

column1: Operator: Toni Sacconaghi with Bernstein has our next question.
Antonio M. Sacconaghi: Yes. Thank you. I have one for Luca and one for Tim please. Luca
column2: I'm wondering as we think about modeling Q4
column3: iPhone ASPs are typically up sequentially about 2% to 4%
column4: sort of low single digits. Perhaps you can help us think through how we should be thinking about Q4. I know you provided some commentary last quarter on how we should be thinking about Q3 ASPs.

column1: Luca Maestri: Toni
column2: as you know
column3: we do not provide guidance for either units or ASPs for any product category
column4: but of course we provided guidance on revenue and that the guidance range implies growth of 16% to 19%. We expect the growth to come from strong growth from iPhone
column5: from services and from wearables
column6: which has been a bit of our pattern during the course of the year. On iPhone ASP
column7: the only thing that I would point out is that obviously we're exiting the June quarter at a significantly higher level than in the past and so that I think is important to keep in mind as we move into the September quarter. It's important to keep in mind the type of revenue growth that we've implied in our guidance.

column1: Antonio M. Sacconaghi: Okay. Thank you. Tim
column2: I was wondering if you could just comment a little bit about the health of the smartphone market. Apple's smartphone iPhone units have been relatively flat for four years and I think you've probably been a share gainer during the period which would suggest at least at the high end of the market
column3: that it's perhaps flat-to-down and I'm wondering if you can comment on
column4: A
column5: whether you believe that and what you think might be happening with replacement cycles. And specifically
column6: also what impact if any you've seen from wider availability and less expensive replacement batteries for iPhones.

column1: Timothy Donald Cook: I think the smartphone market is very healthy. I think it's actually the best market in the world to be in for someone that is in the business that we're in. It's an enormous sized market and whether it grows
column2: from our point of view
column3: whether it grows 1% or 2% or 5% or 6% or 10% or shrinks 1% or 2%
column4: it's a great market because it's just huge. And so that's kind of the way that I view that. iPhone revenues are up 20% for the quarter over last year. We're really pleased with that and if you look at the sort of the cycle
column5: which I'll define as Q1
column6: Q2
column7: Q3 for ease
column8: you'll see that we've grown like mid single digits and on an average weekly sales point of view
column9: and of course double digit on the ASP and so I think it's really healthy. In terms of replacement cycles
column10: as I'd mentioned I think on a previous call
column11: some replacement cycles are lengthening. I think that the major catalyst for that was probably the subsidy plans becoming a much smaller percentage of total sales around the world than they were at one time and so I think that some are lengthening. And
column12: but I think for us
column13: the thing that we always have to do is come out with a really great innovative product
column14: and I think that iPhone X shows that when you deliver a great innovative product
column15: there's enough people there that would like that and it can be a really good business
column16: and so that's how to look at that. In terms of our installed base
column17: which is something very important for us as it is one of the key drivers of services
column18: our active installed base on iPhone grew double digits over last year during the quarter and so we're thrilled with that and you can see that carrying through to the services line and the growth that we had there. In terms of batteries
column19: we have never done an analysis internally about how many people decided to get a lower-priced battery than buy another phone because it was never about that for us. It was always about doing something great for the user and I think if you treat the users and the customers well
column20: then you have a good business over time and so that's how we'd look at that.

column1: Nancy Paxton: Thank you
column2: Toni.

column1: Antonio M. Sacconaghi: Thank you.

Laura Martin: Yeah
column2: can you hear me okay?

column1: Nancy Paxton: Yes.
Luca Maestri: Yes.
Laura Martin: Great. Okay. Super. So I'd like to focus on product roadmap and strategy. There is a war going on for the home
column2: the connected home
column3: over the Internet of Things. And with two products
column4: the HomePod and Apple TV in the home
column5: my question is strategically
column6: how do you feel about the importance of being in the home and whether it threatens your dominance outside the home with your core business in the mobile devices if you sort of lose that battle? I'm just trying to figure out strategically when you think about where the puck is going
column7: how important is it for you to have a beachhead in the home as well as out of home?

column1: Timothy Donald Cook: I think the home business
column2: Laura
column3: is bigger than the HomePod and Apple TV. They're both important products clearly
column4: but everybody has their iPhone at home as well and everybody has their Mac at home and everyone has their iPad at home. And so in terms of the Siri access point
column5: as you can tell from the 100 billion number I quoted in the script
column6: there's an extraordinary amount of usage of these products that are used to perform home-related functions. I do that every day with controlling all my home automation and so on and so forth. Part of that is on HomePod but part of it is with the Apple Watch and the iPhone and the iPad
column7: and so I think home is important. Home is important. Work is important. The movement between the two are important. Health is important. So the smartphone has become the repository that goes across the whole of your life
column8: not something that is just meant for a portion of it and so I think all of those are important and we're focused on all of them.

column1: Laura Martin: Okay. That's helpful
column2: actually. Okay.

column1: Timothy Donald Cook: Thanks for your question.
Laura Martin: Yeah. Sort of. I mean I'll watch your product roadmap and be able to tell what the answer is. The other thing
column2: the thing I get in fights with investors about the most is this and I'd love your insight on this. I love the expansion of the new products. The question I have is are they actually on-ramps into the Apple ecosystem
column3: the Beats
column4: the Watch
column5: the AirPods
column6: subscriptions
column7: are they on-ramps into the ecosystem or is the on-ramp to the ecosystem the iPhone and then these new products add revenue per member once you get somebody into the ecosystem via the iPhone?

column1: Timothy Donald Cook: A lot of people that buy Apple products buy for the whole ecosystem
column2: even though they might not currently use all the different products. And so the way that I think about those products are they're products within the ecosystem itself. And there's the AirPods have really gone through the roof and the Apple Watch has hit an air pocket and has gone to a whole different level as I'd mentioned earlier with our overall wearables revenue. And so in my view
column3: this is a part of the – they are a core part of the ecosystem.

column1: Nancy Paxton: Thank you
column2: Laura.

column1: Laura Martin: But do they attract people to the ecosystem or does the person have to have an iPhone first?
Timothy Donald Cook: It is
column2: well
column3: but on your point though
column4: it is clear from communications I've had with users that some of them were attracted to iPhone because of the Apple Watch.

column1: Laura Martin: Oh
column2: I see.

column1: Timothy Donald Cook: So the Apple Watch led them to the iPhone. The reverse of that is also true
column2: is that somebody got the iPhone and then decided I really want something to coach me in fitness and to curate some of the communications and so forth like the watch does so well and so it's not always a linear path. I see these things as being somewhat fluid and different for each user.

column1: Nancy Paxton: Thank you
column2: Laura.

column1: Laura Martin: So they're complementary and self-reinforcing? Okay. That makes sense. All right. Thanks very much.
Timothy Donald Cook: That's exactly right. Thank you for the question.
Laura Martin: Thank you.
Nancy Paxton: Thank you
column2: Laura.
