column81: we recently announced Apple Business Manager
column82: a new way for IT teams to deploy Apple devices at scale. The response from companies around the world has been tremendous with over 40
column83: 000 companies currently enrolled. Let me now turn to our cash position. We ended the quarter with $237.1 billion in cash plus marketable securities. We also had $102.5 billion in term debt and $12 billion in commercial paper outstanding for a net cash position of $122.6 billion. As explained earlier this year
column84: it is our plan to reach a net cash neutral position over time. As part of this plan
column85: we returned over $23 billion to investors during quarter. We repurchased 92.5 million Apple shares for $19.4 billion through open market transactions and we paid $3.5 billion in dividends and equivalents. For our fiscal year 2018
column86: revenue grew over $36 billion to $265.6 billion
column87: an all-time record. Every geographic segment grew double digits with new records in the Americas
column88: Europe
column89: Japan and rest of Asia-Pacific. We also set new all-time records for net income
column90: up 23% versus last year
column91: and EPS up 29%. And we returned a total of almost $90 billion to our investors during the year
column92: including almost $14 billion in dividends and equivalents and over $73 billion in share repurchases. Before we discuss our December quarter outlook
column93: I'd like to describe a number of changes in our financial reporting that we're implementing as we enter our new fiscal year. First
column94: given the increasing importance of our services business and in order to provide additional transparency to our financial results
column95: we will start reporting revenue as well as cost of sales for both total products and total services beginning this December quarter. Second
column96: also beginning in this December quarter
column97: we're adopting the FASB's new standard for revenue recognition. This will not result in any change to our total revenue
column98: but it will impact the way we report the classification of revenue between products and services. In particular
column99: the revenue corresponding to the amortization of the deferred value of bundled services such as Maps
column101: and free iCloud services was previously reported in product revenue. After adopting the new standard
column102: this revenue will now be reported in services revenue. The change in classification between products and services will also apply to the costs that are associated with the delivery of such bundled services. After we file our 10-K
column103: we will post a schedule to our Investor Relations website showing the reclassification of fiscal 2018 revenue from products to services in connection with the adoption of the new standard. The size of this reclassification amounts to less than 1% of total company revenue. And for clarity
column104: this reclassification was not contemplated in our previously stated goal of doubling our fiscal 2016 services revenue by 2020. That goal remains unchanged and excludes the revenue that is now shifting from products to services over that timeframe. Third
column106: we will no longer be providing unit sales data for iPhone
column107: iPad and Mac. As we have stated many times
column108: our objective is to make great products and services that enrich people's lives
column109: and to provide an unparalleled customer experience so that our users are highly satisfied
column110: loyal and engaged. As we accomplish these objectives
column111: strong financial results follow. As demonstrated by our financial performance in recent years
column112: the number of units sold in any 90-day period is not necessarily representative of the underlying strength of our business. Furthermore
column113: a unit of sale is less relevant for us today than it was in the past
column114: given the breadth of our portfolio and the wider sales price dispersion within any given product line. Fourth
column116: we will be renaming the other products category to wearables
column118: and accessories to provide a more accurate description of the items that are included in this product category. As we move ahead into the December quarter
column119: I'd like to review our outlook
column120: which includes the types of forward-looking information that Nancy referred to at the beginning of the call. We have the strongest lineup ever as we enter the holiday season and we expect revenue to be between $89 billion and $93 billion
column121: a new all-time record. This range reflects a number of factors to be considered. First
column122: we considered the effect on Q4 and Q1 of the launch timing of our new iPhones this year versus last year. Second
column123: we expect almost $2 billion of foreign exchange headwinds. Third
column124: we have an unprecedented number of products ramping
column125: and while our ramps are going fairly well
column126: we have uncertainty around supply and demand balance. And fourth
column127: we also face some macroeconomic uncertainty
column128: particularly in emerging markets. We expect gross margin to be between 38% and 38.5%. We expect OpEx to be between $8.7 billion and $8.8 billion. We expect OI&E to be about $300 million
column129: and we expect the tax rate to be about 16.5% before discrete items. Also today
column130: our board of directors has declared a cash dividend of $0.73 per share of common stock payable on November 15
column131: 2018 to shareholders of record as of November 12
column133: I'd like to open the call to questions.

column1: Nancy Paxton: Thank you
column2: Luca
column3: and we'd like to ask that you limit yourself to two questions. Operator
column4: may we have the first question please?

column1: Operator: Certainly. Our first question will come from Wamsi Mohan with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
Wamsi Mohan: Yes. Thank you. Tim
column2: there has been some real deceleration in some of these emerging markets
column3: partly driven by some concerns around some of the rules the administration is contemplating and partly driven by things that are more specific to China
column4: for instance
column5: like some of the regulations around gaming. So can you talk about how you see the trajectory there for the business and what you think of the initiatives of some companies like Netflix and Fortnite trying to bypass the App Store around subscriptions and I have a follow-up.

column1: Timothy Donald Cook: Sure. Great question. Starting with emerging markets. The emerging markets that we're seeing pressure in are markets like Turkey
column2: India
column3: Brazil
column4: Russia. These are markets where currencies have weakened over the recent period. In some cases
column5: that resulted in us raising prices and those markets are not growing the way we would like to see. To give you a perspective in of some detail
column6: our business in India in Q4 was flat. Obviously
column7: we would like to see that be a huge growth. Brazil was down somewhat compared to the previous year. And so I think
column8: or at least the way that I see these
column9: is each one of the emerging markets has a bit of a different story
column10: and I don't see it as some sort of issue that is common between those for the most part. In relation to China specifically
column11: I would not put China in that category. Our business in China was very strong last quarter. We grew 16%
column12: which we're very happy with. iPhone in particular was very strong
column13: very strong double-digit growth there. Our other products category was also stronger
column14: in fact
column15: a bit stronger than even the overall company number. The App Store in China
column16: we have seen a slowdown or a moratorium
column17: to be more accurate
column18: on new game approvals. There is a new regulatory setup in China
column19: and there things are not moving the way they were moving previously. We did see a few games approved recently
column20: but it's very far below the historic pace. And as you've probably seen
column21: some of the larger companies there that are public have talked about this as they've announced their earnings as well. We don't know exactly when this will – the approvals will return to a normal pace
column22: so I would not want to predict that. I do not view – just for avoidance of doubt here
column23: I don't view that that issue has anything to do with the trade-related discussions between the countries. I think that is strictly a domestic issue in China. In terms of larger developers
column24: if you step back and look at the value proposition for people from the App Store
column25: there are two key constituencies in that equation. There's the user and there's the developer. If you start with the user
column26: what the App Store provides people is the best and safest place for users to get apps. And we have a tremendous process and infrastructure around achieving that. And where it is not perfect
column27: we wind up reviewing over 100
column28: 000 apps per week between new apps and updates for existing apps
column29: and then work with developers quickly to fix the issues. And we also provide the user a one-payment model for purchasing apps and subscriptions and in-app purchases
column30: et cetera
column31: so that they are not in a position that they have to share their private information across many companies. And so that's the proposition for the user. For the developer
column32: we obviously provide the developers a tremendous amount of developer tools
column33: programs
column34: compilers
column35: languages
column36: of course the operating system
column37: APIs
column38: SDKs
column39: and have a huge developer relations team. And we do a tremendous amount of marketing for developers
column40: including the new Today Editorial that we just started in the past few months
column41: personal recommendations
column42: search tools
column43: and so on and so forth. And so there will be – there's no doubt in my mind there have already been some large developers that concluded that they could do something on their own. We're fine with that. I think Luca mentioned in his comments that the largest – if I look at the largest developer
column44: they make up less than 0.3% of the services revenue
column45: so it's probably good to think about that in that context
column46: and there are millions of apps on the store obviously
column47: and 30
column48: 000 or so subscription apps. And so the subscription business itself is nearly as broad as the App Store itself is
column49: and so that's the value proposition. I think that the vast majority of people are very happy with it
column50: including the most important people at all
column51: which is the user.

column1: Wamsi Mohan: Thank you
column2: Tim. I appreciate the response.

column1: Timothy Donald Cook: Yeah.
Wamsi Mohan: If I could just ask you really quick on Apple's role in healthcare
column2: it's been growing significantly since the early introduction in the Watch and then the various kits for developers
column3: including HealthKit
column4: CareKit
column5: et cetera. And when you combine that with your very staunch advocacy for privacy
column6: I see Apple could become a really large disintermediating force in all the friction in the healthcare industry today in the way medical information is shared and distributed. Is this the way that you see the future for Apple in healthcare? And do you see a means to also grow your services business through the healthcare offerings that could become subscriptions to your customers? Thank you.

column1: Timothy Donald Cook: I think Apple has a huge opportunity in health. And you can see from our past several years that we have an intense interest in the space and are adding products and services
column2: non-monetized services
column3: so far to that. And I don't want to talk about the future because I don't want to give away what we're doing
column4: but this is an area of major interest to us. Thank you.

column1: Nancy Paxton: Thank you
column2: Wamsi. Could we have the next question
column3: please?

column1: Operator: Shannon Cross from Cross Research has the next question.
Shannon S. Cross: Thank you very much for taking the question. Given the $4 billion range in revenue that you're giving for the quarter and all the things that are going on in the world right now
column2: can you maybe give a little detail about the variables that you took into account when you were coming up with this? Geopolitical trade
column3: macro
column4: component costs
column5: I don't know if you can just give us some ideas of what the puts and takes were. Thank you.

column1: Luca Maestri: Yes
column2: Shannon
column3: I'll take this one. At the revenue level
column4: we started from the fact that we are very
column5: very excited about the lineup of products and services that we have getting into the holiday season. It's the strongest lineup that we've ever had. And our guidance range
column6: by the way
column7: represents a new all-time quarterly revenue record. As I explained in my prepared remarks
column8: there are a number of things that need to be considered as part of this guidance range. The first one is the fact that the launch timing of the new iPhones this year is essentially in reverse order versus last year
column9: and that has had an effect on Q4 and will have an effect on Q1. Last year
column10: we launched the top end of our iPhone lineup
column11: which was iPhone X
column12: during Q1 and placed the entirety of the channel fill for iPhone X in Q1. This year
column13: we launched the top end of the lineup
column14: which is the XS and the XS Max during Q4. Obviously
column15: this resulted in more pronounced ASP growth in Q4 of 2018 and obviously a tougher compare for Q1. So I think it's important to keep that in mind as you look at the revenue guidance that we provided. The second point that needs to be kept in mind
column16: it is a fact of life and we dealt with it for a number of years now
column17: is the fact that when I look at currencies around the world
column18: virtually every foreign currency has depreciated against the U.S. dollar in the last 12 months. And when we look at the impact of foreign exchange on our revenue for the December quarter
column19: we're looking at 200 basis points of headwinds which translates
column20: given our the size of our business
column21: to almost $2 billion of headwind to our revenue. The third point that I think it's important to keep in mind
column22: and Tim has talked about this
column23: we are launching
column24: in the last six weeks
column25: we've launched an unprecedented number of new products. They're all ramping right now. The ramps are going fairly well
column26: but obviously we have some uncertainty around supply/demand balance for some of these products. And then finally
column27: the last point that we've taken into account is what Tim's talked about in terms of some level of uncertainty at the macroeconomic level in some emerging markets where clearly consumer confidence is not as high as it was 12 months ago. So take that into account and that's how we got to the range.

column1: Shannon S. Cross: Okay. Thank you. And then
column2: I just want to talk a little bit about the pullback in terms of guidance from a unit perspective. I understand you don't want to give guidance because of 90 days is a short period of time and it can fluctuate
column3: but what kind of qualitative commentary do you think you'll be able to provide? Because it's obviously investors have spent the last however many years going P times Q. So
column4: how should we think about what we can expect and sort of how are you going to manage this process as we go through? I know it's all our job to forecast
column5: but.

column1: Luca Maestri: Yes. Let me walk you through the rationale that we've used and then I'll talk about this qualitative commentary that you were mentioning. As I said
column2: right
column3: our objective is to make great products
column4: provide the best customer experience
column5: and get our customer satisfied
column6: engaged and loyal to our ecosystem. When you look at our financial performance in recent years
column7: take the last three years
column8: for example
column9: the number of units sold during any quarter has not been necessarily representative of the underlying strength of our business. If you look at our revenue
column10: given the last three years
column11: if you look at our net income during the last three years
column12: if you look at our stock price here in the last three years
column13: there's no correlation to the units sold in any given period. As you know very well
column14: in addition
column15: our product ranges for all the major product categories have become wider over time and therefore
column16: a unit of sale is less relevant for us at this point compared to the past
column17: because we got this much wider sales price dispersion
column18: so unit of sale per se becomes less relevant. As I know you're aware
column19: by the way
column20: our top competitors in smartphones
column21: in tablets
column22: in computers
column23: do not provide quarterly unit sales information either. But of course we understand that this is something of interest and when we believe that providing qualitative commentary on unit sales offers additional relevant information to investors
column24: we will do so.

column1: Timothy Donald Cook: Looking at one additional point there just for clarity is
column2: Shannon
column3: our intention is to continue to give revenue guidance at the company level and gross margin guidance in the other categories that we've been providing and so that our guidance isn't changing. It's the actual report that changes.

column1: Nancy Paxton: Thank you
column2: Shannon. Could we have the next question please?

column1: Operator: Our next question comes from Mike Olson with Piper Jaffray.
Mike J. Olson: Thanks very much and good afternoon. With the staggered iPhone launch
column2: were you able to discern any impact on the XS and XS Max from buyers potentially waiting for the XR
column3: and what if anything can we take away from the December quarter guidance related to what you're seeing for early demand of the XR? And then I have a follow-up
column4: thanks.

column1: Timothy Donald Cook: Mike
column2: it's Tim. The XS and XS Max got off to a really great start and we've only been selling for a few weeks. The XR
column3: we've only had out there for I guess five days or so at this point
column4: and so we have very
column5: very little data there. Usually there is some amount of wait until another product shows up and look
column6: but in looking at the data
column7: on the sales data for XS and XS Max
column8: there's not obvious evidence of that in the data
column9: as I see it.

column1: Mike J. Olson: Got it
column2: and you mentioned record levels for various components of the services business. As we look forward
column3: if growth of services is to maintain something close to the recent pace
column4: what are the components of services that you're particularly excited about that could drive that and be the strongest drivers? And maybe an offshoot to that
column5: it seems like the news flow around augmented reality has slowed a little bit in recent months. Is that potentially a materially contributor to services in the near future? Thanks.

column1: Luca Maestri: Mike
column2: as we said
column3: during the September quarter
column4: we set new records for many
column5: many services categories
column6: right
column7: from Apple Music to cloud services to the App Store to AppleCare and Apple Pay really has an exponential trajectory right now. When we look at our services business
column8: we think about the fact that we have a very large and growing installed base. The installed base of all our major product categories is at an all-time high and has been growing over the last several quarters
column9: so the opportunity for us to monetize our services business continues to grow over time. Of course
column10: we're also improving the quality of the services that we provide and if you look back during the last three years
column11: we've added new services to our portfolio. We added Apple Pay
column12: we added Apple Music. We added this advertising business on our App Store. And clearly
column13: we will want to continue to offer new services over time
column14: so there are a number of vectors that allow us to continue to grow the business over time. We have stated that we want to double the size of the services business from the level that we had in fiscal 2016 by 2020. We are well on pace to achieve that
column15: and we feel very
column16: very confident about the future and the opportunities that we have in the services space.

column1: Timothy Donald Cook: Mike
column2: in terms of your question on AR
column3: I have a different view than you do on this one. Just a year ago
column4: practically a year ago
column5: we came out with ARKit 1. Six months or so after that we came out with 1.5. We then recently came out with ARKit 2. The number of things that you can do are growing significantly. The number of developers that either have done something
column6: or even more the case
column7: that are working on things that I've seen are growing tremendously. There's a lot of interest out there and the number of categories that I'm seeing from gaming to shopping
column8: to I was in China a few weeks ago and saw AR in an art sense
column9: in an art exhibit. I was in Berlin last week and saw it being used in a historical educational kind of sense. I'm seeing it sort of everywhere I go now
column10: and so I think we are in the early days
column11: and it'll keep getting better and better
column12: but I'm really happy with where things are at the moment.

column1: Nancy Paxton: Thank you
column2: Mike. Can we have the next question please?

column1: Operator: Next we'll go to Katy Huberty with Morgan Stanley.
Kathryn Lynn Huberty: Thank you. Tim
column2: given the current trade negotiations and broader geopolitical risk
column3: do you have any plans to consider diversifying the supply chain? And if you were to do that
column4: either on your own or sort of forced
column5: do you think it would have significant impact on the business or profitability?

column1: Timothy Donald Cook: Katy
column2: if you look at the products that we have created and are manufacturing
column3: they're really manufactured everywhere. We have significant content from the U.S. market. We have content from Japan to Korea to many countries
column4: and we have great content from China as well
column5: and so there are many hands in the products. The vast majority or almost all of the R&D is in the United States
column6: as well as a lot of the support organizations. And so
column7: I think that that basic model where you look around the world and find the best in different areas
column8: I don't expect that model to go out of style
column9: so to speak. I think there's a reason why things have developed in that way and I think it's great for all countries and citizens of countries that are involved in that. And I'm still of the mindset that I feel very optimistic and positive that the discussions that are going will be fruitful. These relationships
column10: these trade relationships are big and complex
column11: and they clearly do need a level of focus and a level of updating and modernization. And so I'm optimistic that the countries
column12: the U.S. and China and the U.S. and Europe and so forth
column13: can work these things out and work for the benefit of everyone.

column1: Kathryn Lynn Huberty: That's helpful color. And
column2: Luca
column3: as a follow-up
column4: NAND prices fell significantly during the September quarter. Why aren't we seeing that flow through to margin expansion for the overall company?

column1: Luca Maestri: You're referring to the guidance that we provided for Q1
column2: I imagine.

column1: Kathryn Lynn Huberty: Yes.
Luca Maestri: Let me give you the puts and takes
column2: Katy. You're correct. We are going to be getting some benefits from commodities in general and memory in particular. Memory on a sequential basis is about 30 basis points favorable for us going into the December quarter. And obviously
column3: we're going to be benefiting from the leverage
column4: which is typical of our seasonality in the December quarter. On the other hand
column5: as I mentioned before
column6: currencies have weakened against the U.S. dollar
column7: and the impact that we expect at the gross margin level from foreign exchange is a 90 basis points headwind sequentially. And of course
column8: at this point in the cycle
column9: we also have higher cost structures because
column10: as I said
column11: we've launched so many new products in the last six weeks. So those are the puts and takes
column12: leverage and commodity savings on one side and FX and the new products on the other side.

column1: Nancy Paxton: Thank you
column2: Katy. Could we have the next question
column3: please?

column1: Operator: Next
column2: we'll go to Jim Suva with Citigroup.

column1: Jim Suva: Thank you very much
column2: a question for Tim and a question for Luca
column3: and I'll ask them at the same time
column4: so you can decide who wants to go first or second. But operationally
column5: Tim
column6: I think your company is at a disadvantage relative to others in India
column7: giving where items are produced versus shipped versus taxed versus installed as well as ability to own stores. So can you help us address that? Is India going to potentially be a big area
column8: as I think you got about only about 1% market share
column9: but it sounded like things may be softer there? And then for Luca
column10: there will probably be a lot of pushback about not giving iPhone unit data. It sounds like you're still going to give revenue data
column11: if I heard that correctly
column12: but some people may fear that this now means that the iPhone units are going to start going negative year over year because it's easier to talk about great things and not show the details of things that aren't so great. So thank you very much
column13: gentlemen.

column1: Timothy Donald Cook: Okay
column2: I'll start with India. We've had really great productive discussions with the Indian government
column3: and I fully expect that at some point
column4: they will agree to allow us to bring our stores into the country. We've been in discussions with them
column5: and the discussions are going quite well. As you point out
column6: there are import duties in some or most of the product categories that we're in. In some cases
column7: they compound
column8: and this is an area that we're giving lots of feedback on. We do manufacture some of the entry iPhones in India
column9: and that project has gone well. I am a big believer in India. I am very bullish on the country and the people and our ability to do well there. The currency weakness has been part of our challenge there
column10: as you can tell from just looking at the currency trends
column11: but I view these as speed bumps along a very long journey
column12: though. And the long term I think is very
column13: very strong there. There's a huge number of people that will move into the middle class. The government has really focused on reform in a major way and made some very bold moves. And I applaud them for doing that and I can't wait for the future there.

column1: Luca Maestri: And
column2: Jim
column3: let me take the question on units. First of all
column4: as Tim said
column5: our approach to guidance
column6: providing guidance doesn't change at all. We continue to provide the same metrics that we were providing before. In terms of reporting results
column7: one of the things that we are doing
column8: and it's new and it's in addition to the information that we provide to investors because we've heard some significant level of interest around this
column9: is starting with the December quarter
column10: for the first time we're going to be providing information on revenue and cost of sales
column11: and therefore gross margins for both products and services. And this will be the first time that we're going to provide gross margin information for our services business
column12: which we believe is an important metric for our investors to follow. Given the rationale on why we do not believe that providing unit sales is particularly relevant for our company at this point
column13: I can reassure you that it is our objective to grow unit sales for every product category that we have. But as I said earlier
column14: a unit of sale is less relevant today than it was in the past. To give you an example
column15: the unit sales of iPhone at the top end of the line have been very strong during the September quarter
column16: and that's very important because we're attracting customers to the most recent technologies and features and innovation that we bring into the lineup
column17: but you don't necessarily see that in the number that is reported. And so therefore
column18: we will
column19: as I said
column20: we'll provide qualitative commentary when it is important and relevant. But at the end of the day
column21: we make our decisions from a financial standpoint to try and optimize our revenue and our gross margin dollars
column22: and that we think is the focus that is in the best interest of our investors.

column1: Timothy Donald Cook: Jim
column2: let me just add a couple things to that for color. Our installed base is growing at double digit
column3: and that's probably a much more significant metric for us from an ecosystem point of view and the customer loyalty
column4: et cetera. The second thing is this is a little bit like if you go to the market and you push your cart up to the cashier and she says
column5: or he says how many units you have in there? It doesn't matter a lot how many units there are in there in terms of the overall value of what's in the cart.

column1: Nancy Paxton: Thank you

72;AAPL;2019-01-30;"Operator: Good day and welcome to the Apple Incorporated First Quarter Fiscal Year 2019 Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. At this time for opening remarks and introductions
column2: I would like to turn the call over to Nancy Paxton
column3: Senior Director of Investor Relations. Please
column4: go ahead.

column1: Nancy Paxton: Thank you. Good afternoon and thanks to everyone for joining us. Speaking first today is Apple CEO
column2: Tim Cook
column3: and he'll be followed by CFO
column4: Luca Maestri. After that
column5: we'll open the call to questions from analysts. Please note that some of the information you'll hear during our discussion today will consist of forward-looking statements
column6: including without limitation those regarding revenue
column7: gross margin
column8: operating expenses
column9: other income and expense
column10: taxes
column11: capital allocation
column12: and future business outlook. Actual results or trends could differ materially from our forecast. For more information
column13: please refer to the Risk Factors discussed in Apple's most recently filed periodic reports on Form 10-K and Form 10-Q
column14: and the Form 8-K filed with the SEC today
column15: along with the Associated Press release. Apple assumes no obligation to update any forward-looking statements or information
column16: which speak as of their respective dates. I'd now like to turn the call over to Tim for introductory remarks.

column1: Tim Cook: Thank you
column2: Nancy and thanks to everyone for joining us today. This isn't the first time you've heard from us regarding the December quarter
column3: so the first thing I want to do is provide some final results and connect those back to the letter we shared at the beginning of the month. As you know
column4: our December quarter revenue was below our original expectations
column5: coming in at $84.3 billion. That's down 5% from a year ago
column6: or down 3% adjusting for foreign exchange. We noted four factors that would impact our results when we provided guidance in November: different iPhone launch timing from a year ago
column7: FX headwinds
column8: supply constraints on certain products and macroeconomic conditions in emerging markets. One of those factors
column9: weak macro conditions in some emerging markets was significantly more severe than we originally foresaw
column10: especially in Greater China. As our letter noted
column11: that challenge was compounded by quarterly iPhone upgrades that were lower than we anticipated. We'll return to upgrades in a moment
column12: but I'd first want to say a bit more about our business in Greater China. Our revenue there was down by $4.8 billion from last year with declines across iPhone
column13: Mac and iPad. Most of the shortfall relative to our original guidance and over 100% of our worldwide year-over-year revenue decline was driven by our performance in Greater China. Despite iPhone upgrades being lower than we anticipated

column43: what's behind this? It's important to understand what's going on from the customer perspective at the point of purchase. We believe that it's the sum of several factors. First
column44: foreign exchange. The relative strength of the U.S. dollar has made our products more expensive in many parts of the world. In Turkey

column48: iPhone subsidies are becoming increasingly less common. In Japan
column49: for example
column50: iPhone purchases were traditionally subsidized by carriers and bundled with service contracts. Competitive promotional activity frequently increase the amount of subsidy during key periods. Today
column51: local regulations have significantly restricted those subsidies as well as related competition. As a result
column52: we estimate that less than half of iPhones sold in Japan in Q1 of this year were subsidized compared to about three quarters a year ago and that the total value of those subsidies had come down as well. Third
column53: our battery replacement program. For millions of customers
column54: we made it inexpensive and efficient to replace the battery and hold onto their existing iPhones a bit longer. Some people have suggested that we shouldn't have done this because of the potential impact on upgrades

column74: flexible solution for everything from home automation to giant render forms. iPad revenue was up 17%

column76: Face ID and A12X Bionic chip

column78: thanks to strong sales of both Apple Watch and AirPods. We don't measure our success in 90-day increments. We manage Apple for the long term and when we consider the keys to our success over time there are three that stand out

column80: our large and growing active installed base and at the heart of it all

column84: by alerting them to potentially serious health conditions such as AFib and by helping them in times of crisis with features like fall detection and emergency SOS. We believe we are just beginning to see the impact we can make to improving health and are deeply inspired by the possibilities. Another example is the work we're doing with silicon. We've embedded machine learning directly into the silicon with our A12 Bionic chip. Our custom Neural Engine not only provides power efficiency and incredible performance in a very small package
column85: but it also enables processing of data and transactions directly on the device. This means iPhone can recognize patterns make predictions and learn from experience and it does all this while keeping personal information private. This is a powerful example of how innovation and privacy can go hand-in-hand at a time when these issues are increasingly important to our users. We are undertaking and accelerating a number of initiatives to improve our results. It's not in our DNA to just stand around and wait for macroeconomic conditions to improve. One such initiative is making it simple to trade in an iPhone in our stores and raising awareness of this opportunity. Because of the quality and durability of iPhones

Apple innovates like no other company on earth and we are not taking our foot off the gas. We'll continue to invest through near-term headwinds just as we always have and we'll emerge stronger as a result. Now for more details on our December quarter results

column1: Luca Maestri: Yes
column2: Katy
column3: let me take that one. First of all
column4: when we talk about the services business
column5: it's very important to start from the momentum that we have. As you know
column6: we have set an ambitious target for ourselves to double the size of our business from fiscal 2016 to 2020
column7: which implied at the time a 19% CAGR. So far
column8: we've been able to grow about 20%. In fiscal 2018
column9: we grew 22%. So we are on track to achieve our objective. And it's important to understand what is driving the growth of the business. First of all
column10: it's our installed base. As we just told you
column11: the installed base continues to grow very nicely. It has reached 1.4 billion active devices at the end of December and really very little of our services revenue is driven by what we sell in the last 90 days. The second factor for the growth of the services business is that within this installed base the percentage of users who are paying for at least one service is growing very strongly. This is due to several factors. First of all
column12: we're offering more and more services. During the last few years
column13: as you know
column14: we launched Apple Music
column15: Apple Pay and advertising service for our developers on the App Store. All these businesses are growing very strongly. Second
column16: we are making it easier for our customers to transact on our digital stores. We accept many more payment methods today which are very common in certain countries around the world. We've also increased the distribution coverage for many of these services. We're bringing AppleCare to more points of sale around the world. We are launching Apple Pay in more and more markets and so on. Thirdly
column17: as you mentioned
column18: our subscriptions are becoming a very large portion of our business and they're growing very well above services average. And the fact that we are saying that we will surpass 0.5 billion during 2020
column19: we're not putting a specific date during 2020
column20: but I think you've seen over recent quarters that we've been adding about 120 million on a year-over-year basis for a number of quarters now. And this is an incredible staggering number
column21: right
column22: when you think about it. We are also broadening the scope of many of these services. If you take Apple Pay as an example
column23: it started off as the most convenient
column24: most private and most secure way to make a payment in a store or in an app. Then we took Apple Pay to Safari
column25: then we started a peer-to-peer service and we're launching it in new markets across the world every quarter
column26: so we are broadening that scope. And of course
column27: similar to what we've done in the past in the last three years
column28: we launched several new services
column29: we're also looking to launch new services going forward that we believe will provide great value to our users and we're really very excited about the opportunities that we see in front of us. I think you're referring to the deceleration in the growth rate that we've seen in the December quarter. And I think you're referring back to the growth that we reported in September. I think an important point I need to make
column30: and I think it's helpful that you asked the question
column31: is that a portion of this deceleration is truly just a reclassification of the amortization of free services that we've made in connection with the adoption of the new revenue recognition standard. And as we explained 90 days ago
column32: this amortization of free services in the past was reported under Products and now gets reported under Services. The reclassification is actually dilutive to our growth rate because the amortization of free services is a relatively stable number
column33: which gets applied to a growing base. So this reclassification reduces our growth rate versus the previous classification. This factor by itself represents roughly one-third of the deceleration that you're seeing. We talked about 27% growth in the September quarter. With the reclassification that growth rate was about 24.5%. So that explains about a third of that deceleration. There are
column34: I would say three factors that explain this difference between the 24.5% to the 19%. The first one is that foreign exchange plays a role. Roughly 60% of our Services business is outside the United States. And as you know the U.S. dollar has appreciated in recent months. And in general
column35: we tend not to reprice our services for foreign exchange on a very frequent basis. The second factor is a well-known issue around the App Store in China. The App Store in China is a large business for us. We believe this issue around the approval of new game titles is temporary in nature
column36: but clearly is affecting our business right now. And then thirdly
column37: we are seeing some level of deceleration in AppleCare
column38: which has had very
column39: very strong growth during fiscal 2018
column40: where we're starting to lap some of the increase in distribution coverage that we put in place recently and the channel fill of Apple components that happened when we increase the distribution coverage. But in general
column41: we are very
column42: very pleased with 19% growth and we think that the business will continue to grow nicely going forward.

Toni Sacconaghi: Yes. Thank you. I have one for Luca and one for Tim. Luca
column2: looks like the midpoint of your Q2 revenue guidance implies the steepest Q1 to Q2 sequential decline in iPhone revenues in history. It also implies a year-over-year deceleration in iPhone revenues. And I'm wondering
column3: if you can comment about whether that's conservatism
column4: whether you're entering the quarter with a high level of channel inventory and maybe you can comment explicitly on that
column5: or whether you actually think the macroeconomic conditions are getting worse?

column1: Luca Maestri: Yeah. I mean three questions there. The first one is a question around conservatism. As we always do when we provide a range
column2: it's a range that we believe we're going to fall within. We've done pretty well with that up until the December quarter
column3: right? I mean
column4: we've been – we didn't miss in years and years. So that's the idea. There isn't a specific level of conservatism. We believe that this is the range where we're going to fall within. On channel inventory
column5: as you know our historical pattern for iPhone channel inventory is that typically we increase inventory in Q1 and we decrease in Q2. And we think this year will be similar and we've exited the December quarter with levels of inventory that we are comfortable with. So that leaves us with the reality that our iPhone performance in Q1 from a revenue standpoint was minus 15%. And we expect that the key factors that Tim mentioned during the call affecting iPhone performance in Q1 will also have an effect on Q2 starting with the strong U.S. dollar environment. On a year-over-year basis
column6: the negative impact from currency is going to be about $1.3 billion
column7: so that's about a bit more than two points versus last year's revenue and so that obviously plays a role. And the macroeconomic environment particularly in emerging markets will continue to be there. On the positive side
column8: we expect that we will continue to grow revenue nicely from the rest of the business which is not iPhone.

column1: Toni Sacconaghi: Okay. Tim
column2: at your September event Lisa Jackson
column3: an Apple VP
column4: stated the company needed to quote design products to last as long as possible. And Apple's clearly doing that by helping with the battery replacement program
column5: iOS working on an older range of products et cetera. But I guess the question is why doesn't that mean that replacement or upgrade cycles for iPhones should continue to extend going forward in part because that's almost one of your objectives? And maybe to that end
column6: maybe you can help us understand what iPhones' average replacement cycle might be today
column7: and how that may have changed over the last three to five years. And again
column8: why wouldn't you expect it to elongate over time given some of the aforementioned things? Thank you.

column1: Tim Cook: We do design our products to last as long as possible. Some people hold onto those for the life of the product and some people trade them in. And then that phone is then redistributed to someone else. And so it doesn't necessarily follow that one leads to the other. The cycles -- the average cycle has extended. There's no doubt about that. We've said several times I think on this call and before
column2: that the upgrades for the quarter were less than we anticipated due to the -- all the reasons that we had mentioned. So
column3: where it goes in the future
column4: I don't know
column5: but I'm convinced that making a great product that is high quality
column6: that is the best thing for the customer and we work for the user. And so that's the way that we look at it.

column1: Nancy Paxton: Thank you
column2: Toni. Could we have the next question

column1: Operator: Next question will come from Shannon Cross with Cross Research.
Shannon Cross: Thank you very much. I wanted to ask about the trajectory of Services gross margin
column2: up about 500 basis points it appears year-over-year. You talked a little bit about sequential. But what's driving the improvement or will it be volatile as we go through the year depending on quarters and mix? Just whatever color you can give us as we start to forecast this? Thank you.

column1: Luca Maestri: Yes
column2: Shannon. I think you've seen that Services gross margins increased on a year-over-year basis by a significant amount. Let me start with sequential because I think it's probably most relevant for us. Sequentially
column3: we increased 170 basis points. It's a business that is growing nicely
column4: so we get good support from our scale. Some of these services are scaling quickly and so we tend to expand gross margins there. And also
column5: we had favorable mix. As you probably know
column6: we have a very broad portfolio of Services. Some of them tend to be accretive to the average gross margin for services
column7: also because of the way we account for them. For example
column8: you know that on the App Store
column9: we book revenue on a net basis and therefore the gross margins tend to be accretive. But we also have services that are very successful
column10: that are below the average for the services business. And so depending on how these separate businesses do in the marketplace
column11: we're going to be seeing some level of movement going forward on services margins. But you've seen that for the last 12 months they've gone up nicely 450 basis points and sequentially they've gone up 170 basis points. But I wouldn't draw necessarily a conclusion on how this services gross margin is going to move over time. We will report of course at the end of every quarter. But important to keep in mind
column12: it's a broad portfolio with very different gross margin profiles within the portfolio. It is important for us to grow gross margin dollars. And if at times we grow services that are at a level of gross margins
column13: which is below average
column14: as long as this is good for the customer and as long as we generate gross margin dollars we're going to be very pleased.

column1: Shannon Cross: Okay
column2: thank you. And then Tim

column5: it should be accretive to margin I would think?

column2: Shannon
column3: we see huge changes in customer behavior taking place now. And I think that it'll likely take place at a much faster pace this year. And so we're going to participate in that in a variety of ways. One of those is through Apple TV and you're well familiar with that product. The second way is AirPlay 2
column4: which we have as just pointed out we have support on a number of different third-party TVs. And we're excited about that. It makes the experience in the living room with people using our products even better. We think that people are really going to like that. Another way is
column5: of course
column6: all the third-party video subscriptions that are on the store. We are participating in this today. And I would guess that that's going to accelerate into the future as the bundle breaks down and people begin to buy likely multiple services in place of their current cable bundle. And then finally
column7: original content where we will participate in the original content world. We have signed a multiyear partnership with Oprah. But today I'm not really ready to extend that conversation beyond that point. We've hired some great people that I have a super amount of confidence in and they're working really hard and we'll have something to say more on that later.

column1: Operator: The next question will come from Walter Piecyk with BTIG.
Walter Piecyk: Great
column2: thanks. I just have a question on the free services. Can you just describe how the math works on that? Is it that the free services are non cash revenue that's getting booked in the Services revenue with no cost and then the costs come out of products? Can you just run us through what the current status versus how you were accounting for that before?

column1: Luca Maestri: Yes in essence when we sell a product at a certain price
column2: we make an assumption. We estimate the value that can be associated to providing free services. In our case
column3: it's providing Maps services
column4: providing Siri and providing free iCloud to all the customers that purchase our product. And so we calculate an estimated value. That value gets deferred and gets amortized over the estimated period of time that we deliver the free services. In the past that deferral and the subsequent amortization was reported under products. Now in connection with the new revenue recognition standard
column5: we are reclassifying essentially that amortization from products revenue to services revenue. So total revenue has not changed
column6: we just report that estimated value under the Services category. We also reclassify the cost that we need to incur to provide those services. So the gross margin rate of these services is clearly significantly dilutive to the overall Services margin. I hope I've...

column1: Walter Piecyk: So it did make services gross margin
column2: got it. And then my other -- my second question is just
column3: when you think about growth in Services
column4: you have selling more to existing paid subscription customers or it's the 300 million going to 0.5 billion. If you can just talk at a high level as far as when you look at growth going forward
column5: is it about -- what is the mix in terms of selling more to existing users
column6: getting new users or -- and maybe some of the individual services that you see the biggest growth opportunity? Thank you.

column1: Luca Maestri: Yes. I mean as I said I mean essentially what -- services -- I said services too is our installed base. So the first driver is growing the installed base. Installed base has grown nicely over the last several years. We've added 100 million in the last 12 months alone. So that's the first step. Then within that installed base
column2: of course we want to make sure that there are more people that are so interested in our services that in addition to transacting on those services on a free basis
column3: they also are interested in paying for those services. And I mentioned that the percentage of paid accounts has increased strong double-digits. So we want to continue to do that. We want to make it easier for our customers to actually use our services and so we are accepting more and more payment methods around the world. And clearly
column4: as you said the idea of adding new services is very important to us. During the last three years
column5: we've added Apple Pay
column6: which has been incredibly successful and is a wonderful customer experience. We've added Apple Music
column7: where we now have more than 50 million paid subscribers and continues to grow very nicely. And we've added a very useful service to our developers. We provide an advertising service for developers in the App Store. The way we've added these services in the past
column8: obviously
column9: we're also very interested in adding new services that can provide great value to our customers in the future. Now we don't want to get into product announcements here
column10: but obviously that is part of our strategy.

column62: we always want to maintain the cash we need to run our business

column64: and invest in our future. We're well on our way towards meeting the investment projections we laid out early last year. We also want to work towards a more optimal capital structure and as we said before
column65: it is our plan to reach a net cash neutral position over time. Given our confidence in Apple's future and the value we see in our stock
column66: our Board has authorized an additional $75 billion for share repurchases. And because we know many of our investors value income
column67: we're also raising our quarterly dividend for the seventh time in less than seven years to $0.77
column68: an increase of about 5% from the previous amount. We paid over $14 billion in dividends and equivalents over the last four quarters alone
column69: making us one of the largest dividend payers in the world. Going forward
column70: we continue to plan for annual increases in dividends per share. As we move ahead into the June quarter
column71: I'd like to review our outlook
column72: which includes the types of forward-looking information that Nancy referred to at the beginning of the call. We expect revenue to be between $52.5 billion and $54.5 billion. This guidance range comprehends 300 basis points of negative foreign exchange impact year-over-year. Also as a reminder
column73: in the June quarter last year
column74: our Services revenue included a favorable $236 million one-time item in connection with the final resolution of various lawsuits. We expect gross margin to be between 37% and 38%. We expect OpEx to be between $8.7 billion and $8.8 billion. We expect OI&E to be about $250 million
column75: and we expect the tax rate to be about 16.5%. Also reflecting the approved increase
column76: today our Board of Directors has declared a cash dividend of $0.77 per share of common stock
column77: payable on May 16
column78: 2019 to shareholders of record as of May 15
column79: 2019. With that
column80: I would like to open the call to questions.

column1: Nancy Paxton: Thank you
column2: Luca. And we ask that you limit yourselves to two questions. Operator
column3: may we have the first question please?

column1: Operator: Certainly. Our first question will come from Shannon Cross with Cross Research.
Shannon Cross: Thank you very much for taking my question. Tim
column2: can you talk a bit more about what you're seeing in China? Clearly
column3: it looks like things are improving sequentially. You also mentioned that last few weeks of the quarter
column4: were stabilizing in emerging markets
column5: I believe. So what are customers saying there and what are your partners saying in China? And then I have a follow-up.

column1: Tim Cook: Yeah. Thanks for the question
column2: Shannon. We're seeing -- in the iPhone space
column3: we saw a better year-over-year performance in the last weeks of the quarter as compared to the full quarter or November and December
column4: which was sort of a -- it appears to be the trough. I think there's a set of reasons for this. One
column5: we made some price adjustments essentially backing out the weaker currency effect and then some. There's stimulus programs that the government has executed including -- and this happened in early April
column6: VAT being reduced from 16% to 13%
column7: so they've been aggressive in the stimulus side. Three
column8: our trade-in and financing programs that we’ve implemented in our retail stores have been very well received there
column9: and I'm happy with the results to date there. And then four
column10: there's an improved trade dialog between the U.S. and China. And from our point of view
column11: this has affected consumer confidence on the ground there in a positive way. And so
column12: I think it's a set of all of these things and we certainly feel a lot better than we did 90 days ago.

column1: Shannon Cross: Great. Thank you. And then
column2: I'm sure you're probably expecting a question on Qualcomm settlement. So what would you like to say on this settlement? How are you thinking about your component providers going forward? And how should we think about this with regard to -- I don't know your development plans in the future because I'm sure you're not going to talk about when you're going to do 5G
column3: but clearly it helps that path. Thank you.

column1: Tim Cook: Yeah. Thank you
column2: Shannon. We're glad to put the litigation behind us
column3: and all the litigation around the world has been dismissed and settled. We're very happy to have a multi-year supply agreement
column4: and we're happy that we have a direct license arrangement with Qualcomm
column5: which was I know important for both companies
column6: and so we feel good about the resolution.

column1: Nancy Paxton: Thank you
column2: Shannon. Can we have the next question
column3: please?

column1: Operator: The next question will come from Samik Chatterjee with JPMorgan.
Samik Chatterjee: Hi. Thanks for taking the question. Tim
column2: you talked about China responding well to these pricing actions that you've taken in that market. Do any of those learnings kind of carry through into how you decide pricing in the remaining emerging markets
column3: like India
column4: et cetera as you get ready for the next product cycle?

column1: Tim Cook: We have made some adjustments in India
column2: and we've seen preliminarily some better results there. Everything that we do does advise everything we do in the future
column3: so we try to learn the best we can and hold [ph] that into our thinking
column4: and we'll obviously do that with this as well.

column1: Samik Chatterjee: Thank you. I just had a quick follow-up for Luca on the Services side. Luca
column2: we see that you're guiding to higher operating expenses quarter-on-quarter. How much of that incremental is going in to support the new services that you're planning to launch later in the year?

column1: Luca Maestri: Yeah. Of course
column2: we are supporting both our products and services business and you can see the trajectory of our OpEx over the different quarters. Clearly as we add new services
column3: we will need to make the necessary investments to support them. Our Services business has multiple streams. In total
column4: it is accretive to company gross margins. You've seen the latest -- we're running services margins at over 60%. So
column5: it's a very important business for us in many ways for our ecosystem and for our ability to monetize it. And so
column6: clearly we will make all the necessary investments to ensure that the new services are successful
column7: and we're really encouraged by the level of customer response that we received so far in anticipation for the launch of these services.

column1: Nancy Paxton: Thank you
column2: Samik. Can we have the next question please.

column1: Operator: The next question will come from Katy Huberty with Morgan Stanley.
Katy Huberty: Thank you. Luca
column2: if I look back over the past five years
column3: June quarter revenue typically declines about 15% from the March quarter. You're guiding to an 8% drop this year. So can you just talk about
column4: which regions or product segments you think can outperform that typical seasonality?

column1: Luca Maestri: Yes
column2: Katy. And keep in mind by the way
column3: we are reporting this guidance including a 300 basis point negative impact from foreign exchange
column4: so actually in constant currency the numbers would be even stronger. At the product category level
column5: we expect that we will continue to have strong revenue growth from the non-iPhone categories as we've had for the first half of our fiscal year. We're also expecting a relative improvement in our iPhone performance on a year-over-year basis in Q3 versus the first half. As Tim said
column6: March was the strongest month of the quarter on a year-over-year basis and so this has given the confidence to provide the guidance that you've seen. Geographically
column7: of course
column8: as you've seen from our results for the March quarter
column9: China is the geo where we found some challenges
column10: but we believe the trajectory should improve over time.

column1: Katy Huberty: Thank you. And then just as a follow-up
column2: Shannon said you're not going to talk specifics around the timing of the 5G phone
column3: but Tim maybe you can talk about how the company approaches a new technology like this given the higher cost but also potentially significant benefit
column4: how you think about the right timing for coming to market with a product
column5: with those characteristics? And then just generally how meaningful you think 5G is as a demand driver for upgrades in your iPhone installed base? Thank you.

column1: Tim Cook: Katy
column2: this is one that I'm going to largely punt on as you would probably guess. We look at a lot of things on the different technologies and try to look at the -- and select the right time that things come together and get those into products as soon as we can. And the -- certainly from a cost point of view there has been -- the technologies have had cost pressure over the last couple of years or so. On the flip side of that there's a number of things in the commodity markets going in the other direction at the moment like DRAM and NAND. And so it's difficult to project what happens next
column3: but it's the aggregate of all of it that really matters from a price point of view.

column1: Nancy Paxton: Thank you
column2: Katy. So we have the next question
column3: please.

column1: Operator: Jim Suva from Citi has our next question.
Jim Suva: Thank you very much. A topic that's probably split or shared by both Tim and Luca on a response
column2: but I'll ask the question and you can decide how to divide it up. In your opening remarks
column3: Tim
column4: you'd mentioned about pricing adjustments that you made in some of the markets and then Luca talked also about the strength of the trade-in program or maybe it was Tim also. Can you help us understand about what type of lessons or elasticity you've learned about pricing and the trade-in programs of how it impacts like revenues and COGS and margins and things? Thank you.

column1: Tim Cook: Yeah. Jim
column2: in the opening remarks I was really talking about China specifically. And I mentioned four things that I believe are responsible for the better year-over-year performance in the Q2 relative to Q1 and also the final weeks of March being better than the Q2 average. And those four are the price reductions
column3: but that's one of them. But there are three others and one of the others is the trade-in and financing programs that we instituted in our retail stores. Clearly
column4: what we've learned here and it's not a surprise really is that the -- many
column5: many people do want to trade-in their current phone. It does -- from a customer user point of view the trade-in looks like a subsidy
column6: and so it is a way to offset the device cost itself. And many people in literally every market that we've tried this in
column7: there is a reasonable number of people that want to take and pay for something on installments instead of all at once. And so
column8: it's a little different in each market in terms of what the elasticity is
column9: but you can bet that we're learning quickly on all of those. The other two items that are not insignificant in China that I don't want to lose here is that the stimulus programs
column10: I believe
column11: are having an effect on the consumer. And the one that I got much visibility in -- that happened in early April was the VAT reduction from 16% to 13%
column12: so it's a very aggressive move. But there are other stimulus programs as well that likely have an effect to the consumer level. And then finally -- and this is not to be under weighted either -- I think the improved trade dialogue between the countries affects consumer confidence in a positive way. And so
column13: I think it's sort of the sum of all of those things.

column1: Luca Maestri: And Jim
column2: if I may add on the gross margin level as we look at pricing actions
column3: of course
column4: anytime you do a pricing action it is gross margin percentage diluted. But what really matters to us and what we look at -- when we look at the elasticity of these programs is to see the impact on our gross margin dollars. And what -- the experience that we've had in a few of these emerging markets has been positive in that respect and so that's what we think matters the most really.

column1: Jim Suva: Thank you so much
column2: gentlemen.

column1: Nancy Paxton: Thank you
column2: Jim. We have the next question
column3: please.

column1: Operator: The next question will come from Wamsi Mohan with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
Wamsi Mohan: Hi. Yes. Thank you. Tim
column2: you shared a lot of color around trade-ins
column3: but I was also hoping maybe you can characterize what sort of dynamics you're seeing across your installed base on these trade-ins. What type of devices are being traded in? Is the profile of someone who has a really old iPhone? Or are you seeing folks that have newer iPhones trading in? And what sort of incentives are you providing beyond sort of the financing to drive that? And do you see this as something that can accelerate replacement cycles here over the next year or so? And I have a follow-up.

column1: Tim Cook: We're -- actually the product that's being traded in is all over the place
column2: to be honest. It's 6
column3: 6 Plus
column4: 6S
column5: 6S Plus
column7: 7 Plus and then fewer 8 and 8 Plus. But there's some of each of those and so you get customers that are on the two-year cycle and customers -- some customers on the one-year cycle and then customers as well on the three and four-year cycles. And so it's really all over the place. In terms of the incentives we're offering currently in our retail stores a trade-in value that has -- that is more than the sort of the blue book of the device if you will for lack of a better description. And so we have topped those up to provide an extra benefit to the user. The installments are different in each geography. I would say that at the moment the geography that is doing the best in installments would be China. And we have a bit of a unique offering there I think versus the -- versus what you can get in the regular market and so that probably further helps there. And so you can bet that we're learning on each of these finding the parts that the user likes the most. I think the key is we're trying to build a -- build something into the consumer mindset that it's good for the environment and good for them to trade in their current device on a new device. And we do our best of getting the current device to someone else that can use that or in some cases if the product is at an end of life we are recycling the parts on it to make sure that it can carry on in another form.

column1: Wamsi Mohan: Thanks for the color Tim. And as my follow-up Luca can you just clarify if the settlement with Qualcomm is creating either a headwind or a tailwind to your gross margins in the near-term? And does your guidance contemplate incremental pricing actions that could be creating some gross margin headwinds? Thank you.
Luca Maestri: As Tim has explained we've reach this comprehensive agreement with Qualcomm. As part of this we have agreed that we're not going to share the financial terms of the agreement
column2: so we plan to honor that. What you see in our gross margin guidance for the June quarter we guided 37% to 38% fully comprehends the outcome of the agreement with Qualcomm.

column1: Nancy Paxton: Thank you
column2: Wamsi. Could we have the next question please?

column1: Operator: Mike Olson from Piper Jaffray has our next question.
Mike Olson: Thanks for taking my question. So
column2: you have more than 1.4 billion active devices and at your event you announced services that leverage that installed base. And you have obviously a remarkable position with kind of this Trojan horse of devices out in so many households. So
column3: I guess
column4: the question is and I know some of these services aren't even live yet but should we expect a continuation of the building out of new services categories like what we saw at the March event? Is there a pipeline of new services in the works? Or have we kind of seen what we're likely to see on that front for the near to intermediate term? And then I have a follow-up.

column1: Tim Cook: Yes
column2: I wouldn't want to get into announcing things on the call
column3: but obviously
column4: we're always working on new things. And -- but we're right now we're really focused on getting these four out there. We have the News+ in the market today. We'll have the Apple Arcade and the Apple TV+ products in the market in the fall and Apple Card will go out in the summer timeframe. And so we've got lots in front of us and we're very excited about getting these out there.

column1: Mike Olson: Right. And then you mentioned the App Store search ad business a couple of times in the prepared remarks. Is that reaching a point where it's become material and maybe moving the needle for overall services revenue? Or is there anything you can quantify related to that? I also imagine that this is a high-margin business at least maybe higher than the overall Services margin but wondering if you can confirm if that's the case or not. Thanks.
Tim Cook: It's growing very
column2: very fast Mike. I think it was up around 70% over the previous year. We're expanding into new geographies as well and we still have more geographies out there that we think can move the dial further. So
column3: it is a -- it's definitely a business that is big and getting bigger.

column1: Nancy Paxton: Thank you
column2: Mike. Can we have the next question
column3: please?

column1: Operator: Our next question comes from Louis Miscioscia with Daiwa Capital Markets.
Louis Miscioscia: Okay and thank you for taking my question. Tim
column2: when you look at the four things that you have announced. And I realize they have different dates when they're coming out but
column3: which ones would you say over the next 12 months has the most potential to help your Services line? And then maybe
column4: which one has the best long-term potential? And then
column5: I have a quick follow-up.

column1: Tim Cook: We're going to wait until we get these things out. And what I can tell you right now is that the -- we're taking sort of consumer interest on the Apple Card and there's been a significant level of interest on that and we're excited. As you know the -- gaming is the top category on the App Store. And so the Apple Arcade will serve some of that market. And it serves it with a different kind of game
column2: which we think will be great for developers and great for users. The TV+ product plays in a market where it's -- there's a huge move from the cable bundle to over the top. We think that most users are going to get multiple over-the-top products. And we're going to do our best to convince them that the Apple TV+ product should be one of them. And then
column3: we're working very hard to get everyone to give Apple News+ a look. Because we think it's a very unique product. And I love magazines. And we have really wanted to support the publishers. And so
column4: we're working very hard to -- at the -- but at the very beginning of the ramp there. We wouldn't do a service…

column1: Louis Miscioscia: Okay
column2: great.

column1: Tim Cook: …that we didn't think could be meaningful. So that's sort of the way I look at it.
Louis Miscioscia: Great.
Tim Cook: Yeah
column2: these aren't hobbies.

column1: Louis Miscioscia: Okay. A quick follow-up on India
column2: obviously market share there is well below China. I believe you're looking to start manufacturing there. But what's the -- obviously the potential could be huge but the market already seems to be pretty dominated on the Android side
column3: so maybe if you could just talk about trying to really aggressively ramp up share there. Thank you.

column1: Tim Cook: I think India is a very important market in the long-term. It's a challenging market in the short-term. But we're learning a lot. We have started manufacturing there which is very important to be able to serve the market in a reasonable way. And we're growing that capability there. And we would like to place retail stores there. And we're working with the government to seek approval to do that. And so
column2: we plan on going in there with sort of all of our might. We've opened a developer
column3: accelerator there
column4: which we're very happy with some of the things coming out of there. It's a long-term play. It's not something that's going to be on overnight huge business. But I think the growth potential is phenomenal. It doesn't bother me that it's primarily Android business at the moment because that just means there's a lot of opportunity there.

column1: Nancy Paxton: Thank you

Importantly

column43: and growth driven by iPad Pro and by strong customer response to the new iPad Mini and iPad Air. This was our third consecutive quarter of growth

The combined effects of government stimulus

We're looking forward to welcoming all of them to Apple. We see this as a great opportunity to work with some of the leading talents in this field

column89: and music and audio features make Apple Watch more useful than ever. And of course
column90: we continue to innovate on Apple Watch's promise to be an intelligent guardian for your health. watchOS 6 includes powerful new features like notifications that warn about high decibel noise to protect your hearing and cycle tracking to aid in women's health care decisions.In the June quarter

column92: making them available in 31 countries and regions around the world
column93: with more to come later this year. We're very proud of the muscle we've built in bringing regulated products like these to market. This is an important competency that creates exciting opportunities for us moving forward.As I noted earlier
column94: we believe macOS Catalina will be a breakthrough in the Mac ecosystem. A new tool included in macOS Catalina called Mac Catalyst gives developers a major head start in bringing their iOS apps to the Mac. Thousands of developers are already using it to bring their apps to the Mac ecosystem and we expect to see a wave of popular apps arriving for the Mac as early as this fall.Again
column95: it's worth taking a step back and digesting the bigger picture here. These updates are the latest steps in a broader strategic effort to make the user experience across iOS
column96: macOS
column98: watchOS and tvOS more effortless and more intuitive. Apple is alone in offering this kind of value and ecosystem to its customers. And these devices and their platforms are unmatched in their ease-of-use
column99: their seamlessness and their privacy and security.And while providing these things
column100: we've created a dynamic environment where developers benefit greatly from creating for and distributing on these platforms. And our customers
column102: benefit greatly from access to all this creativity and innovation.We also unveiled other exciting technologies to make it easier and faster for developers to create powerful new apps. SwiftUI provides an intuitive new framework for building sophisticated user interfaces across our software platforms using simple easy-to-use code. Core ML 3 supports the acceleration of more types of advanced real-time machine learning models
column103: and Create ML lets developers build machine learning models without writing code.We have the world's largest augmented reality enabled platform and thousands of they ARKit-enabled applications in the App Store. Building on this strategy
column104: and our momentum in this area
column105: we introduced three new AR-based technologies. ARKit 3 uses on device
column106: real-time machine learning to recognize the human form and integrates people seamlessly into AR experiences.RealityKit is a new developer framework built from the ground up to provide all the tools and technologies required to make AR objects virtually lifelike. And Reality Composer brings AR content creation to tens of millions of developers who have no 3D experience. Our developers are already running with these new technologies and we think our customers are going to love some of the apps that these creators have in store in the months ahead.On so many fronts there's an enormous amount to look forward to over the next few months

column4: I'll start with your installed base question. Installed base is a function of upgrades and the time between those. It's a function of the number of switchers coming into the to the iOS
column5: macOS and so forth [indiscernible]. It's a function of the robustness of the secondary market
column6: which we think overwhelmingly hits an incremental customer. And it's a function still in the emerging markets and somewhat developed markets to a lesser degree of people knew that they’re buying their first smartphone. There are still quite a few people in the world in that category. And so
column7: the reason that the installed base doesn't correlate to the 90-day clock is that what's happening underneath the numbers is
column8: switchers are still a very key piece of what's going on. The secondary market is very key

column11: they're staying in the ecosystem. And then
