column10: and obviously we've got things that we're not going to talk about just yet that we're working on. But as I've said before
column11: my view is there will be a day in the future that we look back
column12: and Apple's greatest contribution will be to people's health.

column1: Mike Olson: Okay. Thanks. And then with the strong slate of content in Apple TV+
column2: can you just talk about the strategy behind giving it away to those that are buying in applicable device versus charging for it? And my congrats to Nancy. And thank you.

column1: Tim Cook: Yes
column2: it's a gift to our users
column3: and from a business point of view
column4: we'd like to -- we're really proud of the content. We'd like as many people as possible to view it. And so this allows us to focus on maximizing subscribers
column5: particularly in the early going. And so we are - we feel great about doing that.I think it's a bold move. And the price also for those people that are not buying a device in the period of time that we offer this
column6: the price is very aggressive as well. You think - think about the quality of content that you get for 499
column7: and it's amazing. It is amazing.

column1: Nancy Paxton: Thanks
column2: Mike. Can we have the next question please?

column1: Operator: That will come from Evercore’s Amit Daryanani.
Amit Daryanani: Yes. Thanks a lot guys. I guess two questions from me as well. First one
column2: Tim
column3: if you think about the Services business
column4: less than $2 billion away from the targets you had laid out a few years back. But I am wondering if you think about the growth rates you've had in the business over the last several years
column5: the high-teens average
column6: I think
column7: how much of that do you think was driven by the installed base growing versus incremental monetization of the installed base. And do you see that ratio essentially flipping or changing as you go forward?

column1: Tim Cook: I think
column2: we have opportunities
column3: Amit
column4: in both the growth of the installed base as Luca mentioned in his comments
column5: we continue to grow across every category
column6: hit new highs in the last quarter and we hit new highs in all of our top 20 markets.And so the installed base is clearly a piece of it getting the trade-in program going
column7: and the secondary market moving has been helpful in that as well. And
column8: of course
column9: ultimately the thing that builds the installed base is to make customers happy
column10: and that's our -- always our top objective is to have satisfied customers.The other thing that is obviously happening is in many areas
column11: the ARPU is increasing. And so
column12: as there is more offers out there
column13: I mean the one that is today getting the attention is on the streaming side.But if you look at the number of services that have been added over the years
column14: it's significant and people love them. And so it's really both of those. And obviously in - finally in getting more people that are enjoying things for free to - let to pay for some of the premium services. So it's sort of all three of those.

column1: Amit Daryanani: Got it. And if I was just kind of go back to the variables discussion
column2: especially as I think about Apple Watch and AirPods
column3: is there a central way to think about what's the attach rate today to iOS devices for Apple Watch and AirPod update.I just want to understand if I think about 900 million plus iPhone installed base
column4: what kind of penetration do you have at Wearables and how long could this one maybe as you go forward?

column1: Tim Cook: We’re not releasing the precise numbers of our Wearables
column2: but it is a really nice try and get me to say that. The -- what we're seeing in terms of new adds on the Watch
column3: I think Luca may have mentioned this in his comments is about three-quarters of the Apple Watch buyers are new to Apple Watch.And so we are still insignificantly in the build mode there
column4: and so don't think of the penetration as anywhere near sort of a mature penetration. We got lot left there
column5: and the AirPods just keep hitting new highs.And I anticipate that will carry over to this quarter too and we are really proud to add another product out there for people wanting noise-cancelling with the AirPod Pro beginning to sell today.

column1: Nancy Paxton: Thank you
column2: Amit. Could we have the next question please?

column1: Operator: That will come from Shannon Cross with Cross Research.
Shannon Cross: Thank you very much. First
column2: Nancy
column3: just want to send you our best wishes. We will definitely miss you. I'm sure
column4: I agree with Luca
column5: you've been very instrumental over the years.

column1: Nancy Paxton: Thank you.
Shannon Cross: My questions though with regard to China
column2: and I don't know
column3: Tim
column4: if you can talk more about what you're seeing in China
column5: the trends during the quarter
column6: the reception specifically there to the iPhone
column7: any thoughts on - you know
column8: Hong Kong used to be a big market
column9: there is obviously some turmoil there. So if you could provide some more in China that would be helpful? Thank you.

column1: Tim Cook: Yes
column2: we had a very good September
column3: Shannon
column4: and the lead of that is sort of the reception of iPhone 11 and 11 Pro and 11 Pro Max
column5: and so we feel really good about how we've gotten started there. As you can tell from the numbers
column6: we've significantly improved since the beginning of the year. We've gone from minus well into the 20s to minus two last quarter.And if you looked at that in constant currency
column7: we actually grew one. And so there is a very slight growth there. We obviously want that to be better. But we feel good about how we're doing.I think it's a combination of things that are - that have turned things around. On a macro basis
column8: I think the trade tension is less and that clearly looks positive right now with the comments that we've been reading in the press.Secondly
column9: the products have been extremely well received there. Third
column10: the things that we've done from a pricing and monthly payments point of view and trade-in
column11: getting the trade-in program up and running
column12: all of these things have had moved the dial. And so it's sort of the sum of all of that.I would also say
column13: it's not all about iPhone in China
column14: the services area grew double digit. We began to see more gaming approvals in the quarter
column15: or I should say some key gaming approvals.It's not all about quantity
column16: but about which ones
column17: we saw that. Also Wearables
column18: Wearables are doing so great at a company level. They're doing even better in China. And so lots of positives there.

column1: Shannon Cross: Thank you. And then
column2: I'm curious
column3: Luca
column4: maybe you can talk a bit about how you think about operating expense growth. It continues to grow significantly faster than revenue. So I am just curious as to where you're targeting the incremental spend? And then
column5: is there a point at which we might just see some leverage? Thank you.

column1: Luca Maestri: Well
column2: you know
column3: Shannon
column4: we've gone through different cycles. In some cases
column5: our revenue growth exceeds our OpEx growth. In other cases
column6: like fiscal '19
column7: it was the other way around. But our approach frankly is not changing over time. We want to invest in the business.Our primary investments during the last few years have been in the R&D space
column8: because obviously we want to continue to innovate
column9: improve the user experience differentiate our products.We continue to run SG&A tightly. Obviously
column10: if you look at what we had launched in the last few quarters and few years
column11: we launched a lot of new products
column12: and now we are launching a lot of new services.And when we do that we need to make the adequate investments in marketing and advertising to raise the awareness of the new products and new services and that is what you're seeing for example in the guidance that we provided for the first quarter as we’re launching new services right now
column13: and so we're making investments both in engineering and in advertising to support the new launches.

column1: Nancy Paxton: Thank you
column2: Shannon. Could we have the next question please?

column1: Operator: That will come from Bernstein’s Toni Sacconaghi.
Toni Sacconaghi: Yes. Thank you. I think this is for Luca
column2: and then I have a follow-up as well. If I look at your guidance
column3: the midpoint of your guidance for revenues on a sequential basis
column4: it's up about 36.5%. Historically
column5: fiscal Q4 to Q1 was up 50% or more
column6: and even last year given that iPhone is a slower growing product
column7: you guided for revenues to be up 45% sequentially.So given the enthusiasm about the iPhone 11 launch and the new Wearables products and the new services
column8: I guess the question is
column9: why is your guidance not stronger for Q1 on the top line?And is that sort of a reflection of conservatism given that there's a lot of uncertainty in the world and we certainly saw that last year? Or are there other forces at work that we should be considered?

column1: Luca Maestri: Toni
column2: thanks for the question. The guidance that we are providing if you look at it at the midpoint implies an acceleration of growth from the performance that we've seen during the course of fiscal 2019.As I said earlier
column3: foreign exchange is clearly a headwind for us right now. This is about $1.1 billion of negative foreign exchange on a year-over-year basis. So that is something to keep in mind.We feel very good as Tim said about the iPhone
column4: the way the new cycle has started
column5: and we do expect an improvement in our year-over-year growth rate on iPhone. Wearables has very
column6: very strong momentum. The portfolio of services also has incredible momentum.One thing to keep in mind as we look at this guidance range is the fact that we also contemplated the comparison to the launch of the iPad Pro
column7: a year ago for iPad as well as the new MacBook Air that was launched during the December quarter last year.So for the iPad and Mac categories
column8: you need to keep in mind that our launch timing is different on a year-over-year basis.

column1: Toni Sacconaghi: Okay. Thank you for that. And then if I could follow-up
column2: just on the bundling of Apple TV+
column3: I guess for you
column4: Tim
column5: this is really the first time we've seen a significant bundling of services offering and hardware offering.And I'm wondering if you view this as kind of a strategic advantage of Apple and whether we might see more hardware plus services offerings - bundled offerings
column6: and ultimately do you - do you ever believe that your hardware itself might be offered as a bundled service.And maybe while we're on that either you or Luca could give us the 30 second tutorial on how we should think about the deferred revenue accounting? Approximately how much of the $60 are you going to be deferring
column7: and what's your expectation for attach rate on that? Thank you.

column1: Luca Maestri: Let me cover the accounting issue first. Obviously
column2: we need to make some assumptions around the take rate of our customers on the -- on Apple TV+
column3: right. And we don't want to get into the details of that because we do those assumptions as confidential and competitively sensitive.But you need to keep in mind that we contemplate a number of factors including the fact that we have family sharing as part of the service
column4: the fact that there are multiple device purchases
column5: the geographic availability around the world
column6: the availability of local content at the beginning of the service
column7: how many people do we have with payment methods on file.So we use all these things to make assumptions around what the take rate is going to be. Obviously
column8: those assumptions will possibly change over time as we get more information on how the customers behave. We haven't launched the service yet - we're going to serve - serving our customers tomorrow. So we'll see how it goes
column9: but we take into account all these different factors.

column1: Tim Cook: On the bundle question
column2: Toni
column3: we look at each service
column4: and decide what's best to do for it and with TV+
column5: we concluded that a great way to get more people to see the content would be to do this
column6: and it would be a good gift for our users
column7: and so that's what we're doing.You can also see that on the other services we're not doing that. And so it's not part of a broader pattern
column8: or although I wouldn't want to rule out for the future that we might not see another opportunity at some point in time.In terms of hardware as a service or as a bundle
column9: if you will
column10: there are customers today that essentially view the hardware like that because they are on upgrade plans and so forth. And so to some degree that exists today
column11: my perspective is that we will grow in the future to larger numbers that will grow disproportionately.And one of the things we are doing is trying to make it simpler and simpler for people to get on these sort of monthly financing kind of things. That's a part of what we announced with the Apple Card earlier in the call and so we are cognizant that there are lots of users out there that want sort of a recurring payment like that and the receipt of new products on some sort of standard kind of basis and we are committed to make that easier to do than perhaps it is today.

column1: Nancy Paxton: Thank you
column2: Toni. Could we have the next question please?

column1: Operator: That will be from Chris Caso with Raymond James.
Chris Caso: Yes. Thank you. Good afternoon. And Nancy
column2: congratulations to you too
column3: and we're going to miss you.

column1: Nancy Paxton: Thank you.
Chris Caso: My first question is about pricing and the effect of some of the lower price points for iPhone 11 as compared to last year. And it looked like margins and revenues did well on that
column2: and also followed some price adjustments you made in emerging markets last year
column3: and obviously we've seen some improvement in China as well.So if you could talk about maybe what that tells us about pricing strategy in general and perhaps that you're willing to take a little more flexible approach to drive some elasticity if you think that's going to have a positive effect?

column1: Luca Maestri: Yes
column2: Chris
column3: I think that the price moves we've made have been smart and well received and do show a level of elasticity
column4: but the most important thing by far is the product. And I think we've got the best line-up we've ever had in the customer response to the product and what the product does for them is really incredible.And photos I am getting from many users around the world are just incredible that people are taking. And so I think it's product first
column5: and then prices sort of falls out of that
column6: and we did decide to be more aggressive. And looking at the results in the early going
column7: I think it was the right call.In terms of emerging markets we picked sort of locally relevant prices
column8: and in some cases where the dollar had become stronger
column9: we took an exchange rate that would have reflected a while back
column10: instead of the current exchange rate.And in other words
column11: we tried to stay as close as we could to a local price point that we knew was effective for that particular market. And those in addition to the U.S. price that has gotten more of a discussion had been extremely well received.

column1: Chris Caso: Thank you. As a follow-on
column2: perhaps you could talk about the potential for some of the tariffs that are upcoming what -- do you have a view of what potential impact that could have going forward and how Apple is looking to address it? Will you need to adjust your own pricing if in fact the tariffs are imposed?

column1: Tim Cook: We are paying some tariffs today as you know
column2: some that went into effect pre-September
column3: and some others that went into effect in September. So we are paying some that's been comprehended. But in general
column4: my view is very positive in terms of how things are going
column5: and that positive view is obviously factored in our guidance as well.And just the tone I think has changed significantly and I have long thought that it was in both countries
column6: best interests to get to an agreement that may be initially doesn't solve everything but solves some things that each party may want and get to a better place than where we're at and I'm hopeful that that's where we're headed.

column1: Nancy Paxton: Thank you
column2: Chris. Could we have the next question please?

column1: Operator: That will be from Samik Chatterjee with JPMorgan.
Samik Chatterjee: Hi. Good afternoon. Thanks for taking my question. I just wanted to start off with one of the new services Apple Arcade
column2: and if you have any insights in terms of what you're seeing for engagement or retention of customers beyond the initial trial period also how your partnerships with developers progressing there. How does the pipeline look like than any early projections of what that business longer term might look like?

column1: Tim Cook: We're not going to give out projections on it
column2: but I would tell you that we were really pleased with the number of people that enter the trial period. People are just coming out of the 30-day trial period in the last few days or week or so. And so it's really too early to tell what the conversion rate will be.But I feel like we're off to a good start and the - most important of everything. The customer feedback to date has really been incredible and we're very excited for the future of the service.

column1: Samik Chatterjee: Great. As a follow-up if I can
column2: trying to attack the Wearables question within the angle
column3: what are you seeing in terms of -- I believe consumer behavior in upgrading Wearables like Apple Watch AirPods and how are you thinking about your ability to accelerate some of that replacement cycle by driving innovation?

column1: Tim Cook: I think we
column2: because the Watch is relatively young. We haven't seen enough upgrade cycles to really establish a pattern as yet. And as I've mentioned before
column3: 3 out of 4 customers buying an Apple Watch currently or last quarter I should say were buying an Apple Watch for the first time. And so there is still a very
column4: very large new to Apple Watch in this regard.I do think the upgrade market will look at larger over time
column5: but just don't have a current view as to -- how often and so forth. On the AirPods we're anxious to see the customers for the new AirPods Pro.But I would guess that one particularly in the early going will be people that have AirPods today and want to have -- also have a pair for the times that they need noise cancellation.

column1: Nancy Paxton: Thank you. Samik. A replay of today’s call will be available for two weeks on Apple Podcasts

column5: and financial analysts can contact Tejas Gala or me with additional questions. Tejas is at 669-227-2402
column6: and I am at 408-974-5420. Thanks again for joining us.

column1: Operator: And that will conclude today's conference. Again
column2: thank you all for joining us today.";[0.05717437201964537

column32: exactly in line with our guidance. A favorable one-time item impacted the rate by 230 basis points.Net income was an all-time record of $22.2 billion
column33: up $2.3 billion or 11% over last year. Diluted EPS was also an all-time record at $4.99
column34: up 19% and operating cash flow was a very strong $30.5 billion
column35: an improvement of $3.8 billion over a year ago.Let me get into more detail for each of our revenue categories. iPhone revenue of $56 billion grew 8% year-over-year
column36: as we saw a great customer response to the launch of our newest iPhones. We set all-time revenue records in several countries
column37: including the U.S. Mexico
column38: the UK
column39: France
column40: Spain
column41: Poland
column42: Thailand
column43: Malaysia and Vietnam.Our active installed base of iPhones has reached an all-time high and is growing in each of our geographic segments. In the U.S.
column44: the latest survey of consumers from 451 Research indicates iPhone customer satisfaction of 98% for iPhone 11
column45: 11 Pro and 11 Pro Max combined. Among business buyers planning to purchase smartphones in the next quarter
column46: 84% plan to purchase iPhones.Turning to services. We set an all-time revenue record of $12.7 billion with double-digit growth in all of our five geographic segments. As Tim mentioned
column47: we established new all-time records for Apple Music
column48: cloud services
column49: payment services and our App Store search ad business and December quarter records for the App Store and AppleCare. We are well on our way to accomplishing our goal of doubling our fiscal year ‘16 services revenue during 2020. We've actually already reached that goal on a run-rate basis with the results of the December quarter.Customer engagement in our ecosystem continues to grow and the number of both
column50: transacting and paid accounts on our digital content stores reached a new all-time high with paid accounts growing double digits in all of our geographic segments. We now have over 480 million paid subscriptions across the services on our platform
column51: up 120 million from a year ago. And at this point
column52: we expect to hit our goal of surpassing the 500 million mark already during the March quarter. Given the tremendous momentum we're experiencing across our services offerings
column53: we're increasing our target for paid subscriptions and aim to reach 600 million before the end of calendar 2020.App Store revenue grew strong double digits
column54: thanks to robust customer demand for both in-app purchases and subscriptions. Our third-party subscription business grew across multiple categories and increased almost 40% year-over-year.Our first-party subscription services also continued to perform extremely well. Apple Music set an all-time revenue record
column55: offering a catalog of over 60 million songs to our customers. iCloud also generated an all-time revenue record
column56: growing very-strong double digits while offering our customers a safe
column57: secure and seamless experience across all their devices. It was a December quarter record for AppleCare
column58: thanks to strong service agreement attach rates and expanded distribution
column59: many of our partners have come to appreciate the strength of the AppleCare brand and our ability to deliver the very-best service and support in the world. That value resonates with both our partners and our customers
column60: and we are very happy to see that quality of experience delivered to more and more of our users.Next
column61: I’d like to talk about Mac and iPad. Mac revenue was $7.2 billion and iPad revenue was $6 billion. Both products had a difficult year-over-year comparison due to the launches of MacBook Air here
column62: Mac mini and iPad Pro during the December quarter a year ago and the subsequent channels fill. Despite the tough compare
column63: on a demand basis
column64: our performance for both Mac and iPad was around even to last year.Importantly
column65: around half of the customers purchasing Macs and iPads around the world during the quarter
column66: were new to that product. And the active installed base of both Mac and iPad reached a new all-time high. The most recent surveys from 451 Research measured a 93% customer satisfaction rating for iPad from consumers and 92% from businesses
column67: and among both consumers and businesses were planning to purchase tablets in the March quarter 78% plan to purchase iPads.Wearables
column68: home and accessories established a new all-time record with revenue of $10 billion
column69: up 37% year-over-year with very strong double-digit performance across all five geographic segments and growth across Wearables
column70: accessories and home. We set all-time records for Wearables in virtually every market we track
column71: even as we experience some product shortages due to very strong customer demand for both Apple Watch and AirPods during the quarter.We also continued to see strong demand for our products in the enterprise market as our technology solutions enable businesses to do their best work. 100% of Fortune 500 companies in the healthcare sector use Apple technology in areas such as patient experience
column72: clinical communications and nursing workflows
column73: and we're also seeing smaller companies in this sector drive innovation with our technology and apps. One example is Gauss Surgical
column74: which uses Core ML in iOS to more accurately estimate blood loss during child birth and surgery. This helps clinicians have more complete and timely information on whether a patient needs an intervention
column75: which can impact both
column76: clinical outcomes and costs.Another example is Butterfly Network
column77: a medical imaging company
column78: which makes handheld ultrasound device that connects to iPhone or iPad to enable clinicians to take an ultrasound anywhere at a cost that is dramatically lower than other solutions in the market today.Let me now turn to our cash positions. We ended the quarter with $207 billion in cash plus marketable securities. We issued a 2 billion euro-denominated green bond
column79: retired $1 billion of maturing debt and reduced commercial paper by $1 billion during the quarter
column80: leaving us with total debt of $108 billion. As a result
column81: net cash was $99 billion at the end of the quarter and we maintained our target of reaching a net cash neutral position over time.We returned nearly $25 billion to shareholders during the December quarter. We began a $10 billion accelerated share repurchase program in November
column82: resulting in the initial delivery and retirement of 30.4 million shares. We also repurchased 40 million Apple shares for $10 billion
column83: through open market transactions
column84: and we paid $3.5 billion in dividends and equivalents. As we have done for the last several years
column85: we would share our plans for the next phase of our capital return program when we report results for the March quarter.Finally
column86: as we move ahead into the March quarter
column87: I'd like to review our outlook
column88: which includes the types of forward-looking information that Tejas referred to at the beginning of the call. We expect revenue to be between $63 billion and $67 billion. The wider than usual revenue range comprehends uncertainty related to the recently unfolding public health situation in China. We expect gross margin to be between 38% and 39%. We expect OpEx to be between $9.6 billion and $9.7 billion. We expect OI&E to be about $250 million and we expect the tax rate to be about 16.5%.Also today
column89: our Board of Directors has declared a cash dividend of $0.77 per share of common stock
column90: payable on February 13
column91: 2020 to shareholders of record as of February 10
column92: 2020.With that
column93: let's open the call to questions.

column1: Tejas Gala: Thank you
column2: Luca. We ask that you limit yourself to two questions. Operator
column3: may have the first question
column4: please?

column1: Operator: Yes. That will be from Amit Daryanani with Evercore.
Amit Daryanani: Thanks a lot. Good afternoon
column2: guys. I guess
column3: first one for me on Wearables
column4: fairly impressive to see
column5: it’s already a $10 billion business for you guys. Could you just touch on the growth that you are seeing on the Wearables side? How much the growth you think is coming from first time buyers of AirPods or Apple Watch versus folks that seem to be just upgrading the products that they have
column6: because it looks to us the adoption rate is fairly low in your installed base
column7: so there should be a long run way
column8: but love to just understand how you see the growth divided between those two buckets.

column1: Tim Cook: Yes. Amit
column2: it’s Tim. If you look at the Apple
column3: the Wearables as a category within the Wearables
column4: Home and Accessories revenue
column5: Wearables grew 44%. So
column6: it was very strong
column7: as you say. Both Apple Watch and AirPods did very well in terms of collecting new customers. Apple Watch in particular
column8: 75% of the customers are new to the Apple Watch. And so
column9: it’s still very much a selling to new customers at this point.

column1: Amit Daryanani: Perfect. And I guess
column2: Luca
column3: you could just touch on gross margins. The March quarter guide I think implies gross margin of flat to actually up 10
column4: 15 basis point. It's rare for you guys to actually guide gross margins up in March I think because you have a fairly high seasonal sales deleverage happening. So
column5: what are the offsets that's enabling what looks like a better than seasonal guide for gross margins?

column1: Luca Maestri: Yes. That's right
column2: Amit. It’s about flat sequentially
column3: and by the way significantly higher on a year-over-year basis. But on a sequential basis
column4: you are right
column5: on one side we got the loss of leverage from the usual seasonality but we expect that that loss of leverage will be offset by better mix and cost savings.

column1: Tejas Gala: Thank you
column2: Amit. Can we have the next question
column3: please?

column1: Operator: That will come from Tom Forte with D.A Davidson.
Tom Forte: So
column2: congrats on the launch of Apple TV+. I wanted to know internally
column3: how you're getting success
column4: is it truly on critical acclaim
column5: is it on number of consumers that are using the service
column6: contribution and service revenue
column7: et cetera
column8: et cetera? Thank you.

column1: Tim Cook: Hey
column2: Tom
column3: it’s Tim. We are primarily measuring our sales on the number of subscribers. As you can tell from the way that we launched the product
column4: we started with a very aggressive price at $4.99. And in addition to that we have our bundle where if you buy pretty much any device
column5: you’re getting a year for free. And so
column6: we're very focused on subscribers. That said
column7: the product itself is about storytelling. And we think if we do that well
column8: then we will find that there will be some number of those that will also be critical acclaimed. And we're seeing that with the morning show
column9: we're seeing that with Little America and others.

column1: Tom Forte: Great. And then
column2: my second question is I think you indicated that last month we started offering consumers the ability to use their Apple Card to buy an iPhone on an installment basis. Can you talk about how that’s had an impact on your unit sales for iPhones?

column1: Tim Cook: So
column2: retail stores did fantastic on iPhone
column3: very strong double-digit growth in iPhone from a year-over-year point of view. And one of the factors that enabled that was the -- getting to a monthly payments on the Apple Card to make it very simple. Of course
column4: that’s U.S. only at this point
column5: but the U.S. is very key market for us. And so
column6: it was an important part of it.

column1: Tejas Gala: Thank you
column2: Tom. Can we have the next question
column3: please?

column1: Operator: That will come from Shannon Cross
column2: Cross Research.

column1: Shannon Cross: Thank you very much. I wanted to go back to revisit China. Tim
column2: can you talk about what you are seeing in the region -- what you were seeing in the region prior to the health crisis? And then
column3: can you also update us a bit in terms of your manufacturing strategy
column4: dual-sourcing
column5: geographic diversification
column6: even with the region
column7: just so we have some idea of how this will be managed? Thank you.

column1: Tim Cook: Yes. Thanks
column3: Shannon. In terms of China
column4: the results from last quarter
column5: and then I will get into the coronavirus in a second. For the results from last quarter
column6: we had double-digit growth for iPhone in Mainland China. So
column7: that was an important change from where we've been running. We also had double-digit growth in services in Mainland China and we had extremely strong double-digit on Wearables. And so
column8: really
column9: there were a number of different factors in terms of the things that customers are responding to. iPhone 11 is doing well there
column10: the product has been very well-received with its battery life and the camera is unbelievable. We also
column11: as you probably know
column12: have certain trading programs going and financing programs. These have also been well received.And so
column13: it’s sort of the sum of all of this. And we are tracking quite a large percentage of new customers on products like the Mac. Three quarters of the customers buying a Mac in China are new
column14: and nearly two-thirds of the customers buying iPad are new. So
column15: it was a terrific quarter. We had three of the top four selling smartphones in urban China according to Kantar.In terms of the coronavirus
column16: as I mentioned earlier
column17: first and foremost
column18: our thoughts are with all of those that are affected across the region. And as I've mentioned
column19: we’re donating to groups that are working to contain the outbreak. We are also working very closely with our team and our partners in the affected areas
column20: and we have limited travel to business critical situations as of last week. The situation is emerging and we're still gathering lots of data points and monitoring it very closely. As Luca had mentioned
column21: we have a wider than usual revenue range for the second quarter due to the greater uncertainty.I'll talk about supply chain and customer demand some to give you some color. With respect to the supply chain
column22: we do have some suppliers in the Wuhan area. All of these suppliers
column23: they’re our ultimate sources
column24: and we’re obviously working on mitigation plans to make up any expected production loss. We've factored best thinking and the guidance that we've provided you.With respect to supply sources that are outside the Wuhan area
column25: the impact is less clear at this time. The reopening of those factories after Chinese New Year has been moved from the end of this month to February 10th
column26: depending upon the supplier location
column27: and we've attempted to account for this delayed start up through our larger range of outcomes that Luca mentioned earlier.With respect to customer demand and sales
column28: we've currently closed one of our retail stores and a number of channel partners have also closed their store fronts. Many of the stores that remain opened have also reduced operating hours. We're taking additional precautions and frequently deep-cleaning our stores as well as conducting temperature checks for employees. While our sales within the Wuhan area itself are small
column29: retail traffic has also been impacted outside of this area
column30: across the country in the last few days. And again
column31: we have attempted to account for this in our guidance range that we’ve provided you. I hope that gets you some color.

column1: Shannon Cross: Yes. That was very helpful. Luca
column2: maybe if you could just touch on from a gross margin from perspective
column3: the commodity pricing environment and availability. Obviously
column4: there has been some movement on DRAM and NAND. So
column5: if you can talk about how you are thinking about inventory levels and managing that going forward? Thank you.

column1: Luca Maestri: Yes. As I said earlier to the question around the gross margin guidance for the March quarter
column2: we are seeing a benign commodity environment. Most commodities have been declining during the December quarter
column3: and we expect the same to happen in the March quarter. As always
column4: and as you probably know
column5: we look at the way these prices move and at times when we feel it’s appropriate we buy certain commodities in advance. And so
column6: we will continue that practice as we go through the year.

column1: Tejas Gala: Thank you
column2: Shannon. Can we have the next question
column3: please?

column1: Operator: That will come from Katy Huberty from Morgan Stanley.
Katy Huberty: Luca
column2: can you address the modest slowdown in services growth this quarter
column3: 17% versus 18% in September? Which services categories accelerated versus where did you see some deceleration in the growth?

column1: Luca Maestri: Katy
column2: let me make a couple of comments here. The 17% during the December quarter
column3: we look at it against our fiscal year ‘19 growth rate
column4: which was 16%. So
column5: we feel very good about the results for the December quarter. As Tim and I mentioned during our prepared remarks
column6: it was very broad-based growth because we grew double digits in services across all the five geographies. We set all-time records for many
column7: many categories
column8: music
column9: cloud
column10: search ads
column11: payment services
column12: December records for the App Store and the AppleCare. If you remember
column13: we had set two goals for ourselves in the services segment. The first
column14: we set a goal to double our fiscal ‘16 revenue during 2020. And when we look at it on a run rate basis
column15: we’ve already achieved that goal with the results of the December quarter.We also set a goal to pass 500 million paid subscriptions during 2020. And given that we are already at 480 at the end of December
column16: we expect to pass that mark during the March quarter. So
column17: now
column18: we are setting a new target for ourselves for paid subscriptions. And so
column19: we are now aiming to reach 600 million before the end of calendar 2020. So
column20: we feel that the services business is growing incredibly well. Of course
column21: we have launched new services very recently. For example
column22: Apple TV+ just launched in November. And so
column23: while these services did not have a material impact in our December quarter results
column24: we expect that over time they start contributing to the growth of the services business. But
column25: we feel very happy with the 17%.

column1: Katy Huberty: Thank you for that. Tim
column2: as a follow-up
column3: at some point in the future
column4: Apple will launch a 5G iPhone. How big of a demand driver do you view 5G capability in a handset? And what's your view as to what the killer app will be from a consumer perspective?

column1: Tim Cook: Sorry. We don’t comment on future products. And so
column2: I will try to sidestep a bit. With respect to 5G
column3: I think it’s -- we're in the early innings of its deployment on a global basis. We obviously couldn’t be prouder of our lineup and are very excited about our pipeline as well and wouldn’t trade our position for anybody.

column1: Tejas Gala: Thanks
column2: Katie. Can we have the next question
column3: please?

column1: Operator: We’ll hear from Kyle McNealy with Jefferies.
Kyle McNealy: So
column2: we were seeing some signs of new spectrum being deployed for 5G deployments and even additional 4G capacity
column3: and it’s already having a positive impact for handset upgrades to use that new capacity? Do you get the sense that wireless carriers are getting more incentivize to upgrade handsets to get a leverage out of these new network investments? How much might this be helping
column4: and do you think it will continue to accelerate?

column1: Tim Cook: I think that we’ve had some great partners
column2: not only in the U.S. but also around the world that are really helpful this quarter
column3: as partners. And so
column4: I think that probably a part of that is the level of investments they have. And then
column5: a part of it is probably making sure that those customer stick with them in a environment where there's a lot of trading back and forth. So
column6: I am optimistic that it will continue.

column1: Kyle McNealy: Okay
column2: great. And then
column3: the comment that you made about capacity in the Wearables division with AirPods Pro and Apple Watch 3
column4: what should we think about the timeline of when those capacity constraints might be alleviated? And will they come from capacity additions or the natural workout of unit shipments and something on the demand side?

column1: Tim Cook: I'm hopeful that the Series 3 will come in to balance during this quarter. On AirPods Pro
column2: I don't have estimate for that for you. I just can't predict when at this point. We seem to be fairly substantially off their and we're working very hard to put in additional capacity.

column1: Tejas Gala: Thanks
column2: Kyle. Can we have the next question
column3: please?

column1: Operator: Yes. Wamsi Mohan
column2: Bank of America.

column1: Wamsi Mohan: Hi. Thank you. Tim
column2: Apple has a very valuable installed base of users. Can you see a future where Apple can become larger in the advertising market
column3: as you build out TV+
column4: given you could have the unique position and ability to drive targeted ads to users without compromising on privacy?

column1: Tim Cook: I think
column2: it is possible to have advertising in a straightforward manner that doesn’t encroach on people's privacy. I wouldn’t want to conjecture about us in that business. I think for the TV+ business
column3: we feel strongly that what the customer wants is an add-free product
column4: and so that's not our aversion to ads
column5: it’s what we believe that a customer wants.

column1: Wamsi Mohan: Okay. Thank you. And Luca
column2: can you just clarify if the services revenue this quarter had any impact of deferrals associated with TV+ at all? And how can you help us maybe size the impact of the amortization of the content costs associated with TV+ as we think about the next couple of years? Thank you.

column1: Luca Maestri: Yes. So
column2: yes. Of course
column3: we launched the service and so there was a very small contribution to revenue from the deferral
column4: and there was also contribution to revenue from the people
column5: the subscribers that are actually paying for the service. When you think about what goes into the Apple TV+ revenue
column6: at this point
column7: there are two components. There is paid subscribers
column8: these are the customers that pay for the service and we recognize revenue over the subscription period. And then
column9: we got the what we call the Apple TV+ bundle subscribers. These are the customers that buy an eligible hardware device and redeem the offer for a three-year of TV+ services. We deferred revenue for this offer
column10: based on three items
column11: the first one is the value of the service that is being provided
column12: the one year of Apple TV+. The second one is the number of customers that are eligible for the offer. And the third one is our estimate of the expected number of customers that will redeem the offer. So
column13: you need to keep in mind that from our total eligible device sales
column14: you need to make a number of reductions for family sharing
column15: for multiple device purchases and for geographic availability.Also
column16: the take rate can also be impacted by the availability of local content
column17: and we also require a payment method on file. So
column18: this estimate is reviewed quarterly and gets updated based on actual trends of the offer. So
column19: these inputs provide us with the amount of revenue that we deferred for each device sale that then gets recognized over the one-year period that the TV plus service has provided. So
column20: when you take the combination of paid subscribers and bundled subscribers
column21: you get the Apple TV+ revenue. Of course because we’ve launched the service very recently
column22: the amount of revenue that we recognized during the quarter
column23: was immaterial to our results.With regard to the cost of developing the content
column24: we -- essentially as we incur these costs
column25: we put them on the balance sheet and then we amortize over a certain period of time depending on the type of content that we produce.

column1: Tejas Gala: Thanks
column2: Wamsi. Can we have the next question
column3: please?

column1: Operator: We’ll hear from Cowen and Company's Krish Sankar.
Krish Sankar: I had two questions. First one
column2: Tim
column3: I just wanted to pick your brain a little bit on the overall smartphone market. There is a general view that when 5G phones come out they’re going to be more expensive due to higher component costs
column4: but at the same time
column5: it looks like you guys have proven that there is a market for low cost geographies to phones like iPhone SE. So
column6: how do you see these two different segments within the smart phone market evolving over the next one to three years? And then
column7: I had a follow-up for Luca.

column1: Tim Cook: Again
column2: I’m going to stay away from commenting about future products. But
column3: generally
column4: I think it’s important when you think about 5G is to look around the world at the different deployment schedules. And some of those look very different perhaps than what you might be seen here. And so
column5: that’s very important. In terms of the price
column6: I wouldn’t want to comment on the price of handsets that aren’t announced.

column1: Krish Sankar: And then
column2: a follow-up for Luca. OpEx as a percentage of sales for March looks like e about 15% higher than in your prior quarters. Kind of curious how much of that is -- part of it is driven by some of your Intel modem asset purchases or TV+ in the OpEx or how do we think about it on a go forward basis?

column1: Luca Maestri: Yes. I think we felt good about our OpEx results
column2: because they were at the low end of our guidance range. But clearly
column3: we want to make all the necessary investments in the business. And in terms of the new services
column4: not only for TV+ but all the new services that we launched during 2019
column5: this is period where we’re making the necessary investments in advertising and marketing
column6: and that level of investment is reflected in our OpEx results. And also
column7: as you correctly stated
column8: we completed the acquisition of the Intel baseband business unit in December quarter. And so
column9: we had -- we reflected the run rate of the expenses related to that business
column10: partially during the quarter
column11: after the completion of the transaction. And that is a very important core technology for the Company. So
column12: we will continue to make all the necessary investments also there. There is a third category of expenses that affected the December quarter
column13: and it’s a fact that our revenue was very strong
column14: and we have certain valuable expenses. For example
column15: credit card fees that are associated with the higher volume and of course impacted our OpEx results.

column1: Tejas Gala: Thanks
column2: Krish. Can we have the next question
column3: please?

column1: Operator: That will be from Mike Olson with Piper Sandler.
Mike Olson: Good afternoon. Thanks for taking the questions. So
column2: slightly different take on an earlier question on Wearables
column3: and that is
column4: what impact you think Wearables is driving people into the Apple ecosystem? You mentioned 75% watch buyers are new to the Apple Watch
column5: but are many of them new to Apple overall? I'm sure a lot of existing iPhone
column6: iPads or Mac users are going to Wearables customers
column7: but do you think Wearables bring people into the ecosystem to buy other devices in a material way?

column1: Tim Cook: I think that -- Mike
column2: it’s Tim. With each Apple product that a customer buys
column3: I think
column4: they get tighter into the ecosystem because they like -- that's the reason that they're buying into it
column5: is they like the experience
column6: the customer experience. And so from that point of view
column7: I think each of our products can drive another product. I would think
column8: in that case it’s more likely that the iPhone comes first
column9: but there's no doubt in my mind that there's some people that came into the ecosystem for the Watch.

column1: Mike Olson: Okay. And then
column2: I think you recently mentioned that augmented reality will pervade our entire lives. And I'm wondering if you could share your thoughts about how you think it starts to impact our lives most significantly. For example
column3: will the inflection point in AR come from gaming or industrial usage or some other category? In other words
column4: where will the average person kind of first feel that impact of AR on their lives in a significant way? Thanks.

column1: Tim Cook: I think
column2: when you look at AR today
column3: you would see that there are consumer applications
column4: there are enterprise applications. This is the reason I'm so excited about it is
column5: you rarely have a new technology where business and consumer are both see it as key to them. And so
column6: I think
column7: the answer is --- that's the reason
column8: I think it’s going to pervade your lives is because it’s going to go across business and your home life. I think
column9: these things will happen in parallel. There are already companies that are deep into enterprise business that are working on applications for the enterprise. And of course you can see -- you go on to store
column10: see thousands of apps that are AR kit enabled at this time and would even more coming.

column1: Tejas Gala: Thank you
column2: Mike. Can we have the next question
column3: please?

column1: Operator: That will come from Raymond James
column2: Chris Caso.

column1: Chris Caso: Yes. Thank you. Good afternoon. I guess
column2: the first question is on gross margins. And you spoke about the favorable mix. Wondering if you could expand on that a little bit. And clearly
column3: iPhone is doing well within the overall mix that growing year-on-year. But
column4: if you could talk about what's happening to the mix within iPhone
column5: is that improving as well and also helping margins? And is there anything else you would point to with regard to the overall mix in margins?

column1: Luca Maestri: Yes. And I think that the mix helped us both in Q1 and its helping us with the guidance for Q2. And as you said
column2: some of it is mix of iPhones. The customer response for iPhone 11
column3: 11 Pro and 11 Pro Max is being exceptional. And that clearly has helped our mix. iPhone 11 was our top selling model throughout the quarter
column4: every single week of the quarter. And so certainly
column5: better mix within iPhone. The other point that I would like to point out is that as we move from Q1 to Q2
column6: the proportion of revenue coming from services increases versus the holiday quarter. And given that fact that services are accretive to gross margin for the Company
column7: we end up getting a better mix from services as well.

column1: Chris Caso: Okay. Thank you. And I guess
column2: follow-on question with regard to OpEx. And it has been growing at a faster rate than revenue for I guess largely over the last three years or so. Can you set us some expectation with regard to when you get a return on that investment? I understand there are new investments that are happening now. But
column3: how should we think about potential leverage going forward? Is there a point in time where the OpEx spending tend to level off and you get some return on that or is it just the function of a faster revenue growth in future?

column1: Luca Maestri: Well
column2: I would start by saying that our expense to revenue ratio is incredibly competitive relative to other companies in our sector. There are years when our OpEx grows faster than our revenue but we also had years in the recent past where the opposite has happened. We continue to believe that we have a lot of great opportunities in front of us. And just if you look this past year
column3: we launched many new initiatives
column4: for example
column5: on the services front
column6: which we want to support with the appropriate level of investment
column7: and not only marketing and advertising but also in R&D.As I mentioned earlier
column8: we closed the acquisition of the Intel baseband business because we think it’s a very important strategic core technology for the Company going forward. And I think from the results that you’ve seen during this quarter and the guidance that we provided for the March quarter

column3: we have not really seen Apple pull back from investing. And you as a company have largely maintained the product introduction cadence. But given these are unprecedented times and there are a lot of challenges associated with product development
column4: during a time when you have a global footprint for such activities and unable to really do a lot of things in person
column5: how should we think about the product development and introduction cadence as we go over the next several quarters? And I have a follow-up.

column1: Tim Cook: Well
column2: we’re continuing to operate. And so
column3: as you can tell
column4: along with everything else going on
column5: we were able to launch and ship the iPhone SE
column6: the iPad Pro with the Magic Keyboard
column7: and the MacBook Air. And so
column8: the business continues and the new products are our lifeblood. And so
column9: we’re continuing to work. Everybody’s getting used to the work-at-home. In some areas of the Company
column10: people maybe even more productive
column11: in some other areas they’re not as productive. And so
column12: it’s mixed
column13: depending upon what the roles are. But
column14: as you can tell from what we did this quarter
column15: despite the environment
column16: we have our head down
column17: are working because we know that our customers want the products that we’ve got. They’re even more important in these times.

column1: Wamsi Mohan: Thank you
column2: Tim. As a follow-up
column3: I know you’re doing a lot with both the Apple Card and financing plan for iPhones to get your products in the hands of customers. But
column4: I was wondering
column5: would you consider using the strength of your balance sheet maybe a little differently
column6: structure maybe deferred payments or things like that
column7: or do you think that there could be other steps like bundling that you will consider versus what you already currently do? Thank you.

column1: Tim Cook: Well
column2: as you know
column3: we launched the payment plan earlier on Apple Card for iPhone. We’re working on doing that for other products as well. And you’ll see something on that shortly. So
column4: we’re very-focused on the affordability point. The trade-in programs also are fairly wide across the board and act as both something great for the environment
column5: also something great from a way to get that entry price down. In terms of deferred payments
column6: nothing to announce today. But
column7: as you know
column8: having access to the card
column9: at least in the United States
column10: gives us more degrees of freedom. And that is not using our balance sheet. But
column11: we play a key role in deciding what kind of programs go with the card.

column1: Tejas Gala: Thanks
column2: Wamsi. Can we have the next question
column3: please?

column1: Operator: That will come from Morgan Stanley’s Katy Huberty.
Katy Huberty: Thank you for the question. I hope the whole team is staying healthy and safe. Tim
column2: I want to start on a longer term question. Where do you see structural changes on the back of this health crisis that might present opportunities for new revenue streams at Apple? And I’m particularly thinking about your past comments on health and augmented reality. But I’m sure there is even more areas of inspiration and creativity coming out of the company. And then
column3: I have a follow-up.

column1: Tim Cook: I think
column2: there are things from just a great reminder of how important our products are for remote work. And it’s pretty clear to me that where things will get a lot closer to normal than they are today
column3: obviously. I think many people are finding that they can learn remotely. And so
column4: I suspect that trend will accelerate some. I think that’s probably also true about working remotely in some areas and in some jobs. And so
column5: I think we have significant solutions and products for all of those groups. On the health area
column6: I gave some examples in my opening comments about the ECG being used on the Watch. You can bet that we’re looking at other areas in this. We were already doing that because we viewed that that area was a huge opportunity for the Company and a way for us to help a lot of people. And so
column7: you will see us continue on that. I wouldn’t say that the health door opened wider. I would say
column8: it was already opened fairly wide.

column1: Katy Huberty: Okay. And then
column2: as a follow-up
column3: the $50 billion share repurchase authorization is impressive in absolute terms
column4: but it is a bit lower than the last couple of years. So
column5: just any context around the thought process of landing on $50 billion. And then
column6: related to that
column7: you have one of the strongest balance sheets in the world. Does the current environment change your thinking at all around M&A opportunities?

column1: Luca Maestri: Let me answer that
column2: Katy. First of all
column3: on the buyback. As I said
column4: in general
column5: our approach to capital allocation has remained the same for the last several years and it’s not changing now. Keep in mind here
column6: we’re talking about just the authorization
column7: right? And when you look at our actual results at the end of every quarter
column8: you see how much we actually do in terms of share repurchases. The $50 billion is in addition to over $40 billion that is still remaining from the past authorization that we’ve received from our Board
column9: right? So it’s the total available or outstanding in terms of authorization is over $90. And as you look at our run rate during the last several years
column10: you know that that is a very adequate amount. And as you know
column11: we will provide an additional update a year from now. So
column12: nothing really has changed there. And nothing has changed on our approach for M&A. We’ve been quite active over the last several years. We purchase companies on a very regular basis. We’re always looking for ways to accelerate our product roadmaps or fill gaps in our portfolio
column13: both on the hardware side
column14: on the software side
column15: on the services side. So
column16: we will continue to do that. And so
column17: also on the M&A front
column18: nothing has changed.

column1: Tejas Gala: Thanks
column2: Katy. Can we have the next question
column3: please?

column1: Operator: That will come from Amit Daryanani with Evercore.
Amit Daryanani: Thanks for taking my question. I have two as well. I guess
column2: first off on the channel inventory. I was hoping if you could talk about how did channel inventory look like in the March quarter
column3: because it sounds like it may be below the historical ranges. And then
column4: the discussion you had for June quarter performance of iPhones
column5: what are you embedding from a channel building back inventory levels in that expectation.

column1: Tim Cook: Amit
column2: it’s Tim. If you look at the iPhone channel inventory during Q2
column3: the reduction of it was more than the reduction from the previous year. It’s not unusual that we reduce in Q2. In fact
column4: if you look back
column5: generally speaking
column6: in the first half of the calendar year
column7: we reduce channel inventories; during the second half of the calendar year
column8: we generally raise channel inventories. That’s a seasonal thing. And sitting here today
column9: I believe that will happen this year as well. So
column10: hopefully
column11: that answers your question. And by the way
column12: we ended in a comfortable position. You could conclude from that that we were within a target range.

column1: Amit Daryanani: That’s really helpful. Maybe just for follow-up. Tim
column2: I was hoping you could maybe talk a little bit about
column3: how do you think about Apple’s manufacturing strategy and perhaps need for some diversity
column4: especially given everything in the Company and everyone has gone through over the last 12 months
column5: how do you think about that? And do you feel comfortable that the supply chain and the manufacturing base is well situated today to launch the traditional fall products that they used to get from Apple?

column1: Tim Cook: As you know
column2: our supply chain is global. And so
column3: our products are truly made everywhere. And I would focus on that versus focus on one element of the manufacturing process
column4: which tends to get more visibility
column5: which is the final assembly. We have some final assembly in the United States; we have final assembly in China as well. I think
column6: you’d have to conclude
column7: or at least I conclude that if you look at the shock to the supply chain that took place this quarter
column8: for it to come back up so quickly really demonstrates that it’s durable and resilient. And so
column9: I feel good about where we are. That said
column10: we’re always looking at tweaks. And it’s just not something we talk about
column11: because if we view it as confidential and competitive information. And so
column12: we will look at the -- as we get out of this totally
column13: we will look to see what we learned and what we should change.

column1: Tejas Gala: Thank you
column2: Amit. Can we have the next question
column3: please?

column1: Operator: We’ll hear from Jeriel Ong with Deutsche Bank
Jeriel Ong: Hi
column2: guys. Thanks for letting me ask a couple of questions. So
column3: I want to focus my question on Services. The segment was solid in the quarter despite overall macro weakness. I can kind of see the logic behind it being strong despite product weakness overall. As you kind of look at the rest of the year
column4: do you think that sustains or at some point does the macro impacts worldwide impact the Services line?

column1: Luca Maestri: Jeriel
column2: let me take that one. We typically don’t give a lot of specifics about our categories. But I’ve said
column3: as we look into the June quarter
column4: we see two distinct trends in our services business overall. Our ecosystem is very strong. Our customers are very engaged. We are continuing to grow double digits
column5: the number of transacting accounts and paid accounts. And so
column6: we expect our digital services to continue at the same level of performance that we have seen during the March quarter. And that includes the App Store
column7: of course
column8: our video business
column9: our music business
column10: cloud services. So
column11: we expect all these businesses to continue to grow very strongly.Given the overall economic environment
column12: the level of demand right now
column13: there are two businesses that we believe are going to be impacted during the June quarter. One of them is AppleCare. AppleCare is essentially comprised of our product repair business and the warranty agreements that we signed with our customers when they purchase our devices. Both these businesses have been affected obviously by the store closures. And not only our retail stores
column14: but also our partners points of sale
column15: and obviously
column16: the reduced level of customer traffic because of the social distancing measures. Right? And we do expect AppleCare to be affected during the during the June quarter.The other business
column17: which we think is going to be impacted by the overall economic weakness and the uncertainty on when businesses will reopen is advertising
column18: which is the sum of our advertising business on the App Store
column19: on Apple News
column20: and the third party agreements that we have on the advertising front. So
column21: these are two things that during the June quarter will create a headwind for the Services business.

column1: Jeriel Ong: Got it. I appreciate that. My second question is about the overall purchasing decisions the consumers are making. So far
column2: through April
column3: have you seen increased perhaps downtick across your product line? So for example
column4: somebody might have shift maybe toward the lower end of the storage mix of certain products. And do you expect that going forward
column5: as unemployment uptick and macro impacts kind of layer on through the rest of ‘20? Thanks.

column1: Tim Cook: I haven’t seen what you’re asking. No. I have seen a strong customer response to iPhone SE
column2: which is our most affordable iPhone. But it appears that those customers are primarily coming from wanting a smaller form factor with the latest technology
column3: or coming over from it from Android. So
column4: those are the two principal kind of segments versus somebody buying down
column5: as you’re talking about it. We’ve also seen -- we launched the iPad Pro in the midst of all of this and the reception there has also been incredibly good. And that’s obviously our top of the line iPad. And so
column6: I’m not seeing what you’re alluding to
column7: at least at this point.

column1: Tejas Gala: Thanks
column2: Jeriel. Can we have the next question
column3: please.

column1: Operator: That will be from JP Morgan’s Samik Chatterjee.
Samik Chatterjee: Hi. Thanks for taking my question. If I can just start with a question on kind of what you’re seeing in China. You mentioned going to the pickup in activity. But
column2: is that driven by more kind of footfall in the stores
column3: or what’ve you seen relative to online activity
column4: and how much of this recovery is being driven online? Any thoughts on that
column5: please?

column1: Tim Cook: Yes. What we saw in China for the full quarter -- and I’ll speak about mainland China because I think that’s the source of your question. We saw strong results in iPad and in Wearables
column2: and in Services. And if you look up underneath the full quarter
column3: we saw a strong January
column4: and then a significantly reduced demand in February as the shelter-in-place orders and the lockdowns went into effect in China and the stores closed. And then
column5: in March
column6: as stores reopened
column7: the recovery began. And then
column8: we’ve seen further recovery in April. Where that goes
column9: we will see. But that’s kind of what we’ve seen so far there.To your question about store traffic
column10: store traffic is obviously up from where it was in February
column11: but it is not back to where it was pre the lockdown. There has been
column12: however
column13: more move to online. And as I mentioned earlier in my remarks
column14: it’s pretty phenomenal actually. Retail had a quarterly record for us during the quarter. And that’s despite stores being closed for the three-week period around the world. And ex China -- and then China was closed prior to that three weeks. And that’s partly because the online store had such a phenomenal quarter
column15: and that included in China
column16: but it was also other regions as well. So
column17: there is definitely a move. And whether that’s a permanent shift
column18: I would hesitate to go that far
column19: because I think people like to be out and about. They just know that now is not the time to do that.

column1: Samik Chatterjee: If I can just follow up on your previous comment about the strong demand you’re seeing for iPhone SE. Just given the price point
column2: I’m wondering if you are expecting any change in terms of the geographic mix of where the demand comes from relative to typically what do you see for other iPhones from the line up on
column3: just giving the lower price point?

column1: Tim Cook: I think
column2: it plays in every geo
column3: but I would expect to see it doing even better in areas where the median incomes are less. And so
column4: we’ll see how that plays out. And I expect some fair number of people switching over to iOS. So
column5: it’s an unbelievable offer. It’s
column6: if you will
column7: the engine of our top phones in a very affordable package. And I think -- and it’s faster than the fastest Android phones. And so
column8: it’s an exceptional value.

column1: Tejas Gala: Thank you. Can we have the next question
column2: please?

column1: Operator: Certainly. Our last question today will be from Chris Caso with Raymond James.
Chris Caso: Yes. Thank you. I wanted to follow up with another question on iPhone SE and the decision to bring it back and where it sits within the total iPhone strategy. And I guess
column2: coupled with the fact that iPhone 11
column3: you made the decision to bring that at a lower price point. What does that tell us with respect to your approach to iPhone pricing and flexibility? Is this helping to add users and kind of bring people into the ecosystem? And if so
column4: what does that imply for gross margins?

column1: Tim Cook: Chris
column2: we’ve always been about delivering the best product at a good price. And that fundamental strategy has not changed at all. As you know
column3: we did have an SE for a while. It’s great to bring it back. It was a beloved product. And so
column4: I wouldn’t read anything into that other than we want to give people the best deal that we can while making the best product.

column1: Chris Caso: Okay. As a follow-up -- the follow-up question is on commodity pricing. And I think
column2: you had expected to see some commodity price declines through the March quarter. If you could talk about what you expect
column3: as you go through the year
column4: perhaps in this new environment
column5: and again
column6: whether that turns into a challenge or a headwind for gross margins as you go into the second half?

column1: Tim Cook: Yes. For March
column2: Chris
column3: we saw NAND pricing increase slightly while DRAM and displays and the other commodities declined. For the June quarter
column4: we would expect NAND and DRAM pricing to remain at this historically low level
column5: while displays and most other commodity prices we expect to decline.

column1: Tejas Gala: Thank you
