column22: video and cloud services. Our new services Apple TV+
column23: Apple Arcade
column24: Apple News+ and Apple Card are also contributing to overall services growth and continue to add usersâ content and features. At the same time customer engagement in our ecosystem continues to grow at a fast pace. The number of both transacting and paid accounts on our digital content stores reached a new all-time high during the June quarter with paid accounts increasing double-digits in each of our geographic segments. In aggregate
column25: paid subscriptions grew more than 35 million sequentially and we now have over 550 million paid subscriptions across the services on our platform
column26: up 130 million from a year ago. With this momentum we remain confident to reach our increased target of 600 million paid subscriptions before the end of calendar 2020. Wearables
column27: Home and Accessories established a new June quarter record with revenue of $6.5 billion
column28: up 17% year-over-year. Our Wearables business is now the size of a Fortune 140 company and we set June quarter records in the majority of markets we track. Importantly Apple Watch continues to extend its reach with over 75% of the customers purchasing Apple Watch during the quarter new to the product. Next
column29: I'd like to talk about the impressive performance of Mac. Revenue was $7.1 billion
column30: up 22% over last year and a June quarter record. We grew double digits in each geographic segment and set all-time revenue records in Japan and rest of Asia-Pacific as well as June quarter records in the Americas and Europe. Customer response to our new MacBook Air and MacBook Pro launches has been extremely strong. iPad performance was equally impressive with revenue of $6.6 billion
column31: up 31% and our highest June quarter revenue in eight years. Demand was strong around the world with double-digit growth in each of our geographic segments
column32: including a June quarter record in Greater China. The launch of our new iPad Pro has been received incredibly well in every region of the world. Both Mac and iPad are extremely relevant products in the new working and learning environments and the most recent surveys of consumers from 451 Research measured customer satisfaction at 96% for Mac and 97% for iPad. Around half of the customers purchasing Mac and iPad during the quarter were new to that product. And as a result
column33: the active installed base for both products reached a new all-time high. Our retail business had record June quarter revenue. Thanks to the performance of our online store which had records in all geographic segments and grew across all major product categories. In June
column34: we launched Apple Card Monthly Installments for more products in our US stores allowing customers to pay for their devices all the time with 0% interest. We're very pleased with the level of customer interest this new offering has generated. In the enterprise market
column35: we continue to see companies leverage Apple products and offerings to successfully navigate their businesses through COVID-19. In healthcare
column36: we are seeing rapid acceleration of telehealth to support a more flexible model of patient care. Many hospitals such as UVA Health
column37: Rush University Medical Center and UC San Diego Health are using apps on iPad and iPhone to have triage
column38: monitor and care for patients who are at home. This helps free up hospital capacity to support patients who need inpatient care while enabling continued care for patients who do not require in-person visits. Since many call center employees are currently working remotely
column39: Apple Business Chat has proven an invaluable tool for staying connected with customers. This quarter HSBC deployed Apple Business Chat in its US and UK contact centers. Apple Business Chat provides a flexible and secured channel for digital banking assistance through a native Apple experience improving the efficiency and experience for both customers and agents. We are seeing similar adoption by hundreds of other organizations. Let me now turn to our cash position. We ended the quarter with almost $194 billion in cash plus marketable securities. We issued $8.5 billion of new term debt
column40: retired $7.4 billion of term debt and increased short-term borrowing facilities by $1.1 billion during the quarter leaving us with total debt of $113 billion. As a result
column41: net cash was $81 billion at the end of the quarter and we continue on our path to reaching a net cash neutral position over time. We returned over $21 billion to shareholders during the June quarter
column42: including $3.7 billion in dividends and equivalents and $10 billion through open market repurchases of 31.3 million Apple shares. We also began a $6 billion accelerated share repurchase program in May resulting in the initial delivery and retirement of 15.2 million shares. And finally
column43: we retired an additional 4.8 million shares in the final settlement of our 15th ASR. As we move ahead into the September quarter
column44: I'd like to provide some color on what we are seeing
column45: which includes the types of forward-looking information that Tejas referred to at the beginning of the call. Similar to last quarter
column46: given the uncertainty around the world in the near-term
column47: we will not be issuing revenue and margin guidance for the coming quarter. However
column48: we will provide some additional insight on our expectations for the September quarter for our product categories. On iPhone
column49: we expect to see recent performance continue for our current product lineup
column50: including the strong customer response for iPhone SE. In addition
column51: as you know
column52: last year we started selling new iPhones in late September. This year we project supply to be available a few weeks later. We expect the rest of our product categories to have strong year-over-year performance. For services
column53: we expect the September quarter to have the same trends that we have observed during the June quarter except for AppleCare where during the September quarter a year ago we expanded our distribution significantly. As a consequence
column54: we expect a difficult comp for AppleCare also considering the COVID related point of sale closures this year. For gross margin
column55: keep in mind that we will have a different mix than in prior years as I just explained. For OpEx
column56: we expect to be between $9.8 billion and $9.9 billion. We expect the tax rate to be about 16.5% and OI&E to be $50 million. Also today our Board of Directors has declared a cash dividend of $0.82 per share of common stock payable on August 13
column57: 2020 to shareholders of record as of August 10
column58: 2020. And finally
column59: today we're announcing a four for one split of Apple common stock to make our stock more accessible to a broader base of investors. Each shareholder of record at the close of business on August 24
column60: 2020 will receive three additional shares for every outstanding share held on the record date and trading will begin on a split-adjusted basis on August 31st
column61: 2020. With that let's open the call to questions.

column1: Tejas Gala: Thank you
column2: Luca. We ask that you limit yourself to two questions. Operator
column3: may we please have the first question?

column1: Operator: Yes
column2: that will be from Katy Huberty with Morgan Stanley.

column1: Katy Huberty: Thank you. Good afternoon. Tim in light of the economic adversity that you talked about in the prepared remarks
column2: can you just walk us through how Apple is leveraging finance and trade-in programs to make technology more affordable and accessible during this period
column3: while also addressing the opportunity to recycle and reuse products and maybe also extend that to how these programs might expand over time and then I have a follow-up.

column1: Tim Cook: Yes. As Luca mentioned
column2: in June we actually rolled out to the overwhelming balance of our other products the ability to do interest rate
column3: interest free financing in our stores with payments. And that's in addition to trade-in which is becoming a more common trend now which I think is terrific because it is great for the environment and it acts as a subsidy
column4: if you will
column5: against the price of the new phone. And so when you compound these two things with the financing and the trade-in it makes the product super affordable. And we're really happy with what we're seeing in that regard.

column1: Katy Huberty: And then
column2: as a follow-up
column3: just specifically to iPhone the category returned to growth. As you pointed out
column4: the installed base is larger today. Our math would suggest that replacement cycles in some cases are elongated. And then you have the affordability element that you just discussed. Does all of that combine to build confidence that we're entering a longer period of iPhone revenue growth after what's been six quarters of decline?

column1: Tim Cook: We're very pleased with how we did on iPhone. It was better than we thought largely because as we pointed out in the prepared remarks May and June were much better. If you look at iPhone in totality the things that get me very optimistic is the size of the active installed base. The fact that if you look in the major geographies like the US
column2: we had the top two selling smartphones. In the UK we had three of the top four. In Australia
column3: we had five of the top six. And in Japan we had the top four. Urban China we were
column4: iPhone 11 was the top selling smartphone in the country. And so these are some very different geographies with their very different competitive situations and we're doing fairly well. The iPhone SE
column5: it's also clear that from the early data we're seeing a higher switcher number than we did in the previous year
column6: which we feel very good about. And it also seems to appeal to some people that were holding onto the device a little longer because they wanted a smaller form factor phone. And so the combination of the smaller form factor and an incredibly affordable price made the iPhone SE very popular. iPhone 11 is still the most popular smartphone
column7: but iPhone SE definitely helped our results. And as we -- as Lucas said in his outlook
column8: we do see that continuing into this quarter currently.

column1: Tejas Gala: Thank you
column2: Katy.

column1: Katy Huberty: Thank you. Congrats on the quarter.
Tim Cook: Thank you so much.
Tejas Gala: Can we have the next question
column2: please?

column1: Operator: Yes
column2: that would be from Krish Sankar with Cowen & Company.

column1: Krish Sankar: Hi
column2: thanks for taking my question. I have two of them. First one
column3: Tim
column4: when you look at the services business and in terms of your TV+ content production have the movement restrictions impacted the content production efforts? And along the same path four years ago your premonition on services being a $50 billion business in 2020 came sooner than expected
column5: I don't know if you want to make any such forecast four years out and how you think services revenue is going to be. Then I have a follow-up for Luca.

column1: Tim Cook: I'm sorry. I missed that second question because the audio didn't come through. But I think I got the gist of the first. And that is production has been affected for Apple TV+ as I think it has for most people. We are working to get restarted. I don't have a precise date yet when we will get it restarted
column2: but there will be some impact because we shut down in the March time frame and are yet to really restart in a significant way particularly for those that are shut in the LA area given the current status of the virus and those. And I'm sorry I missed your
column3: the second part of your question.

column1: Krish Sankar: Yes
column2: Tim
column3: I was trying to see
column4: four years ago you made a great prediction that services is going to be $50 billion by 2020. I wanted to see if you have any update to the prediction four years down the road?

column1: Tim Cook: We're not updating today. We feel good. We want to take the moment and feel good about achieving the doubling six months early. And we do have still hanging out there
column2: as you know
column3: the subscription number that we're shooting for later in the year at 600 million. So we do have that objective out there.

column1: Krish Sankar: If I could just squeeze in one for Luca. With the strong sales in Mac given the shelter-in-place
column2: do you think the back-to-school season got pulled in by a quarter or do you expect the momentum to still continue? Thank you very much.

column1: Luca Maestri: As I said
column2: when I was talking about providing some commentary for the September quarter
column3: we expect all the non-iPhone product categories to have a very strong year-over-year performance. So we definitely
column4: I mean
column5: the back-to-school season is clearly this one and we are very excited not only for the Mac
column6: but also for the iPad. We've got a fantastic lineup of products and we know that these products are incredibly relevant especially given the current circumstances. So we expect the performance that we've seen for Mac in the June quarter to continue.

column1: Tejas Gala: Thank you. Can we have the next question
column2: please?

column1: Operator: Yes. From Cross Research we'll hear from Shannon Cross.
Shannon Cross: Thank you very much. Tim
column2: can you talk a bit about what you're seeing in China? I know the revenue was up 2% and I think Luca talked about record iPad
column3: but just curious as to given their 5G  how you're seeing the market play out? And then I have a follow-up. Thank you.

column1: Tim Cook: Shannon
column2: the growth that we -- we did see growth in Greater China for the quarter of 2%
column3: currency affected China
column4: a bit more than in other places
column5: it affected 400 basis points. And so in constant currency
column6: we would have grown at 6%. As I had mentioned before
column7: the iPhone 11 has been our best-selling phone and has been number one in urban China and so we're very
column8: very proud of that. iPad was helped in the June quarter there by the work from home and distance learning as it was in other geographies and the Mac also grew strong double digit during the quarter. And services set a new June quarter record there. We also continue to see extremely high new customer rates on Mac and iPad there
column9: to give you a perspective
column10: about three out of four customers that are buying the Mac are new in China and about two out of three that are buying the iPad are new. And so these are numbers that we're super proud of.

column1: Shannon Cross: Great. And then
column2: can you talk a little bit more about the decision to bring Mac Silicon in-house
column3: then the benefits that you expect to see or you've seen from vertical integration of acquisitions like the Intel modem business? Thanks.

column1: Tim Cook: Thanks. Yes
column2: I mean
column3: what we will end up -- what we'll end up with is a common architecture across all of our products
column4: which gives us some interesting things that we can do in products that are -- that is sort of unleashes another round of innovation. And so I don't want to say a lot about it
column5: other than we are extremely excited about it
column6: it's something that we've worked on quite a while to get to this point and we're looking forward to shipping the first Mac with Apple Silicon later in the year.

column1: Tejas Gala: Thank you
column2: Shannon. Can we have the next question please.

column1: Operator: That will come from Amit Daryanani with Evercore.
Amit Daryanani: Thanks a lot for taking my question guys. I have one and a follow-up as well. Fortunately
column2: I guess
column3: Tim
column4: if I think about the strength
column5: you're seeing with iPhones right now
column6: do you have a sense in terms of where is this trend coming from? Is it more replacement cycles getting shorter or which is getting new customers into the iOS ecosystem because
column7: clearly these growth rates seem fairly impressive in the context of a pandemic and upcoming refresh cycle that we have?

column1: Tim Cook: I think
column2: Amit
column3: it's a combination of a strong launch with iPhone SE and some -- probably some pick up because of the economic stimulus that hit different countries at different points in time. And probably some of the reopening that took place across the quarter
column4: particularly in May and June as Store started to reopen. And so it's a combination of all of those. And as you know
column5: we've been having a strong cycle with the iPhone 11 and the 11 Pro. And so when you combine the -- a strong cycle plus and iPhone SE launch
column6: plus the reopening of the stores
column7: et cetera
column8: I think there were a lot of things that we're going in the right direction there.

column1: Amit Daryanani: Perfect
column2: that's helpful. And then I guess
column3: Luca
column4: if I could just follow up with you. I'd love to get your perspective on how do we think about the overall 38% gross margins? What do you think of the levers to improve this as you go forward
column5: not really September quarter
column6: but over the next one to two years? And in that context
column7: do you see a point where the product gross margin starts to stabilize because they have been trending somewhat lower for the last couple of quarters now.

column1: Luca Maestri: Yes. Well
column2: let me start with what we've seen during the June quarter. We were at 38%
column3: we were down slightly sequentially but up the same amount on a year-over-year basis. And really the big negative impact that we felt for several quarters now has been the strength of the US dollar
column4: so the foreign exchange impact on a sequential basis was 90 basis points on a year-over-year basis was 130 basis points. So obviously that is something to keep in mind. And then
column5: the other aspect; I think it's always important to keep in mind
column6: Amit
column7: is that we sell many different products. They have different margin profiles. And so sometimes a different mix can have an impact on the aggregate level of products gross margins and we are very pleased to see the performance of Mac
column8: iPad and Wearables but obviously
column9: it's a different mix. Going forward
column10: the variables are always the same
column11: is that the foreign exchange will continue to play an impact
column12: the mix of products there
column13: we're going to be selling
column14: will have an impact as well. The commodities market has been relatively benign and we'll see how that plays out over time. As you know now for several years
column15: we've been managing gross margin
column16: I would say
column17: fairly well in spite of some difficult situations like the one with the strength of the dollar and we plan to continue to make a good trade off decisions between revenue and units and margins.

column1: Tejas Gala: Thank you
column2: Amit. Can we have the next question
column3: please?

column1: Operator: It will come from Kyle McNealy with Jefferies.
Kyle McNealy: Hi
column2: thanks a lot for the question. Our team in Asia recently
column3: we did some survey work on smartphones in China. It showed that there is still a high proportion of the installed bases on 6
column5: 8 devices. I know you talked about the trade-in programs and promotions that you've been doing there. I wonder if you can tell us whether there is anything else that you're doing to get these customers in your latest technology? What made those customers be looking for and how should we think about when an upgrade cycle might come on more strongly there in China? Thanks.

column1: Tim Cook: Customers upgraded different at a different pace and I don't have in front of me the exact installed base data from China. But much like in other geographies
column2: the upgrades have extended some
column3: it extended some during the depths if you will of the pandemic in China and the rest of the world
column4: and probably to some degree is happening still at this point. The key things that we can do is keep innovating
column5: deliver product that people can't imagine
column6: going through life about. And obviously keep rolling out these programs that makes the front-end purchase be much less
column7: and this is things like the financing in the trade-in programs that you mentioned. And I do feel like those are going quite good in a number of geographies.

column1: Kyle McNealy: Okay
column2: great
column3: thanks. And one more if I may. Congrats again on the strong iPad and Mac results
column4: that's really impressive. I guess the obvious question is
column5: should we ever think about how much of that might be pull-forward and what might be the future upgrades in next few years? Anything else you can share on how you think about growth from here or whether there is a hangover period maybe after the back-to-school season or holiday season. That would be helpful. Thanks.

column1: Tim Cook: The installed base is growing and the new customer numbers that Luca went over in the aggregate are still very high in the close to 50% kind of range. And so
column2: that to me
column3: makes the -- bodes well for the future. There is clearly
column4: as we had indicated
column5: there is some amount of work from home and remote learning that do affect the results of Mac and iPad positively. They probably affect wearables and iPhone
column6: the other direction. And -- but on Mac and iPad
column7: these are productivity tools that people are using to stay engaged with their work or stay engaged with their school work. And we believe we're going to have a strong back to school season. Sitting here today
column8: it certainly looks like that.

column1: Tejas Gala: Thank you
column2: Kyle.

column1: Kyle McNealy: Great. Thanks very much.
Tejas Gala: Can we have the next question
column2: please?

column1: Operator: That will come from Cleveland Research's Ben Bollin.
Ben Bollin: Good evening
column2: everyone. Thanks for taking the question. Tim
column3: I was hoping you could share a little bit about where you think channel inventory is? You talked about the tightness you saw exiting the June quarter for Mac and iPad. Interested
column4: where you think inventory is across major product categories. And then I had a follow-up for Luca.

column1: Tim Cook: We usually -- we've gotten away from talking about channel inventories. But to give you a perspective sitting here looking at it
column2: on iPhone the inventory is slightly less than it was a year ago and that's I'm saying that at a quarter end point
column3: so at the end of Q3. And obviously iPad and Mac are constrained and so both of those are less than they were in the year ago quarter.

column1: Ben Bollin: Okay. And then
column2: Luca
column3: I'm interested
column4: any color you could share about the impact COVID had on OpEx in the quarter
column5: be it work from home
column6: stipends
column7: travel
column8: other employee support costs. And also how the company is thinking about the longer-term opportunity of employees working remotely maybe more permanently many considerations and how that could influence the future OpEx? Thanks.

column1: Luca Maestri: Well
column2: on the OpEx front
column3: there are being obviously certain things that have been affected in terms of cost reductions. Obviously
column4: travel
column5: it is a perfect example. The number of meetings that we have internally
column6: some of those costs have been reduced. We've also invested heavily in initiatives for example
column7: we're really trying to help during a very difficult circumstances. For example
column8: we have had a program for example where we match our employee donations
column9: we made donations directly as a company around the world to many institutions and governments. On a net basis
column10: I would say probably the cost have outweighed the savings both during the March and the June quarter
column11: but we think it's absolutely the right thing to do. From an employee perspective
column12: what we said so far is that here in the United States
column13: in most -- the majority of our population will continue to work from home until the end of the year. And then we'll see
column14: I mean
column15: we've taken an approach that we try to understand how the virus is evolving over time. We've taken a very cautious approach of both with our corporate facilities and with our retail stores. I think what you've seen with retail stores is that we have reopened in number of geographies around the world. We've reopened here in the United States. We've had to re-close some of the stores yet here in the United States
column16: as the number of cases has gone up. And we will continue to track how the virus is doing. And hopefully at some point
column17: we're going to get to a point where there is a vaccine or there is a cure. And so we will make those decisions as we get more information.

column1: Tejas Gala: Thank you. Can we have the next question
column2: please?

column1: Operator: That will be from Jeriel Ong with Deutsche Bank.
Jeriel Ong: Yes
column2: thank you so much. I have two questions as well. I'd like to focus on the gross margin expansion within the services line all-time record for the quarter. I'm just curious whether you think that will sustain
column3: I understand within services is a pretty wide range of gross margins by business
column4: and I'm wondering if that should continue to improve.

column1: Tim Cook: Well
column2: as you've seen
column3: obviously
column4: we've had a sequential expansion in gross margin for services. And that was driven primarily by mix as you said
column5: right. We have a very broad portfolio and depending on which one of the services does better than we have an impact on Services gross margins. We like the Services business because it is -- it's a recurring type of revenue and the margins are accretive to company margin. We did over 67% this quarter
column6: but we want to offer very competitive services across the board and the same -- I think I'm going to make the same comments that I made on products. What matters to us is to be successful with everything that we do and provide great products and services to our customers. So the relative success of our products and services in the marketplace will drive to a certain extent with our margins are
column7: that's the margins are a byproduct of our success in the marketplace.

column1: Jeriel Ong: Got it
column2: really appreciate that. And I wanted to ask question on the Wearables segment. It seems to me that you're categorizing the Wearables business as maybe being a little bit impact from pandemic similar to the iPhones. And it's the first time that Wearables hasn't materially upsided and at least a while in recent memory. I guess the drivers of the Wearables being Watch and predominantly Watch and AirPods. What are your thoughts going forward on whether there is a little bit of pent-up demand perhaps that might resume ads that will get back to a more normalized environment?

column1: Tim Cook: I think on the Watch in particular is like the iPhone more affected by store closures
column2: because people -- some people want to try on the Watch and see what it looks like
column3: look at different band choices and those sorts of things. And so I think as stores closed
column4: it puts more pressure on that. I was -- we did come out sort of the way we told you last quarter
column5: we were going to come out from the color that we gave you. So we knew things would decelerate because of the closures. So we will end up being
column6: we're very pleased with how we did. But the store closures definitely affect the wearables and the iPhone.

column1: Tejas Gala: Thank you
column2: Jeriel.

column1: Jeriel Ong: Got it. Really appreciate that.
Tejas Gala: Yes. Can we have the next question
column2: please?

column1: Operator: That will come from Jim Suva with Citigroup.
Jim Suva: Thank you very much. And I have two questions. I'll ask them at the same time and it's one for Tim and one for Luca. Tim
column2: the coronavirus
column3: your company has done a fantastic job at overcoming one of the hurdles. So congratulations to you. As you look forward
column4: say to the Christmas holiday shopping season
column5: and given the economic challenges around the world of virus
column6: coronavirus and your product launches and things like that. Can you give me commentary maybe how this Christmas you're looking forward
column7: to say
column8: maybe some past cycles of Christmas? Because it just seems like it's a little bit different
column9: but Apple is really showing a lot more strength coming into this Christmas than may be some of the past years. And then for Luca
column10: I think you made a quick comment
column11: Luca
column12: that you mentioned something about a few weeks later
column13: was Apple like iPhone
column14: iPhone chips or product launches or maybe expand upon that. I know things are more difficult
column15: but I didn't quite keep the commentary
column16: it was in your prepared comments
column17: we'll go about a few weeks late that let's just have a quick little blood. Thank you so much
column18: gentlemen.

column1: Tim Cook: Yes
column2: we take it one quarter at a time. And so
column3: we'll give you color on the December quarter and October. Generally speaking
column4: I think we need to see a vaccine or therapeutic or both. And there is some optimism around that and in that particular timeframe. And so
column5: we'll see
column6: I don't have any information that is publicly available there. But I think that would boost consumer confidence quite a bit if it begins to happen and I think that any kind of consumer style company would benefit from that.

column1: Luca Maestri: And Jim
column2: on the iPhone
column3: I said in my remarks that we launched a year ago
column4: we launched the new iPhone in late September. So I was referring to the new product. And I said that this year
column5: the supply of the new product will be a few weeks later than that.

column1: Jim Suva: Great. Congratulations to you and your entire organization and teams. Thank you so much.
Tim Cook: Thanks so much.
Tejas Gala: Thank you. Can we have the next question
column2: please?

column1: Operator: That will come from Wamsi Mohan with Bank of America.
Wamsi Mohan: Hi. Yes
column2: thank you. I was wondering if you can maybe comment on the penetration of Apple Card users in the iOS installed base? And have you seen any change in the buying behavior of Apple Card users in terms of accelerating spend on more Apple products and services? Then I have a follow-on.

column1: Tim Cook: We saw changes in consumer spending as the shutdowns occurred and the store closures occurred
column2: we could see that across the Card. It affected the categories that you would guess the most like travel and entertainment et cetera. But overall if you sort of pull the lens out on the Apple Card
column3: we're very happy with the number of people that have Apple Card. We believe based on what we've heard that it's the fastest rollout in the history of credit cards and so we feel very good about that.

column1: Wamsi Mohan: Okay. Thanks
column2: Tim. And as a follow-up
column3: now that Apple has Apple Silicon for Macs. Would you ever consider monetizing this as a merchant silicon vendor or is this going to be forever for Apple use?

column1: Tim Cook: Well
column2: I don't want to make a forever comment
column3: but there are -- we are a product company and we love making the whole thing. And because if we can -- on the user experience in that way and with the goal of delighting the user. And that's the reason that we're doing the Apple Silicon is because we can envision some products that we can achieve with Apple Silicon that we couldn't achieve otherwise. And so that's how we look at it.

column1: Wamsi Mohan: Thanks
column2: Tim.

column1: Tejas Gala: Thank you

Thank you again for joining us.

column1: 79;AAPL;2020-10-29;"Operator: Good day everyone and welcome to the Apple Inc. Fourth Quarter Fiscal Year 2020 Earnings Conference Call. Today’s call is being recorded. At this time for opening remarks and introductions
column2: I would like to turn things over to Tejas Gala
column3: Senior Analyst
column4: Corporate Finance and Investor Relations. Please go ahead
column5: sir.

column1: Tejas Gala: Thank you. Good afternoon and thank you for joining us. Speaking first today is Apple’s CEO
column2: Tim Cook
column3: and he will be followed by CFO
column4: Luca Maestri. After that
column5: we’ll open the call to questions from analysts.

column1: Tim Cook: Thanks Tejas. Good afternoon and thanks for joining the call today. Back in April
column2: I said we were in the most challenging environment in which Apple as a company has ever operated. That atmosphere of uncertainty
column3: of resolve
column4: of making difficult calls with limited information has not only come to define Apple’s year
column5: but each of our lives as individuals across this country
column6: and around the world. It has been a chapter that none of us will forget. In the face of these challenges
column7: Apple stayed relentlessly focused on what we do best
column8: seeing in every obstacle an opportunity to do something new
column9: something creative
column10: something better on behalf of our customers. Today we report a quarter and a fiscal year that reflects that effort. This quarter
column11: Apple achieved revenue of $64.7 billion
column12: a September quarter record
column13: despite the anticipated absence of new iPhone availability during the quarter
column14: and the ongoing impacts of COVID-19
column15: including closures at many of our retail locations. We also set a new all-time record for Mac and Services. Outside of iPhone
column16: each of our product categories saw strong double digit year-over-year growth
column17: despite supply constraints in several product categories. Our results for this quarter were ahead of our expectations
column18: driven by stronger-than-expected iPhone and Services performance. As we anticipated
column19: we launched new iPhone models in October
column20: a few weeks later than last year’s mid-September launch. Up to that mid-September point
column21: customer demand for iPhone was very strong
column22: and grew double-digits. On Services
column23: we saw stronger-than-expected performance across the board. Geographically
column24: we set September quarter records in the Americas
column25: Europe and Rest of Asia Pacific. We also set a September quarter record in India
column26: thanks in part to a very strong reception to this quarter’s launch of our online store in the country. Greater China is the region that was most heavily impacted by the absence of the new iPhones during the September quarter
column27: still we beat our internal expectations in the region
column28: growing non-iPhone revenue strong double digits and iPhone customer demand grew through mid-September.

column1: Luca Maestri: Thank you
column2: Tim. Good afternoon
column3: everyone. We are very pleased to report today a new September quarter revenue record
column4: which caps a remarkable level of performance for our fiscal year 2020
column5: during which we set new all-time records for revenue
column6: earnings per share and free cash flow
column7: in spite of an extremely volatile and challenging macro environment. We could not be more proud of the way our team has innovated and executed
column8: throughout this unprecedented period of uncertainty. We reported total revenue of $64.7 billion for the September quarter
column9: up 1% from a year ago. This is a very impressive level of performance
column10: when we consider that this year; we did not launch and ship any new iPhone models during the quarter. Outside of iPhone
column11: we grew 25% in aggregate
column12: and had strong double-digit year-over-year revenue growth in each of our product categories. We set all-time records for Mac and Services
column13: and a September quarter record for Wearables
column14: Home and Accessories. We also achieved new September quarter records in the vast majority of countries that we track
column15: including among others
column16: The U.S.
column17: Canada Brazil
column18: Germany
column19: France
column20: Italy
column21: Spain
column22: Turkey
column23: Russia
column24: India
column25: Korea
column26: Thailand
column27: Malaysia and Vietnam. Products revenue was $50.1 billion with very strong underlying performance across each product category. Our products outside of iPhone grew a combined 30%
column28: despite supply constraints on iPad
column29: Mac and Apple Watch throughout the quarter. For iPhone
column30: through mid-September
column31: customer demand grew double-digits. As a result of this level of sales performance and the unmatched loyalty of our customers
column32: our installed base of active devices reached an all-time high in aggregate
column33: and in each of our major product categories.

And that's the reason you see in some of the channels too selling the hardware on a per month kind of basis. If that begins to look like a subscription
column3: perhaps to some buyers because they're used to holding the phone for a fixed period of time and then turning it over and using the residual value of that phone in a way that gives them a de facto kind of subsidy on a new phone. And so there is something today in the market that works somewhat similar. On the services side; we have -- we had customers coming to us and asking for an easier way to buy all of our services. And we wanted to provide that and we're looking forward to tomorrow to getting Apple one out there.

But I suspect that just the COVID in general take something off from a worldwide economic point of view.

column2: we're doing everything we can do. But we're prioritizing safety first
column3: obviously. And so with our stores as an example
column4: we've come up with a new concept that puts an essentially turns the store into an express storefront. And we've implemented that in a number of places where we believe that helps from the safety of our employee and the safety of the customer's point of view

column7: the channel is doing some similar things and then some different things as well. And so I think everybody to the best of their ability is putting in contingency plans and finding a way to adapt to the environment. But it is difficult to call and there's a level of uncertainty in it

And so we are very bullish about this area and view that there are there are more things that Apple can do in this space. And in so it's an area of great interest to us.

column1: TimCook: Yes
column2: we placed our thoughts in the color that Luca provided when he said that all products excluding iPhone
column3: all products and services excluding iPhone or all products

column5: normal will become something different. Because I think people are learning that there are aspects of this that work well. And so I don't believe that we're going to go back to where we were. And I think that means that iPads and Macs are even more important in those environments. The growth in both of these last quarter were phenomenal as you can tell from your from datasheet with Mac at 29 and iPad at 46. These are tremendous numbers and as Luca said the September quarter was the all time high for Mac in the history of the company
column6: and by not by little bit by $1.6 billion. And so it was a substantial difference that we did have aggressive promotion for college students that were going back to going back to school. And so that invariably part of it. But I think the other part of it during the remote work thing is not something that's going to snap back to the way it used to be anytime soon.

column22: investments
column23: restructurings
column24: or legal settlements. It's not possible to accurately predict demand for our goods and services
column25: and therefore our actual results could differ materially from our guidance. Before moving to Q&A
column26: I would like to draw attention to a new accounting rule that we implemented in Q1. The new rule requires excess tax benefits from stock-based compensation to be presented as an operating activity in the consolidated statements of cash flows. We retrospectively adjusted our consolidated statements of cash flows to re-classify excess tax benefits from financing activities to operating activities. And as a result
column27: you will see an increase in our free cash flow measures for prior periods. Additionally
column28: beginning January 1
column30: the excess tax benefit or deficiency for stock-based compensation is recognized as a component of tax expense rather than equity. This change resulted in a decrease to our tax expense for the quarter and a corresponding increase to our net income and earnings per share. Specific changes are presented in the footnotes to the consolidated statement of cash flows and related metrics provided in our press release. Further disclosure of the impact of the adoption of this accounting change can be found in our Form 10-Q. With that
column31: we will move to Q&A. Operator
column32: please remind our listeners how to initiate a question

column1: Operator: At this time
column2: we will now open up the call for questions. . Thank you. Our first question comes from Justin Post with Merrill Lynch. Please proceed with your question.

column1: Justin Post: Got it. I saw on the front page of the release you're really focused on India. Can you give us a progress update on how you're doing? Any thoughts on how far you're willing to take the investment levels there? And what are your thoughts on maybe when international margins can start to make progress? Thank you.
Brian T. Olsavsky: Sure
column2: Justin. Thank you. Yes
column3: I think Jeff's comments were pretty dead on. The launch of Prime last year was a big turning point. We've increased Prime selection by 75% since launching that nine months ago in India
column4: also increased the fulfillment capacity for sellers by 26% this year. On the content side
column5: we've announced A-Team in the original TV series and we're customizing the content
column6: so it's a really vast selection of local and global movies and TV shows that are available to the Indian public. You'll also notice that the Fire TV Stick was – a new version of it was launched in India with some important features there such as the ability to search in Hindi and in English
column7: free data usage for three months and also data monitoring
column8: which is important there. So again
column9: we continue to be encouraged by both the response from customers and sellers. As far as level of investment is concerned
column10: it is certainly one of our important investment areas. We see a lot of potential for the country and our business there.

column1: Justin Post: Any thoughts on how much it is impacting your international profitability?
Brian T. Olsavsky: Sure. I can't quantify it
column2: or break it out specifically
column3: but I will say it's a large factor as well as a couple other things in the international segment. So
column4: keep in mind that we launched Prime Video in the fourth quarter
column5: and now we have that in over 200 countries and territories. We're spreading a lot of the Prime benefits that we see in North America to other countries. We just opened up Amazon Fresh in Tokyo last weekend
column6: but also Prime Now. You saw other things like our business B2B business just opened up in the UK. We have Amazon Devices. So there's a lot of moving parts here. The other big influence is the same trends are happening in international with respect to FBA growth and the fact that our Amazon fulfill network
column7: or the units we shipped
column8: are growing at a much faster clip than our paid unit growth. Last year we said that was a 40% – nearly 40% growth worldwide. So we're making the investments in warehouses
column9: fulfillment capacity and delivery capacity to handle that. So there's a lot going on in international. We are very encouraged with the growth of the Prime program
column10: and we're hopeful for the Prime Video that we launched in the fall.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from Mark Mahaney with RBC Capital Markets. Please proceed with your question.
Mark Mahaney: Okay. Two questions. The North American operating margins seem to come down like 70 bps year-over-year
column2: and I know it's not big books view of the margins
column3: I get that. But it's sort of a change. You've had margins be flat or up year-over-year for quite some time
column4: and then they dipped down. Just could you explain that? And then secondly on these – on the Echo devices
column5: the Echo family
column6: Alexa devices that are coming out
column7: could you comment at all about what kind of impact you're seeing in terms of increased wallet or per share within households? Are you seeing it have an impact in terms of Amazon customers more likely to spend more once they have these devices in particular categories like groceries or household products
column8: pantry products that they're more likely to spend because they have these devices in their houses
column9: in their kitchens
column10: in their living rooms? Thank you.

column1: Brian T. Olsavsky: Sure
column2: Mark. Let me start with the Echo question first. So
column3: yeah
column4: we're very encouraged by the customer response to the Echo products. Not only the Echo products but the ability to use tablets
column5: our tablets now as Echo devices
column6: since we've spread the Alexa technology to many of those devices. And we're also happy with the success we've had with developers. There's now over 12
column7: 000 Alexa skills. So we think that's all foundational. The monetization
column8: as you might call it
column9: is a theme of your questions. That's not our primary issue right now. It's about building great products and delighting customers. We think as engagement – as we pick up engagement with the devices
column10: it helps the engagement with Amazon as a whole. So whether someone is ordering off their Alexa device or whether they're going to their phone
column11: or going to their computer
column12: it all has the same effect for us. So
column13: very pleased with the initial progress. We see a lot of momentum there and we continue to invest. And that's one of the answers to your second question on North America operating margin. So if I step back
column14: let me just talk generally about investments. So right now
column15: we're just seeing a lot of great opportunities before us. And we're continuing to ramp up the investments in pursuit of those opportunities. And the big picture is
column16: again
column17: as we've said customers – the things customers love can grow to be large
column18: we'll have strong financial returns and they're durable and can last for decades. So in that category
column19: and some of the things that we're investing the most in are as you say the Echo and Alexa devices. We're doubling down on that investment
column20: video content and marketing
column21: not only in the U.S. but globally with the launch of our Prime Video in the fall. So
column22: we're building global scale in that business in both content and marketing. As I said earlier
column23: we're expanding Prime benefits in the U.S. and also globally. Things like Prime Music
column24: Prime Now
column25: Amazon Fresh
column26: all expanding globally. And we have launched Prime in India
column27: China and Mexico. I know I'm drifting a bit from North America
column28: but it's all part of the same theme. We also have this trend going on in our fulfillment networks where strong FBA growth and high growth in Amazon fulfilled unit is resulting in a large increase in fulfillment capacity. We're also investing in new technologies such as artificial intelligence
column29: machine learning. You're starting to see some of that show up in things like Amazon Go
column30: our beta store that we have developed in Seattle
column31: drones. We use those technologies a lot in our internal businesses and we're also developing services for AWS customers. So – and that's of course another area is AWS continues to grow and add services and features and doing so at an accelerating rate. So there's a long list
column32: and I can keep going. But I think the general theme is there's a lot of investment in front of us that we're optimistic about
column33: and we continue to ramp those investments. In North America
column34: that manifests itself mostly in the device area
column35: the content area and also the expansion of the fulfillment networks.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from Brian Nowak with Morgan Stanley. Please proceed with your question.
Brian Nowak: Thanks for taking my questions. I have two. The first one
column2: Amazon always had a pretty big focus on efficiencies. I'd be curious if you could talk about examples or areas where you have been able to iron out inefficiencies in the fulfillment process. And any still existing examples where you see low hanging fruit to really improve fulfillment efficiency? And then back to the point on investment. You didn't mention brick and mortar at all. There's been a lot of mention in the press about Amazon brick and mortar. I guess it would be curious to hear how you think about the importance of an Amazon brick and mortar presence and how that fits into the long-term strategy?

column1: Brian T. Olsavsky: Sure thing. So
column2: particularly as it pertains to our fulfillment center networks
column3: I think the biggest areas of efficiency right now are in our Amazon Robotics areas. That technology continues to improve
column4: and we have – we're now multiple generations down. We just launched am Amazon Robotics fulfillment center in the Tokyo area recently
column5: and I toured that last month
column6: and it's just amazing to see the strides that Amazon Robotics has taken and the efficiency we're getting in our warehouse as a result. The other efficiencies that we're seeing are network efficiencies
column7: especially as we add things like sort centers. It's a collaboration and the movement between warehouses and sort centers and then to the end customer. The ability to have control through our sort centers has allowed us over the last few years to extend our cutoff times from 3:00 p.m. in most cases till midnight. So
column8: greater control of our processes. If we do it cost effectively can also have favorable benefits both for our warehouse flow and also for our customers and their ordering pattern. So
column9: there's a lot of efficiencies that are going on day-to-day around here. One of the benefits of rapid growth is the ability to create leverage on purchases and a lot of the processes that we run. So
column10: your second question was on stores. Yes
column11: I think you're seeing the expansion of our bookstores. We have six bookstores right now
column12: and we have announced another six. The Amazon Go is in beta in Seattle
column13: and while that's not large and only one site
column14: we're excited about the potential there and the use of the technologies of computer vision
column15: sensor fusion and deep learning. We think that has a lot of potential. Again
column16: it's only one location that's still in beta. But along with the bookstores
column17: we also have – you'll see us in pop-up stores and college pickup points. So
column18: for us it's another way to reach the customer and test what resonates with them
column19: and we're pleased with the results.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from Ron Josey with JMP Securities. Please proceed with your question.
Ronald V. Josey: Great. Thanks for taking the question. Brian
column2: I think you mentioned the accelerating growth within AWS on new products and last year you added about 1
column3: 000. Can you just talk about maybe the plans for AWS and product growth going forward here in 2017 and the focus on innovation? Thanks

column1: Brian T. Olsavsky: Sure. Yes
column2: we haven't updated that number
column3: but suffice to say the innovation pace continues to accelerate. We are very proud of the launches in Q4. The Amazon Connect
column4: which we think will provide customer service capability to customers
column5: and Amazon Chime
column6: which we also believe will resonate with customers. We've had a lot of adoption of our new services. We've had – customers migrated more than 23
column7: 000 data basis using the AWS Database Migration Service since that launched last year. And just generally we continue to expand geographically. We have announced additional availability zones and regions worldwide. So
column8: again
column9: signed a number of big customers. I guess I would point out in the quarter
column10: Liberty Mutual
column11: Snap and Live Nation all starting relationships with us or expanding their current relationship. We're now over a $14 billion run rate. We're happy with the business and the team
column12: and again
column13: for us innovation is going to be key as we move forward.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from Dan Salmon with BMO Capital Markets. Please proceed with your question.
Daniel Salmon: Hey. Good afternoon
column2: everyone. Brian
column3: I had a couple questions about your growing advertising business. We see more and more of it appearing on the site. And I was interested to hear a little bit more about how you expect that business to roll out internationally. I think it's largely U.S. based today
column4: but be curious to hear about that. And then second
column5: I think it's fairly obvious why someone selling within the Amazon ecosystem would be interested in promoting on the platform
column6: but maybe tell us a little bit about maybe over the long-term there are opportunities for sort of non-endemic advertisers within your platform. Thanks.

column1: Brian T. Olsavsky: Sure. Yeah
column2: it's pretty early in the days with advertising
column3: but we're very pleased with the team we have and the results. Our goal is to be helpful to consumers and enhance their shopping or their viewing experience with targeted recommendations
column4: and we think a lot of the information we have and preferences of customers and recommendations help us do that for customers. We have a sponsored product
column5: it's off to a great start
column6: and it's a very effective way for advertisers to reach those especially interested customers. While you're on the topic of advertising
column7: I thought I'd point out that in other revenue
column8: advertising is in other revenue
column9: as is co-branded credit card agreements and also some other advertising services. That decelerated from 99% in Q4 to 58% in Q1. But the fluctuation and the volatility was essentially in the co-branded credit card agreements and the other services
column10: which can fluctuate quarter-to-quarter based on contract terms. And that's what happened. Advertising remained strong and was consistent growth with Q4.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from Steven Ju with Credit Suisse. Please proceed with your question. Stephen Ju - Credit Suisse Securities (USA) LLC Thank you. So you periodically disclosed usage growth for AWS. But it has been some time since we saw one. So we're wondering if you can update us in terms of where you are now. If not
column2: I mean
column3: should we think about the growth in your cash deployment as an indicator of the ongoing growth? Thank you.

column1: Brian T. Olsavsky: Yes. Sorry
column2: I don't have a usage number to share with you today. If it will help
column3: I will tell you that
column4: again
column5: we're now over $14 billion run rate. You clearly see our – we break out very clearly our AWS segment revenue and operating income
column6: and you'll also keep in mind that there's price decreases that are part of the business
column7: and we're pretty public when we do those. And if you remember last call
column8: I mentioned that we had seven price decreases that were timed for December 1. So
column9: about a third of the impact of those was seen in Q4
column10: and then again that's one element of the sequential operating margin. But in general
column11: we're very happy with that team and the progress they're making. And we're deploying more capital as you can see to support the usage growth.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from Douglas Anmuth with JPMorgan. Please proceed with your question.

Douglas T. Anmuth: Thanks for taking the question. I just want to ask you about CapEx. It looks like CapEx including leases more than doubled year-over-year. So I know you listed kind of a long list of the many investment opportunities here
column2: but can you just point out anything else in particular that drove the pretty substantial increase there? Thank you.

column1: Brian T. Olsavsky: Sure. Yes
column2: the CapEx
column3: which is principally the fulfillment centers was – grew 51% year-over-year. As you'll remember
column4: we added 26 warehouses last – fulfillment centers last year
column5: 23 in the second half of the year. Some of that cost of start-up is before the start-up some comes in a quarter afterwards. So there was some carryover from that. But generally
column6: the biggest trend here is that the differential between Amazon fulfilled network unit growth and paid unit growth. So that nearly 40% growth in Amazon fulfilled units last year
column7: and the continuation of the strong growth higher than the paid unit growth that we see in 2017 is resulting in a lot of fulfillment center capacity. And the fulfillment centers I'll also say with the robotics technology tend to be more capital intensive than prior versions of warehouses
column8: and then they generally have much better operating efficiencies and variable costs following their start-up. On the capital leases
column9: that grew 45%. A good deal of that is tied to the AWS business. As I just mentioned
column10: a lot of that is tied to usage growth. But a caution; CapEx can fluctuate quarter-to-quarter
column11: and if you look back to last year
column12: the trailing 12 months was only 7% growth from the quarters through Q1 of last year. So certainly it was a bigger step-up in 2016 now carrying into 2017.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from Mark May with Citi. Please proceed with your question.

Mark A. May: Thanks. I know that we talked about over the last couple of quarters that part of the step-up in CapEx was to catch up from the under-investment in 2015. Just curious if you'd say – have you made a lot of progress in terms of catching up with some of the fulfillment needs that you saw necessary in the business at the beginning of last year? And then I know you just said that you're – it's still early days in terms of advertising
column2: but there's a perception out there that over the last year or so that the company has sort of really begun to focus more on this business opportunity. Has something really changed at the business in the last year? And do you see advertising becoming a more meaningful part of the business over the near to midterm
column3: I guess?

column1: Brian T. Olsavsky: Sure. Let me start with advertising. So
column2: yes
column3: I think scale is helping. We've had great teams working on advertising for a while now. Our scale and number of customers
column4: number of clicks
column5: number of eyeballs
column6: and new content – video content and other opportunities for advertising has really helped create some scale in that business. So we're very happy. I can't project it forward. But we're happy with the growth there. I think the sponsor products was a very inventive move for us
column7: and I think that is having some really good impact on advertising growth. On your second point about fulfillment capacity; here's how I'd generally generalize it. In Q4 of 2015
column8: we were pretty vocal or pretty transparent anyway that we ran out of space in Q4
column9: especially due to some very strong demand for FBA space and services. Last year we changed some of our incentives and worked with FBA merchants to try and have better throughput through our FCs
column10: particularly in Q4. That combined with the step-up in fulfillment centers that I mentioned
column11: the 26 new ones
column12: left us in a really good position. We had a very clean holiday
column13: and we think it worked well for both customers
column14: Amazon and also for sellers – for FBA sellers. So that leaves us now continuing to grow internationally as well because we continue to see strong FBA adoption
column15: and it's a big part of our business
column16: and it's a big part of our value with the additional Prime eligible ASNs that FBA provides. So
column17: again
column18: they're self-reinforcing
column19: the FBA program and also our Prime program. The Prime program attracts more people to Amazon
column20: and they buy more including FBA products and conversely more FBA products in our warehouses helps our in-stock of things that people want to buy
column21: Prime eligible in-stock
column22: and that helps reinforce the Prime program.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from Heath Terry with Goldman Sachs. Please proceed with your question.
Heath Terry: Great. Thanks. I'm wondering if you could give us a sense of how we should think about the increase in unearned revenue. Obviously
column2: this quarter biggest increase that you have seen from at least from a dollar perspective. What does that say about the way customers are changing in the behavior in the AWS business? How should we think about the way that that might be impacting pricing
column3: mix
column4: near-term growth?

column1: Darin Manney: Hi
column2: Heath. This is Darin. Yeah
column3: on a deferred revenue balances
column4: as we've said in the past
column5: the primary drivers of that increase are both the activity that we're seeing with our AWS customers and the purchase of Reserved Instances and prepaid credits for their account
column6: as well as Prime member purchases. We're not breaking out the specific growth rates for Prime
column7: but certainly it – we like what we see in terms of the growth
column8: and it's been consistent with what we have seen over the last quarter or so. Certainly
column9: the – part of that increase in deferred balances is related to Reserved Instances. As customers get more comfortable and begin to put more sustained workloads into the AWS services through buying RIs
column10: they're able to get fairly significant discounts on their usage. And so we like that model. Customers certainly like that model. And collecting that through deferred revenue and then letting customers use that over time is very helpful.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from Colin Sebastian with Robert W. Baird. Please proceed with your question.
Colin Alan Sebastian: Thank you. A question on the transportation and logistics initiatives. And in particular
column2: if you could share any of the effects or learnings thus far with air cargo. In particular
column3: what kind of performance or cost-efficiencies that you may be realizing or expect to realize from this effort. Thank you.

column1: Brian T. Olsavsky: Sure
column2: Colin. As you point out
column3: we're – we have expanded our own fleet. We now have 18 planes in service for Amazon
column4: and we have announced rights to lease up to 40 planes. So it's gone very well. The ability to control shipments within our network has gone up
column5: and we think the cost is very good. So on that front
column6: it's better control
column7: better capacity control
column8: especially search capacity
column9: and also good costs. So we have great relationships with third party carriers. We will continue to and we value all our partner relationships as we develop our own capability particularly in intra-network. We're putting it to good use
column10: as I mentioned before
column11: with the sortation center example.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from Scott Devitt with Stifel. Please proceed with your question.

Scott Devitt: Hi. Thanks. I was just wondering if you could talk a little bit about where you are in terms of an investment in capabilities in India at this point and how you think about that market longer term. And then secondly
column2: also if you could just comment on the limitations and your willingness to invest more throughout LatAm the way you have more recently in markets like China and India. And if I could
column3: just finally
column4: you've previously discussed satisfaction with the measurements of success for the video product in terms of consumer engagement
column5: and the effects on Prime. I was just wondering if you could comment on whether these metrics are continuing to improve as spending continues to rise on video and consumer awareness is seemingly growing as well. Thank you.

column1: Brian T. Olsavsky: Let me start with your middle question. I think it was about Latin America growth. Let me step back and talk about international growth in general. So our approach varies by country
column2: and if you look
column3: historically we've taken multiple approaches. So in China
column4: we bought an existing business Joyo.com and built off that base. In India
column5: we started from scratch and have built a lot of things ourselves. And it's always going to depend on the country that the dynamics in that country both for retail
column6: for online
column7: and for foreign investment. But a real key factor in all of this generally is management bandwidth as well. So
column8: we pick our spots carefully. You'll see – you heard in the quarter that we've announced the intention to buy Souq in the Middle East. Where does that fit into this strategy? Well
column9: Souq's pioneered e-commerce in the Middle East
column10: and they're creating great shipping experience for their customers and they're multiple countries
column11: and they're doing a great job. So we see this as an example where we can learn from them
column12: and also support their efforts with our Amazon technology and global resources. So we're in Mexico
column13: but we're not in other parts of Latin America. We have a business in Brazil. But other countries we'll take on a case-by-case basis
column14: again
column15: bounded by what our management bandwidth can support and prioritization versus other things. You obviously heard my long list of investments. All of those are pretty much gated by the need for people and software engineers and strong teams to approach them. So international expansion gets played off in the same prioritization that other efforts do.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from Jason Helfstein with Oppenheimer and Company. Please proceed with your questions.
Jason Helfstein: Thanks. So is there just an accounting housekeeping a way to think about stock-based comp? You guys aren't providing that by segment anymore
column2: but the rates of growth kind of differed by the businesses. And so is there just a way to think about
column3: A
column4: will that be in the queue? Or are you not disclosing it anymore? And is there a way to think about what I guess the patterns would be consistent with historical patterns by segment? Thanks.

column1: Darin Manney: Hi
column2: Jason. This is Darin. Yes
column3: we
column4: a number of quarters back
column5: started breaking out stock-based compensation by segment
column6: and now we have collapsed that in our op income by segment. So it's definitely in there. We do provide some disclosure by P&L line item on a consolidated basis
column7: that helps you identify that stock-based compensation expense in total and you'll see the trend and analysis and the metrics at the back of the press release.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from Eric Sheridan with UBS. Please proceed with your question.

Eric J. Sheridan: Thanks for taking the question. Maybe I can take two away from the press release just to understand a little bit of the quarter-over-quarter cadence. On the retail subscription services
column2: that saw a pretty big jump up in the growth rate year-on-year in Q1 versus Q4. I think that might be Prime memberships that come on to paid from trial. But just wanted to understand what maybe some of the driver was of that quarter-over-quarter in terms of the growth rate. And net shipping costs actually grew at the slowest rate by our count in a couple of years. It looks like you're starting to get some improvements there in terms of revenue over costs on the shipping line. Just wanted to know what that was in terms of what is driving that and can we expect that to possibly continue. Thank you.

column1: Brian T. Olsavsky: Sure. Let me start with the retail subscription services revenue. So there's multiple things in that category. The largest is Prime membership fees
column2: but also other subscription services like audio books
column3: eBooks
column4: digital video
column5: digital music
column6: and other subscription services. So you're right
column7: there was an acceleration
column8: much like the comment I had on advertising and the other revenue category. The Prime membership growth rates for Q1 and Q4 last year are relatively consistent. So the volatility is in these other items. So I'm not quantifying the Prime membership or commenting on the growth rates
column9: other than to say it's been very strong and Q4 strength has continued into Q1. Your comment on shipping costs
column10: yeah
column11: that is going to – it was lower unit volume as well
column12: but generally
column13: costs are going to be a combination of the tail – the headwinds are obviously going to be FBA growth and shipping more products ourselves and this expansion of our Prime program and the demand for products from our Prime customers. And the demand has been great. Again
column14: there's over 50 million items that people can get delivered to their doorstep within two days or
column15: in some cases
column16: next day or same day. So it's going to be a big part of our cost structure but it's an investment we work hard to reduce as far as rates
column17: and we're glad to spend it to support our Prime program.

column1: Operator: Thank you. And our final question will come from Greg Melich with Evercore ISI. Please proceed with your question.
Greg Melich: Hi. Thanks. I had a follow-up and then a new question. The follow-up is
column2: would love an update. You talked a lot about the fulfillment centers
column3: but could you update us on where we are in terms of rolling out Prime Now facilities and sorting centers? You're just accounting a few – you feel that scenario
column4: it's a really ramped up investment this year or what you got last year is sort of what you need?

column1: Brian T. Olsavsky: Sure. I'm sorry. You said Prime Now and what was the other thing?
Greg Melich: And the sorting centers.
Brian T. Olsavsky: Sort centers. Sort centers
column2: right. Well
column3: I don't have updated numbers for you
column4: but the Prime Now is available in more than 45 cities across eight countries. The Same-Day is available in 30 cities in the U.S. So
column5: that's a bit on the quantification of those. I can't tell you much more on sort centers.

column1: Greg Melich: But were you thinking about building out the capacity? It sounds like last year
column2: you had that big surge in fulfillment centers. There isn't a similar surge about to happen this year on some of those other areas?

column1: Brian T. Olsavsky: Yes. I can't project that. We're still growing that and we're happy with the progress in Prime Now and the service that – the value that it creates for Prime customers. And as I said
column2: we have expanded internationally
column3: which was a big goal of ours as well. So we will continue to grow that. I can't quantify it for you right now. The other similar like facility metric you might want is that AmazonFresh is now in 21 metro areas in the U.S. as well as London and Tokyo.

column1: Darin Manney: Thank you for joining us on our call today and for your questions. A replay will be available on our Investor Relations website
column2: at least through the end of the quarter. We appreciate your interest in Amazon.com
column3: and look forward to talking with you again next quarter.";[0.020433850865833714

column16: including reconciliations of these measures with comparable GAAP measures. Our guidance incorporates the order trends that we've seen to-date and what we believe today to be appropriate assumptions. Our results are inherently unpredictable and may be materially affected by many factors
column17: including fluctuations in foreign exchange rates
column18: changes in global economic conditions and customer spending
column19: world events
column20: the rate of growth of the Internet
column21: online commerce and cloud services and the various factors detailed in our filings with the SEC. Our guidance also assumes
column22: among other things

column24: investments
column25: restructurings or legal settlements and excludes the impact of our proposed acquisition of Whole Foods Market. It is not possible to accurately predict demand for our goods and services
