column28: please remind our listeners how to initiate a question.

column1: Operator: At this time
column2: we will open up the call for questions. We ask each caller please limit yourself to one question. Thank you. Our first question comes from line of Heath Terry with Goldman Sachs. Please proceed with your question.

column1: Heath Terry: Great. Thank you. I was just wondering if you could give us a sense on the investments that are planned in Q3. Previously
column2: you've been willing to provide sort of some qualitative guidance around how you're rank ordering those or in terms of the ones that are the largest areas of investment in the quarter. I'm just wondering if you could update us on that given the guidance for Q3 and what we saw in investment in Q2.

column1: Brian T. Olsavsky: Sure. Let me see what I can tell you on that. First of all
column2: I want to remind you that Q3 is typically a lower operating income quarter as we're preparing for the Q4 holiday peak. The other dynamic is that
column3: similar to last year
column4: a large percentage of our new fulfillment centers are coming online in the second half of the year
column5: a lot of them in Q3. So
column6: to give that some perspective
column7: the Amazon-fulfilled network
column8: or the combination of retail and FBA shipments coming out of our warehouses has been nearly 40%. It was that last year
column9: and it's continued through this year. Last year we added 30% additional square footage to handle that additional shipping volume
column10: and about 80% of that went into service in the back end of last year. And that's what I mentioned about this time last year. The similar dynamic this year
column11: we are going to have about 80% of our increase in square footage for fulfillment and shipping coming online in the back end of the year
column12: so that's a major increase. The other comment I would make is on the video content. Video content last year
column13: I highlighted the fact that it was going to be a significant step up between second half of 2016 and the second half of 2015. We are still – we lapped that most of the first half this year and we'll also be increasing video spend on a sequential and year-over-year basis in Q3
column14: and that's included in this guidance. Other than that
column15: can't give much more specifics except to say that the large investment areas remain the increasing fulfillment capacity to service the strong growth of the FBA business. I will also point out that the strong usage growth in AWS has led us to a step up in infrastructure in capital leases to build the capital leases in the trailing 12 months. They've increased 71% through the end of Q2 versus last year. That is servicing – accelerating usage in our largest AWS services as well as geographic expansion. So that's additional factor sequentially in the quarter year-over-year.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from Colin Sebastian with Robert W. Baird. Please proceed with your question.
Colin Alan Sebastian: Great. Thank you. A question on the grocery category and the announcements that we have – that we heard recently. Specifically
column2: does that imply that the strategy has changed around fresh
column3: which was presumably replacing the trip to the grocery store? Or should we think about adding different modes such as pick up points and bricks and mortar as serving a distinct customer base or geared to reduce the cost bottleneck around home delivery? Any comments would be helpful. Thanks.

column1: Brian T. Olsavsky: Sure
column2: Colin. First
column3: as far as Whole Foods is concerned
column4: as Darin mentioned
column5: it's not included in this guidance since it hasn't closed yet
column6: but we are excited about that acquisition and looking forward to working with the team at Whole Foods. We think they are very customer-centric
column7: just like us. They've built a great business
column8: focus around quality and customer. So we're really glad to join up with them. On your larger question about what the place of Amazon Fresh
column9: likely Prime Now and some of our other efforts
column10: I would say we believe there'll be no one solution
column11: so we're experimenting with a number of the formats from physical pickup points in Amazon Go to online ordering and delivery to your door through Prime Now and Amazon Fresh. And we'll see how customers respond. We like the response that we've seen so far. We think it's a valuable – all those are valuable services
column12: Amazon Go is not out of beta
column13: but the other ones are. On top of that
column14: we're looking forward to adding the Whole Foods team and their great reputation for quality customer service to this offering.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from Justin Post with Merrill Lynch. Please proceed with your question.
Justin Post: Yes. A couple of questions. It definitely seems relative to your guidance
column2: you may have stepped up spending in the second quarter. Anything in particular to call out
column3: India or anything like that? And then just thinking bigger picture
column4: I'm wondering why physical locations might make sense for Amazon. Why is that a positive use of capital going forward? Thank you.

column1: Brian T. Olsavsky: Sure. As far as Q2 is concerned
column2: we were very encouraged by the revenue and unit growth acceleration
column3: particularly in North America. We see that tied to the Prime growth and the adoption of Prime and success of that program. Also point out that AWS stepped up its run rate from a $14 billion run rate last quarter to $16 billion. So we saw the largest quarter-over-quarter and year-over-year increase in revenue in that business as well. And gross margin expanded 130 basis points. So as you point out
column4: the year-over-year difference is primarily driven by investments
column5: what we were within the guidance range and we continue to invest in
column6: as I said
column7: fulfillment capacity and logistics services
column8: digital video
column9: our Echo and Alexa
column10: Echo devices and Alexa platform India
column11: the buildup at the AWS infrastructure
column12: all the things I mentioned not to mention Prime Now and Amazon Fresh and Prime benefits. We did see a big jump in head count in year-over-year. You'll see it's 42%
column13: and in the past
column14: I'd say most of that is driven by operations hiring. I've even said that headquarters or office hiring many times in the past was below the level of revenue growth. Right now
column15: what we're seeing is an accelerated growth rate in software engineers and also sales teams to support primarily AWS and advertising. So
column16: yes
column17: the growth rate of those two job categories actually exceeded the company growth rate. So we are adding – having success hiring a lot of people and pointing them at some very important programs and customer-facing efforts. On the place of physical
column18: again
column19: as I mentioned in the earlier question
column20: we are experimenting with a number of formats. You've seen the physical bookstores and I would say that the benefit there is again
column21: we have a curated selection of titles and it's also a great opportunity for people to touch and feel our devices and see them
column22: especially the new Echo devices. I went into the store in Seattle last week and I saw about a third of the people were standing around the device table learning how they work
column23: how they interact with devices. So
column24: I saw firsthand the customer experience
column25: I think
column26: that's what we're seeing as a benefit to the physical stores right now.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from Mark May with Citi. Please proceed with your question.

Mark A. May: Thank you. A question on the comments around the fulfillment investments. Could you characterize or maybe even quantify how much of the fulfillment infrastructure investment that you're making is kind of incremental
column2: is geared towards handling growth and sort of the existing business and infrastructure versus expanding your capabilities in fulfillment
column3: like adding more inbound or last mile and/or from entering new international markets where you need to invest ahead of growth versus just sort of keeping up and maintaining growth within sort of your existing footprint? And then AWS
column4: you had some price adjustments in May
column5: yet the Q2 growth was quite good. Can you just comment about the impact that those cuts may have had in Q2 and if you're modeling those also in your Q3 guidance
column6: maybe the impact there? Thanks.

column1: Brian T. Olsavsky: Yes. Let me start with the second one. So
column2: yes
column3: we've had numerous price decreases
column4: and we continue to have that in the AWS business
column5: both absolute decreases in service costs and also rolling out new services that may be cannibalizing more expensive other services that we provide. So
column6: nothing really to note on Q2 or Q3 from that standpoint. The fulfillment investments
column7: I can't split it out for you between Amazon logistics support sort centers and fulfillment centers. What I can say
column8: the biggest dynamic going on again is that Amazon fulfilled unit growth of nearly 40%
column9: which was last year and carrying into this year. It's a global number and we are very glad to have the success of the FBA program. We are matching that with just over 30% increase in square footage
column10: and you're right
column11: that does include some shipping sort centers and things that are incremental and new functions for us
column12: if you will. But that's about all I can say on that right now. I think we're very happy with the FBA program. It's impact on Prime and we think Prime and FBA are self-reinforcing. We know customers really like it
column13: the additional selection that FBA provides. So we like those combined
column14: and we are working very hard to match that with capacity in an efficient manner.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question is from Douglas Anmuth with JPMorgan. Please proceed with your question.
Douglas T. Anmuth: Thanks for taking the question. I just wanted to follow up on AWS
column2: and just on the back of the price cut
column3: obviously 1Q being the first full quarter
column4: but it looks like 2Q
column5: as Mark said
column6: things did stabilize some. Can you just talk about whether you're seeing more of a volume pickup response here and companies kind of more actively moving volume into the cloud at these lower prices? And then just secondly
column7: on Prime
column8: the value of a Prime subscription for the consumer seems to continue to increase as you add more features in there. Can you just talk about your view around the flexibility of the price of annual Prime subscription? Thanks.

column1: Brian T. Olsavsky: Sure. On the price of Prime
column2: I have nothing to add at this time. We think that the – we are increasing the value of the Prime program every day. So it becomes more and more valuable and again
column3: as we've said
column4: it's the best deal in retail. On AWS
column5: yes
column6: we are seeing great customer adoption. Again
column7: as I said earlier
column8: the run rate's gone up from $14 billion to $16 billion in Q2
column9: and also we had the largest sequential and year-over-year dollar rise in revenues. Our usage in all of our large services are actually accelerating and they're growing at a rate higher than our revenue growth. So
column10: you're seeing great adoption. We are seeing AWS customers migrate more than 30 databases over the last year-and-a-half. We signed some very big customer wins
column11: like Ancestry
column12: High Tail
column13: California Polytechnic State University and others
column14: that we're very proud to have. So
column15: yes
column16: the momentum in the business is very strong. We continue to open new regions. We'll be opening five regions in the near future in France
column17: China
column18: Sweden
column19: Hong Kong and a second government cloud region in the East. So
column20: yes
column21: we like the momentum in that business. Stepping back
column22: I would say that while pricing is important
column23: again
column24: we're generally being selected because of our functionality and pace of innovation
column25: the innovation keeps accelerating. It did in the first half of this year
column26: the pace of new services and features. We also know the customers value our partner and customer ecosystem and really the experience we've had
column27: we've been at this longer than anybody else.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from Mark Mahaney with RBC Capital Markets. Please proceed with your question.
Mark Mahaney: Hey. I want to stick with AWS
column2: please. So the AWS revenue growth showed almost no change but the AWS operating margin was lower I guess than we've seen in
column3: I don't know
column4: six quarters or something like that. I find that a little surprising but then I also saw that the tech and content came in materially heavy
column5: I think
column6: versus our and I assume other expectations. So could you just talk about that a little bit
column7: the profitability
column8: if there's anything that's changed in the profitability of AWS? Thanks.

column1: Brian T. Olsavsky: Sure. Those margins
column2: as we say frequently
column3: are going to fluctuate quarter-to-quarter and always going to be a net of investments
column4: excuse me
column5: price reductions and cost efficiencies that we drive. So I would say the biggest impact in the margin that you're seeing in Q2 is really around the 71% increase in assets acquired under capital leases. Most of that is for the AWS business. So we've really stepped up the infrastructure to match the large usage growth and also the geographic expansion. And that is showing up in tech and content. On the marketing
column6: if you look under the marketing expenses
column7: they are also up
column8: and that is driven by the increases we're seeing in the sales team both in AWS and advertising. So I would point to those two as probably larger than normal impacts on Q2 operating margin.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from Brian Nowak with Morgan Stanley. Please proceed with your question.
Brian Nowak: Thanks for taking my questions. I have two. The first one
column2: as you continue to add more Prime Now markets with one to two-hour shipping
column3: can you just talk to some of the logistical challenges that you've already encountered and worked through? And talk to kind of if you really do see one to two-hour shipping become a larger piece of the business over the next year
column4: what's the biggest challenge you have to make sure that you manage? And the second one on the subscription revenue
column5: it looks like subscription revenue growth was strong again
column6: over 50%. Could you just talk to what drove that acceleration? Was it Prime? Or is there something else in there? Thanks.

column1: Brian T. Olsavsky: Sure. Let me start with your second question on the subscription revenue. It grew 53% year-over-year versus 52% in Q1. So
column2: we continue to see strong Prime membership growth. That is the main thing. There's also – in that line item are also other monthly fees associated with some of our other subscription services like audiobooks
column3: e-books
column4: digital video and digital music. Again
column5: I would say that we're very happy with the Prime membership growth and it has remained pretty consistent both in Q4 and then through Q1 and Q2 of this year. On your second question on Prime Now
column6: so Prime Now is now available in 50 cities across eight countries. We do learn. It's something to do in every city and have different – slightly different shapes and sizes of those buildings and different density profiles. And so we are learning as we go
column7: learn as we grow internationally as well. That is a service that customers love. That's not an inexpensive service
column8: though
column9: and we also have – so we're constantly working on our cost of delivery and our route densities. And again
column10: we like what we see and we'll continue to expand that and we'll be working very hard on making that not only a valuable Prime offering
column11: a Prime benefit
column12: but also a lower-cost operation as well.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from the line of Dan Salmon with BMO Capital Markets. Please proceed with your question.
Daniel Salmon: Hey. Good afternoon
column2: Brian. I think I heard you earlier say that your head count for advertising salespeople is growing faster than the company as a whole
column3: or company's head count growth rate as a whole. I would just like to use that maybe as a springboard to talk a little bit about what you think the right mix is for how you sell in terms of self-service versus salespeople. And then a second one would just be a quick one. I know it's early
column4: but be curious to see what you're seeing with users of the Echo Show
column5: with the screen on it
column6: and if you're seeing any particularly different type of user behavior there versus the original devices with that one. Thank you.

column1: Brian T. Olsavsky: Sure. Yes. It's early on the Echo Show. As you know
column2: we just started shipping those in late June
column3: but we're very excited about the potential and the addition of the video screen and the messaging capability and video capability. So it's – I've used mine
column4: it's awesome. It's a big step up in my mind
column5: but we'll get more customer feedback as we go along. On advertising
column6: technically what I said is the sales force has grown higher than the rate of growth in the business itself
column7: which was 42% regular head count and that sales force is primarily AWS and advertising. So
column8: we built self-service tools and obviously we want to make those as efficient as possible for customers and advertisers
column9: but we realize that we will need actual sales contact with the accounts as well. So it's a mix. I can't get into the split
column10: really
column11: but I would see both growing.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from line of Eric Sheridan with UBS. Please proceed with your question.
Eric J. Sheridan: Thanks so much for taking the question. Maybe two. One
column2: with respect to international margins
column3: is there anything there you can give us in terms of rank order or color
column4: whether it be geographies or category expansion that we should be thinking about that are driving some of the cost curve in the international side of the business? That would be number one. Number two
column5: stock-based comps stepped up a lot
column6: both quarter-over-quarter and year-on-year. Wanted to know if there was anything either organic or inorganic that was driving that step-up in stock-based compensation. Thank so much.

column1: Brian T. Olsavsky: Sure. I'll start with the second one. Yes
column2: as you noted in the press release or the 8-K
column3: we had an absolute step-up from Q1 of $792 million to Q2 of $1.2 billion. So it increased 51% year-over-year in Q2 versus a head count increase of 42%. I'll also say that we generally see a step-up from Q1 to Q2 because we do our employee RCU grants in Q2 of each year. So that's a normal trend. But the 51% year-over-year is also – it's a combination of the hiring we've done but also an adjustment we made to our estimated forfeiture rate. We're seeing less forfeitures
column4: which is a great sign for our employee retention
column5: but you have to make adjustments to your reserves as you see that. So that was another influence in Q2. On operating margins internationally
column6: I would step back and say a lot of the investments we're making in North America we're also making in international. Prime benefits including Prime Video and remember we launched Global Video in Q4 of last year to 200 countries
column7: Prime Now
column8: Amazon Fresh
column9: the general rise of FBA and added selection
column10: both retail and FBA to make Prime more attractive
column11: and the fulfillment and logistics costs that go with that
column12: and the additional constant effort to reduce prices and accelerate shipping. So that all impacts both North America segment and international. The North America segment is a little further along in the Prime
column13: excuse me
column14: yes
column15: the Prime membership growth curve. And so in some respects we are giving benefits earlier in the lifecycle to international Prime customers than we did in North America just because it launched later. And there's also India
column16: as I mentioned
column17: we continue to invest in India. We're very hopeful with the progress we've made with sellers and customers alike in India and we see great momentum and success there
column18: so we continue to invest and we have some of our best people in that business.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from line of Brian Fitzgerald with Jefferies. Please proceed with your question.
Brian P. Fitzgerald: Thanks
column2: guys. You mentioned before just stand of new fulfillment centers
column3: it takes a bit of time for them to ramp optimization. How should we think about that path optimization over a year or so? As you continue to scale operations and you bring data to bear and robotics and Kivas and AI machine learning
column4: are you finding that kind of new fulfillment center optimization curve is accelerating?

column1: Darin Manney: Hi
column2: Brian. This is Darin. Yes. We're getting more efficient every time we put new capacity into the network
column3: whether that's through automation or just through the experience we've gained over the years. We still say it takes up to three years or three peaks to get to kind of network efficiency for a new particular facility
column4: and that's about the same although the whole network gets sufficient over time. So there's a big mix going on
column5: and we like the new innovation that we're bringing to the capabilities
column6: but that ramp still stays about consistent as it was.

column1: Operator: Thank you. And our final question comes from line of from Jason Helfstein with Oppenheimer and Company. Please proceed with your question.
Jason Helfstein: Thanks for taking my question. Just one
column2: other slowed from 58% in the first quarter to 53% year-over-year. Anything to call out? And then just you made a comment about physical stores and reaction to one other question that was really about showcasing new devices. Is it fair to say that probably means locations would have small footprints versus large footprints if you're thinking about that? Thank you.

column1: Brian T. Olsavsky: I'm sorry. What was the first part of your question?
Jason Helfstein: The other
column2: other revenue slowed from 58% in the first quarter to 53%. Is there anything to call out around that?

column1: Brian T. Olsavsky: No
column2: nothing in that other line item. It's advertising and also other things like cobranded credit card agreements. I would say that advertising revenue growth has been strong and fairly consistent over the past three quarters. So that number will move around
column3: but there's other things in it that more the variance and the volatility is in the other line items. Your question on stores
column4: we are – again
column5: I personally think the new devices
column6: the ability to see new devices is a great asset
column7: but I don't want to shortchange the rest of the bookstore and the ability to have curated selection and the creativity we've had in taking new look at the bookstores. So we are experimenting with different formats
column8: and we look at different sizes and we look at revenue cost per square foot just like any other physical retailer. So
column9: we haven't essentially nailed the model yet
column10: and we continue to experiment to see what works and how it differs by city or more suburban locations.

column1: Darin Manney: So thank you
column2: Brian
column3: and thank you all for joining us on the call today and for your questions. A replay will be available on our Investor Relations website through at least the end of the quarter. We appreciate your interest in Amazon.com and look forward to talking to you again next quarter.";[0.1497165176249049

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from the line of Mark Mahaney with RBC Capital Markets. Please proceed with your question.
Mark Mahaney: Great. I guess I'll ask two as well. The first one is that was a bit of unusual upside to your guidance
column2: even stripping out Whole Foods. What most surprised you in the quarter? You have been pretty consistent on how you reported versus your guide
column3: so something unusual happened or somewhat unusual happened
column4: what would you attribute that to?

column1: Brian T. Olsavsky: Sure. In Q3
column2: yes
column3: I would say we had a very strong Prime Day. As you know
column4: we talked about that on the last call. But it really carried into the quarter. We had a record day for sign-ups for free trials for Prime in Prime Day globally
column5: had a very strong Prime Day in particular internationally. So
column6: it really got a lot more traction in this
column7: the third year that we've had it. So I would point mostly to those factors. It was also a very strong quarter for AWS. Revenue growth was the same as Q2
column8: and now we're at an $18 billion run rate
column9: whereas last quarter when I had this call

column11: so very pleased with the customer response in the AWS business as well. And usage growth is actually growing a lot higher than revenue growth. So particularly pleased with the new customers that we've added and the additional workloads that we've picked up from existing customers.

column1: Mark Mahaney: And then
column2: briefly
column3: on the international retail
column4: that growth also by itself was intrinsically stronger than you've seen in a while. Any particular markets
column5: geographic markets
column6: you would call out there?

column1: Brian T. Olsavsky: Yeah
column2: I would – yeah
column3: it was pretty strong across the board. We had the impact of Souq obviously
column4: this quarter internationally and the Diwali holiday in India was a few days earlier
column5: which maybe pushed some sales into Q3 versus Q4. But generally
column6: it was the strength of Prime Day internationally
column7: and it carried through the quarter
column8: but generally
column9: I would point to the increased selection. A lot of the building blocks that we've been working on
column10: all the Prime benefits
column11: advancements in free shipping offers or faster shipping offers
column12: the Prime benefits would drive engagement
column13: of course
column14: adding selection
column15: adding Fulfilled by Amazon partners and the selection that they bring. So again
column16: I wouldn't point to anything other than the Prime Day pickup
column17: but it was stronger than probably I anticipated.

column1: Mark Mahaney: Okay. Thank you
column2: Brian.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from the line of Brian Nowak with Morgan Stanley. Please proceed with your question.
Brian Nowak: Thanks for taking my questions. I have two. Just on Whole Foods again

column4: customer-obsessed
column5: ready to work together to continue their mission and expand on their offerings that we can offer customers. The other things I mentioned

column9: Prime Now
column10: and Whole Foods as we can explore different ways to serve the customer. So

column12: and we're thrilled to finally be working together after the summer of closing the deal. On subscription revenue

column14: as you said
column15: 600 basis points higher than Q2. In this line item
column16: is certainly the fees associated with Amazon Prime and also it's where a lot of our subscription services for digital music
column17: digital video
column18: audiobooks
column19: e-books

column23: on the other subscription services
column24: music especially
column25: it works just so well with our Echo device that we're seeing a lot of growth in that area as we increase the number of Echo devices and customers using the Echo devices.

Eric J. Sheridan: Thanks for taking the question. In the comment in the release on seasonal workers

column1: Dave Fildes: Yes
column2: Eric
column3: this is Dave. I think we put out a release
column4: I think
column5: earlier this quarter talking about 120
column6: 000 operations folks to bring into our fulfillment centers this year. So
column7: we're continuing to hire and hire across a number of locations. We talked earlier this year about expecting to see a greater than or – roughly or greater than 30% square footage growth in operations. So

column9: but it requires a tremendous effort from a number of our folks as well
column10: and so we'll continue to hire there.

column1: Brian T. Olsavsky: While we're on this subject of head count
column2: head count grew 77% year-over-year in the quarter. That includes the impact of the Whole Foods and Souq acquisitions. Without those
column3: without that head count
column4: the base Amazon grew 47%
column5: which is still up from 42% in Q2. So a lot of the additional pickup in Q3 was tied to our ramp for the holidays. We continued to hire a lot of software engineers. We continued to hire a lot of sales reps and it's tied directly to our major investment areas of AWS
column6: Prime Video and devices.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from the line of Douglas Anmuth with JPMorgan. Please proceed with your question.
Douglas T. Anmuth: Thanks for taking the question. Brian

column3: at this point
column4: you're prioritizing expansion into new product categories. In particular

Can you just help us understand the approach in general to new categories and pharmacy in particular? Thank you.

column2: I can't confirm or deny any of the rumors related to pharmacy or anything else. I will say we do see a lot of opportunity with Whole Foods. As I said
column3: there will be a lot of work together between Prime Now
column4: AmazonFresh
column5: Whole Foods
column6: Whole Foods products on the Amazon site
column7: Amazon Lockers at the Whole Foods stores. So
column8: there will be a lot of integration
column9: a lot of touch points and a lot of working together as we go forward. And we think we'll be also developing new store formats and everything else just as we talked about in the past before Whole Foods. Amazon Books stores
column10: Amazon Go
column11: and the opportunity that that technology presents. We have on campus bookstores. So
column12: we are experimenting with a lot of formats. I think that Whole Foods really gives us a vast headstart on that and a great base. And a great team to work with who has a lot of history and a lot of – they probably have 10 years to 20 years of learnings that we don't have and wouldn't have. So
column13: we're really excited about that and I think working together
column14: will bring our different strengths to the table and really be able to build on behalf of customers.

column1: Douglas T. Anmuth: Great. Thank you
column2: Brian.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from the line of Mark May with Citi. Please proceed with your question.
Mark A. May: Thank you. The other category which includes advertising accelerated 58% in the quarter. I think the common view there is that that's a fairly high margin business
column2: certainly higher than corporate average. Is there any reason why that isn't the right assumption to make? Essentially what impact is the growth in the ad business having on the company's overall profitability? And in terms of the increased losses in the international retail segment of the business
column3: can you provide some color around how much of that's being driven by Amazon launching into new markets
column4: which I know you continue to do
column5: versus investing more heavily in existing markets?

column1: Brian T. Olsavsky: Sure. Let me start with the revenue. So you're right
column2: other revenue grew 58% in the quarter. And that includes advertising services and other things such as our cobranded credit card agreements. Advertising revenue continues to grow very quickly and its year-over-year growth rate is actually faster than the other revenue line item that you see there. But I would say
column3: generally
column4: we're very pleased with the advertising business. Our goal here is to be helpful to consumers and help them make better shopping and selection choices. We'll also provide – and giving them targeted recommendations
column5: so making it helpful for customers rather than intrusive. And then we believe that by creating that growth (17:19) and engaging advertising experience with the customers
column6: it will also maximize success for our advertisers. So
column7: it's an important part of the flywheel and so it's the traffic and the customers
column8: especially the Prime customers that come to the site
column9: are really the ones that we can use to help them select items and use advertising to help make their decisions more informed when they're picking products. On the international
column10: yeah
column11: I can't split it
column12: the effects
column13: but I will tell you again
column14: it is international expansion and primarily in India where we're continuing to add benefits. And we launched Prime there a year ago
column15: if you remember
column16: and we've had more Prime members join in India than in any other country in the first 12 months. We have free shipping on 10 million items there and we're continuing to add benefits; Prime Video
column17: Amazon Family. We had the first Prime Day there this year
column18: Prime Music
column19: Amazon Business is also expanding in India. So
column20: a lot of positive momentum and investment going on in India
column21: very pleased with that. We also recently announced Echo and Alexa are available in India. So that should be well received by the Indian consumer base. But excluding India and Souq
column22: the rest is the Prime benefits and the continued growth in the other countries that we have been in for a while
column23: continue to roll out Prime Now and AmazonFresh. In video
column24: if you remember in Q4 of last year
column25: we launched Prime Video in over 200 countries globally
column26: continue to build up not only the offerings
column27: but also the engagement that we see from those Prime customers. So becoming more engaged and we're also doing the basic blocking
column28: tackling of adding selection
column29: especially FBA selection
column30: increasing free shipping offers and also speed of shipping offers. So
column31: there's a lot of different influences there. You saw the growth rate. We believe that it's resonating with customers. So
column32: we will continue to invest and think that we have a good path forward.

What level of investment should we expect in Brazil maybe relative to like in Australia or in India? And then a follow-up on the Whole Foods

column6: more recently
column7: added physical books again
column8: a third-party marketplace offering. So
column9: I think
column10: we're excited about the electronics getting out there. There is a wide variety of products included in that category: smartphones
column11: tablets
column12: cameras
column13: TVs
column14: what have you. So
column15: I think
column16: we're really excited to get that technology out there for Brazilians. And I think beyond that
column17: we really just focus on those categories and growing selection there
column18: but I can't speculate on what we might do in the future there.

column1: Brian T. Olsavsky: And on Whole Foods
column2: yes
column3: I believe the total is 465 stores or thereabouts. And we have 12 bookstores now. We are adding a few more in the near future in California
column4: Washington DC
column5: and Austin. So
column6: yeah
column7: you will see more expansion from us. We're not ready to announce what that will look like and we are working with the Whole Foods team on how many more stores we might have in that area. But still early
column8: so those plans will develop over time.

column4: obviously

column11: have about an 800-basis-point easier comp Q3 to Q4
column12: taking those two things into consideration
column13: how should we think about AWS growth through the end of the year?

column12: I mean

column1: Brian T. Olsavsky: Yeah
column2: on AWS
column3: we don't provide segment level estimates

column5: we had a number of price cuts timed about around December 1 of last year. That certainly had an impact on Q4 of last year. But again
column6: price cuts and not only price cuts but new products that have lower average cost and can cannibalize more expensive products is pretty much a part of our business all the time in AWS. So we're looking forward to a strong Q4 and re:Invent is in December or the end of November
column7: early December
column8: so that is also an exciting time of year for the AWS business.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from the line of Scott Devitt with Stifel. Please proceed with your question.
Scott William Devitt: Hi. Thanks. I had two
column2: please. First
column3: Prime Now
column4: Fresh
column5: Prime Pantry
column6: and Whole Foods
column7: they're all distinct offerings

column10: given the recent management changes in video
column11: Brian
column12: I was just wondering if you could speak to any strategic shifts in video or changes in the pace of content portfolio build in coming years? Thank you.

column1: Brian T. Olsavsky: Sure. Let me start with video. And I just want to be clear. We're going to continue to invest in video and increase that investment in 2018. And why are we going to do that? It's because the video business is having great results with our most important customer base
column2: which is our Prime customers. It continues to drive better conversion of free trials
column3: higher membership renewal rates for existing subscribers and higher overall engagement. We're seeing the engagement go up year-after-year in video and also music and a lot of the other Prime benefits. We also know Prime members who watch video also spend more on Amazon. And we have a lot of data where that's the advantage we have is that we see the viewing patterns
column4: and we also see the sales patterns
column5: so we can tie the two together and understand which video resonates with Prime members
column6: which video doesn't
column7: and make mid course corrections. So we always do that. We're always changing the emphasis and looking for those more impactful shows
column8: more shows that resonate better with our customer base
column9: and things they want to see. So that will always be an important part of our Prime offer
column10: and we'll continue to use the data that we have to make better and better decisions about where to invest our dollars in Prime Video. So we remain very bullish on the video business
column11: and we're looking forward to a lot of interesting new projects at the back-end of this year and also lined up into next year. On the
column12: sorry
column13: the second comment was
column14: oh
column15: the overlap. Yes. So Whole Foods
column16: I think I mentioned this earlier
column17: but we definitely see commonality and overlap with the Whole Foods business as well as Amazon in total
column18: but specifically Prime Now and also AmazonFresh. And we're going to work to see how we expand those offerings
column19: and in some cases combine them. We're not sure how it'll play out. But we're going cooperate across those different customer touch points and trying to make them better for customers. We know customers are going to buy
column20: just like in the physical world
column21: sometimes you go to a convenience store
column22: sometimes you go to a supermarket
column23: sometimes you go to a superstore. Sometimes you need things within an hour
column24: sometimes you can wait days for shipments. So there's no one paradigm for all customer engagement
column25: and we're looking for the ones that resonate best with customers and we're going to continue to work on those.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from the line of Jason Helfstein with Oppenheimer. Please proceed with your question.
Jason Helfstein: Thanks. I'll actually ask two
column2: if I can. Just any way you can comment on the increase in Whole Foods traffic after the close? And then second
column3: talk about your desire to have an ad supported business on Fire TV or through Prime Video? Thank you.

column1: Brian T. Olsavsky: Let me start on traffic. So we're not disclosing traffic figures. Whole Foods will be issuing a final 10-K early next month. So you'll see a better perspective on the entire quarter. The quarter that
column2: or the four week period that you see running through the Amazon P&L this quarter is pretty hard to draw conclusions on other than revenue at this point. But Dave
column3: do you have more on the...?

column1: Dave Fildes: Yeah
column2: Jason
column3: this is Dave. On the ad supported question
column4: I think what you've seen to-date is really particularly as you're looking as a customer
column5: as a Prime Video member and watching content
column6: we view that as you've paid into that service and able to watch those shows ad free. There may be instances where you're viewing a first episode and there's an ad leading into that if it's the first free episode
column7: but generally we like to have that as customers have paid into that program and they'll be able to enjoy that without interruption.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our final question comes from the line of Ron Josey with JMP Securities. Please proceed with your question.
Ronald V. Josey: Great. Thanks for the question. Just wanted to ask about delivery and just over the last several months
column2: we've seen a lot of announcements and products around delivery options between Lockers
column3: the testing of the Kohl's partnership
column4: Whole Foods obviously
column5: Amazon Key came out recently
column6: just wanted to better understand this investment. Is this a result of
column7: or the thesis that more options could drive obviously more sales on the flip side
column8: do you think you're losing sales by not having those options? Thank you.

column1: Brian T. Olsavsky: Probably a little of both. We think that especially as we get into more and more Amazon Logistics deliveries
column2: we're going to experiment with different ways to deliver things that make it easier on consumers
column3: things that cut down on potential theft on doorsteps
column4: but really it's mostly about increasing convenience for them.

column1: Dave Fildes: Yeah. I think that's right. In terms of overall investments there.
Brian T. Olsavsky: And the other investments obviously are on the -maybe on the bigger-ish things or like planes and transportation capacity in general. There our philosophy is
column2: again
column3: we are going to watch out for our customers
column4: we're going to build capacity that gives them great service 12 months a year but particularly at holidays. By investing in those transportation options
column5: we do so at same cost or cost parity I would say at the very minimum. But it also allows us to do interesting things like extend cut off times for customers. It enables Sunday delivery
column6: enable better weekend delivery. So we're seeing a lot of benefits
column7: just the ability to stretch the order cut off from what once was 3 PM in the afternoon to midnight. Has huge benefits for both the customer and also for Amazon. It results in incremental sales and it also builds that trust that when you need something
column8: Amazon is going to be there for you. And I need to remind you that the Thursday Night Football Game will start in two hours and 20 minutes
column9: so...

column1: Dave Fildes: On that
column2: thanks for joining us on the call today and for your questions. A replay will be available on our Investor Relations website at least through the end the quarter. We appreciate your interest in Amazon
column3: and look forward to talking with you again next quarter.";[0.24063897541810575

column1: Operator: [Operator Instructions]. Our first question comes from the line of Mark Mahaney with RBC Capital Markets.

column3: we've seen in a couple of years

Was that one of the factors? Was it the full quarter of the Whole Foods impact? Was it advertising revenue? Just what drove that result and how sustainable is it?

column1: Brian Olsavsky: Sure
column2: Mark. Let me address your question by answering the entire company on noteworthy North America elements are strongest. So for the quarter
column3: we came in at the highest end of our revenue range
column4: $60.5 billion
column5: 26 -- 36% FX-neutral growth and 25% FX-neutral growth
column6: excluding the Whole Foods acquisition. So the fact that we came in at the high end of the range
column7: volume was high
column8: especially in North America
column9: and a lot of times in Q4 and other quarters actually

column11: I would say. The ops team did a great job handling record volumes in Q4 and also incorporating all the new capacity we had opened in 2017. If you remember

column13: coming off the similar increase in 2016. So amid all these opening of new buildings
column14: many of them late in the year
column15: the ops team did a fantastic job. Advertising was also a key contributor as we're continuing to make more value -- the offering's more valuable
column16: both to customers and advertisers alike
column17: and that was particularly strong in North America
column18: although not in the North America segment. I would also point out
column19: AWS had a strong quarter
column20: accelerating growth versus Q3 and also expanding operating margins by 100 basis points. So particularly in North America
column21: I would say there's the volume -- the strong volume -- top line volume
column22: combined with increased advertising revenues and also very clean operational performance. Obviously

column24: in the name of customer experience in prior years

column26: in hindsight
column27: probably one of the cleaner Q4s recently.

column1: Operator: Our next question comes from the line of Ross Sandler with Barclays.
Ross Sandler: Hey guys

column4: and that's been kind of moving in tandem with the Amazon fulfilled unit growth. Is that the right way to think about it? It looks like it might be getting a little bit of leverage in the model right now what's driving that

column1: Brian Olsavsky: Sure. Let me start with that last one. Yes
column2: the shipping costs are going to be very tied to AFN unit growth and also the impact often greater Prime adoption and faster shipping methods. So we consider that a very strong quarter as down sequentially in the growth that we've seen recently. That will fluctuate quarter to quarter. Again
column3: it was a very strong operational quarter in Q4
column4: and we've expanded the number of items that shipped free. There are now over 100 million items in the U.S. So shipping cost is always going to be a strong part of our offering
column5: and we're -- it's going to be increasing due to our business model
column6: and we
column7: at the same time
column8: look then to minimize the cost by getting more and more efficient in that area
column9: AWS
column10: yes
column11: if you remember last year
column12: we did have price increases in December of last year towards the end. So it had a partial impact on the quarter. But generally
column13: just strong usage growth -- usage growth continues to be strong growing at a higher rate than our revenue growth rate
column14: and customers continued to add workloads and expand. And as I said
column15: we're adding new services and features all the time
column16: over 1
column17: 400 in 2017 alone. So it's a number of factors
column18: I would say. It's not as simple as lapping a cost error -- excuse me
column19: price decrease last year
column20: but we're very happy with the performance in the AWS business. Now over a $20 billion run rate.

column1: Operator: Our next question comes from the line of Mark May with Citi.
Mark May: Brian
column2: if you look back historically
column3: your Q1 operating income guidance is typically about $300 million
column4: $400 million lower than your Q4. Obviously
column5: it's significantly greater than that this quarter. Maybe if you could shed a little light on why that is so and what are some of the key drivers there. And AWS and cloud pricing appears to have been more subtle in the recent quarters. Maybe if you could talk a little bit about the pricing environment and why that has been the case at least compared to trends from back in '14
column7: previously.

column1: Brian Olsavsky: Sure. Let me start with guidance. So yes
column2: the operating income guidance is $300 million to $1 billion. Operating income last year was $1 billion. Q1 is generally when we see the volume drop off from Q4 obviously
column3: but a lot of the cost remain from the year-over-year build up in cost
column4: particularly in the fulfillment network. So it's generally a headwind every Q1. It's -- given the 30% plus growth in square footage last year that we've built
column5: that's 1 major headwind from Q4 to Q1. But we also continue to invest
column6: particularly in Alexa and our device area. As I mentioned in a number of comments earlier
column7: we're very happy with the results
column8: the customer adoption
column9: the device sales that we're seeing and the general customer acceptance there. So we will continue to invest there. That's probably the 2 largest factors in Q1
column10: I would say.

column1: Dave Fildes: This is Dave. Just on the second piece on pricing. I think on the pricing environment
column2: nothing really to call out there. I guess
column3: just a reminder on our pricing philosophy for AWS
column4: I mean periodic price reductions are a normal part of our business where reduced prices more than 60x with AWS since launching. So really
column5: our kind of goal philosophy here is to drive efficiencies in our ops and pass those savings on to customers
column6: and some of that's through
column7: again
column8: with the more than 60 price reductions
column9: but also finding through new service and future launches
column10: better options for customer that -- customers to present more efficient features for them to be able to run their businesses.

column5: to reach new customers. So we're working with advertisers of all types and sizes to help them reach our customer base and the goal of driving brand awareness
column6: discovery and better purchase decisions by the customer.

column1: Operator: At this time
column2: we will now open up the call for questions. Our first question comes from line of Eric Sheridan with UBS. Please proceed with your question.

column1: Eric J. Sheridan: Thanks so much for taking the question. Wanted to ask if you had any update on the state of the advertising business
column2: sort of the state of conversations with advertisers? What product uptake you're seeing out in the marketplace? And sort of how that's looking now as we move out of 2017 and into 2018 broadly for the platform? Thanks so much.

column1: Brian T. Olsavsky: Yes
column2: sure
column3: Eric. I would say advertising continues to be a bright spot both from a product standpoint and also financially. It continued to be a strong contributor to profitability in Q1. It's now a multibillion-dollar program. You can see the – in our supplemental revenue disclosure
column4: it's in other revenue
column5: and it's the majority of the other revenue in that line item. So our philosophy there again is we're continuing to focus on finding valuable ways to make our advertising opportunities better for customers
column6: showing them new products that they may not have seen otherwise and also for emerging and established brands
column7: helping them to reach customers. I think the advertisers generally are all shapes and sizes
column8: and their common theme is they all want to reach our customers generally to drive brand awareness
column9: discovery and eventually purchase. Before I go into the second question
column10: I want to make a comment about the Prime program. The Prime program continues to drive great strength in our top line
column11: as you've seen over the last few years actually. We continue to increase the value of Prime
column12: including speed selection and digital entertainment options. We've been expanding FREE Same-Day Shipping and One-Day options. And our Two-Day shipping
column13: it's now available on over 100 million items
column14: up from 20 million as recently as 2014. And we continue to add digital benefits like Prime Video. The value of Prime to customers has never been greater. And the cost is also high
column15: as we pointed out especially with shipping options and digital benefits
column16: we continue to see rises in costs. So effective May 11
column17: we're going to increase the price of our U.S. annual plan from $99 to $119 for new members. The new price will apply to renewals starting on June 16. Prime provides a unique combination of benefits
column18: and we continue to invest in making this Prime program even more valuable for our members. As a reminder
column19: we haven't increased the U.S. annual price of Prime since our single increase
column20: which was in March of 2014.

column1: Dave Fildes: Yeah. And
column2: Eric
column3: sorry to just go back to your initial question too
column4: just to hop back on that

column10: of course
column11: part of our supplemental sales disclosure. So you'll see that other revenue
column12: in total
column13: increased 132% ex-FX year-over-year to about $2 billion in the first quarter. Again
column14: $560 million is included in there

column17: ex-FX. Beginning in the first quarter
column18: sales of apps
column19: in-app content

column21: rather than that online stores revenue. So in the first quarter

column13: again
column14: we're – we are accelerating. We've accelerated for the last two quarters. The FX-neutral growth was 48% in Q1
column15: up from 44% on the same basis in Q4 and 42% in Q3. And now nearly a $22 billion run rate. So what we're saying is just continued strong usage both by existing customers and signing new customers for – see increased pace of enterprise migrations as customers are having success with AWS and increasingly trying new services. We are seeing people move more and more of their workflows to AWS and at a faster pace. And customers are moving databases to AWS as Aurora continues to grow at a very rapid clip. So stepping back
column16: I would say
column17: what is driving the growth
column18: we believe
column19: again
column20: it's the value that we create for AWS customers. We have the functionality and pace of innovation that others don't. We have partner and ecosystem that others don't. And we have proven operational capability and security expertise that's highly valued to the AWS customer base.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from the line of Mark May with Citi. Please proceed with your question.
Mark A. May: Thank you. Some of the data that we've seen suggests that this year
column2: the rate of growth in the build out of fulfillment centers and other parts of the retail logistics network as well as data centers
column3: but more on the former
column4: that rate of growth is slowing this year relative to last year and even the year before. I know that you guys go through periods of kind of heavy investment
column5: then you grow into that capacity. But I just wonder if you could comment a little bit about where we are kind of in that ebb and flow of that cycle right now. And in terms of the accounting change that Dave referenced earlier with regard to revenue going from cost of revenue to the other line
column6: can you comment if that particular type of advertising
column7: that trade dollars type of marketing
column8: is that growing at a meaningfully different rate than the ad revenue that's already booked as revenue? Thanks.

column1: Dave Fildes: Yeah
column2: Mark
column3: this is Dave. On that second question
column4: we've not commented on the growth rate or given the prior year period
column5: so not much we can say there. As I said
column6: the $560 million
column7: if you were to back that out and look at the sort of pre-existing advertised – or other revenue rather that was included in that line item
column8: we'd be growing about 72%. But again
column9: that's not in relation to the COGS portion.

column1: Brian T. Olsavsky: And on the question on capacity
column2: – excuse me
column3: cap – I'll address it as CapEx and capital leases
column4: we're still seeing strong investment there. If I look at the quarterly trends
column5: you're right
column6: that this quarter was up 33% in isolation versus last year. I look back to last year's first quarter and we grew 82% year-over-year. So it was a particularly heavy quarter
column7: particularly for investment in warehouses. So if I step back on the trailing 12 months though
column8: CapEx
column9: which is predominantly tied to our fulfillment center network
column10: is up 47%. That is above the Amazon fulfilled unit growth rate
column11: but we combined the strength of the FBA program and the space requirements as we get into bigger and bigger products. That's a representative number for that period. On the capital leases
column12: which is a good proxy for the spend to support the AWS business
column13: that's up 49% year-over-year on the trailing 12 months. So again
column14: usage rates continue to exceed the revenue growth rates. Usage rates are strong
column15: but we also have a number of projects underway that seek to increase our efficiency of our data centers. So have a couple things at play there that hopefully keep that number closer to the revenue growth rate.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from the line of Doug Anmuth with JPMorgan. Please proceed with your question.
Douglas T. Anmuth: Thanks for taking the question. Brian
column2: you had significant operating income upside in 1Q and I think a better outlook for the second quarter than many expected. Can you just talk about the biggest factors that drove the delta relative to your 1Q guide? And is there any reason to think that you couldn't see similar leverage in the back half of the year? Thanks.

column1: Brian T. Olsavsky: Sure. Yes
column2: we came in well above our range that we had given of $300 million to $1 billion. I would attribute it primarily to a few things. First
column3: the top-line growth was – continued to be strong coming out of Q4. We had great consumer business strength. We also had strong AWS revenue strength
column4: where I already mentioned that we accelerated into the quarter
column5: which is a different trend that we've seen recently. So customer adoption in AWS remained strong. And when we hit the higher end of our range or just above our range on – with FX included
column6: we generally see really good drop through on the incremental sales
column7: given the fixed costs we have in fulfillment centers and data centers and quite frankly
column8: people. So we saw great efficiencies at the higher level of revenue
column9: and we're able to handle it. So that was generally very good financially. We – at the time of guidance
column10: we were concerned a bit about the high – relatively high inventory we had at year-end in space utilization. So we're still very full in our fulfillment centers. But we were able to correct that due to the high sales without having additional handling and transportation cost that you would normally see the reconfigure inventory locations. So that also helped and probably differential versus the guidance estimate. And then
column11: lastly
column12: I would say
column13: advertising continues to be a strong contributor to profitability and had strong results this quarter. As far as what that portends for future quarters
column14: for now
column15: I want to focus on Q2 and it's incorporated into our Q2 guidance. So we expect a lot of the strength areas to continue
column16: consumer demand
column17: AWS and advertising. We will definitely see higher investments as we move through the year. For example
column18: video content spend will increase year-over-year
column19: and we'll continue to hire
column20: in particular
column21: software engineers. We'll have some costs in Q2 ahead of what's anticipated to be a Prime Day in early Q3. So – and then as you know
column22: Q3 is generally a lower quarter due to all the work to get ready for holiday and the hiring of people and building teams. So
column23: I won't go beyond Q2 at this point
column24: but again
column25: we're very happy with the customer reception we had in Q1 and then the income that
column26: that drove.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from Mark Mahaney with RBC Capital Markets. Please proceed with your question.
Mark Mahaney: Okay. Great. Thanks. Two questions. The $239 million in other income
column2: what was that? And then could you just wax a little bit eloquently hopefully
column3: on advertising revenue? And like how do you balance what are – what should be a monstrous amount of ad revenue opportunities
column4: especially high profit
column5: high margin ad revenue opportunities against an ideal or optimal consumer experience? These sponsored units I see in every search I do on Amazon seems great from an advertising perspective
column6: but I sometimes wonder if it doesn't dilute the consumer experience. So just talk about how you balance that. And then finally
column7: as part of advertising
column8: you've got also a heck of a lot inventory around all of that video
column9: that Prime Video that you have that you don't allow – that you don't directly charge for
column10: how do you think about that as an advertising revenue opportunity? Thank you.

column1: Brian T. Olsavsky: Sure. Let me wax eloquently. Try to anyway. So let's start with the $239 million; that is essentially where attributable to warrants that we have in companies that we partnered with. We have transportation companies that we partnered with and other technology companies. As the stock market increased in Q1
column2: a lot of these companies also went up. So that's where we book the gain on warrants that we have with – on investments. It's also – there was a good bit of FX gain due to the shift in currency and the weakening of the dollar. That showed up on a lot of lines on the P&L
column3: but that one was positive. On advertising
column4: so let's step back a bit. It's now a multibillion-dollar program and growing very quickly. Our main goal here is to help customers discover new brands and products. So we show the sponsored products
column5: we're trying to show people things they had maybe wouldn't have seen otherwise in their normal search results. So we're looking for a good balance here
column6: as we said. We want customers to get the benefit of the new brand and product discovery
column7: and then we want to let sellers for both emerging and established brands
column8: reach those customers. Those advertisers are of all shapes and sizes with the main goal of
column9: again
column10: trying to reach our customers whether it's to drive brand awareness
column11: discovery or hopefully purchase. So
column12: we take the responsibility for that very seriously and are always balancing helpfulness of the advertising and try not to make it disruptive. But you're right
column13: there are always pressures in that. We will come down on the side of the customer. On your question on video advertising
column14: yes
column15: there may be opportunities over time to have more advertising in our Video
column16: but we choose not to do that right now.

column1: Dave Fildes: Yeah
column2: I think the only thing I'd add to on that just related to Prime Video
column3: as you may have seen in the announcement earlier today about the renewed agreement for the streaming partnership with Thursday Night Football. So we'll have 11 games in 2018 and 2019
column4: be able to deliver that to over 100 million Prime members globally
column5: which is a great continuation of the partnership we've had with the NFL. We've done some things like the Prime Original Series All or Nothing; the third season's coming up soon
column6: focused on the Dallas Cowboys. So that was one of our first forays in the live format that – one of the first forays in the live format where we had live ads and kind of
column7: we're not only learning the technology
column8: but learning to – learning that business. And I think we've been pleased with what we've seen so far obviously and look forward to the next few seasons with the NFL.

Justin Post: Yeah
column2: thank you. I'd like to maybe dive into a couple of local recent overhangs. First
column3: on shipping partners
column4: just wondering how dependent are you on any shipping partner? And can you talk about any initiatives you've had to build out your own shipping network? I know in some countries that you might be over 50% of the stuff you're delivering. Could talk a little bit about dependency there? And then secondly
column5: on taxes
column6: can you remind us what happened when Amazon started collecting taxes on your own items in various states? And just kind of overview of your view on collecting third-party sales – taxes from third parties in other states if that were to pass? Thank you.

column1: Brian T. Olsavsky: Sure. Let me start with transportation. We have a great group of carriers that we use globally and you know who they are. But we're also growing our teams and capabilities to ensure that we can keep up with increased volume on our own
column2: particularly around the holiday season. So that's driven a lot of our expansion of Amazon Logistics. It's driven the creation of sort centers. It's driven the purchase of airplanes to move product between points within our delivery network. So we will continue to operate with this combination of external partners and internal capability. We like what we see so far with our Amazon Logistics capability. It's well over 50% in some countries
column3: particularly the UK. It helps with again Prime Now and AmazonFresh and a lot of initiatives that we'll see
column4: which again we mentioned the Prime Now is tied in with Whole Foods
column5: now in 10 cities. So we think it's a core competency that we have and we need to have
column6: and we'll continue to invest in that.

column1: Dave Fildes: Yeah
column2: and Justin
column3: this is Dave
column4: just on the sales tax piece. Today
column5: on the first-party sales
column6: we collect on our own products in all 45 states that have a state-imposed sales tax. On the 3T piece
column7: we do collect on behalf of our sellers in two states
column8: Washington State as of the first of this year
column9: and then Pennsylvania turned on here on April 1. So in terms of your question of sort of impact from the first-party piece that's been coming online
column10: many of those states came on over a period of time to get to that 45 total
column11: going back over many years. So yeah
column12: nothing really more to add on that. I think I would say we do continue to believe that the sales tax issue needs to be resolved at the federal level
column13: and we're actively working with the states
column14: with retailers and Congress to get federal legislation passed. We're not opposed to collecting sales tax within a constitution and permissible system that is both simple and applied evenhandedly.

column3: creation – or excuse me

column11: video content

column17: to 40
column18: 000 [Technical Difficulty] (31:46-31:51). Yes

Mark Mahaney: Okay. Hey
column2: maybe two things. Just a little bit of color on that unit growth
column3: I think
column4: it was 17%
column5: any particular things to call out there as that would have stunted that growth or negatively limited? Or is that just kind of the new

column1: Brian T. Olsavsky: Sure. Let's start with unit growth. So I will note
column2: we did a very strong unit growth rate last year in Q2
column3: with 27%
column4: so we're comping against that. As we look back on that
column5: there were number of factors. I mean
column6: in any quarter there can be product mix or ASP differentials which shift the unit growth figure
column7: but if you also remember
column8: we dropped our Super Saver Shipping threshold twice
column9: the early part of last year from $49 to $35; and then down to $25. So there was a bit of growth
column10: particularly in lower ASP items from that
column11: that we saw last year. So we're comping that. Another factor is digital content that moves to subscription. So Amazon Music and Kindle Unlimited
column12: while they're very successful and it's a good transition
column13: they just – the units do not count in this unit calculation. So there's some things like that
column14: that maybe obfuscate the numbers a bit
column15: but we're really pleased with the retail growth. We think it's driven by again Prime
column16: the Prime program
column17: the engagement of Prime customers as well as increased selection
column18: and particularly third-party selection. On operations

column20: you're going to see a lot of different pace of increase in both infrastructure costs and capital costs
column21: and the addition of fixed cost heads. So one thing that you'll notice is that
column22: we've grown – we've stepped down our rate of growth of fixed head count
column23: excluding the acquisitions we've grown 26% year-over-year at the end of June
column24: on a trailing 12 month basis. But 23% of that was in the second half of last year. So we are continuing to look at where we're investing head count. We're seeing a lot of our growth areas being fueled by head count that's moving within the company. There's a lot of movement of tech head count. And so there was less external hiring in the first half of this year. We don't think that
column25: that's necessarily the long-term trend
column26: but it certainly created a lot of operating efficiencies
column27: and now we'll reset and evaluate where we need to still add people. So I think the first half of the year could be a good test of where our cost structure is
column28: coming off of the investment that leads up to the holiday. Last year
column29: there was a lot of first half investment. If you look back on infrastructure and fixed head count that may be made that less pronounced. But this year it's a little more apparent.
