column5: I think
column6: we're having a lot of success with devices and customers are enjoying those. We talked to coming out of Prime Day
column7: had some good success and happy customers enjoying some of the devices there. So I think
column8: that's a lot of – the focus now is really having a good and exciting roadmap of recent revises and more to come ahead
column9: and getting those into customers' hands.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from the line of Heath Terry with Goldman Sachs. Please proceed with your question.
Heath Terry: Great. Thank you. Just on the AWS point
column2: as you're seeing customers to AWS
column3: you're adding new customers to AWS
column4: can you give us a sense of sort of where you're seeing customers spend focus. How successful – you mentioned database
column5: but what other areas you're potentially seeing as customers move up the stack with you and grow? And then
column6: you flagged the flat capital lease growth on a year-over-year basis. In the past when you've talked about the growth in CapEx and capital lease
column7: you generally referred to trying to grow those numbers or that infrastructure growth overall more or less with the business. Is there some level of efficiency breakthrough that you've gotten there where that's no longer the case? Or is it a function of timing? How should we think about what that CapEx and capital lease spend signals about your expectations for growth?

column1: Brian T. Olsavsky: Sure. I would say it's just a demonstration of the very tight period where we – we've still added a lot
column2: I mean
column3: $4.6 billion is a lot of capital leases
column4: but the rate of growth over last year is flat. So what I would say is
column5: I'm not sure about the breakthrough element of it. We do spend a lot of time driving better efficiency in our data centers. We do see it; sometimes it is higher than other quarters. The starting point for our expectation would be
column6: the usage growth would be very – that our growth in infrastructure costs would start with the growth in usage
column7: which has been exceeding the revenue growth rate. But we can drive more efficiently and we can sometimes bank the efficiencies of prior investments that we've made in other periods. So it will fluctuate quarter-to-quarter. I would say last year in the first half was a pretty large investment area. I'll lump it in with capital expenditures
column8: but in the first two quarters
column9: Q1 of last year
column10: it was 82% growth year-over-year in capital expenditures
column11: Q2 was 67%. This year
column12: those numbers are 33% in Q1
column13: and 1% in Q2. So it's a – there's a bit of timing at play here
column14: but I think overall
column15: in the longer-term
column16: we certainly work to drive efficiency in both AWS infrastructure capability
column17: and also in our warehouse networks. I don't have on the other piece
column18: on product detail
column19: I don't have anything more for you. I would just say that
column20: our growth is coming from customers that span from start-ups to enterprise customers to government agencies
column21: and they start small and then they continue to build and shift their businesses to us
column22: and many of them have gone – a large number have gone all-in on AWS
column23: and have had a chance to lower their cost structures as a result. I'd count Amazon in that category
column24: because on the consumer side of the business
column25: we increasingly see infrastructure savings due to the conversion to AWS resources.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from Brian Nowak with Morgan Stanley. Please proceed with your question.
Brian Nowak: Thanks for taking my questions
column2: I have two. The first one on the ad business
column3: Brian
column4: I was just wondering
column5: could you give us some examples of some products you've had particular success with on the ad side? And I know you guys are always focused on removing customer friction points and solving pain points for customers
column6: maybe talk to us about some of the still existing pain points for your advertiser customers you're looking to address with the advertising product? And the second one
column7: I know it's an accounting question
column8: but we're going to be asked it a lot. On revenue accounting
column9: can you just sort of walk us through any of the accounting changes that any of the revenue lines had in the current quarter because of the multiple accounting moving pieces? Thanks.

column1: Brian T. Olsavsky: Yeah
column2: let me give Dave a chance afterwards to talk about that piece
column3: but I'll start with advertising. So conceptually stepping back
column4: it's now a multi-billion dollar business for us. We're seeing strong adoption across a number of fronts. Amazon vendors
column5: sellers
column6: authors as well as third-party advertisers who want to reach Amazon customers. So we have hundreds of thousands of emerging and established advertisers. And they're using our services to achieve their marketing goals to – whether that's to drive new brand awareness
column7: discovery or ultimately purchase decisions on our site. Pain points and improvements
column8: I would say
column9: our priorities include improving the usability of our tools for advertisers
column10: helping make smarter recommendations for customers. Automating
column11: we're doing a lot of work on automating the activities that the advertisers need to do
column12: and continue to invent new products for those advertisers. We also think measurement is going to be important so we're focused on our measurement capabilities
column13: so advertisers understand what outcomes they're driving on our properties. And we think that we're uniquely positioned to show them the direct benefit of their advertising.

column1: Dave Fildes: Yeah. And Brian
column2: this is Dave. Just on the accounting piece
column3: specifically to Q2
column4: the impact of the Accounting Standards Update
column5: revenue recognition changes we did starting in the first part of year
column6: it's a $640 million increase to other revenue
column7: specifically related to how we treat some of the advertising service. So you remember as part of the adoption beginning in 2018
column8: certainly the advertising services were classified as revenue rather than cost of sales. So $640 million more is in other revenue this second quarter. You'd see that in that line item
column9: which is about $2.2 billion here in the second quarter. In addition to that
column10: some of the other factors I talked about last quarter
column11: some of the treatment of gross to net changes in some sales of apps and app content
column12: digital media costs
column13: some of that shift created a headwind for online stores revenue. So that year-over-year growth rate for that line item would have been higher
column14: but for that change.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from Eric Sheridan with UBS. Please proceed with your question.
Eric J. Sheridan: Thanks so much. Two questions if I can. On Whole Foods
column2: any update on the integration of Whole Foods within the broader Prime ecosystem
column3: the way in which you're tying those assets and customer bases together to sort of promote the flywheel that you've talked about a fair bit? And Prime Now
column4: any update on the scale of markets globally
column5: and what you're learning as Prime Now continues to scale in terms of how users adopt the service
column6: putting SKUs closer to prem what that does to the velocity of purchasing? Thank you so much.

column1: Brian T. Olsavsky: Sure. So
column2: it was a big quarter for Whole Foods and Prime. We launched additional savings for Prime members at Whole Foods. If you go to Whole Foods store or Whole Foods Market 365 store
column3: you see a lot of yellow stickers for 10% discounts of hundreds of sale items. You also see deep discounts on selected popular products. So Prime members have adopted this benefit
column4: it's one of the fastest rates we've ever seen for a Prime benefit
column5: and they've already saved millions of dollars on everything from seasonal favorites to as I said popular daily sales. So in addition
column6: we've expanded grocery delivery to 20 cities so that's picking up steam. During the Prime Day
column7: we had some unique deals for Prime customers at Whole Foods. Actually
column8: the deals lasted for a week at Whole Foods. And people had
column9: again the ability to see the benefit that Prime membership save incremental dollars
column10: because of it at Whole Foods. And the Prime Rewards Visa Card
column11: which gives you 5% off on all purchases has been applied to Whole Foods' purchases as well. So that is the second wave
column12: probably after the first wave where we talked in previous calls about initial price drops
column13: putting lockers in the stores
column14: selling some of the Whole Foods' products on the Amazon site
column15: and other things. So the invention level is still really high. We think it's a big milestone this quarter to launch Prime benefits with Whole Foods
column16: and we'll keep going
column17: we'll see how that develops. Prime Now
column18: I guess
column19: my comments are that
column20: it's in 50 cities worldwide
column21: it's across 9 countries. It is different than – we have multiple options for you in grocery delivery. We have the delivery services – so AmazonFresh and Prime Now which serve a certain need. We have a traditional grocery store now with Whole Foods
column22: and then we have the combination of those two with home delivery
column23: and we're using Prime Now or Whole Foods products through Prime Now to make those deliveries as well as the new kind of stores with Amazon Go that we're experimenting with. So lots of innovation
column24: invention on that front as well.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from Ross Sandler with Barclays. Please proceed with your question.
Ross Sandler: Good evening. Hey guys
column2: I had two questions. First is on the Music business. So I think
column3: you said recently you had tens of millions of paying subscribers. So are those paying music listeners coming from Prime
column4: and using the mobile app
column5: or they coming in from Echo? Any color on what's driving that uptake and converting users into paid members? Then the second question is
column6: you mentioned efficiency gains in retail and the improvement in retail operating margin. If we look at International
column7: it's still negative
column8: but it's also improving pretty meaningfully
column9: so can you parse where that improvement's coming from between India and the other emerging markets versus some of the more mature markets in Western Europe?

column1: Brian T. Olsavsky: Sure
column2: let me start with that second question. So
column3: yes
column4: we have seen over the last few quarters
column5: improved operating margins internationally. I would say in places like Europe and Japan
column6: we're seeing many of the efficiencies I talked about earlier on fixed head count
column7: operations costs
column8: infrastructure costs
column9: and also things like marketing working to be very efficient. I would also say that
column10: although it's smaller internationally the impact of advertising is starting to show up more and more internationally. It's growing quite quickly just as it is in North America. But you're right. We continue to invest. We're investing in India obviously
column11: and have seen good traction there. We just passed our Fifth Year Anniversary – celebrated our Fifth Year Anniversary
column12: as the most visited site in India. So we think there's a lot of great innovation that has continued to occur for Indian consumers and sellers
column13: and that will continue. But you're also seeing additional expansion. So we launched Prime in Australia; we're rolling devices out. We launched Echo and Alexa in France. The Echo Spot in India and Japan
column14: and we announced that we're going to expand Echo and Alexa soon to Italy
column15: Mexico and Spain. So I would say that we're continuing to frontload Prime benefits in the newer geographies. So that's one of the issues that we see with operating margin. But we think it's the right thing to do. We are seeing strong traction in that front as well. We also like that the – on Prime Day
column16: we were able to expand our list of countries that experience Prime Day; this year to Australia
column17: Singapore
column18: the Netherlands and Luxembourg. So we're very bullish on our International business. We do realize it's a period of investment and we're in different stages of growth in different countries.

column1: Dave Fildes: Yeah
column2: and this is Dave. Just quickly on Music
column3: as you mentioned
column4: tens of millions of paid customers are enjoying Amazon Music. When you look at the Amazon Music Unlimited subscription
column5: it continues to grow very quickly. We've got those offerings in more than 30 countries now and the catalog there's tens of millions of songs
column6: and a lot of rich playlists
column7: personalized stations
column8: those kinds of things. Of course we started in Music with Prime Music
column9: a little bit earlier in that space
column10: and I think that's been a great way for Prime members to enjoy some of that catalog for free
column11: and then as they enjoy that
column12: be able to move into the Amazon Music Unlimited skill. One of the great things that's also part of that
column13: I think
column14: you alluded to it is just Alexa
column15: and one of the most popular features we see as you probably imagine for using those devices are just interacting with Alexa
column16: wherever you may be is being able to listen to music. So that's proven to be a
column17: I think
column18: a good skill for folks to be able to enjoy in addition to a really kind of rich and growing Amazon skill set. We now have more than 45
column19: 000 skills available to customers.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from Youssef Squali with SunTrust Robinson Humphrey. Please proceed with your question.
Youssef Squali: Thank you very much. On the new Supreme Court decision
column2: you guys have been collecting state taxes in all 45 states where it's applicable for a 1P. And for a 3P
column3: I think
column4: it was in two states. Have you seen any slowdown to growth in these two states since you began collecting taxes? I think
column5: you started maybe last 12 months or so. When will you start collecting taxes in the rest of the country
column6: and will you charge for it? Because my understanding is that
column7: in those two states you do not collect or you do not charge to help these 3P sellers file taxes or collect state taxes. Thank you.

column1: Dave Fildes: Yeah. Hey
column2: Youssef this is Dave. So right now
column3: as you mentioned 45 states that have state-imposed sales tax
column4: first-party products we do our own collection on that. For 3P sellers right now
column5: it's three states. So Washington State started as of January 1
column6: Pennsylvania as of April 1
column7: and most recently Oklahoma on July 1. So those are the ones where we're collecting and remitting. We haven't said – and to your second point we've not talked about any kind of trends. As you could imagine some of these are still really early days.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our final question comes from Jason Helfstein with Oppenheimer & Company. Please proceed with your question.
Jason Helfstein: Thanks. Given the focus in the press release about Alexa Voice Services
column2: any thoughts about how you would monetize on third-party devices? And then just a follow up on Amazon Prime Video Channels
column3: any plans to offer standard skinny bundles to become a cable replacement? Thanks.

column1: Brian T. Olsavsky: Yeah
column2: let me start with Alexa. So right now
column3: our emphasis is around expanding the reach of Alexa and the usefulness. So as Dave mentioned
column4: we're now up over 45
column5: 000 skills. We have a developer network of – that's expanded and we have over 13
column6: 000 smart home devices from 2
column7: 500 unique brands. You're seeing things like expansion into the hotel space where we're partnering with hotels to allow you to experience Alexa while you're traveling. And you saw from the quote that was in our press release from Jeff
column8: the number of Alexa-enabled devices has tripled in the past year
column9: so – including some really large companies like Polk
column10: Sonos
column11: Acer
column12: Hewlett-Packard
column13: Lenovo
column14: BMW
column15: Ford
column16: Toyota to name a few. So that's the biggest emphasis
column17: is getting the expansion of Alexa to places where it can be useful. We also are developing new machine learning tools to help developers more easily build Alexa skills. We feel like we're getting great traction there. So I think your original question was about monetization of Alexa
column18: but right now the biggest thing we can do is to make it as useful as possible
column19: and make devices that can use the skills.

column1: Dave Fildes: Yeah
column2: and then just on the second question. I mean
column3: I can't speculate on what we might do in the future
column4: but I'd say today
column5: with Prime Channels
column6: I think
column7: we're really pleased with the growth we're seeing. We've seen some good channels come online over the last few quarters
column8: and seen some good traction there. So we'll keep focusing on building out even better selection
column9: because it's clear to us that customers want that option to be able to add that content as part of their Prime memberships.

column1: Dave Fildes: Thanks for joining us today on the call and for your questions. A replay will be available on our Investor Relations website at least through the end of the quarter. We appreciate your interest in Amazon
column2: and look forward to talking with you again next quarter.";[-0.20219175018307878

column1: Operator: At this time
column2: we will now open the call up for questions. Thank you. Our first question comes from the line of Justin Post with Merrill Lynch. Please proceed.

column1: Justin Post: Great. Thank you for taking my question. I guess the big one is the deceleration in unit growth or online stores
column2: which are probably related to that. I know it's a tough 3Q comp
column3: but could you comment a little bit about that? And then kind of what initiatives could be most interesting to maybe reaccelerate that over the next couple of years? What categories? Thank you.

column1: Brian T. Olsavsky: Thank you
column2: Justin. Yeah
column3: let me just remind you a couple of things from last year. We had two reactions on our Super Saver Shipping threshold in the first half of the year between February and May. That did spur a lot of unit growth in the second and third quarter. We also have issue with digital content
column4: not an issue
column5: but the fact that digital content is moving to subscriptions
column6: Amazon Music Unlimited and Kindle Unlimited in particular. It's been really popular. I'll just remind you that the units – those do not count in our unit totals nor do the units from Whole Foods Market. So
column7: yeah
column8: I would say essentially with that backdrop
column9: we're still very
column10: very encouraged by the demand and the reception from customers on the consumer side. We have Amazon fulfilled units are still growing faster than paid units. 3P is now up to 53% of total paid units. In-stock is very strong
column11: especially as we head into the holiday period. I think we're well positioned for the holiday. We have over 100 million Prime eligible items that are available for FREE Two-Day Shipping for Prime members. And again
column12: when we're talking about the unit deceleration
column13: a lot of the fastest growing areas
column14: things like subscription services
column15: AWS and advertising are not caught in that metric.

column1: Dave Fildes: And
column2: Justin
column3: this is Dave. Just to add on to that. You mentioned the online stores. Just a reminder
column4: there is a little bit of impact from the revenue recognition. So you see the online stores revenue growing about 11% ex-FX
column5: to be higher than that
column6: but for the adoption ad standard. So there's a little bit of a headwind there as well.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from line of Mark Mahaney with RBC Capital Markets. Please proceed.
Mark Mahaney: Okay. I was going to also then ask you to drill down a little bit on the international retail business. That seemed to slow down
column2: I guess that whatever
column3: 15% or something year-over-year. Any particularly color? Any markets that would have led to that? Though the comp was tougher
column4: but anything else you'd call out there? Thanks a lot.

column1: Brian T. Olsavsky: Sure. On a year-over-year basis
column2: I think you have to look at two things. We did the Souq acquisition last year in May. So the full pickup on that year-over-year was in 2017 and now we're lapping that. There's also material change in the Diwali calendar in India. About half of our Diwali sales last year were in Q3. This year they'll be fully in Q4. So those are a couple factors that hit the international growth area in particularly. But I also point out that we launched Turkey in the quarter and now we have 17 Amazon websites globally. So we're still very pleased again with the international business
column3: continue to invest in Prime benefits
column4: international expansion as I just mentioned
column5: and we're still seeing very good pickup. Story is different country-by-country obviously. Some are much further along than others
column6: but overall we're very happy. India
column7: although Diwali moved into Q4
column8: so far that's going really well. We've seen great response from customers. We've had 60% growth in new customers during the period. Orders are coming in from 99% of the pin codes in the country. So
column9: great first wave of the
column10: what we call the Amazon's Great Indian Festival
column11: which lead into Diwali.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from line of Douglas Anmuth with JPMorgan. Please proceed.

Douglas T. Anmuth: Thanks for taking the question. You had significant operating income upside in 3Q relative to your guide. Can you just talk about the biggest drivers there in terms of outperformance? And then when you think about your 4Q outlook
column2: how should we think about the minimum wage increase that you've talked about? And then any other one-time or special items that might be weighing on that operating income outlook? Thanks.

column1: Brian T. Olsavsky: Sure. Let me start with Q3 and this will be commentary pretty much on the whole year that was especially true in Q4. So
column2: first of all
column3: we've had very strong growth in some very profitable businesses that we have
column4: most notably AWS and advertising. But we've also had great cost performance this year in three specific areas I'll call out. So
column5: first on head count. If you'll remember
column6: we grew head count 48% in 2016 and 38% last year
column7: if you adjust for Whole Foods. With Whole Foods
column8: it was 66%
column9: but without Whole Foods we still grew 38%. We have looked to really leverage our investment from the last couple years and as we've funded and moved
column10: invested in a lot of new areas as we've talked about
column11: AWS
column12: devices
column13: digital content
column14: we've had a lot of movement within the company that has filled a lot of those roles. So we're only up 13% on head count through nine months year-over-year. So a real step down in that. Again
column15: the theme here is going to be banking some of the investments from prior years and looking to gain greater control. In our fulfillment center world
column16: we had grown square footage for our fulfillment center and shipping areas by over 30% the last two years
column17: 2016 and 2017. I've talked about that in prior calls. Making that investment to match up with very strong Fulfilled by Amazon demand and AFN or Amazon Fulfilled Network units that are growing at a faster rate than our paid units. This year we're only adding about 15% to our square footage. So again
column18: getting better efficiencies on what we have and banking the multi-year investment that we've been making. And the last one
column19: which is really significant
column20: is on the infrastructure side. You see the operating margin for AWS is up to 31% this quarter. A lot of that is based on efficiencies of our data centers
column21: not only for the AWS business
column22: they're also for our Amazon consumer businesses
column23: who is AWS' biggest customer. If you look at capital leases
column24: which is where we spend money for the data centers
column25: it's up only 9% year-over-year
column26: trailing 12 months
column27: and it was up 69% last year
column28: at the end of the year. So those three areas have driven a lot of the cost performance and a lot of the deviation from probably the estimates that I've come up with this year. So we are really happy that again we're seeing great cost performance in a number of areas across the business.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from the line of Mark May with Citi. Please proceed.
Mark A. May: Thank you. Question on AWS. Obviously in the last few quarters
column2: you've seen accelerating revenue growth. This quarter
column4: still quite strong
column5: but dollar and percentage growth did slow. I'm just kind of curious are you just reaching a point in terms of a lot of large numbers where it will be more difficult to sustain not only accelerating growth
column6: but sustain kind of the 40-plus-percent growth levels where we've been recently? Or was there something also going on kind of in the quarter that maybe drove that? Thanks.

column1: Brian T. Olsavsky: Yeah
column2: thanks for your question. This growth rate is going to bounce around. We've had sequential increase in growth rate the prior three quarters
column3: I believe
column4: it was. This quarter is slightly down
column5: but still 46% growth is very strong. We are at an annualized run rate above $26 billion and that was about $18 billion this time last year. So we're very happy with the growth in the business
column6: the momentum that we're seeing with enterprise customers. And we just mentioned on the cost side
column7: it's been a very good year from gaining greater efficiencies in our infrastructure costs.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from line of Brian Nowak with Morgan Stanley. Please proceed.
Brian Nowak: Thanks for taking my questions. I have two. The first one
column2: the fourth quarter revenue guide and the fourth quarter revenue deceleration. Maybe can you just help us understand a little bit any of the specific categories or countries that have been the largest contributors to revenue growth throughout the course of this year? And which of those are really slowing down sort of driving this potential deceleration that you're guiding to? Then the second one
column3: you've applied robotics to the warehouses now around Kiva. Curious for your thoughts about the need or desire to invest in autonomous driving technologies to think about some of the other retailers partnering with Waymo and other players
column4: et cetera.

column1: Brian T. Olsavsky: Sure. Let me talk about guidance. So our guidance for the fourth quarter implies 10% to 20% growth and includes an 80-basis point unfavorable impact from foreign exchange. I wouldn't point to any specific country. Once you adjust for the fact that Whole Foods
column2: it was purchased in August of last year and that has impacted every quarter since then
column3: Q4 will be the first solid non-Whole Foods comp since before we bought them since Q2 of last year. So if you
column4: even factoring that
column5: and we're looking at Q4 and we have very high error bars on the quarter. Much of our
column6: not only our revenue for the quarter
column7: but also for the year comes in that very tight window between middle of November and the end of the year. So it's always a very difficult period for us to estimate. What I would say is that we feel like we're in great shape for the holiday. The warehouses are very clean. We feel like we're going to have great capacity not only for retail products but also for FBA. We're going to have great capacity for shipping to our customers. So we're very ready to go. Selection should be at its highest point
column8: especially for Prime members. So we're very bullish on the fourth quarter. And we'll just have to see how revenue comes in. I will say there's one housekeeping item on Prime revenue recognition that you should be aware of and may remember from prior quarters. This year
column9: we took Prime subscription revenue and amortized it over the quarters on a straight line method. Previously
column10: we had done it on a
column11: is tilted more to Q4. It's based more on shipping units. So what you've seen is a push of revenue and income from Q4 into Q1
column12: 2 and 3 that we've mentioned on each call. This is the quarter where that will reverse. That is to scale it for you. Under the old methodology we would have had $300 million more of both revenue and operating income in the quarter. That has again been caught up for in prior quarters
column13: but again not a huge factor on the growth rate for revenue
column14: but just another item to consider. On the Robotics
column15: I don't have much to say on autonomous driving. We are putting most of our efforts right now
column16: continue to into our Robotics program. We think it's been a great addition to our fulfillment capacity. It makes the jobs in our warehouse that much better. It makes the people around the robots that much more productive. It allows us to have much greater density of product storage and a number of other benefits. It has some additional capital intensity
column17: but it has good return on invested capital from our standpoint.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from the line of Eric Sheridan with UBS. Please proceed.
Eric J. Sheridan: Thanks for taking the question. With a lot of offline retailers talking more about omni-channel
column2: wanted to understand sort of the investments you might be making around unifying the efforts with Whole Foods and Amazon Prime Now
column3: speeding up delivery
column4: giving consumers as much choice as possible and moving SKUs closer to households. How should we be thinking about that push in 2019 and 2020 and how that might open up new areas of wallet share for the company? Thanks guys.

column1: Brian T. Olsavsky: Sure. Yeah
column2: I think we've started to show our strategy on the Whole Foods side. You'll see even this quarter we started to have greater expansion of our grocery delivery out of Whole Foods using Prime Now. We're now in 60 cities in the U.S.
column3: giving customers delivery in as fast as an hour on thousands of great organic products from Whole Foods. We've also expanded grocery pickup and that's available in 10 cities. So the customers can pick up at the Whole Foods store. You'll see that we've started to tie Whole Foods into Alexa. You can build your cart using Alexa and then check out using the Prime Now app. So there's going to be a lot of
column4: as you say
column5: omni-channel overlap
column6: especially in the grocery business. On the storefront
column7: we're also
column8: as you can see
column9: experimenting with numerous store formats. Amazon Go is now up to six stores. We opened five in the quarter. We're getting great feedback on that. Customers love the ability to quickly walk in
column10: select items they want and leave without waiting in a checkout line. We opened up a Amazon four-star location in New York City where we're going to test the concept of a highly curated selection of top categories across Amazon. We of course have Amazon bookstores
column11: 18 bookstores in the U.S. So we're going to experiment with multiple ways of reaching the customer
column12: wherever they happen to be.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from line of Ross Sandler with Barclays. Please proceed.
Ross Sandler: Great. I guess two questions. Any color on
column2: it looks like shipping costs and maybe labor costs might see some inflation in 2019. So do you agree with that? Or what are some of the things you can do to potentially offset some of that pressure? And then
column3: the 15% fulfillment square-footage growth
column4: you're obviously deploying a lot of automation and there's a lot more efficiency gains in the current generation of fulfillment centers than maybe the older ones. So how should we think about a 15%? Is that not a good reading indicator on growth into 2019? Or is it – any color there would be helpful. Thanks.

column1: Brian T. Olsavsky: Sure. I think it's comparable to – last question first. I think the 15% is comparable to the 30%-plus that I mentioned in 2016 and 2017. We are debating whether the dynamics of the warehouse are changing so that square footage may not be the main indicator
column2: might be cubic feet
column3: but if we switch to that way of looking at it
column4: we'll make sure that we bridge the gap on the difference between the two. But the other comment about cost
column5: I believe you're probably referring to the U.S. rumored USPS rate hikes in transportation cost. We're not expecting a material impact from these rate changes in 2019. Annual rate increases from our transportation partners is a really regular occurrence and we negotiate hard and we'll always work hard internally to get even more efficient on our own shipping method. So
column6: we don't see that as being a huge issue. On wages
column7: of course
column8: we did raise wages and starting November 1 just under 400
column9: 000 employees
column10: both full-time and part-time in the U.S. and UK will be getting a substantial wage increase. So that is factored – I'm not quantifying that today
column11: but it's factored into our Q4 guidance and it will be obviously factored into guidance into 2019.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from the line of Youssef Squali with SunTrust Robinson Humphrey. Please proceed.
Youssef Squali: Great. Thank you very much. Two quick questions. First
column2: can you quantify the contribution of PillPack acquisition in the quarter? Maybe help us understand the strategy there. And then there is some news
column3: reports suggesting that you guys were working on an ad supported video streaming service under the IMDb brand. Can you just help shed any more light on that
column4: is that especially relative to your Prime Video offering? Thank you very much.

column1: Brian T. Olsavsky: Let me start with PillPack. The deal closed in September. So it wasn't a material impact on the quarter
column2: but we're excited
column3: really excited to start working with the management team there. They're very strong. They've done a great job building a highly differentiated customer experience
column4: just customer-centric like we are. And right now our focus is on learning from them and innovating with them on how best to meet customer needs over time. I'll let Dave handle the second question.

column1: Dave Fildes: Yeah. I think
column2: I mean
column3: we have no plans to build an ad-supported Prime Video offering for free at this time.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from the line of Jason Helfstein with Oppenheimer & Company. Please proceed.
Jason Helfstein: Thanks. Two questions. First
column2: I think I may have missed earlier. You gave out the impact of ASC 606. And then maybe second question
column3: I think what one of the things people are trying to think through is you obviously guide to revenue and operating income
column4: but as the business is more than 3P and advertising
column5: gross profit is now much more important and just the way you kind of capture the value you provide. So maybe if you can – is there a way to just kind of help us kind of foot the perhaps slower revenue growth we're seeing versus what's obviously you extracting kind of more value for your partners and customers and for yourself? Thanks.

column1: Dave Fildes: Yeah. Thanks
column2: Jason. This is Dave. Just quickly on the ASC impact
column3: Brian mentioned earlier that of course we've been talking about it all year the changing
column4: and the subscription revenue recognition is now straight line. So on a comp basis you'd expect to see subscription revenue be about $300 million lower due to that accounting change. The other piece that we hadn't talked about is the reclass that we gave in the past few quarters
column5: specifically around the advertising services that have moved from Contra COGS into other revenue beginning in 2018. That was about $750 million increase to that other sales revenue category here in the third quarter.

column1: Brian T. Olsavsky: Yeah. And your comment on revenue versus operating income versus potentially gross profit
column2: I would say the impact of third-party growth and we're now – up to 53% of our paid units in the quarter were third-party. It's steadily been going up. It's up 300 basis points year-over-year. So I think the impact on revenue growth rate
column3: since the revenue component of that is not as large
column4: is probably something to consider on a year-over-year period. I think it tends to not be as big a factor
column5: sequentially quarter-over-quarter is the gradual growth in it. But again
column6: we'll continue to give revenue guidance and also operating income to an appropriately conservative level that we've tried to maintain over time.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from the line of Anthony DiClemente with Evercore ISI. Please proceed.

Anthony DiClemente: Thanks very much. Just wanted to dig in a little bit on advertising and the growth opportunity there. If you can help us on the potential for higher ad pricing in terms of the ROI for your marketers hopefully being reflected in higher price per ad. And then what about the ad load? So are we kind of close to being at a full ad load? Is there a long runway there? Just trying to get a sense for pricing and volume underneath advertising. And then also along the lines of advertising
column2: heading into the holiday season
column3: should we expect any increase in your efforts around Alexa commercialization
column4: voice keyword ads let's say
column5: and does that fit into your broader advertising growth strategy? Thanks.

column1: Brian T. Olsavsky: Yeah
column2: let me talk a little bit more broadly about advertising. So yeah
column3: we are seeing really strong adoption across a number of groups
column4: Amazon vendors and sellers for sure
column5: authors
column6: as well as third-party advertisers who want to reach Amazon customers. As far as penetration
column7: we don't have that quantified for you
column8: but we still believe that there is a lot of room to continue to improve the presentation of and bringing to our customers new and more relevant purchase options. So we're continuing to invent both on the product side
column9: the tools side with our goal being improve the usability of the tools for advertisers
column10: make smarter recommendations for customers
column11: automate activities so that advertisers don't have to work as hard
column12: and invent new products for advertisers. If we do this right
column13: we think we'll both help advertisers and help Amazon consumers at the same time. So I know it doesn't answer the question about specific rate increases or capacity
column14: but that is the general strategy that we're seeing in advertising.

column1: Dave Fildes: Yeah
column2: and this is Dave. Just jumping on the Alexa point
column3: I mean
column4: I think the short answer is we don't have any plans to add paid advertising to Alexa. I think we clearly had a lot of exciting things happen in the last month or two in terms of new announcements in devices out there. And I mean really looking at that
column5: the goal is to make customers' lives easier and make it more convenient and a lot of that is you're seeing that in the homes and to some extent on the Go. So I think if you look at the recent announcements
column6: you're seeing a few things. I mean
column7: one
column8: we're bringing a lot of cool hardware options to customers. Second thing
column9: I mean
column10: making the Alexa service smarter. It's getting smarter and more capable. And then also delivering tools for developers
column11: helping them build for and really with Alexa. So I think making her smarter and seeing that she gets smarter with all the skills
column12: leveraging the cloud and AI
column13: becoming more knowledgeable and introducing a lot of really new cool new features. So really excited about the customer response with those devices and those tools so far and looking forward to doing even more.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from the line of Lloyd Walmsley with Deutsche Bank. Please proceed.
Lloyd Walmsley: Thanks. Wanted to just follow up on the advertising side and get a sense for how much you guys feel like you're demand constrained versus supply constrained
column2: either in the ability to put more ads on your property and/or just provide the tools to advertisers and do you feel like there's more demand than you can satisfy? Any color you can share there?

column1: Dave Fildes: Hey
column2: this is Dave. I mean nothing specific. I mean I think so much of what we're focused on is making sure that there's a high degree of relevancy and usefulness for customers when you look at advertisements that you see on the site in particular and how we position those. And so we spent a lot of time looking at the data to make sure that customer behavior and feedback is telling us that it's useful and helpful and customers making those purchase decisions. And so
column3: we're always testing different levels of that and trying to understand
column4: and the various features
column5: whether it's display or some of the sponsored elements that are out there
column6: what kind of feedback is out there
column7: but certainly keep that in mind as we roll out new things.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our final question will come from the line of Colin Sebastian with Baird. Please proceed.
Colin Alan Sebastian: Great. Thanks. I guess two quick ones. Any change in the trajectory of Prime membership growth since the June price increase? And then
column2: how would you describe the pricing environments for the core AWS services? And is this still a key lever that you use for business development? Thank you.

column1: Brian T. Olsavsky: Yeah. Sure. Let me start with the Amazon Prime price increase. Of course
column2: that went into effect earlier the year in May. We're very pleased with the renewal data and annual sign up data that we've seen. Since then
column3: program remains very strong
column4: both in membership and engagement
column5: and a lot of our video content
column6: music and shipping definitely as well as other Prime Benefits. We just continue to see that ramp up
column7: not only in the U.S.
column8: but in other countries. So we do continue to make the Prime offer better as well. I mentioned earlier the linkage with Prime member savings at Whole Foods market that we set up in Q2
column9: the expansion of grocery delivery to more than 60 cities in the U.S. using Prime Now and Whole Foods stores
column10: the ability to pick up groceries from Whole Foods. Adding content
column11: we have a great slate of content coming out in the fourth quarter here. Hopefully
column12: you've seen already Jack Ryan and The Romanoffs and pretty soon you'll see the follow-up season to The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel and also a couple other things
column13: and hopefully you'll see Thursday Night Football tonight when you get home.

column1: Dave Fildes: This is Dave. Just on the AWS pricing philosophy. I mean
column2: just a reminder. When we look at this
column3: our pricing philosophy has worked relentlessly
column4: take cost out of our own cost structure and where we can pass savings on to the web services customers in the form of lower prices. So it's easy to lower prices
column5: but it's much harder to be able to afford the lower prices and that's something we work very hard in all our businesses
column6: including AWS to do that. So when you look at AWS now
column7: we've lowered prices 67 times since we launched
column8: including a few more in the last few months. So those pre-OC price reductions are a normal part of our business for us.

column1: Dave Fildes: (30:42) call today and for your questions. A replay will be available on our IR website
column2: at least through the end of the quarter. We appreciate your interest in Amazon.com
column3: and look forward to talking with you again next quarter.";[0.14431709005232074

column3: just

column14: planning

Mark Mahaney: Thanks. Just comment a little bit on the international revenue outlook and any commentary on India and whether you think there's a material impact on your business? Secondly

column4: however

column6: we will
column7: but we're evaluating the situation. Our main issue and our main concern is trying to minimize the impact to our customers and sellers in India. We've built our business around price selection and convenience. We don't think the changes help in those dimensions for both the customers in India and also the sellers. Dave
column8: why don’t you talk about the advertising growth?

column1: Dave Fildes: Yeah
column2: yeah. I think I mean

column6: placements

column10: I think
column11: make it easier for companies to grow with the ad tools and the ad services that we offer and we're continually excited about the opportunity there.

column6: device areas
column7: AWS
column8: especially sales and marketing. So variable marketing was pretty consistent with prior periods and we feel good about our return on investment on the marketing
column9: the variable marketing.

Doug Anmuth: Great. Thank you. I just wanted to follow up on India
column2: just bigger picture
column3: Brian
column4: do the new policies change your view at all of the attractiveness or the potential of operating in India and how do you think about your investment strategy there in the near term? And then also just hoping you could talk about some of the impact in the US and UK from free shipping during the fourth quarter holidays?

column1: Brian Olsavsky: Yeah. Really
column2: we're still evaluating the situation in India. We feel very good about the long term prospects in India and doing a good job for both Indian customers and Indian sellers. The new regulations need to be interpreted
column3: need to be -- need to make sure they don't have unintended consequences. And again
column4: I don't think it's necessarily consistent with better price
column5: better selection and better convenience for the Indian customer. So it's not all we can say on that topic right now.

column1: Dave Fildes: Yeah. And I think Doug

column6: both from sort of a first party side
column7: but also sellers continuing to do well. As part of the holiday offering
column8: we sold a number of record breaking number of Alexa devices as well and I think just in that shipping vein
column9: really pleased with the continued engagement from Prime members
column10: we had the most ever number of Prime members sign up this quarter than any quarter we've had. So really pleased with that.

Mark May: Thank you. When I try to back out the impact factors like Whole Foods
column2: the advertising accounting change and other factors
column3: what I see is stable and pretty healthy revenue growth for the retail segment
column4: but a slowdown in Q4 from what seems to have been

column9: do you see these factors persisting this year? Thanks.

column1: Dave Fildes: Yeah. Thank you. Let me start with that last part
column2: because I think if we step back and put 2018 in perspective
column3: there are some clear trends regarding our cost structure. Starting with fulfillment costs
column4: so in the prior two years
column6: and 2017
column7: we had grown our square footage tied to fulfilment and shipping by greater than 30%. In 2018
column8: that number grew by 15%. Certainly
column9: unit demand was lower
column10: but AFN or Amazon Fulfilled demand were
column11: we’ve combined FBA and retail
column12: remained strong. So we had a banking
column13: if you will
column14: of some large expansions in the prior two years. Similarly on headcount
column15: we grew headcount by 48% in 2016
column17: if you exclude the acquisitions of Whole Foods and Souq
column18: which drove the number up to closer to 68% I believe. Last year
column19: we were at 14% growth. And so
column20: there was a lot of leverage and a lot of
column21: in a way
column22: there was a lot of pre hiring in 2017 that we digested in 2018
column23: while we still continue
column24: in some areas

column31: that number grew 10% last year

column36: we certainly do take costs seriously and we will continue to work on operational efficiencies. I would expect these investments to increase relative to 2018 and we've reflected what we see so far in Q1 in our guidance.

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from the line of Heath Terry with Goldman Sachs.
Heath Terry: Great. Thank you. A little bit -- to dig a little bit deeper into the CapEx capital lease side of things

column1: Brian Olsavsky: Yeah. I see total CapEx that was -- grew 33% in Q1
column2: 1% in Q2
column3: negative 1% in Q3 and then positive 17% in Q4
column4: just the quarter itself. So there was
column5: as you say

column7: when you talk about the -- supporting the AWS business that's still growing in a very high clip and a very strong and healthy growth in FBA and customer demand and our expansion into new countries
column8: both with AWS and also with our core consumer business. So I am not prepared to give you the forecast for the year right now. I would say that

column3: gross margins were well up 180 basis points year-over-year

column7: I would say
column8: were outbound shipping cost
column9: including the free shipping that we did
column10: but mostly

column12: as I think Dave mentioned

column15: expanding our device and usage. There are a group of customers who use our devices and then we monetize that in different ways to commitment to Amazon and the video and everything else. So a bit of it was mix

column17: which has a lower gross margin more because of the revenue treatment was stronger in Q4.

column2: Brian
column3: just to get back to the accounting side. We did adopt that revenue recognition standard in 2018 as I mentioned. As part of the adoption

column6: so you will see that in the other revenue in total.

Colin Sebastian: Thanks. I guess two for me as well. In the quarter
column2: looking backwards
column3: not considering India and the impact going forward
column4: but the international growth accelerated
column5: so I was curious any particular regions or product categories to call out

column8: health and beauty
column9: curious what the strategy is there
column10: I assume to expand selection
column11: but is it also an indication of an increasing focus on those retail categories? Thanks.

column3: the -- more than half of our units sold are from third party sellers. So it's very important to us that we have the right business profile
column4: both for Amazon and for the sellers. So we will always be evolving that
column5: part of that involves changing fee structures
column6: sometimes
column7: adding new fees or subtracting old ones

column9: on an FX neutral basis
column10: the growth was 15% in Q3 and 19% in Q4. But last call
column11: if you remember
column12: I talked about the timing of Diwali and the impact that had on our growth rates. If we adjust for that and again Diwali had
column13: took place primarily in Q4 this year and it was split between Q3 and Q4 last year. If we adjust for that

column1: Operator: Thank you. Our next question comes from the line of Lloyd Walmsley with Deutsche Bank.
Lloyd Walmsley: Thanks. Two if I can. First
column2: just on the advertising side

column13: so
column14: but even as we look for advertising opportunities on places like Amazon.com

column1: Dave Fildes: Yeah. And on transportation

column13: mostly the year-over-year accounting days

column8: we do continue to expand our Amazon logistics and delivery capability and it also matches up with our faster ship speed that we're seeing for Prime members as well. We added
column9: of course
column10: we have over 100 million items that customers would get within two days

column12: 000 cities in town. So Amazon deliveries are a big part of that. Again

column1: Brian Olsavsky: Yeah. Sure. Let me start with the AWS operating margin
column2: as you called it out. That number will move around
column3: we're very pleased with the 29.3% that we saw during the quarter. Of course
column4: at any point in time
column5: this business is going to be a combination of lowering prices
column6: expanding geographically
column7: adding people to build
column8: especially tech teams and sales teams to build new and innovative products and staying very relevant and ahead of our customers’ minds. And infrastructure
column9: well again
column10: it will balance between quarters a bit. Our capital lease expenditure in Q4 was a bit higher than the prior three quarters. That had slight impact on the operating margin
column11: but again year-over-year
column12: operating margins were up and were almost 280 basis points. We've said quite openly that this is going to bounce around. What we do is to create great value for the customer on one end and then work to minimize our cost of infrastructure and we're getting more and more creative around getting efficiency up and getting our cost of acquisition down.

column3: Brian

column1: Brian Olsavsky: Sure
column2: Doug. Yeah
column3: let's start with Q1. So you remember last quarter
column4: I made the point that 2018 saw lower growth in some of our key cost areas. Things like fulfillment capacity
column5: which have been growing over 30% a year in 2016 and 2017
column6: dropped to 15% last year. Headcount growth was 48% in 2016
column7: 38% if you exclude Whole Foods and Souq acquisitions in 2017. That dropped to 14% last year. And then
column8: financial leases for infrastructure
column9: which are good proxy for capital investment and infrastructure
column10: after growing 69% in 2017
column11: grew 10%. So all of those trailing 12-month metrics actually stayed the same or slightly declined in Q1. So we had continued efficiency. We didn't put a lot of new fulfillment center capacity or infrastructure into place at least compared to Q1 of last year. And hiring was moderate; we actually are down to 12% on a trailing 12-month basis. So I would say that is a continuation of last year. But my point from the last call still holds in that
column12: we do expect those growth rates to be higher for all of 2019. So most of that will happen in the next three quarters
column13: and we have that built into the Q2 guidance. We also hit the high-end of the revenue range
column14: which is always good from an efficiency standpoint and the drop-through on the higher end of the revenue. So now turning into Q2
column15: I would like to tell you a bit about why that's lower. So we have - we're currently working on evolving our Prime free Two-Day Shipping program to be a free One-Day Shipping program. We're able to do this
column16: because we spent 20 plus years expanding our fulfillment and logistics network
column17: but this is still a big investment and a lot of work to do ahead of us. For Q2 guidance
column18: we've included approximately $800 million of incremental spend related to this investment. And just to clarify
column19: to give a little more information
column20: we have been offering
column21: obviously
column22: faster than Two-Day Shipping for Prime members for years
column23: one day
column24: same day
column25: even down to one to two hour delivery for Prime Now. So we're going to continue to offer same day and Prime Now selection in an accelerated basis. But this is all about the core free Two-Day offer morphing into - or evolving into a free One-Day offer. We've already started down this path. We've in the past months significantly expanded our one-day eligible selection and also expanded the number of zip codes eligible for one-day shipping. So we're taking a significant step. It wasn't showing up in Q1. It was minimal in Q1's results. It's a significant step and it will take us time to achieve. And we want to ensure that we have good delivery experience for our customers as we evolve this offer. And lastly
column26: I would say in Q2
column27: as a reminder
column28: each year
column29: we - Q2 is a time when we grant RSUs to employees. And we traditionally see a step-up in stock-based compensation expense in Q2
column30: and we're seeing the same thing this year.

column1: Doug Anmuth: Thank you.
Brian Olsavsky: And that - sorry
column2: and that's also tied in with your question about revenue acceleration. We do believe that
column3: although there's not explicit lift built in for the faster shipping
column4: we have seen good order trends month to date. And we expect - we built the Q2 range about - around what we've seen.

column7: so they can understand the incremental customers they're seeing on Amazon through advertising with Amazon. So it's more right now about tools and making better recommendations

column9: things like that

column11: I guess

column4: as a result

Anthony DiClemente: Thanks very much. A couple of questions. In the shareholder letter

So maybe just talk a little bit about that. Is this just law of large numbers as time goes by? What is Amazon doing to sort of sustain that growth rate in the third-party marketplace business? And then second question is maybe just quickly on media spend. Just update us on how you're thinking about the trajectory of video content spend. Any strategic changes there in terms of library versus originals versus films or TV content? Thanks.

column1: Brian Olsavsky: Yeah. Let's step back on the third-party question. So again
column2: let me reiterate our approach. So main goal here is that it will allow customers to have the broadest selection
column3: the best available price and also the most convenient options on how they receive the item. If we're delivering on those three elements
column4: we're indifferent as to whether it's sold by us or a third-party. We actively recruit sellers to sell on our platform
column5: it's because it adds selection. It adds - if it's in the FBA program
column6: it adds Prime eligible selection. We spend billions of dollars a year
column7: as Jeff said
column8: on infrastructure
column9: tools and services
column10: not only to allow sellers to sell
column11: but to help themselves more successfully. So we have a vested interest in the success of our sellers. Any growth acceleration or deceleration that you see can be very much tied to the total sales of the customer - that we have the customers in any country. So you'll still see the percentage of third-party units increased and has been steadily over the last few years. So again
column12: the sellers are as important to us as anything for servicing the customers' need for price selection and convenience. The elements I just talked about of investment
column13: further investment in one-day shipping is directly going to be a cost that we bear and it's also going to be a direct benefit to sellers as well as the Prime eligible selection in our warehouses.

column1: Dave Fildes: Yeah. And then
column2: Anthony
column3: just real quick
column4: this is Dave
column5: on your question around media and probably more particularly the video strategy and what we're investing in
column6: I mean
column7: we are continuing to invest meaningfully in digital video. It's an area where we're very excited about. Lots of very popular
column8: critically acclaimed shows have obviously come out
column9: things like Homecoming
column10: Jack Ryan
column11: more recently Hanna
column12: Guava Island
column13: and some great titles. So I think look for us to continue to invest there. There was - on the accounting side
column14: we did adopt an accounting standard in January that amended our accounting for how we cap for produced original video content. And under that new guidance
column15: we capitalize production cost for original video content. Previously
column16: we only capitalized a portion of those costs. So the net impact for the first quarter to operating income wasn't material. It was - for Q1
column17: the impact of a change was a decrease of about $130 million to cost of sales due to the capitalization change. As we go through 2019
column18: though
column19: we would expect the impact to increase in the latter part of the second half of the year
column20: in line with our production schedule as it grows throughout the year.

column2: thanks. I guess somewhat along those lines or at least along the lines of growth

I'm sure that's not representative of what you expect growth to look like. So just trying to understand sort of where the disconnect is there

column1: Brian Olsavsky: Sure. Thanks for that question
column2: Heath. No
column3: I would say
column4: A
column5: we're not expecting diminished returns in any of our businesses or growth rates nor are we restraining the business or constraining the business in any way with our capital. I would point you back again to the investments that we made in 2016 and 2017. So we did front-load a lot of the investment both in fulfillment centers and also infrastructure. But more than that
column6: it's more than kind of leading through excess capacity. We have some really
column7: really impressive gains and efficiencies in both the warehouses and also the data centers. We talk efficiency. And every percentage utilization in our data centers is worth tens and more millions of dollars. So again
column8: that's a big part of our model. It is not only investing
column9: but also working on efficiencies
column10: adding new products and features for customers. And as we lower costs
column11: we pass those along to customers
column12: either through new rates or new deals that we have. So I would say that I would look back on the performance in 2018 and say that that was great work with a - on a lot of efficiency as we also banked a lot of capacity that had been built previously. Moving forward

column14: again
column15: growth
column16: geographic expansion in AWS and also efficiencies to limit how much we actually need. I think we're also getting much better at adding capacity faster
column17: so there's less need to build it 6 to 12 months in advance

column20: launching the Hong Kong region gets us to a footprint of 19 cities in China. So it continues to be a really good story for us.
