column1: Brian Olsavsky: Before we move on to the Q&A
column2: I'd like to lead off with a few comments. What we've all seen transpire in the past two months has been gut-wrenching and unprecedented. But it has also been a time of heroic action by healthcare workers
column3: government officials
column4: police and emergency personnel and all essential workers in our communities.This includes frontline Amazonians
column5: including our Whole Foods team and our partners around the world. They've provided a lifeline of groceries and other critical supplies to the doorsteps of all of us at this critical time. I'd like to give you some insight into what we have seen at Amazon and how we are responding to this crisis.Beginning in early March
column6: we experienced a major surge in customer demand. Particularly for household staples and other essential products
column7: across categories such as health
column8: and personal care
column9: groceries and even home office supplies. At the same time we saw lower demand for discretionary items such as apparel
column10: shoes
column11: and wireless products. This large demand spike created major challenges in our operations network.And with our seller community and our suppliers
column12: what we generally have experienced getting ready for spikes in demand for known events
column13: like the holiday season and Prime Day
column14: we also generally spend months ramping up for these periods.The COVID crisis allowed for no such preparation. We took quick action to react to the higher order levels
column15: while continuing to provide for the safety of our workforce. We established rigorous safety and cleaning protocols
column16: including maintaining six foot social distancing
column17: procuring 100 million masks
column18: tens of millions of gloves and wipes and other cleaning supplies.We began requiring temperature checks across our operations network. In our Whole Foods stores
column19: we added plexiglass barriers between cashiers and customers
column20: and reserve special hours for senior customers to shop. We temporarily raised wages and overtime premiums
column21: we funded a new Amazon relief fund
column22: and we allowed employees to take unpaid time off at their discretion. To deal with the unprecedented demand
column23: we hired an additional 175
column24: 000 new employees
column25: many of whom were displaced from other jobs in the economy.We took steps to dampen demand for non-essential products
column26: including reducing our marketing spend. Our network pivoted to shipping priority products within one to four days and extending promises on non-priority items. Our independent third-party sellers
column27: most of whom are small and medium-sized businesses worked tremendously hard to serve our customers
column28: and we are grateful for their efforts.Third-party sellers continue to see strong growth in our stores
column29: with more than half of our units sold or from third-party sellers. We increased grocery delivery capacity by more than 60%
column30: and expanded in store pickup at Whole Foods stores from 80 stores to more than 150 stores. And other Amazon teams shifted their focus to directly helping customers and the overall effort to fight the COVID virus.AWS has created data lake to assist healthcare workers
column31: researchers
column32: scientists and public health officials working to understand and fight the coronavirus. Many of our AWS products are helping in the government response to the crisis
column33: and are there for customers who are seeing their own demand spikes
column34: companies enabling video conferencing
column35: remote learning and online health services
column36: for example.Amazon Flex is supporting food banks by donating delivery services of groceries to serve 6 million meals in Los Angeles
column37: Miami
column38: Nashville
column39: Orlando
column40: San Francisco
column41: Seattle and Washington DC
column42: with plans to ramp this up to 25 cities across the U.S. And Alexa is helping customers access important CDC guidance
column43: and help them evaluate their own COVID-19 risk levels.How is all this impacting our business? While customer demand remains high the incremental revenue we are seeing on many of the lower ASP essential products is basically coming at cost. We've invested more than $600 million in COVID related costs in Q1
column44: and expect these costs could grow to $4 billion or more in Q2. These include productivity headwinds in our facilities as we provide for social distancing and allow for the ramp up of new employees.Investments in personal protective equipment for employees
column45: enhanced cleaning of our facilities
column46: our wages for our hourly teams and hundreds of millions of dollars to develop COVID-19 testing capabilities. In Q1
column47: we also had another $400 million of costs related to increased reserves for doubtful accounts. On the flip side
column48: we did see a drop in travel
column49: entertainment and meeting costs
column50: as well as lower marketing as a way to dampen our demand for non-essential items.While we can't have great certainty about what the next few quarters will look like
column51: I'm humbled by the efforts of my fellow Amazonians in delivering essential goods and services to so many people. We take this responsibility seriously and we're proud of the work our teams are doing to help customers through this difficult time.With that
column52: let's open up for questions.

column1: Operator: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Doug Anmuth with JPMorgan. Please proceed with your question.
Douglas Anmuth: First
column2: I just wanted to ask
column3: within the $4 billion of COVID related incremental costs in Q2
column4: you talk about spending hundreds of millions on your own testing capabilities. Can you just talk about the strategic thinking there underlying trying to build this in-house versus sourcing from elsewhere? And does this potentially take you into a new business path over time? And then how do you think about the spending here in Q2 and whether over time does that change your margin structure for an extended period of time beyond just the next quarter? Thanks.

column1: Brian Olsavsky: Sure. Doug
column2: first on testing. So
column3: we estimate the testing will be about $300 million in Q2 if we're successful. We put some of our best people on it. I think everyone is trying to get testing. It's not readily available on the scale that we needed to test our scale of employees.So we are working to do that ourselves and to build protocols and to - and to again
column4: we'll see how we do that differently and I don't know
column5: you know again
column6: about future business opportunities. Our main concern is
column7: is getting testing in the hands of our employees and then potentially as we have excess capacity
column8: perhaps we can help in other areas.On the spending
column9: a lot of the costs that we're seeing are tied to this COVID response. Most of it is hitting in people cost
column10: both in productivity and also in wages and relief funds and all. So can't really tell how long that will last. It's probably good that I am only - we’re only giving guidance for Q2 at this point. We're going to probably learn a lot more in the next few weeks
column11: next few months. And we'll continue to update this
column12: but for now
column13: most of what we see are temporary cost in the scheme of things
column14: but certainly very expensive temporary costs. And also ones that we're not sure how long they'll last.

column1: Operator: Your next question comes from the line of Brian Nowak with Morgan Stanley. Please proceed with your question.
Brian Nowak: I have two
column2: Brian. The first one
column3: is the current situation is
column4: sort of I think
column5: in many ways sort of showcase the ability of your network to provide goods for people and the value of Prime and Amazon to customers. So I guess in light of that
column6: can you talk to us at all about the impact you've seen on the Prime customer account from the current situation? And any color on how you've been able to expand Prime's reach into new customers or demographics from this?Then the second one
column7: I know there's a lot of changes going on in logistics and things
column8: but Amazon is always a learning company. So any learnings you've had so far in the logistics side about how you actually may be able to learn some new best practices to run more efficiently post-COVID from the current [indiscernible] you've been going through?

column1: Brian Olsavsky: Well
column2: I think we've learned that it's easier to get ready for a holiday or a Prime Day then it is to be ready for something like this when everything hits at once. High demand and also a need to restock automatically and prepare for it. So that's not something that we want to keep learning
column3: but we're doing our best to maintain and provide key services for
column4: and essential items for our Prime customers and all our Amazon customers.On the Prime program
column5: what we're seeing is
column6: again
column7: you're seeing a lot of pickup in Prime shopping benefits. We see our prime customers are shopping more often and they have larger basket sizes. We're also seeing a lot more use of our video benefits and our digital benefits.So in March
column8: for the first time viewers nearly doubled
column9: which is I think a good time for people to when they're
column10: a lot of them are staying at home to stay entertained. And you'll see our video collection. It's also beyond kind of Prime Video. It's also our channels and video rentals also went up
column11: as I'm sure others in the entertainment business saw that as well.I think people are finding more benefit from Alexa when they're at home. They're listening to more music
column12: asking questions
column13: particularly questions related to COVID and issues around it. They're using it in education with their children. And I think we're seeing a lot more on the communication side using people using Alexa calling and drop in.So I think the Prime story is that shopping is
column14: you know
column15: really important for people now
column16: especially when they
column17: those people can't leave their houses. I think the digital benefits are scaling well. I think they are handling the additional demand
column18: and it gives it gives people a good time and reason to use all of their Prime benefits that maybe they hadn't used as much in the past.

column1: Operator: Your next question comes from the line of Mark Mahaney with RBC. Please proceed with your question.
Mark Mahaney: First
column2: could you just talk about where you are in terms of fulfillment efficiencies? The way you track it pre-COVID
column3: Amazon was able to
column4: had some sort of level of standard of meeting demand with within a certain period of time
column5: how low that got given the surge in demand
column6: and where you are in terms of the recovery? In other words
column7: when are you going to be - how long will it take for Amazon to get back to a point where you'd have the same sort of service efficiency levels on the retail side that you had pre-COVID? How far are you away from that?And then the second one was

column9: but maybe even a kick up in the growth rate? What are you seeing there in terms of

column11: maybe on a delayed basis? Just talk about what's happening to that side of the business in this crisis. Thank you.

column1: Brian Olsavsky: Sure. Well
column2: we're happy with the growth in Q1on such a large base
column3: again
column4: we're
column5: now it's $41 billion run rate
column6: and that's 33% year-over-year. But what we're seeing post-COVID is
column7: it varies by industry. I think what is probably where we're a bit well positioned is that we have such a breadth of customers
column8: there's millions of active customers from start-ups
column9: to enterprises
column10: to public sector. So there's a lot of variance.And again
column11: in what individual industries are seeing right now
column12: things like videoconferencing
column13: gaming
column14: remote learning
column15: entertainment all are seeing much higher growth and usage. And things like hospitality and travel certainly have contracted very severely
column16: very quickly. So
column17: I think there's going to be a mixed bag on industries
column18: and of course this is will be tied to general economic conditions for the country and the world
column19: quite frankly.So right now where we want to be there for our customers. We want to be able to scale up when they need us. We want to be there and support them regionally around the world. And we've been doing a good job at that
column20: I believe.On the fulfillment efficiency
column21: I think you were talking about one day
column22: probably is the heart of your question
column23: when we will get back to what we have seen and levels of one day. So a little bit on that. So again
column24: as I mentioned in my introductory comments
column25: we had to kind of absorb this shock of top line demand and also ability to stabilize our operations.We had to take the step to focus on essential items
column26: extend the shipping period from one to four days
column27: and then further on non-essential items. I had restrict things that were coming into the warehouses
column28: and focus on the essential products. So we think that is still was the right course of action. And as we add capacity
column29: we're trying to resume more normal operations as far as the shipping of non-essential items and the speeding up of one-day shipments.I will explain a bit on the one-day shipping cost
column30: because it's aligned with this. So we originally thought we would spend $1 billion roughly on one-day shipping in Q1. And what we're seeing is
column31: we pretty much spent about that same amount because it's - in the old days
column32: we would have perhaps had the option to ship things two-day
column33: three-day
column34: four-day and seen a break on rates for the actual shipment.But most of our one-day costs are really what we've done to our logistics networks to allow for one-day shipping. Things like putting inventory closer to the customer
column35: things like building up our AMZL network and delivery network and also having multiple pull times and shipping windows during the day.So those are actually coming in
column36: all those things are coming in very handy to us to help get more capacity out of what we currently have. And we're glad we've made that investment
column37: but we don't actually see a savings because we're still shipping things once they're available very quickly to customers.So it's really a combination of how long it takes to get things in stock
column38: picked
column39: packed and shipped. The shipping is still pretty fast and is still coming quickly. It's taking longer to get things into our warehouse and out of our warehouse. So that's really the challenge right now is to speed that up
column40: and that will
column41: when we do that we'll see a resumption of more one-day service.But
column42: right now things are still so up in the air that I can't really project when that day will be or what point in Q2 or Q3 or beyond.

column1: Operator: Your next question comes from the line of Heath Terry with Goldman Sachs. Please proceed with your question.
Heath Terry: I did want to dig just a little bit deeper into your comments on AWS. Yesterday
column2: during Microsoft's call they had mentioned that they had seen two years worth of digital transformation in the cloud in two months. I'm curious if you

column6: the $4 billion for the expenses in the second quarter. If we adjust for that implies a pretty material increase in profitability quarter over quarter. Any sense of
column7: or any sense that you can sort of share with us just what the drivers behind that profitability is? How much of that is annualizing the one-day investments in the efficiencies that you're seeing there
column8: versus anything else in particular that you would that you would call out?

column1: Brian Olsavsky: Yes
column2: so first on AWS. I mean I don't have comments. You may have heard us talk about digital transformation. I think what I would say is
column3: we've continue to see a healthy adoption of our business and healthy usage not only in the United States but globally.Our backlog of future contracts continues to build
column4: and I still think the basic value proposition of AWS that we've always pointed to
column5: things like having the most functionality
column6: largest vibrant community of customers and partners having really proven operational and security experience. And building what customers need in the areas of machine learning and artificial intelligence
column7: and other really key areas has not been impeded by this COVID crisis yet.And yes
column8: we are seeing different performance in different industries. But our sales force is still there to help
column9: help not only with current capacity
column10: but also the transition to new
column11: as people make that journey onto to the cloud. And then expand their use of the cloud.On the $4 billion
column12: or sorry
column13: on the Q2 guidance. I think the question is perhaps if how do we have a range that's above zero
column14: if we have $4 billion of cost? Is that pretty much the essence of your question? I think there is - there are some efficiencies that would leverage that we get on fixed cost on higher volumes
column15: even if they are somewhat breakeven on a contribution profit basis. There's some improvement in our cost structure when we have high volumes.There's also been a resumption of seller volume
column16: especially from third parties using direct shipments to customers as companies are - you get more capability both in this country and other countries. We will continue to moderate our marketing in the time period when we have
column17: again
column18: very much the demand we are trying to fulfill is there and there's some products that are still out of stock.So it doesn't make sense to always do marketing
column19: especially variable marketing in those situations. And we continue to
column20: we believe we'll be saving travel and entertainment costs through the quarter. That's in
column21: I would say in a couple of hundred million dollar size ranges on the cost.So there's a lot of moving parts here
column22: but certainly the investment we're making in the COVID response is pretty significant. On the one-day
column23: I would remind you that the one-day started in earnest Q2 of last year. So we're starting to lap that investment. It's not as large on a year-over-year basis as it's been in the past four quarters.And then the other thing that I would just point out is the - remember the impact of a change in the useful life of our servers
column24: mostly hitting in the AWS business that was a $800 million benefit year-over-year in Q1. And that will continue into the rest of the year. And that that again is the benefit we're seeing from being able to use our server and infrastructure assets for a longer time period. We've been working on the ability to run them longer
column25: it's a hardware and a software challenge.And as we have had success there operating at scale for over 13 years now
column26: we've been able to extend our useful life for assets
column27: or recognized that we have been extending the life. So that's a benefit that we've seen in Q1
column28: and we'll see it the remaining from here on out.

column1: Dave Fildes: Yes
column2: just to add to that too
column3: is I think about $800 million or nearly $100 million benefit in the first quarter
column4: we do expect the change to the decrease as the year progresses some. Keep in mind.

Eric Sheridan: Maybe two

column3: on the demand of the revenue side

column1: Brian Olsavsky: Sure. Sorry
column2: Eric
column3: I don't have much for you on the second point. Certainly we would look to see lower shipping costs. Although I would
column4: but a lot of
column5: I mean there's certainly things that we do long haul. There's things that we reposition
column6: the airplanes. There's things that we do on long haul trucking
column7: and that's where probably the fuel component would be larger. But we haven't quantified that
column8: not for our guidance. I can't break it out for you right now.On how this may have played out differently in different geographies
column9: we're actually seeing a lot of consistency
column10: I would say in the types of products that people are buying in the state home restrictions. So it's been pretty consistent. There's obviously timing differences between countries
column11: on one certain countries and when it's maybe ones where they are in their curve
column12: and flattening the curve and all that.I think the biggest impact internationally has been in India
column13: where of course
column14: we similar to other companies in India
column15: we're now only fulfilling our essential goods such as grocery. So that's cut back a lot on our offering
column16: and we will further expand when the Indian government announces that were allowed to resume operations. So we're in a bit of a holding pattern except for grocery in India.And in France
column17: there's been restrictions placed on us by the French courts. They did not impact Q1 business because essentially led to the closure of our French fulfillment centers in the middle of April. French customers are still able to order many millions of products from the selling partners we have who can ship directly to customers and through our global fulfillment. And we're continuing to appeal this court decision
column18: but that's also different experience than the other countries internationally.

column1: Operator: Our next question comes from the line of Justin Post with Bank of America. Please proceed with your question.
Justin Post: A couple
column2: just wondering if you're seeing any sustainable changes in consumer habits you could call out

column4: adding more products in the consumable categories to their subscribe and save
column5: anything you see that could really signal a longer-term change in consumer habits

column1: Dave Fildes: Justin
column2: it's David. I think on some of the consumer behavior
column3: I certainly point to grocery. If you look at the remainder of the online grocery is up in our online sales. So it's not isolated like you can see for physical stores
column4: but we have seen an increased demand in online grocery shopping and we have a number of ways for customers to do that.Prime Now
column5: Fresh and then of course Whole Foods online for delivery or pick up. And really beginning in March and continuing now through April
column6: seeing that increased demand so
column7: that's continued. And a lot of our focus is on working around the clock and offering as much delivery as possible.We've increased delivery order capacity more than 60%
column8: and our stores have gone up. Whole Foods stores that offer pick up capability has gone from roughly 80 stores before the events to more than 150
column9: so a lot of work being done there.On the physical stores
column10: which you can see the growth there. It increased year-over-year at about 8%. That is predominantly Whole Foods
column11: but it's the Whole Foods in-store shopping experience
column12: rather than the online order. So that's up quite a bit from the run rate you've seen in some recent quarters. It's again similar
column13: saw lot of folks that were a stay at home measures were not yet in place where shopping in large volumes and stocking up at our stores.Since that time more recently
column14: we have seen some of those growth rates for the in-store shopping moderate some. So a lot of work being done there
column15: both in for the workers that are doing to delivery in the workers that are in the stores.A lot of focus on our part to make sure that they're safe and healthy
column16: and able to accommodate customers make sure customers are comfortable
column17: however they choose to shop.

column1: Brian Olsavsky: And I'd add to that. Justin

column3: video
column4: Alexa
column5: certainly communication features on our devices.We launched Prime Video Cinema in U.S.
column6: U.K. and Germany where movies are going direct to pay-per-view because of lack of theaters. And that was a good move by the team and that's been very well received. We've also made a lot of kids and family content available free to watch on Prime Video. So I think people are getting a better look at what's available with the Prime membership.

column1: Justin Post: And then
column2: second half of the quarter
column3: are you assuming
column4: kind of
column5: we go back to normal as the quarter progresses and some deceleration?

column1: Dave Fildes: Well we are heavily constrained
column2: again it's an odd quarter because generally the biggest uncertainty we have this customer demand
column3: and with the order and how much of it they'll order. Demand has been strong
column4: the biggest questions we have in Q2 are more about ability to service that demand and that is the products that people are ordering in a full way
column5: not blocking or making it hard to find non-essential items
column6: increasing marketing
column7: and everything else.So I think the challenge is really on everything besides the top line. And top line is certainly not to be taken for granted. There's always the importance of having attractive offerings in stock for customers.But usually things you can count on
column8: the cost structure
column9: the ability to get products
column10: yes
column11: your capacity for shipping and delivering
column12: those are usually things that you can take for granted
column13: and in this quarter
column14: you can't. That's really where the uncertainty is driven.

column2: Brian

column5: I guess

column1: Brian Olsavsky: Sure. I think there's still supply chain concerns on a lot of PPE
column2: not only that we use
column3: but also that we sell to customers
column4: things like masks. There's general availability
column5: but still outages of things like cleaning wipes
column6: masks
column7: talk about testing
column8: but that's not something that we sell.So there are a lot of supply chain concerns are mostly in those areas right now. I'm sorry
column9: I forgot the other part of your question. Can you remind me what you just…

column1: Stephen Ju: The third-party unit mix de-indexing a little bit as a percentage of total this quarter. I'm just wondering if that's just normal fluctuations
column2: or are you just prioritizing the first-party delivery against what's probably limited resources on the heightened demand.

column1: Brian Olsavsky: Yes. Thanks
column2: Stephen. I would say that
column3: yes
column4: it's a little off during this period
column5: because it's not so much we're restricting and favoring 1P or anything. It's we're prioritizing essential items
column6: and a lot of those tend to be
column7: especially in the consumable area tend to be retail supplied items from vendors.So I would say that is the reason that FBA would have not have been as high as it normally would be. MFN is picking up a lot of the opportunity
column8: and sellers are taking that opportunity ship direct because then it doesn't have to come into our warehouse obviously. So it's a bit of a different type of 3P mix right now. We're trying to minimize the impact on FBA sellers as we open up our warehouse as well.Many of them are also MFN or direct shippers to our customers. So it's the ability to satisfy demand of our customers from our seller community has never been more important and we're very grateful to our third-party sellers. They've been through a lot as well.

column2: everyone
column3: and welcome to the Amazon.com Q2 2020 Financial Results Teleconference. At this time

column6: I will be turning the call over to Director of Investor Relations

column1: David Fildes: Hello
column2: and welcome to our Q2 2020 financial results conference call. Joining us today to answer your questions is Brian Olsavsky
column3: our CFO. As you listen to today’s conference call

column1: Brian Olsavsky: Thank you for joining us today. I’d like to start by thanking and recognizing the contributions of hundreds of thousands of Amazon employees and delivery partners and hundreds of thousands of small and medium-sized businesses who are working hard to serve our customers all around the world in these uncertain times.
Operator: At this time
column2: we’ll now open the call up for questions. We ask each caller
column3: please limit yourself to one question.  Your first question comes from the line of Eric Sheridan with UBS. Please proceed with your question.

column1: Eric Sheridan: Thanks so much for taking the question. Maybe I could just dive in on the normalized trends you’re seeing as you exit June and get into July. You made a push into essentials and deemphasized non-essentials
column2: as we talked about in the last earnings call. Where are we in terms of the company getting the mix between essentials versus non-essentials right in terms of offering to customers? Where are you in terms of returning to normal on next-day and two-day shipping initiatives to drive Prime? If there was any color on the state of affairs with either of those by geo or region of the world
column3: that would be great. Thank you so much.

column1: Brian Olsavsky: Sure
column2: Eric. Thanks for your question. So first
column3: on the trend. So if you remember
column4: we exited Q1 and spoke at the end of April. We had taken a lot of steps in March and April to
column5: first
column6: limit the incoming non-essential products into our warehouses
column7: and then we reversed that or eliminated that decision in mid-April. So we started to normalize on our channel mix. And I would say
column8: as we moved into late April and early May
column9: we expected that because a lot of the sellers can toggle between MFN or FBA sales that we would see MFN drop as FBA picked up. But to a large extent
column10: MFN remained strong even as FBA picked up. So we had a very favorable mix
column11: if you will
column12: coming from March on. It started to normalize a little bit more to normal levels towards the end of the quarter
column13: but MFN still remains high. On the product side
column14: a lot of what we saw in March and early April was sales of consumables and groceries and safety items. And we talked a lot about the fact that
column15: that was coming at pretty much zero cost – or excuse me
column16: zero profit when you factored in the COVID-related costs.

column1: David Fildes: Yes. And this is just David. I think just from a geographic perspective
column2: Brian’s opening comments there
column3: a lot of these order trends and activity
column4: you can see that both the North America and the International segment are growing well. So a lot of those kind of trends in category performances and first-party and third-party seller growth

column6: we’re seeing a lot of growth across the board

column8: in particular
column9: our more established international regions.

column5: obviously
column6: when I asked that. But what I also want to ask really is when you think about new investment areas
column7: and at the top of the list
column8: maybe some new international launches are really building out some of the markets that you’ve – like India
column9: Brazil and Mexico or the business-to-business operations
column10: like there’s a ton of new investment areas
column11: and it seems like the Amazon historically
column12: and I’m sure it’s the same now
column13: would be using this kind of revenue surge and really investing aggressively in these new areas. So just talk about that. I know you’ve got spend on COVID
column14: but as you think about the next three to five years
column15: you’ve got these really profit surges. How can you deploy those? Or how do you want to deploy those into some of the newer investment areas? Thanks a lot.

column1: Brian Olsavsky: Sure. Thanks for your questions
column2: Mark. First
column3: on when we get back to par
column4: we don’t know yet. We’re getting progressively better
column5: but we’re also balancing what is going to be very stepped up demand and capacity in Q3 and Q4. So if you look at our historic run rates and can see how big a quarter Q2 was
column6: Q2 was actually higher revenue than Q4 of last year
column7: which is unheard of. And Q3 is now forecast to be also higher than Q4 of last year. So we’ve kind of moved the peak forward
column8: and for different reasons
column9: we’re trying to
column10: mainly
column11: like as I said
column12: first priority is getting – is making sure our employees are safe and that we continue to do social distancing and keep everybody safe and healthy. Second priority is getting capacity online because we do not have – in Q2
column13: we generally have lower revenue. And in Q2
column14: like I mentioned
column15: we were able to use the excess capacity that did exist to serve the higher demand. Now as we move into Q3
column16: we’re starting to – we need to build the inventory more for Q4
column17: and we’ve run out of space. So we’ve got our hands full on that challenge
column18: but we’ve got a really good team that’s been working very hard probably since late February on this issue. And when you talk about profitability
column19: we’ll also mention that there are a couple of expenses that have gone down in the interim. Marketing
column20: we cut marketing probably by about 1/3 in Q2 as – mainly because we’re trying to manage demand. It started to normalize and get back to somewhat normal levels in – at the end of Q2
column21: but – and therefore
column22: we’ll see a higher level in Q3. But certainly
column23: marketing costs were lower. You probably saw it in a lot of companies. Travel expenses have almost drawn to a halt. Meeting costs
column24: even medical costs in some examples or in some cases have been delayed as people don’t go to the doctor or don’t go there as quickly. We think that will normalize over time. And as far as investments
column25: we’ve got a lot of investments already in play. So I don’t think it’s a matter of necessarily accelerating investment or – we’re always looking for new investments that make sense to us. But during this time
column26: I would say we’ve actually accelerated our ops investment. We pulled in capacity that we probably didn’t think would be needed until 2021
column27: maybe later. On grocery
column28: we’ve also greatly expanded our grocery delivery capacity
column29: and that’s probably ahead of schedule.

column1: David Fildes: Yes. This is Dave. Just to add to that
column2: I think Prime is such a big focus
column3: and some of the growth statements that Brian talked about at the opening of the call
column4: whether it was strength in Prime membership and the acceleration we saw in the U.S. or worldwide or some of the usage stats like the grocery momentum or the doubling of video hours
column5: for us
column6: it’s just another encouraging sign. We think there’s still a lot more value we can add to that program. And that’s not just in the United States where we’ve got sort of a broader set of services than some of the other regions
column7: but really focusing on supporting in some of those other regions. And so we’ve got places like Australia
column8: the Middle East. We’ve talked about India many times
column9: but a lot of focus on building that out. I think what’s great about a place – all geographies with a place like India is we’re really focused on digitizing the Indian sellers. A lot of micro
column10: small and medium-sized businesses there. We launched some new features there to help support the digitization efforts with some of those brands and just a lot of work
column11: great work being done by that team. They have some goals there around getting more sellers on board and hiring many more people as well. So a lot of focus there.

column1: Operator: Our next question comes from Brian Nowak with Morgan Stanley. Please proceed with your question.
Brian Nowak: Thanks for taking my question. I have two. The first one
column2: Brian
column3: is going back to the investments
column4: and you’re often making multiyear investments for customers and customer offerings
column5: and you’re the man behind the capital allocation plan. I guess I’d be curious to hear about can you give us some examples of areas of investment that may have been pushed out this year because of shelter in place and the higher demand that you’ve been seeing? So what were areas where you thought you were going to spend more at the start of the year than you actually have now in the current 2020 plan? And then the second one
column6: the international strength
column7: I appreciate the color on Europe and Japan. Nice to see the profitability. Maybe just talk to us sort of qualitatively about some puts and takes around your core international markets
column8: Europe and Japan? And how to think about whether or not they could be more or less profitable than the U.S. long-term? Thanks.

column1: Brian Olsavsky: Sure. I think you’ll – starting with that second one. You’ll notice that the International segment was profitable this quarter
column2: and that’s a great sign. It is heavily driven by the pickup in demand that we saw
column3: as I mentioned
column4: I believe
column5: in multiple calls. What’s going on internationally is we have some very healthy established countries that we’ve been in a long time. And we have probably accelerated their adoption of Prime benefits. We’ve pushed video and devices and music and other things to those countries probably earlier in the life cycle than you would have seen in the U.S. So there’s a bit of a forward investment on Prime benefits in many of those countries. But what you also see are investments in new countries. Obviously
column6: India is the biggest one
column7: but also
column8: to a lesser extent
column9: the Middle East
column10: Brazil
column11: Turkey and Australia are recent addition. So there’s always an element of expansion going on there. Advertising is growing
column12: so that’s a good source of profitability. But if you look at what happened in Q2
column13: it was essentially just the much higher volumes than we had anticipated or had on a run rate. So our fixed costs were leveraged to the hilt. Obviously
column14: we will add some capacity and things in transportation and fulfillment centers
column15: but all other fixed costs were pretty much leveraged on that higher demand. The UK in particular
column16: was very strong because there’s probably more stay-at-home orders and the way the economy was developing in the UK. We had a very
column17: very strong quarter there. So I would say that the surge in demand internationally also helped drive that profitable
column18: maybe a little earlier than the trajectory would have shown. And I’m not sure that
column19: that is going to continue for the next couple of quarters
column20: but it’s a good sign that we could leverage that. And a lot of the same trends in the U.S. were apparent internationally
column21: higher Prime – more frequent Prime purchases and higher basket sizes. So all good signs
column22: and perhaps we got a glimpse of the future on the demand curve. Your second question on slowing investments. The list is very short on what we’ve had to slow down. It’s mostly – it hasn’t been done necessarily for cost reasons
column23: it’s been done for people reasons. The one I’d point to is studios. We’ve had to delay production. I think most studios have. And that’s been augmented by some new things like our Amazon cinema where we’re having first run movies. And so I think in this time
column24: when people want entertainment
column25: people are having trouble creating new content across the board. And that’s a bit of a challenge
column26: but it’s not something we’re doing intentionally. We’re doing it to protect the actors and film crews
column27: and we think that’s the right decision. As I said
column28: a lot of the investments are being pulled in
column29: especially on the upside and grocery delivery
column30: same-store pickup. A number of whole food stores that you can pick up deliveries on tripled this quarter. So the list is short on things that we’re slowing down on
column31: I would say. It’s just we’re adapting and probably looking at whether some things have changed and creating some things for the new environment
column32: especially in the entertainment area.

column1: Operator: Our next question comes from Doug Anmuth with JPMorgan. Please proceed with your question.
Doug Anmuth: Thanks for taking the questions. I have two. Brian
column2: first
column3: just curious about your overall thoughts on how the e-commerce adoption curve has been shifted here over the next few years. And anything you can share around behavior for new and existing customers. And then separately
column4: on AWS
column5: the $43 billion run rate obviously slowed some in the quarter
column6: but hoping you could comment just on the pace of IT decision-making in this environment
column7: whether you’re still impacted by some clients more highly exposed to challenged verticals? And due to those factors
column8: is it possible that AWS can accelerate growth going forward? Thanks.

column1: Brian Olsavsky: Yes. Let me start with that second one. Thanks
column2: Doug. So in the AWS segment revenue
column3: what we see are companies are working really hard right now to cut expenses
column4: especially in the more challenged businesses like hospitality and travel but pretty much across the board. We’re helping them. We’re actively
column5: with our sales force
column6: looking for ways that we can help them save money. This includes things like scaling down the usage where it makes sense or benchmarking their workloads against our architectural best practices. So that’s not going to help our usage growth in the short run
column7: but it will help those customers save money. And we think that’s the right thing to do
column8: not only for their success and so they can come out of this at a better shape but also for the long-term health of our relationship with them as an AWS provider. But we’re also seeing a lot of companies that are really wishing that they had made more progress on the cloud because they’re seeing how companies that are on the cloud can turn into a variable cost and either scale up or scale down depending on their particular situation. They realize their on-premise infrastructure is not really flexible to go up or down. And especially in the time of sinking demand
column9: it’s a big fixed cost for them. So we expect – we’re seeing migration plans accelerate. They’re certainly not going to happen overnight
column10: but we see companies moving more in that direction. We think that will be a good long-term trend. And there’s certainly winners in this area right now
column11: things like video conferencing
column12: gaming
column13: remote learning and entertainment. All are seeing usage growth. And it’s a bifurcated world out there. So the – on your e-commerce adoption
column14: I think it’s hard to tell. We’re super encouraged by the fact that grocery delivery has picked up
column15: and that’s been accelerated versus what we would have thought. We certainly are glad to be there for our Prime members who are shopping more frequently and buying more. We do know that there’s reasons that there are other options are limited. I mean there are always retail options out there
column16: especially to go pick up in store
column17: but less people want to go into stores perhaps now. So we’re going to have to see what is maybe a step-up in the curve and getting to a point quicker versus what are some onetime sales and things like – hopefully
column18: things like masks and gloves and cleaning supplies in the fullness of time become onetime purchases
column19: but we’ll see. And sorry
column20: your last point was on new customers versus existing customers. We’re seeing similar trends. We’re seeing good pickup in frequency and basket size for new members in Prime as well
column21: certainly not the same as people have been Prime members for a number of years. But it’s encouraging. And as you saw
column22: Prime growth retention has increased. We’ve accelerated the number of – the growth of Prime members
column23: both in the U.S. and internationally. So that’s a good sign that we’re happy about. And we hope that
column24: that has long-term ramifications.

column1: Operator: Our next question comes from Ross Sandler with Barclays. Please proceed with your question.
Ross Sandler: Yes. Just a follow-up to that last comment. So the Prime behavior for international Prime members
column2: you guys have talked about how like in the 16
column3: 17 countries
column4: the overall service levels are a little bit behind
column5: selection is a little bit behind. So has the last few months in the pandemic closed that gap meaningfully in terms of GMV per Prime member for international versus what you see in the U.S.? Any comment there? And then on the 3Q guidance
column6: you pushed Prime day for western markets into 4Q. So how much of the deceleration – it’s obviously a really strong number for 3Q
column7: but the growth rate is decelerating a little bit. Is that mostly from Prime Day? Or can you just talk about what kind of behaviors you’re seeing right now as you go into 3Q? Thank you.

column1: Brian Olsavsky: Right. Well
column2: we ramped up through the quarter in Q2 and ended up with 41% year-over-year growth in FX-neutral – on an FX-neutral basis. A lot of those trends are continuing into Q3. You see our revenue range is $87 billion to $93 billion coming off of $89 billion quarter. So I would say that the – if you look at the growth rate
column3: that translates into somewhere in the 24% to 33% growth rate in Q3. So I can’t break out exactly the Prime impact because there’s – but suffice to say
column4: it’s a big driver on why 41% growth in Q2 turns into 24% to 33% growth in Q3 on what turns out to be higher revenue volume. And then on Prime behavior
column5: it’s – I can’t really give you more on that because it is actually a very localized set of staff by country. In international
column6: aggregate does not matter that much. And what I would say is
column7: generally
column8: what we’re seeing is similar trends in international in response to COVID purchasing patterns. I wouldn’t say it closed the gap. I said – I would say they both went up. And we’ll see how it goes from there. I think there’s definitely any differences in selection or differences in shipping. There’s a myriad of factors that go into a Prime member’s decision to be a Prime member and to what they buy and what they use as far as our benefits that we give them. So I don’t want to make too many sweeping comments on that right now.

column1: Operator: Our next question comes from Brent Thill with Jefferies. Please proceed with your question.
Brent Thill: Thanks
column2: good afternoon. I was curious if you could just expand on AWS. There was a little bit of a slowdown across the board and a number of the cloud numbers. I’m just curious if there’s a common trend that you’re seeing there. And perhaps just talk about the backlog. I know you’ve disclosed the backlog has been improving in the filings
column3: but a little more color on AWS would be certainly helpful. Thank you.

column1: Brian Olsavsky: Yes
column2: sure. I’ll give you the backlog number. It grew 65% year-over-year and 21% quarter-over-quarter. So that’s healthy
column3: and we have the average contract length is over three years for our AWS contracts. I would say contract volume and negotiations are strong and have maintained through this period. So it is – that’s a good sign. It really does boil down to short-term versus long-term incentives here for a lot of our customers. They’re – if you’re in an industry that’s been heavily impacted by COVID in the economy
column4: you’re looking for ways to save money and you’re trying to do a click and we’re trying to help in that regard. And one of the best ways to save money long-term is to use the cloud
column5: not only to turn it into a variable cost
column6: it could be a fixed cost
column7: but also to be able to take advantage of the partner network that we have
column8: the security that we have and also the constant evolution of products and services that we bring to market.

column1: Operator: Our next question comes from Aaron Kessler with Raymond James. Please proceed with your question.
Aaron Kessler: Great. A couple of questions. First
column2: maybe just one of your competitors noted that growth was slowing in some markets that have opened up
column3: I guess
column4: probably more in Europe. Maybe just thoughts there. Are you seeing any changes in sort of the markets that are starting to open up? And just any commentary on the Zoox acquisition
column5: how you kind of – can use that technology longer term as well? Thank you.

column1: Brian Olsavsky: I imagine you mean on consumer business
column2: countries opening up.

column1: Aaron Kessler: Correct.
Brian Olsavsky: Yes. Well
column2: we still see strong demand. So I don’t have any particular color on that regard by country. We do think probably the UK was very – grew very strongly in Q2
column3: and that
column4: I believe
column5: is starting to moderate a bit but still stronger than normal. So I don’t want to go by country
column6: but I think those trends will start to perhaps become evident. But the – from our vantage point
column7: the Prime members still continue to order more frequently and in larger basket sizes.

column1: David Fildes: Yes. And then
column2: Aaron
column3: just on your second question on Zoox
column4: I mean
column5: it’s – there’s not too much to say at this point. It’s still pretty early
column6: but I think it probably goes without saying it’s a tremendously forward-thinking team
column7: which resonates with us. And they really do kind of pioneer in that space
column8: the ride-hailing space. So a lot of cool work they’re doing
column9: designing autonomous vehicles and focused on the passenger
column10: right
column11: in front of mind in that. So I think
column12: again
column13: just as we think about kind of the innovation components and commitments to solving kind of problems and challenges for customers
column14: it’s pretty exciting for us to be able to work with them and bring that vision to fruition in the years ahead.

column1: Operator: Our final question comes from Justin Post with Bank of America. Please proceed with your question.
Justin Post: Great. A couple of questions. Obviously
column2: a great cost quarter on the leverage side. Any changes in e-commerce gross margins to call out? Is scale and getting size
column3: improving gross margins or anything on the mix shift there that’s interesting? And then secondly
column4: we talked about a lot about one day investment last year. Obviously
column5: the shipping times were impacted by COVID
column6: but are you back to kind of normal times? And where are you on the one day investment? Thank you.

column1: Brian Olsavsky: Sure. On one day
column2: again
column3: we’re first prioritizing employee safety. We have a lot of effort in that regard. We’ve changed over 150 process paths. We’ve instituted social distancing
column4: cleaning
column5: temperature taking
column6: both with our warehouse employees and also our transportation employees. So that’s really still priority one. And second is capacity expansion
column7: especially as we head into the second half of the year
column8: which generally sees a step-up in volume even over the first half of the year. So we will – we are improving the percentage of one day. We’re not back to where we were pre-COVID. We don’t think we’re going to be back in the short run
column9: but we will continue to improve it. And hopefully
column10: it’ll be less noticeable for our consumer base. On the gross margin side
column11: it’s very much a mixed bag right now. There’s – before the COVID outbreak
column12: the positives were generally AMZL costs – delivery costs were becoming more efficient. Advertising was – and AWS were certainly a strong component of gross margin increases. Product mix could go either way depending on the country. But as this COVID has played out
column13: consumables and grocery
column14: which are lower margin
column15: have started to – have been a negative impact on gross margin. But the – we feel good about where we are. Gross margin for the quarter was 40.8% and was down 200 basis points from last year. It’s probably more tied to the addition of one-day shipping. And even if we didn’t do as much one-day shipping as we’ve been doing post COVID
column16: the costs of one-day shipping are already built into our structure. We’ve already reconfigured our network. We’ve already created the capacity to be able to ship. It’s just a matter of whether or not we can get it out through the warehouse and to you in one day or not.

column1: David Fildes: Thanks for joining us today on the call and for your questions. A replay will be available on our Investor Relations website at least through the end of the quarter. We appreciate your interest in Amazon
column2: and look forward to talking with you again next quarter.";[-0.03575408533520552
